DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead in 5th item in package to CORRECT age of Farrell to 87 sted 89.
DOC.TEXT: Charlie Farrell, silent film star of ``Seventh Heaven'' and the TV father in the popular 1950s series ``My Little Margie,'' died Sunday of heart failure at age 87. Farrell leaped into stardom with a minor role in ``The Ten Commandments.'' It was in the 1927 silent ``Seventh Heaven'' that Farrell and Janet Gaynor established themselves as the screen's top heartbeats. ``Seventh Heaven'' walked away with the best director and actress Oscars at the first Academy Awards. Farrell played a widower father opposite Gale Storm on 150 episodes on television's ``My Little Margie.'' His movie roles included ``Wings of Youth,'' ``Sandy,'' ``Old Ironsides,'' ``The Rough Riders,'' ``Aggie Appleby'' and ``The World is Ours.'' Farrell retired from movies after making about 10 silents and more than 40 talkies. Farrell and his actress-wife Virginia Valli, who died in September 1968, worked with partner Ralph Bellamy to develop the posh Palm Springs Racquet Club, which became a mecca for Hollywood elite. Farrell was mayor of Palm Springs for six years, from 1948 to 1953, and he successfully fought efforts of gamblers intent on moving into the area.

DOC.HEAD: Studies: Experimental Drug Relieves AIDS Symptoms
DOC.TEXT: The experimental drug DDI can help AIDS patients gain weight and feel better but can have severe, even life-threatening side effects, according to two reports published today. Many hoped the new medicine would be a less toxic alternative to AZT, the only medicine approved for routine use against AIDS. A major nationwide study is under way to see how DDI compares with AZT in controlling the disease. The new, smaller studies confirm that DDI is promising, but also caution that it can harm the pancreas and cause other painful symptoms. ``There is some evidence that it inhibits the AIDS virus,'' said Dr. Howard A. Liebman of Boston City Hospital, senior author of one of the studies. ``The important question is: Will the spectrum of toxicity prove to be the limiting factor of the drug? Will that make it not any better than AZT and perhaps worse?'' The two studies, conducted on small numbers of patients by doctors at Boston City and the University of Rochester, were published in the New England Journal of Medicine. The results were similar to those of another preliminary study conducted at the National Cancer Institute and published last July in Science. All three studies were so-called Phase I trials. They were intended to determine the maximum dose that patients can tolerate, not whether the medicine had an effect on their illness. Nevertheless, the researchers found that many of the patients clearly improved while taking DDI for a few weeks. In an editorial in the New England Journal, Dr. Anthony S. Fauci, director of AIDS work at the National Institutes of Health, wrote that ``there certainly is a suggestion of short-term benefit from DDI.'' About 800 patients are enrolled in a major study that compares DDI with AZT, or zidovudine. An additional 8,600 people who cannot take AZT because of side effects or worsening symptoms are using DDI in an unusual program that makes the drug available prior to its formal approval by the Food and Drug Administration. In his editorial, Fauci predicted that the two latest reports will stir up ``inevitable enthusiasm'' about the treatment. But he added that doctors and patients should withhold judgment about DDI until tests aimed at determining the drug's effectiveness in fighting the virus are completed. The studies published today were directed by Drs. John S. Lambert of Rochester and Timothy P. Cooley of Boston City and involved a total of 71 patients. Many of the patients felt better or put on weight while taking DDI. Virus levels fell, while the number of white blood cells _ the infection-fighting cells that are destroyed by the AIDS virus _ increased. However, high doses of the drug caused a potentially fatal pancreas inflammation and severe foot pain. Liebman, senior author of the Boston City study, said the pancreas ailment often occurred after three or four months of DDI treatment and frequently affected the sickest patients. ``Physicians have to be very alert to the toxicities,'' he said. ``A lot of physicians are not sensitive to this. They are just happy to be able to give something to their patients.'' Even if DDI turns out to be no better than AZT, it may still be an alternative for some patients. AZT often loses its effectiveness after a year or so of treatment, and it also suppresses the body's ability to make new blood cells.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Members who published a Des Moines, Iowa-dated story that was the first item of PM-Religion Rdp for March 16, 1990, moved in advance as b0186 of March 14, may wish to publish the following clarification.
DOC.TEXT: In an academic study of the air time television preachers devote to fund-raising and promotion, cited in an Associated Press article March 16, the findings for Pat Robertson's show were inflated by an overemphasis on special telethon programs. The communications professor who conducted the study, Stephen Winzenburg of Des Moines' Grand View College, said Robertson devoted an average 44 percent of air time to fund-raising and promotion. Robertson's organization says its record shows that the Robertson programs on average devote 18 percent of air time to what they regard as fund-raising and promotion. Winzenburg says a disproportionate concentration of telethon programs among the Robertson programs he monitored may have skewed the result. Two of the six Robertson shows he studied were telethon programs. Winzenburg says the non-telethon Robertson shows he monitored devoted an average 30 percent of air time to content he considered to be fund-raising and promotion.

DOC.HEAD: Co-Chairman of Joffrey Ballet Resigns
DOC.TEXT: The co-chairman of the troubled Joffrey Ballet has resigned, The New York Times reported in Friday's editions. Anthony A. Bliss announced his resignation Thursday and told the Times that David H. Murdock, the other co-chairman, had also resigned, and that Frank W. Lynch, vice chairman of the board, had either resigned or was about to. The three executives are said to be among those opposed to the continuing directorship of Gerald Arpino, who founded the company with the late Robert Joffrey. Arpino earlier this month resigned as artistic director of the ballet and withdrew his works and Joffrey's from the ballet's repertory. He quit after the Joffrey board of directors voted to set up an operating committee that would run the company in place of both Arpino and the 55-member board. But Arpino remains artistic director of the company's ballet school. And negotiations are continuing on his future role in the Joffrey. Arpino has been a dancer and choreographer with the modern ballet company since its early days in the mid-1950s. However, critics and dance buffs alike have often called his works pedestrian instead of inspired, and without structure, purpose or artistry. The Joffrey, like many dance companies, has financial problems. Based in New York and Los Angeles, it faces a deficit of about $2 million. Murdock had agreed to close the deficit with gifts, loans and fund-raising over three years, The New York Times previously reported.

DOC.HEAD: Boom or Bust? Idea of National Lottery Seen as Longshot
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Thomas Jefferson once ran a lottery to pay off his personal debts, calling it a wonderful concept because ``it lays taxation only on the willing.'' Now, some members of Congress are talking about a national lottery as a possible way to raise money without raising taxes, especially after George Bush's campaign pledge: ``Read my lips, no new taxes,'' But visions of mega-jackpots aside, the very idea of a national game seems like a bad gamble for states already in the lottery business and for religious and social groups. ``We oppose the idea,'' said Michael Carr, director of the Michigan lottery and head of the North American Association of State and Provincial Lotteries. ``We would prefer the money stay in the states. Clearly, it would be competition.'' Lotto America, a 10-state group that pools its resources to offer bigger jackpots, also views a national game as a bad bet. ``I don't think there's enough room in the marketplace,'' said Jim Davey, director of the Oregon lottery and vice president of Lotto America. ``A national lottery would significantly cut into Lotto America sales. There's probably a limit on the disposable income people have for gambling.'' Lotteries are now a billion-dollar industry. Thirty-one states and the District of Columbia offer games, and sales this year are expected to top $20 billion _ four times what they were in 1982, lottery officials say. Most states make a profit of 30 percent to 40 percent that is earmarked for such things as education and aid to the elderly. And some congressmen are itching to get in on the action. Sen. Alan Simpson of Wyoming, the Senate's No. 2 Republican, said Tuesday a a national lottery was a possible revenue source to plug into the federal budget. Rep. Austin Murphy, D-Pa., plans to try again with a national lottery bill he first suggested in 1985. Attempts at starting a national lottery have failed in the past, in large part because Rep. Dan Rostenkowski, D-Ill., chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, is adamantly opposed to them, and his panel has jurisdiction in the House. Murphy's bill would return a share of the take to states selling tickets. The congressman recognizes that any measure that lacks such a provision ``doesn't have a chance,'' according to Mike Johns, a staff member of the House labor standards subcomittee. But there are many opponents who see lotteries as a shell game that tax the poor. ``A lottery is the sale of an illusion to poor people who view it as the only possibility of breaking out of the cycle of poverty they live in,'' said Weston Ware of the Baptist Christian Life Commission in Texas. ``It's bad public policy, bad social policy and bad moral policy.'' Valerie Lorenz, executive director of the National Center for Pathological Gambling in Baltimore, also thinks the idea is a bad one. ``It is absolutely foolhardy to legalize any type of gambling without studying the social and economic costs of promoting an addictive process,'' she said. ``The government would be promoting an addiction.'' Still, the chance to win instant riches by buying a ticket has gilt-edged appeal. And taxpayers are weary of shelling out more and more to the government. ``The resistance to gambling in increasingly counterbalanced by the desire not to pay more taxes,'' said Emory University history professor Dan Carter. A 1984 Gallup Poll commissioned by the trade magazine Gaming and Wagering Business found that 62 percent of Americans supported an annual national game and 26 percent opposed it. But Paul Dworin, the magazine's publisher, said such sentiments would not be enough to offset political realities. ``I don't think it has a chance,'' Dworin said. ``Will Utah allow a national lottery to operate. Will some of the southern states in the Bible Belt?'' This wouldn't be the first Congress to try to hit the jackpot with a quick fix. In 1776, the Continental Congress approved a lottery to raise $10 million for George Washington's army. It was abandoned because most colonists couldn't afford the $10 ticket and the ``wealthier ones who were Tories had no desire to aid the rebellion,'' said John Scarne in his ``Complete Guide to Gambling.'' Lotteries also helped finance Ivy League schools such as Harvard, Dartmouth and Princeton. But games were outlawed in the 19th century because many of them were fixed. New Hampshire reintroduced gambling in modern times with a statewide sweepstakes in 1964 for public schools. But a lottery would have to rake in a lot of money to put a dent in the $3.01 trillion national debt. A Congressional Research Service study in 1985 said every American over age 16 would have to spend $2,041 on the game to eliminate a deficit of $185 billion. And H. Roy Kaplan, an associate professor at the Florida Institute of Technology, said the most optimistic estimates from a lottery game would not be enough to cover the interest on the national debt. ``In realistic terms, the national debt is unapproachable in terms of a lottery's ability to diminish it,'' Kaplan said.

DOC.HEAD: Dump Program Turns Rubbish Into Art
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Who steals William Wardham's work steals art; who steals his raw materials, steals trash indeed. Wardham is the first artist-in-residence at San Francisco's huge trash transfer station near Candlestick Park. He's happily been welding metal scraps into more than half a dozen works already on display near his work area. ``There is so much activity, so much history in this,'' the 48-year-old sculptor said, holding crumpled chrome that once was a grocery cart. ``You immediately ask yourself how it got that way. Was it crushed by a hydraulic press here in the yard, or did something happen to the grocery cart?'' Jacqueline Tripp, head of the program for Norcal Solid Waste Systems Inc., said the goal is to get people to start thinking about recycling to reduce the amount of garbage they generate. ``It's important to be aware of all the waste out there and that some of it can be reclaimed,'' Tripp said. ``We have to find a means to extend the life of our landfills.'' Wardham says the smell bothers him occasionally, although the 2,000 tons of trash received every day is deodorized somewhat by a bubble-gum smelling aerator that also controls dust with moisture. Tripp said Norcal plans to pay artists-in-residence an average of $2,000 a month for a one- to six-month stint at the site where trash is dumped and then shipped to landfills at other sites. Completed works will remain at the solid-waste transfer station as part of a growing exhibit open to visitors, including school children and civic leaders, according to Tripp. ``We renovated a building for an artist's studio right on site here,'' she said. ``I think we'll see some interesting pieces of art created.'' Jo Hanson, a long-time conceptual artist who helps select artists for the dump project, proposed it out of her love of creating art from trash she found on the streets in front of her San Francisco house. ``By bringing together the environment and art we're carrying a message that will make people more thoughtful about materials,'' she said. ``There is an infinite supply of material here, both in quantity and variety.'' In 1970, Hanson said, she was sweeping the sidewalk in front of her home when she ``began to see art in what was there, blowing past me every day.'' ``I've studied garbage in the streets of other big cities and San Francisco has unique trash,'' she said. ``People don't hide their private lives here. ``Just from the stuff on the sidewalks you can follow the progress of some people's affairs, including their drug dealings and sex lives.'' Hanson and Wardham say working with used materials is more challenging because the items have a history that can influence the artist. ``You can do conceptual things that relate to where the trash comes from and where it goes,'' Hanson said. ``Recently, I've begun working with metal that has been run over in the streets enough to make it into interesting shapes. There's an urban energy to the pieces.'' So far, Hanson has received 30 applicants from artists interesting in working at the dump. ``I think we've always had a more progressive outlook here,'' she said. ``This is just another innovative art program.''

DOC.HEAD: No Censorship, but Control Is Another Question
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Censorship ended with the fall of Nicolae Ceausescu in December, but the opposition says state control of television and major newspapers, and of newspaper distribution, is just as effective. Spokesmen for independent news outlets and parties say telling the opposition story is extremely difficult as Romania approaches its first free elections in 44 years, scheduled for May 20. The chief target of criticism is the National Salvation Front, which dominates the interim government and is suspected by many of seeking to bring back a milder form of communism. Many ranking members of the Front, including interim President Ion Iliescu, are former Communists who had been critical of Ceausescu. Front leaders profess democratic ideals, including a commitment to freedom of the press. The Human Rights Law Group, based in Washington, D.C., said after a fact-finding tour in late April that many Romanians believed the Front controlled the government. It said the Front's advantages ``are amplified by the government's control of television, printing presses and newsprint, distribution of national and opposition print media, international communications networks, and air and ground transport.'' ``There are widespread complaints that the newspapers distributed by the government, especially those of opposition parties and certain independent papers, often fail to reach their destination, are not delivered promptly or are returned when they could have been sold,'' the monitoring group said. Several journalists working for independent dailies or opposition party papers echoed those concerns in recent interviews. On television, ``representatives of opposing political parties . .. have three minutes to tell their story from scripts held in their hand,'' said Petre Mihai Bacanu, president of the 4,000-member Independent Journalists Union. ``Mr. Iliescu could grin on the screen all day and nobody at the television would mind,'' he said. Supporters of the Front say Iliescu and other senior officials get more coverage because national leaders make more news than obscure candidates for Parliament. Several journalists said even coverage of news events was biased in the Front's favor. One example cited was a demonstration organized by the Liberal Party at which the camera dwelt at length on barefooted gypsies in the crowd. Most Romanians think of gypsies as idlers and thieves. Images of roses, flattering graphics and stirring music were added to taped coverage of a Front rally, the journalists said. Distribution of independent or opposition daily newspapers was one of the problems mentioned most often. Bacanu is a member of the group that publishes Romania Libera, which has a circulation of 850,000 and is the largest paper regularly critical of the government. He snorted when asked whether copies were reaching readers in the provinces. ``People on the train simply throw them off,'' Becanu said. Gelu Netea, manager of the Liberal Party paper Vitorul, said state trucking companies were run by ``neo-Communists,'' meaning supporters of the Front, who did not honor contracts to deliver the newspaper nationwide. In Bucharest, ``the press distributor regularly either doesn't take our copies or only a small amount,'' Netea said during an interview in his office. He gestured at stacks of newspapers several days old. Other government companies with agreements to distribute 80,000 copies nationally ``will take only 40,000 on a given day and then will wait up to five days to take them to newsstands,'' he said. Officials and supporters of the government denied the charges. Both sides agree the state-run presses, which turned out only a half-dozen dailies in Ceausescu's day, are woefully inadequate for printing the more than 700 newspapers now being published. Some typesetting machines at the central printing plant date from the 1940s and much of the lead is melted in an antiquated gas-fired furnace. ``Welcome to Gutenberg's era,'' a foreman on the printing floor told a Western reporter who was touring the plant.

DOC.HEAD: Vision of Euro-Unity Inspires A Pan-European Weekly
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: It's mid-morning and publisher Robert Maxwell is on the telephone lambasting someone about distribution problems in Germany, or doing an interview with a London radio station. It's part of a hectic countdown to Friday when the 66-year-old tycoon launches his latest venture, a pan-European weekly. Fired by a vision of a united Europe, he says he'll back the newspaper, The European, for ``as long as Europe is around,'' and rails against those skeptical about the viability of The European as ``uninformed, biased scribblers.'' With the crumbling of the East-West divide in Europe and moves toward closer unity of the 12-nation European Community, Maxwell believes The European is an idea whose time has come. ``The Europeans have ended their stupid nationalism,'' he says. ``We're in the business of uniting Europe.'' ``There are no buts about this,'' Maxwell said in an interview in his penthouse suite at Maxwell House, London headquarters of a global publishing and communications empire spanning two dozen countries. He's the new paper's owner, editor-in-chief, masthead designer and owner of the company doing the color. ``I've taken on the role of editor-in-chief for this newspaper because the Europeans want to have a guarantee that this isn't just some perfidious Albion foisting a European newspaper on the natives on the continent,'' he told the London radio station. ``And since I'm born in Czechoslovakia, speak a lot of European languages and everyone knows I'm more patriotic than the natives of this country, I'm virtually tailor-made for the job,'' he said. The 64-page English-language newspaper will have an initial print run of 1 million copies Friday, selling in London for 84 cents each. Half in color, it has three sections: main news, business and sports, and a 32-page tabloid lifestyle and arts section called Elan. The theater listings include what's on from Amsterdam to Zagreb, via Cluj, Romania. A dummy edition has front-page stories about Europe from Moscow, Berlin and Paris, and inside are congratulatory letters from, among others, Poland's Lech Walesa and Anglo-French actress Charlotte Rampling. Actor Peter Ustinov writes a column, and the editorial staff of 100 includes some top names in European journalism. The paper is being printed in London, Frankfurt, Roubaix in France, and near Budapest in Hungary. Maxwell, Britain's second-biggest newspaper publisher after Rupert Murdoch, is launching The European as part of the Mirror Group Newspapers which he bought in 1984. He says he is spending $41 million on The European's launch and guarantees advertisers sales of 225,000 copies weekly from July to December, 60 percent in Britain. If sales are under 225,000, advertisers get rebates. The break-even point, Maxwell says, is 300,000. The European enters a British market which, with 21 national daily and Sunday newspapers, has never been more crowded. The boom results chiefly from the defeat of the printworkers' unions, which were crushed by Murdoch and Maxwell to usher in the high technology on which The European depends. Media analysts credit Maxwell with a brave new idea. But many question whether The European is viable only in English and with two-thirds of its projected sales in Britain; whether it can compete with established English-language papers in Europe, such as The International Herald Tribune, The Wall Street Journal Europe and The Financial Times, and whether it can attract vital corporate advertising. And the question remains whether there are enough dedicated Europeans. ``It's an admirable and rather heroic idea,'' says Eric de Bellaigue, publishing analyst at the London brokerage Panmure Gordon. ``But I would doubt if an awful lot of people are going to see themselves at this stage as being European and identifying automatically with something called The European.'' It's ``a very good product in search of a market,'' says Alec Kenny, media director of Saatchi and Saatchi Advertising. ``But you just have to wonder if there are enough people out there in the market place who really want this sort of product,'' Kenny said in an interview. Raymond Snoddy, media correspondent of The Financial Times, agrees. ``As a purely financial venture I wouldn't give many chances for The European's longevity,'' Snoddy says. But Maxwell ``is committed to making it a success and he might be prepared to back it financially long enough until the perceptions of Europeans catch up with his.'' Maxwell, born Labji Hoch to Jewish peasant parents who died at the hands of the Nazis, arrived in Britain penniless in 1940. A decorated World War II British officer, he has sat in Parliament for the Labor Party. But he has never quite been accepted by the British establishment, and rival publications mock him as ``the bouncing Czech'' and a self-publicist. In 1987, in a blaze of publicity, Maxwell launched a new British daily, The London Daily News, which folded after five months. But with The European, Maxwell insists, he'll spend anything for it to succeed. ``Mirror Group Newspapers makes a profit of $1.5 million a week,'' he says. ``I suspect they will be able to sustain any losses on The European for as long as Europe is around.''

DOC.HEAD: Automatic Grocery Lane Lets Customers Scan Own Goods
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Check it out. The latest at the supermarket will let customers become do-it-yourselfers at the checkout lane. Not only for bagging. They will be able to run packaged products over a scanner and weigh their own produce before going to a central cashier. But don't try to slip an extra can of peas or bunch of bananas past the computer. A security system in the CheckRobot Inc. lanes reverses the conveyer if any unscanned, unweighed or switched product is placed on it. And a gentle electronic voice says ``please set the last item aside and continue scanning.'' The lanes were on display Wednesday on the final day of the Washington, D.C.-based Food Marketing Institute's Supermarket Industry Convention at McCormick Place. And Scott M. Sloan, vice president of marketing for CheckRobot, said the benefits of the system, and a new cooperative marketing agreement with IBM, should make it popular. ``It's rare that you'll find a piece of equipment in the food industry that will address the retailer's greatest concern _ and that's the labor shortage _ as well as address the single greatest concern that their shoppers have _ and that's speed of checkout,'' Sloan said. The systems, on the market for about a year, are already installed in 11 supermarkets, including locations in Ontario, Canada, New Jersey, Virginia, Florida and Wisconsin. Other installations are planned soon. Sloan said the lanes are easy to operate. ``You can go to a number of our sites and you can see ... children ... scanning groceries while their mother's at the other end bagging,'' he said. Stores can still provide baggers, and can decide how many cash registers they want to use, but to get the financial benefit from the machines, it's recommended that each cashier handle at least three lines, Sloan said. A computer screen and two rows of buttons face the shopper bringing groceries to the line. Prices of scanned products appear on the screen, while anything that needs to be weighed is put on the scanner surface, which is also a scale. Buttons have pictures of different kinds of produce, such as grapes. Put the grapes on the scale and hit the button, and the price is recorded. For more detailed lists, a button might say ``Fruit Screen,'' and a checkerboard of several varieties appear on the screen. A touch of the right one registers the weight and price. All of this is done with or without a computer voice stating the prices _ at the customer's discretion _ and with recorded video of a woman to give some messages _ including ``Help is on the way'' for those who touch the ``Help'' square on the screen. A receipt at the end of the line is taken to the cashier for payment. While saving labor costs is a selling point of the machines, Sloan said the devices really will fill a void created by a shortage of 16- to 24-year-old workers. Al Zack, spokesman for the Washington, D.C.-based United Food and Commercial Workers union, which represents retail food employees, said there's only a shortage because stores want too many part-timers. He also predicted customer dissatisfaction with self-checkout, and slow lines due to baffled shoppers. ``I don't think many customers consider it a convenience to do the work for the store,'' he said. But Richard Honerkamp, chief financial officer of Deerfield Beach, Fla.-based CheckRobot, said most customers have liked the system, and checkout would be faster _ especially in non-peak hours when stores often shut down most lanes. At each site, conventional lanes also operate. That's the way it must be, at least for now, said Kim Contos, director of special projects for Pay Less Super Markets Inc., which operates nine stores in Anderson and Lafayette, Ind. The chain's flagship store in Anderson is getting five automatic lanes installed. ``We wouldn't convert a store entirely,'' Contos said. ``I don't think any of us are ready for that in the immediate future.''

DOC.HEAD: French President Beset by Sagging Polls, Harsh New Biography
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Francois Mitterrand began his 10th year as France's president this week with his popularity plummeting and his political integrity under harsh attack in a new, best-selling biography. Some political analysts predict Mitterrand's problems will worsen in the coming months. Others suggest the Socialist president will bounce back, as he has many times in an up-and-down, 45-year political career. Recent public opinion polls show a dramatic drop in his popularity. A survey by Sofres, a major polling firm, recorded a 12-point collapse from 61 to 53 percent in a single month, while a poll by the Journal du Dimanche newspaper found only 39 percent of respondents satisfied with Mitterrand's performance. ``Don't ever forget: Francois Mitterrand is an artist of resurrection,'' says Franz-Olivier Geisbert, 41, author of the new, unflattering biography. ``In 1980, he was finished. In 1981, he was elected president of the Republic.'' Geisbert, a prominent journalist who has worked for both leftist and conservative publications, has been following Mitterrand's career for years. His second book on Mitterrand, ``The President,'' is filled with revealing anecdotes and interviews and conversations with presidential advisers, ministers, opposition leaders, reporters, and Mitterrand himself. Currently on the best-seller list, it strips away Mitterrand's image as a lofty, high-principled statesman and depicts him instead as a ruthless, scheming politician who ``squeezed aside principle and ideology'' to carve out his place in history. ``Mitterrand has fascinated me for a long time,'' Geisbert writes in the introduction. ``This man, in fact, is never the man you think he is. He is both better and worse.'' ``The whole Mitterrand is there, in this mix of electoral cynicism and artistic haze. He does not let himself be burdened by scruples when power is at stake,'' Geisbert writes. The book is a devastating behind-the-scenes look at how Mitterrand, 73, exercises presidential power by manipulating political allies and enemies. It chronicles his intense dislike of his longtime Socialist rival Michel Rocard, whom he relegated to minor Cabinet posts until attrition among his stalwarts forced him to name Rocard as premier after Mitterrand's re-election in 1988 to a second seven-year term. The book also describes how Mitterrand cleverly engineered a leftist coalition to beat Valery Giscard d'Estaing in 1981. The maneuver was doubly useful to Mitterrand. It led, ultimately, to the decline of the Communist Party and fueled the rise of the extreme-right National Front party, which has discredited and divided conservative political factions ever since. Mitterrand's troubles have been making headlines for weeks. Political analysts attribute them to several events, including the amnesty of a former Socialist minister involved in a political fund-raising scandal. After the Socialist Party congress in April turned into a mean dogfight among contenders to the presidency (not vacant until 1995), Mitterrand descended into the arena and gave a rare television interview trying to explain the mess. His efforts appeared to make matters worse. The book also paints merciless portraits of some of Mitterrand's closest aides. Jacques Attali, one of his most influential advisers, emerges as insecure and ambitious. Former Premier Laurent Fabius, once seen as Mitterrand's political heir, comes across as a calculating, power-hungry ideologue. Analysts say Mitterrand's drop in popularity can be explained by his loss of favor among voters with political sympathies on the right. Many of these voters backed Mitterrand in 1988, viewing him as a reassuring father figure, comparable to Charles de Gaulle, who would work for the broad national interest. ``The key to his re-election was his ability to preserve influence beyond the political and sociological boundaries of the left,'' Eric Dupin said in Liberation. This loss of right-leaning voters has not been countered by an increase of support from the left, such as young people and blue-collar workers. ``Mitterrand is looking for the choke to get going again,'' headlined Liberation, a leftist daily. ``The Elysee (presidential palace) seems to have run out of inspiration, and enthusiasm.''

DOC.HEAD: Math Goof Makes Telescope Miss Its Mark
DOC.TEXT: It was a math mistake everybody has made in a checkbook, but in this case it caused the Hubble Space Telescope to miss its target by trillions of miles. Somebody added when he should have subtracted. Or vice versa. Embarrassed NASA scientists gave that explanation Wednesday for the failure of the telescope to find two bright stars. The telescope missed its target by one-half degree _ about the width of a full moon as seen from Earth. ``When we were trying to point the telescope to the center of a pretty rich star field with a high probability of acquisition we were really off to one side of that,'' said Jean Olivier, deputy manager of the Hubble project for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. Because of the math error and other problems, scientists won't be able to take the first star pictures with the telescope until next week, NASA said. When the Hubble was launched from the space shuttle Discovery on April 25, they expected the first picture within a week. In the latest glitch, the telescope was looking for two stars of a certain brightness in the star cluster, but failed. Such guide stars are necessary to tell the telescope precisely where it is pointing; without them it is disoriented. Astronomers relied on star charts made in the 1950s when they designed pointing instructions for the telescope, Olivier said. But the stars have moved since then from Earth's vantage point. The mistake was made when the scientists factored in the extent of that movement. They corrected in the wrong direction. ``Instead of subtracting it they added it or vice versa,'' Olivier said. ``Instead of going from 18 arc minutes back to zero we went from 18 to 36 or close to 37,'' he said. ``That was the fundamental problem.'' In the language of astronomers, an arc minute is one-sixtieth of a degree in the 360-degree pie that makes up a circle. The mathematical error threw the telescope's aim off by a half-degree. ``For several days we didn't understand what the problem was and we were thinking we maybe had some problem with the onboard system alignment or the onboard function of the fine guidance system,'' Olivier said. ``Now we can take corrective action and point in the right direction.'' Engineers still are puzzled by a slight jitter in the telescope when it is commanded to roll and by some unwanted motion as the instrument moves from the shadow of Earth into the sunlight. But they are going ahead with focusing tests and other planned setup activities. To date more than $2.1 billion has been spent on the telescope and ground facilities. The Hubble has been ready for launch since 1985, maintained at a cost of $7 million a month. Hundreds of engineers and astronomers have been involved in planning for the telescope's 15-year mission. ``In hindsight you look at it and say how could we have done that,'' Olivier said of the error. ``But going into it, even though it might have been something staring us in the face, it was not obvious to many of us that we had this problem.'' He added: ``I don't know how to explain it ... we made a mistake of about a half-degree and it wasn't caught by many people who worked the problem over the past many years. ``What else can I say?'' Olivier said.

DOC.HEAD: T-Shirt Protest Against RCMP Decision Rouses Human Rights Ire
DOC.TEXT: A T-shirt protest against a government decision to let Sikhs in the Royal Canadian Mounted Police wear turbans with their uniforms has angered human rights advocates. Gerhard Neufahrt of Harrison Hot Springs produced 100 T-shirts emblazoned ``Oh, Oh, Canada'' and showing five Mounties: one wearing a stetson, one a turban, one with braids, one in a veil and one wearing a Viking helmet with horns. He said the purpose was protest rather than profit. ``It's designed to tell politicians they have made a mockery of our history and culture,'' said Neufahrt. ``There is nothing racial about the T-shirt and I have nothing against Sikhs.'' Leaders of the British Columbia Human Rights Coalition disagreed. ``It's disgustingly clear, and we will be deciding soon what to do about it,'' said coalition official Susan O'Donnell. Aspiring Mountie Baltej Dhillon, 23, dismissed the T-shirt as a money-making ploy that preyed on emotions. ``And I am not suprised that polls show people don't like turbans as part of the uniform, especially with this kind of message,'' Dhillon said. In a recent Gallup poll on the issue, 68 percent of 1,049 respondents opposed letting Sikh Mounties wear their traditional turbans, 22 percent were in favor and 10 percent had no opinion. Sikhs belong to a Hindu religious sect founded in northern India about 500 years ago and have a tradition of distinguished service in the military and police.

DOC.HEAD: Today Marks 30th Anniversary of Historic Kennedy-Humphrey Primary
LaserPhoto NY4
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: Thirty years ago today, predominantly Protestant West Virginia said yes to a Catholic and played a pivotal role in the making of a president. When John F. Kennedy routed Sen. Hubert H. Humphrey in the state's Democratic primary on May 10, 1960, he put to rest the notion that a Catholic couldn't be president, experts said. ``It propelled John Kennedy to the nomination and undermined the religious issue,'' said West Virginia Wesleyan professor Robert Rupp, who is organizing a symposium Wednesday to discuss the role of religion, the media and campaign techniques in what he calls ``The Primary That Made a President.'' ``The West Virginia primary really was the difference in John Kennedy's success or defeat,'' said Ted Sorensen, Kennedy's former speechwriter. ``Given the handicap of his religion and to some extent the handicap of his age, he knew he would not be the choice of bosses in the back rooms. He had to win in the primaries and, above all, he had to win in Protestant areas,'' Sorensen said Wednesday. Kennedy's advisers expected the worst from West Virginia, about 90 percent Protestant at the time, although Kennedy had won five of nine earlier primaries. Kennedy beat Humphrey in West Virginia, 236,510 votes to 152,187. Although the vote made political history, West Virginia's people and the grinding, inescapable poverty some of them lived in made a lasting impression on the scion of a wealthy Massachusetts family. ``He had seen poverty before,'' Sorensen said. ``But the long-term hardship faced by many of the people he met in West Virginia, the look on their face and the stories they told made a very deep impression on him. It wasn't a theory any longer.'' Kennedy spent more time campaigning in West Virginia than anywhere else. His advisers, supporters and family members hit every chicken dinner, student rally and ladies' auxiliary meeting they could. ``It was an exhausting campaign. We went to every hill and hollow,'' Sorensen said. When he was asked about his Catholicism, Kennedy's standard response was to talk about his family's military service, a vote-swaying appeal in a state with a high percentage of soldiers, sailors and airmen. ``He said, `Nobody asked my brother about his religion when he died for his country in World War II,''' said Charles Peters, who managed Kennedy's Kanawha County effort and is now editor of the Washington Monthly. Kennedy also had Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., son of the most popular president in West Virginia, on his side. ``That was as if God's son had said it's all right to vote for this Catholic,'' Peters said. West Virginia Secretary of State Ken Hechler, a first-term congressman at the time, was convinced Kennedy's religion would cost him the state. He changed his mind after he saw the Kennedy family in action. ``It impressed me so much that they, as a family team, knew exactly what needed to be done without any kind of chitchat,'' Hechler said. The Kennedy and Humphrey campaigns differed markedly. Kennedy chartered a plane at one point to fly to campaign stops; Humphrey rode around in a bus. Kennedy's theme song was ``High Hopes'' by Frank Sinatra; Humphrey had a folk singer. But the Kennedy high style didn't scare off the simple folk of West Virginia. Peters said he advised against bringing Jacqueline Kennedy to campaign in West Virginia. ``I thought she would come across as a snobbish, Northeast woman who would contrast unfavorably with the down-to-earth Muriel Humphrey,'' Peters said. ``Instead she was a big hit.''

DOC.HEAD: Negotiations Yield Tentative Accord on Small Claims
DOC.TEXT: Months of complex financial negotiations between the United States and Iran produced a tentative, $105 million settlement of more than 2,000 U.S. small claims pending since the 1979 Islamic revolution, the State Department says. The package deal also includes a tentative agreement to pay $400,000 to settle 108 Iranian claims against the United States, deputy spokesman Richard Boucher said Wednesday. The Bush administration repeatedly has declared it will make no deals to secure the release of the U.S. hostages in Lebanon, believed held by pro-Iranian militants, and that the claims negotiations are not related to the hostage situation in any way. Nonetheless, the tentative accord on the small claims is a step toward settling about $16 billion in larger claims that have been a major irritant between Iran and the United States for a decade, officials of both countries said in The Hague, Netherlands, site of the Iran-United States Claims Tribunal. In Washington, a department official who commented on condition of anonymity said he could not predict whether resolving the claims issue will result in the release of hostages or was in any way connected with the recent release of two captives. ``I have no way to speculate,'' the official said. The agreement covers 2,370 U.S. claims, government and private, the department said, with $50 million going to private claims and $55 million to U.S. government claims. U.S. officials in The Hague said an additional 400 or so claims not before the tribunal also are covered. The actual text of the agreement on claims of up to $250,000 must still be written, signed and then ratified by the tribunal. The panel was established under the 1981 Algiers Accord that won the release of 52 Americans held captive at the U.S. Embassy in Tehran for 444 days. ``The proposed settlement is the result of many months of effort,'' Boucher said, noting that negotiators discussed the issue at meetings held almost every month since last April. He said it is not clear how long it will take to wrap up final details of the tentative agreement. State Department officials have said repeatedly that there is no link between the negotiations to settle the claims and the hostage situation. They maintain that the talks at The Hague are not a forum in which hostages are discussed. Boucher said that among the U.S. government claims now near settlement are loans made to Iran by the Agency for International Development. The private claims included those for private U.S. property expropriated by Iran and for goods and services that were delivered but never paid for. The big claims still outstanding involve mainly U.S. military equipment for which Iran contracted but did not receive. After the overthrow of Shah Reza Pahlavi, Iran in 1979 canceled contracts for $9 billion in weapons, including four destroyers under construction that were later taken over by the U.S. Navy. The Tehran government has since claimed $11 billion for undelivered gear. Also outstanding are claims by major U.S. oil firms for properties expropriated by the revolutionary government. The companies have put that figure at $5 billion. Still pending as well is an American offer to voluntarily compensate the families of persons killed in July 1988 when a U.S. warship in the Persian Gulf shot down an Iranian airbus. Iran has yet to accept the offer. The United States is represented at the claims talks by Abraham Sofaer, the State Department's chief legal adviser. Dealing with major claims, the tribunal earlier awarded more than $1.3 billion to American claimants and about $130 million to Iranians, the State Department said. The tribunal also has ordered the return of $492 million in Iranian funds held in escrow after bank claims against the money are satisfied.

DOC.HEAD: American Sets Off to Bicycle Length of Great Wall
DOC.TEXT: Foreigners have ridden horses and danced classical ballet atop China's Great Wall. Now, a California man has set out to become the first person to bicycle from one end to the other, some 3,700 miles. ``Like Mao said, you're not a man until you've reached the top of the Great Wall,'' Kevin Foster said Wednesday. Maybe if the late revolutionary leader Mao Tse-tung were still around, Foster, a 30-year-old part-time actor from Ojai, Calif., might have gotten atop the wall sooner. He spent years trying to persuade Chinese authorities to approve his plan, and several more trying to find financial sponsors in the United States. The last hitches were smoothed out late last year, and Foster boarded a train Wednesday for the western mountain pass where the wall starts at Jiayuguan, 945 miles from Beijing. He will begin his trek later this week. From there, the fragmented remains of the more than 2,000-year-old wall snake through desert and mountains before reaching the sea at Shanhaiguan, east of Beijing. Over the years, the wall has attracted foreigners with strange ideas. They have ridden horseback, danced ballet, performed concerts and held cocktail parties on the wall, originally a symbol of China's desire to keep out the world and now simply a symbol of China. An Englishman ran the length of the wall in 1987. Others have ridden bicycles beside it. But so far, despite hundreds of millions of Chinese relying on bicycles as their only means of transportation, no one has ridden a bicycle on top of the wall its entire length. ``Everyone wants to be first at something,'' said Foster, who said he got the idea as a child when he saw television coverage of former President Nixon visiting the Great Wall in 1972. With his short, tousled ponytail, handlebar mustache and hyperkinetic personality, Foster said his hosts at the Academy of Science's Institute of Geography call him ``that crazy American.'' Last November, he rode the New York subway system for 85 continuous hours to get into the Guinness Book of World Records. Riding the wall on his mountain bike, he risks broken bones and axles. The wall never had an even surface, and the centuries have not been kind. Many portions have steep stairs or slopes, others have been reduced to rubble. In some places the wall has disappeared altogether due to the ravages of invading armies, weather and farmers who steal bricks for their homes. At those parts, Foster and his Chinese entourage will travel in jeeps. In fact, Zhou Yu, one of two young staffers the Institute of Georgraphy assigned to bicycle with Foster, said he thinks much of the trip might best be made in jeeps. ``I know there are some parts we'll look at and say, there's no way we can bicycle it. If we can just walk it, I want to walk.'' The army has refused to let the group even drive near one long stretch of the wall immediately west of Beijing because it is near military installations. Instead, they will detour around the area on train and resume bicycling at Beijing. From there to the sea, Foster said he expects the smoothest biking because many sections have been renovated for tourists. The whole journey will take about seven weeks, Foster estimated. It is costing him $20,000, the fee charged by the institute for making all arrangements. Foster said he will pay it in part with $15,000 he expects to receive from a U.S. helmet manufacturer for wearing their product. ``I can't wait to get it done so I can get on with the rest of my life,'' he said. ``I'm already planning my next project. It will be even bigger.''

DOC.HEAD: US Military Blamed for Civilian Deaths in Panama
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. military failed to observe the laws of war in an attack on a Panamanian installation last December and dozens of civilians may have died as a result, a private human rights group contends. A report made public Wednesday contended that both the U.S. and Panamanian military violated international humanitarian law governing armed conflict during the U.S. invasion of Panama five months ago. The study was prepared by Americas Watch, which attempts to promote protection of human rights in Latin America and the Caribbean. ``Some 15,000 persons were left homeless in the attack, and a very rough estimate is that 50-70 civilians were killed,'' the study said. ``Many more were seriously wounded.'' The attack took place on the Panama Defense Force headquarters, situated in the midst of a poor Panamanian neighborhood called El Chorrillo. The report gave little credence to allegations by some observers that forces loyal to Panamanian Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega were responsible for fires that broke out in El Chorrillo and left numerous civilian casualties. Noriega was ousted by the invading force and subsequently was flown to the United States for trial on drug-trafficking charges. The study said U.S. military leaders were unable to cite military necessity, such as the need for surprise, as a reason for not informing the residents of El Chorrillo that an attack on the headquarters was imminent. There was no immediate comment on the report from the Pentagon. In contrast to the Americas Watch report, Roman Catholic priests at an El Chorrillo church estimated last January that about 20 people died in the neighborhood, many in a fire that was set by retreating paramilitary supporters of Noriega. They said nearly 10,000 people sought refuge in the church and the school and a nearby home for the elderly. The Rev. Javier Arteta said members of the paramilitary Dignity Battalions bore much of the blame for the casualties. ``They came out of their homes shooting in every direction,'' Arteta said, adding that the U.S. military never fired in the direction of the church. The Americas Watch report said the U.S. military failed to follow the laws of war in refusing to free war prisoners upon the cessation of hostilities. As for Noriega's forces, the report said they violated international law by taking civilian hostages and by dressing as civilians during the fighting, thus attracting fire and exposing innocent people to combat. The study also said the U.S. Southern Command in Panama undercounted the number of civilian deaths that resulted from the fighting. The Pentagon total was 202, but the report said 300 is ``more likely the real figure.'' Former U.S. Attorney General Ramsey Clark has estimated the death toll in the 4,000-7,000 range, but the report said there was no basis for such a finding.

DOC.HEAD: Dukakis Camp Packed the House in Bentsen-Quayle Debate, Aide Says
DOC.TEXT: The Dukakis campaign stacked the audience for the 1988 vice presidential debate between Lloyd Bentsen and Dan Quayle and used a whip system to signal their partisans how to react, a top campaign aide says. ``We told people when to cheer and when to applaud and when not to,'' Thomas Donilon said Wednesday at a panel discussion sponsored by the Commission on Presidential Debates. Donilon, who was a top adviser to the campaign of Democrat Michael Dukakis, said people were flown to Omaha, Neb., for the Oct. 5, 1988, debate between the two vice presidential nominees. He said controlling audience reaction was part of an effort to ``have an impact'' on the millions of people watching the debate on television. Fellow panelist Charles Black, an adviser to the Bush campaign, said the debates between the presidential and vice presidential candidates were ``the most important single news events'' of the campaign. Paul G. Kirk Jr., who was Democratic Party chairman during that campaign, and Frank J. Fahrenkopf Jr., who was his Republican counterpart, were present at the panel discussion and said they were unaware of the Dukakis campaign's effort to manipulate the audience. ``We're up there saying, `Quiet down,''' said Kirk, recalling that both he and Fahrenkopf appealed to the audience to refrain from loud responses to candidate statements. But their appeals were ignored as the audience appeared to react spontaneously on several occasions. Asked if he thought the Dukakis campaign tactic was a ``dirty trick,'' Donilon responded: ``I don't think it was a dirty trick at all. We had tickets to give to our supporters.'' But Donilon also conceded the tactic was ``not a good thing to do.'' Later, he said that he disclosed what was done to show how easily debate audiences can be manipulated and to encourage the commission to recommend that future debates be held without a live audience in the auditorium. The commission transcript of the 1988 vice presidential debate showed repeated audience response to Bentsen comments and virtually none to remarks by Quayle. The loudest reaction, described in the transcript as ``prolonged shouts and applause,'' came after Quayle compared his experience to that of John F. Kennedy and Bentsen retorted, ``Senator, you are no Jack Kennedy.'' But that was not the only occasion when the audience reacted to Bentsen remarks. After Quayle said he and presidential nominee George Bush had ``the environmental interest,'' Bentsen said, ``This late conversion is interesting to me.'' The transcript said that remark was followed by ``laughter and applause.'' Partisans of both candidates reacted with what the transcript described as ``cheering and booing'' when Quayle referred to the ``Jimmy Carter grain embargo.'' In late 1979, after the Soviet Union sent troops into Afghanistan, Carter instituted an embargo on grain sales to the communist nation, a move that was widely criticized in the Farm Belt. Black argued against trying to force presidential campaigns to adhere to a debate format set up by people outside the campaigns. He said the debates present ``the toughest, most important set of tactical decisions'' of the campaign and ``it's absolutely essential for each nominee to make those decisions.'' ``We must run our own campaigns,'' Black said.

DOC.HEAD: Environmentalist Calls for Tougher Beach Cleanliness Standards
DOC.TEXT: The Environmental Protection Agency's guidelines for what constitutes clean beach water need tightening, says an engineer for an environmental organization. Diane M. Cameron of the Natural Resources Defense Council urged a congressional panel Wednesday to set a ``zero health risk'' goal for beach water. ``NRDC believes that EPA's recommendation of 19 cases of gastroenteritis per 1,000 marine swimmers as the maximum acceptable public health risk is clearly too high a threshold of risk,'' she said in testimony submitted to the House Merchant Marine subcommittee on oceanography and Great Lakes. ``Many states, including New York and Massachusetts, have adopted EPA's swimmer health risk goal as their own, with the result that many beaches deemed `safe' for swimming may actually be laced with sufficient pathogens to make hundreds of people each day sick with gastroenteritis and other diseases.'' Cameron said a zero health risk is achievable because it doesn't mean zero pathogens. She also suggested developing a ``bathing beach water quality index,'' akin to the familiar ``air quality index.'' However, officials argued that the current system for testing the cleanliness of beach water is adequate and that the federal government should not trample on states' rights. EPA witness William R. Diamond said that ``in the past two decades, programs to control water pollution established by (the EPA) under the Clean Water Act have virtually eliminated the threat of serious illness and disease from swimming at beaches.'' Diamond, who is director of the agency's criteria and standards division in the office of water regulations and standards, said the EPA opposes a bill before the subcommittee which would set mandatory guidelines for testing beach water. The bill, sponsored by Rep. Bill Hughes, D-N.J., would require the EPA to revise its criteria to ensure beach water testing on a weekly basis at minimum. Currently, some states test their water less frequently, or average the results of repeated tests. The bill would also require states to adopt the EPA's standards. They now are voluntary unless a state adopts them as part of its own water-quality program. James P. Burgess, an official with the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration called Hughes' bill unnecessary because current law covers ``a system by which EPA establishes national water quality criteria and states develop state water quality standards is already in place,'' ``Second, NOAA believes that mandatory criteria and uniform testing and monitoring procedures may be an unnecessary intrusion by the federal government into the responsibilities of individual states,'' he said.

DOC.NOTE: For release at 9 a.m. EDT; time set by source
DOC.HEAD: Engineers Named Inventors of the Year
DOC.TEXT: The Inventor of the Year Award for 1990 is being shared by three engineers who developed an electronic automobile transmission. Maurice B. Leising, Howard L. Benford and Gerald L. Holbrook were named winners today by Intellectual Property Owners Inc., which sponsors the annual honor. IPO is an association representing holders of patents, copyrights and trademarks. The three engineers, who will split the $5,000 award, work for the Chrysler Corp. The transmission they developed, which has one-third fewer parts than normal automatic transmissions, was first made available on 1989 model cars. The men were also winners of the Henry Ford II Award from the Society of Automotive Engineers earlier this year. In addition to the inventors of the year, the group named four other Distinguished Inventors of 1990. They are: _David H. Gelfand and Susanne Stoffel of the Cetus Corp., in Emeryville, Calif., who developed a genetically engineered enzyme used in diagnosis of AIDS and sickle cell anemia. _Marinus Los of American Cyanamid Corp. in Princeton, N.J., for a new type of safer herbicide. _Barnett Rosenberg of Michigan State University for Carboplatin, an anticancer agent.

DOC.HEAD: IRS Admits Problems With Sting Operation
DOC.TEXT: The head of the IRS listened quietly as members of Congress described one of his agency's undercover operations as too unbelievable for Hollywood and an embarrassment to the Keystone Kops. ``I'm not sure we have a different side,'' IRS Commissioner Fred T. Goldberg Jr. began when asked for his side of the story. Some aspects of the gambling operation ``were inadequate. Period. No minced words,'' he admitted. That Las Vegas operation, known as Project Layoff, was an effort by the agency to track down those who evade federal gaming taxes and income taxes on their winnings. After 11 months of poor recordkeeping and difficulty collecting from losers, the ``sting'' was shut down in 1985 after the lives of IRS agents were threatened by illegal bookmakers. ``Any businessman in Las Vegas would be thrown in jail if his books looked like Project Layoff's,'' Sen. Richard Bryan, D-Nev., complained Wednesday to the House Government Operations consumer subcommittee. ``The IRS would audit this firm and slap it with so many penalties and so much interest that your hair would stand on end,'' said Sen. Harry Reid, D-Nev. Reid said the project cost taxpayers $600,000 and resulted in only two prosecutions on minor charges. More important, he said, conduct of the sting gave rise to speculation that IRS workers could have skimmed some of the $22 million of bets that passed through the operation. ``How many illegal bookmaking operations that did business with the IRS (sting) were closed as a result?'' asked Rep. Doug Barnard Jr., D-Ga., chairman of the subcommittee. ``To my knowledge, there were none,'' said Inar Morics, assistant IRS commissioner for criminal investigations. Goldberg said IRS planning, control and recordkeeping of the operation, which ended four years before he took office, were inadequate. Although he had little praise for the project, he said the IRS will continue undercover operations, including an occasional sting, as part of its fight against drugs, money laundering and tax evasion. ``If we are going to do it, we've got to do it right,'' Goldberg said. He acknowledged that would include seeking cooperation from the FBI, as was done in the Project Layoff case, and from local gaming authorities, which was not done. ``If we submitted Project Layoff as a TV script, it would be rejected on the grounds that it is too unbelievable,'' Bryan said. ``It was a complete fiasco,'' said Rep. James Bilbray, D-Nev. ``No target was arrested.'' He said the IRS should get out of the sting business. Some Republicans on the subcommittee said they were concerned that failure of the Las Vegas project might slow the IRS fight against drug dealers and organized crime. ``I hope there is no political pressure for you to lay off,'' said Rep. Chuck Douglas, R-N.H. The House subcommittee investigated the project as part of a long-term probe of misconduct among high-level IRS officials. Goldberg said the IRS erred in failing to conduct a timely background check of a woman hired and later promoted in the criminal-investigation division of the Milwaukee office. The woman acknowledged later that she had been involved in illegal gambling. ``The controls which could have prevented the promotion from occurring failed to operate effectively in this case,'' Goldberg said. He said the IRS is investigating allegations that some IRS employees in the Albany office have been the subject of retaliation from superiors because the workers cooperated with subcommittee investigators. ``We take these charges most seriously,'' Goldberg said. ``We cannot and will not tolerate harassment and retaliation within our agency.''

DOC.HEAD: Pro Sports Executives See Coming Shift Toward Cable
DOC.TEXT: TV sports fans don't have to worry about paying to see the Super Bowl or World Series on the tube _ yet. But a panel of professional baseball, football and basketball executives told a House subcommittee Wednesday that as costs rise and network television viewership falls, teams will lean more toward cable, particularly for local viewing of baseball. That doesn't mean viewers will have to pay $10 just to watch the Super Bowl or the World Series, at least for the foreseeable future. Network TV still commands the audiences and advertising revenue to outbid cable TV for the major championship events, the executives said. ``I am confident that for some time to come, free television will remain the key method of distribution to our fans,'' National Basketball Association Commissioner David J. Stern told the House Energy and Commerce telecommunications and finance subcommittee. ``I do not anticipate any dramatic change in the number of NBA games available on, or shifting of our key events away from, free over-the-air television.'' Stern, along with his counterparts in the National Football League and Major League Baseball, said they could not foresee major championship games going to pay-per-view cable before the year 2000. NFL Commissioner Paul Tagliabue repeated an earlier pledge that the Super Bowl would not be offered on pay-cable in this decade. However, under questioning by Rep. Edward J. Markey, D-Mass., Tagliabue and the other executives would not make the same predictions for sports on so-called basic cable services. Tagliabue said it was ``extremely unlikely'' that the Super Bowl would appear on basic cable in the next 10 years, but he couldn't say what would happen to regular-season games. ``Beyond the next four years, it is difficult to speculate as to the nature of NFL television arrangements,'' Tagliabue said. Stern said the NBA championship games were under contract to CBS until 1997, but he would not predict what would happen after that in light of statistics showing the three major networks' share of the viewing audience has dropped from about 95 percent to about 65 percent in the past decade. ``I don't think you're going to see an increase in network'' shares of the audience, Stern added. Baseball Commissioner Francis T. Vincent Jr. said the issue was not so much championship games, to which networks can attract large audiences and therefore outbid cable, but in the broadcast of local games. He said Chicago White Sox baseball recently went to national cable superstation WGN when no local broadcasters would bid for the rights. Vincent said that because of cable, baseball fans elsewhere are seeing games they otherwise would not have had access to.

DOC.HEAD: Keating Defends Senators Who Defended Him
LaserPhoto WX6
DOC.TEXT: Savings and loan financier Charles H. Keating Jr. is defending the five senators who defended him _ whether they like it or not. ``They should be congratulated,'' Keating said Wednesday in a nationally televised luncheon at the National Press Club. The senators, now the target of a Senate Ethics Committee investigation, met with savings and loan regulators in March 1987 on behalf of Keating and his institution, Lincoln Savings and Loan Association of Irvine, Calif. The five _ Alan Cranston, D-Calif.; Donald W. Riegle Jr., D-Mich.; Dennis DeConcini, D-Ariz.; John Glenn, D-Ohio and John McCain, R-Ariz. _ all had received political contributions from Keating. Two years after the meeting, regulators seized Lincoln. They estimated the cost to taxpayers for the failure at $2 billion. Keating and his family are defendants in a $1.1 billion civil fraud and racketeering suit brought by the government. Keating said he is not disappointed that the senators have since tried to distance themselves from him. ``There's something wrong with the system and, from my perspective, that's what the senators were trying to call attention to. I think they did darn well,'' he said. Keating, in an emotional appearance in which he twice recited poetry, proclaimed his innocence and blamed regulators' unjustified and arbitrary writedown of Lincoln's assets for the S&L's collapse. He said he is broke and in danger of losing his house because he hasn't paid his mortgage in four or five months. ``If I were the crook that they say I was and if I were the greediest man in the world, by golly, you'd have to also call me the most stupid because nothing that I supposedly took ... has stuck to my palms or my children's,'' he said. Keating sharply criticized savings and loan bailout chief L. William Seidman for his decision to cut the price on difficult-to-sell S&L real estate in the government's possession. ``He's sure doing his best to make a heckuva lot of people that are rich get richer,'' he said, applauding a move by the Bush administration to nudge Seidman from office. Seidman has dismissed Keating's contentions as ``full of baloney'' and ``way off the mark.'' The press club speech was part of the former S&L executive's campaign to portray himself as a legitimate businessman persecuted by regulators. Last year, during the weekly House Banking Committee hearings into Lincoln's failure, Keating refused to talk to reporters, making his only comments in written statements. But in recent months he's made himself available for interviews. On Tuesday night, he fielded questions from callers to a 90-minute program on the C-SPAN cable television network. ``At this point I am trying to tell you my side of the story and I do appreciate the fact that you're letting me do it,'' he told reporters at the lunch. Keating has sued the government, seeking the return of his S&L. U.S. District Judge Stanley Sporkin is scheduled to hear closing arguments in the case on June 8.

DOC.HEAD: War on Drug Use Among Young Being Lost, Congressmen Say
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration is fighting the war on drugs with rubber bullets and losing the battle to keep school children from taking drugs, according to several members of a House committee. ``Our young people are succumbing to this crisis in greater numbers as the days go by, as both victims and victimizers,'' Rep. Charles Rangel, chairman of the House Select Committee on Narcotics Abuse and Control, said Wednesday. ``An entire generation may be lost before we are finished with the drug crisis,'' the New York Democrat said. ``Without the support of the nation's leadership, the war on drugs will continue to be fought with rubber bullets.'' The attack on the administration's drug use-prevention policies came as Education Secretary Lauro Cavazos touted two new anti-drug initiatives: a model curriculum and a handbook for grappling with drug and alcohol abuse on college campuses. Cavazos also outlined his department's efforts to monitor the implementation of required new prevention programs and policies at schools and colleges. Rangel complained that the strategy overlooks the needs of school dropouts, as well as those of school-age drug abusers in local and state jails and treatment centers. ``Quite frankly, Mr. Secretary, these studies are not helping at all,'' Rangel told Cavazos. ``I am disappointed that we don't have a federal treatment strategy. I'm disappointed that we don't have a foreign policy strategy. In my community, I don't need to give a model plan to the principal, nor do I need a handbook.'' Rep. Bill Grant, R-Fla., said he too was ``frustrated by all these studies.'' He said school children should be given alternatives to using drugs and teachers should learn how to help boost students' self-esteem. Rep. Joseph Brennan, D-Maine, said, ``I don't see any spirit, passion from this administration to seriously do something'' about drug abuse ``and some of the things I see are counterproductive.'' Brennan criticized William Bennett, President Bush's drug policy coordinator, for a recent statement that ``education is kind of a helpful auxiliary, maybe it's something that's nice.'' Cavazos refused to criticize Bennett but stressed ``education is the only solution to drugs.'' Other committee members criticized the administration's approach to drug prevention in the schools. A few, however, praised the department's handbooks and other literature used to tell students about the dangers of taking drugs. ``Education is a critical component of our nation's drug-prevention efforts and I want to commend you for your efforts to date,'' said Rep. Larry Coughlin, R-Pa. The new initiatives in the war on drugs, Cavazos said, will include releasing to about 150,000 public and private schools a model drug use-prevention curriculum covering kindergarten through grade 12. He said the curriculum, titled ``Learning to Live Drug Free,'' is designed to show students how taking drugs harms the user as well as society. Cavazos said more than 600,000 copies of a new handbook for parents have been distributed. He added that in July a handbook for college and university officials will be released to provide strategies for eliminating drug and alcohol abuse on their campuses.

DOC.HEAD: Yogurt Makes USDA Statistics Book for First Time
DOC.TEXT: Yogurt has arrived in the Agriculture Department's annual book of dairy statistics. Last year, according to the new figures, about 912.4 million pounds of plain and fruit-flavored yogurt were produced. There's no way to compare that with 1988 because it's the first time the USDA has published yogurt figures. In addition to the regular yogurt, about 66.3 million gallons of frozen yogurt and 44.2 million gallons of frozen yogurt mix were produced in 1989. By comparison, last year's ice cream production was 831 million gallons, down 6 percent from 1988. Ice milk, at 377 million gallons, was up 6 percent, and milk sherbet was unchanged at 52.2 million gallons. Dan Buckner of the department's National Agricultural Statistics Service said Wednesday the yogurt figures were requested by the International Association of Ice Cream Manufacturers. The trade group asked that the agency gather and publish figures only for frozen yogurt, but Buckner it was decided to include regular yogurt ``so we'd know exactly what we had.'' Budget crunches in recent years have chewed deeply into some USDA statistical and economic research programs, and the ice cream people were prepared to see some of their other items struck from the list in order to get the yogurt figures. However, Buckner said in a telephone interview that it was possible to squeeze yogurt into the statistical study without dropping something else. But there are some dairy items that one of these days may be folded into ``other'' categories and not identified separately. This happens when the number of processing plants and production decline so much that it would be impossible to protect the identities of companies. For many food manufacturers, including those who turn out dairy products, exact production figures for various items are considered trade secrets and are guarded closely. One of the candidates for losing its separate statistical identity is limburger cheese, an aromatic product that tends to identify itself regardless of manufacturer. ``We're going to get a crunch one of these days, and it's going to be dropped into the `other' (category) because such a small number of plants make it anymore,'' Buckner said. Limburger production in 1989 was shown at 901,000 pounds, down nearly 8 percent from 1988. Total cheese output rose 1 percent to 5.61 billion pounds, which included 2.67 billion pounds of American-type cheese.

Farmer Mac, short for the new Federal Agricultural Mortgage Corp., has moved a step closer to its debut in the nation's financial market later this year. The new federal agency was created by the Agricultural Credit Act of 1987 as a secondary market for agricultural real estate loans. Banks and other lenders can convert long-term assets _ in this case, real estate mortgages _ by selling the loans on the secondary market. Those who buy the mortgages then package or pool the loans and sell the mortgage-backed securities to the public. The system is designed to improve the cash flow of the original lenders and make more loan money available. Farmer Mac will share the risk of the farm real estate loan business by guaranteeing returns on the securities. Other federal agencies such as the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. (Freddie Mac), Federal National Mortgage Association (Fannie Mae) and Government National Mortgage Association (Ginnie Mae) serve a similar function for their clientele. Manufacturers Hanover Securities Corp. said Tuesday in New York that it will apply to Farmer Mac to be a certified pooler. As such, Manufacturers Hanover and the First Boston Corp. will co-manage the underwritings. First Boston was the sole managing underwriter for Farmer Mac's original stock issue in December 1988. Initial capitalization was $20 million, provided by the sale of common stock to banks and other financial institutions. The pool assembler is U.S. Agricredit Inc., which has headquarters in Westminster, Colo., plus offices in Washington, D.C.; Lincoln, Neb.; and Topeka, Kan. Agricredit was established in 1988 and is headed by Frank Naylor, president and chief executive officer. Naylor is a former chairman of the Farm Credit Administration and undersecretary of agriculture during the Reagan administration.

Sheep do well on a winter pasture of turnips, says the Agriculture Department. Animal nutritionist Steven P. Hart said he has experimented with sheep grazing on turnip pastures since 1986. The turnips are ``Purpletop,'' a variety familiar to grocery shoppers. Hart, who works at the agency's forage and livestock research laboratory in El Reno, Okla., said the sheep gained well on the crop. ``They'll eat the leaves first, then the top of the turnip,'' he said Wednesday in a report released here. ``Then they'll actually eat down into the heart of the turnip, but they don't pull them out of the ground.''

DOC.HEAD: Warning Label for Explicit Lyrics Draws Varied Response
LaserPhoto WX7
DOC.TEXT: ``It stinks,'' Missouri state legislator Jean Dixon says of the recording industry's voluntary new warning label for albums containing explicit lyrics. ``We all think the label is cute,'' says Daddy O, a member of Stetsasonic rap music group. Jay Berman, president of the Recording Industry Association of America, is hoping that parents whose children bought more than $2 billion worth of records, cassettes and compact discs in 1988 will agree with Daddy O. At a news conference Wednesday, Berman unveiled the industry's uniform ``parental guidance'' label for recordings that might be deemed objectionable because of lyrics dealing with sex, violence, suicide, drug abuse, bigotry or satanic worship. The black-and-white logo, which reads ``PARENTAL WARNING _ EXPLICIT LYRICS,'' will appear on the front lower right-hand corner of new releases reaching retail music stores in July, if the record companies and performing artists decide they are potentially offensive. Recording manufacturers, distributors and retailers hope the standardized stickers will halt the drive in a handful of state legislatures for mandatory warning labels. The music industry is backed by the Parents' Music Resource Center led by Tipper Gore, wife of Sen. Albert Gore Jr., D-Tenn., and the National PTA, the consumer advocates who won the industry's agreement in 1985 to use voluntary warning labels. ``We ask state legislators to consider dropping their legislation in favor of a voluntary system,'' said National PTA president Ann Lynch. ``We clearly have demonstrated that music consumers, especially parents, want and need label information _ not censorship,'' she said. But Mrs. Dixon, a Republican state representative from Springfield, Mo., and chief sponsor of a mandatory warning label bill this year, was unconvinced. ``Are they kidding? It stinks. This is a joke,'' she said. ``This plan doesn't even touch most of the music we're talking about.''
