Berman's trade association represents companies that produce more than 90 percent of the recordings sold in the United States, but many of the objectionable records are released by small, independent companies that don't belong to the recording industry group. Mrs. Dixon also criticized the size, color and content of the warning labels. Her bill would have required a bright yellow label that listed specific offensive material, including sex, violence and substance abuse. ``I'm not happy with this, but we'll give it a chance to work,'' she said. Berman says all but five of the 21 state legislatures that once considered mandatory labeling have backed down since the industry promised in late March to produce a standard, easily recognizable label. He said his association will continue its battle against mandatory labels in state legislatures in Missouri, Pennsylvania, Delaware, New York and Louisiana. Previously, individual record companies produced their own diverse warning labels and compliance was erratic. This resulted in parental complaints and the legislative drives for mandatory labels on albums with objectionable lyrics, primarily rap and heavy metal music. ``We believe the uniform logo will enhance the existing voluntary system and better respond to the legitimate concerns of parents,'' Berman said. ``Now that we have agreed on this new logo, it will be up to parents to use it as they see fit.'' Daddy O, the father of five children, applauded the voluntary labeling system. ``We don't think the government should determine what our children listen to,'' he said. ``We all think the label is cute.''

DOC.HEAD: If Budget Talks Fail, Huge Cuts Loom
With PM-Budget
DOC.TEXT: Defense and many domestic programs would be shredded if the $60 billion to $100 billion in automatic spending cuts that the Bush administration says may soon be necessary actually take place, analysts say. Administration and congressional leaders plan to begin negotiations next Tuesday aimed at working out a budget deal for fiscal 1991, which starts Oct. 1. Should they fail, the Gramm-Rudman deficit-reduction law will trigger spending slashes that White House budget director Richard Darman says will be in the $60 billion to $100 billion range from a spending plan totaling $1.23 trillion. ``Neither Congress nor the administration would contemplate cuts in that realm,'' Robert Reischauer, director of the non-partisan Congressional Budget Office, said Wednesday. ``It's not even in the realm.'' Lobbyists agreed. Ellen Nissenbaum of the Center for Budget and Policy Priorities, which advocates programs for poor people, said a $100 billion cut would mean that 172,000 pre-school students could lose their spots in the Head Start program. About 2.3 million poor and elderly Americans could be dropped by another program that helps them pay their utility bills, she said. ``It would be politically unpalatable across the board,'' she said. Reischauer calculated the effect of a $97 billion cut next year _ the amount CBO believes may be necessary. He said that would work out to 24.7 percent cuts in eligible defense spending and 37.2 percent reductions for affected domestic programs. Even $60 billion in Gramm-Rudman cuts ``would require reductions in defense that were nonsensical from a foreign policy perspective, and would be damaging to domestic programs,'' Reischauer said. The overall U.S. economy also would be badly wounded, analysts said. Cutting federal spending by $100 billion would take that amount away from corporations, members of the public and other beneficiaries of government programs. As the economy cooled, the government's tax collections would drop, its payments to the unemployed and the poor would rise and the deficit would move upward again, Reischauer said. ``You would see a slowdown to virtually a stall'' in the economy, he said. Many in Washington believe it will never come down to automatic cuts of the magnitude Darman is suggesting. They predict that a budget agreement will be reached by negotiation or the Gramm-Rudman law will be changed to reduce the amount of savings that are needed. If not, however, the Gramm-Rudman cuts would be highly noticeable to the public. ``People who make safety inspections of food and inspections of the workplace wouldn't show up,'' said Reischauer. ``Thousands of businesses that sell pencils and paper clips and Stinger missiles and computers to the government would suddenly find their business is off dramatically.'' The Gramm-Rudman cuts would not apply to every program in the budget. In defense, money the government has already committed to contracts cannot be slashed. Therefore, out of the $290 billion defense budget, about $190 billion would be subject to the reductions. Nearly three-fourths of domestic programs would also be exempt from Gramm-Rudman cuts. These includes Social Security payments, interest on the debt and many federal retirement and veterans' benefits. Many other programs, including Medicare and guaranteed student loans, are subject to only limited cuts. That means that programs vulnerable to cuts would be hit hard. They would include many initiatives in which the government is building for the future. Education, public housing, science and highway construction all would be affected. ``You'd find entire agencies firing half their staffs,'' said Stanley Collender, who follows the budget for the accounting firm Price Waterhouse.

DOC.HEAD: TV Debates May Decide Close Demo Race; Wilson Awaits November
DOC.TEXT: Two California Democrats battling for their party's gubernatorial nomination have been trading the lead almost as often as pollsters can crank out new numbers. The race between former San Francisco Mayor Dianne Feinstein and state Attorney General John Van de Kamp may well be decided by two one-hour debates set for statewide broadcast on Sunday and one week later. With less than one month to go before the state's June 5 primary, the candidates have had few face-to-face encounters and the campaign largely has been a fund-raising fight and a battle of television ads. ``These campaigns have become a black box,'' said Darry Sragow, Feinstein's campaign manager. ``On one side you put in dollar bills, and on the other side you run out video tape.'' Total spending for the governor's race is expected to reach $18 million to $20 million by November. The Democratic contest has been marked by sharp shifts in public opinion. Feinstein was well ahead of Van de Kamp in early polls, but the next round of surveys showed her lagging behind by a seemingly insurmountable double-digit deficit. Next, a million-dollar media blitz that extolled Feinstein's performance as mayor of San Francisco and cast her as a take-charge executive moved her from 18 percentage points behind Van de Kamp to 19 ahead in six weeks. That heavy lead soon evaporated, fueled by Van de Kamp ads attacking Feinstein's mayoral record. But a Los Angeles Times poll released in early May had her bouncing back with a 13-point lead, 37 percent to 24 percent over Van de Kamp. The undecided vote was even higher, at 38 percent. On the Republican side, low-key, low-profile Pete Wilson has no major opposition and is steadily raising money for the November general election. When Feinstein was trailing in the polls, Wilson went out of his way to bolster her candidacy in hopes of eroding Van de Kamp's support. But as Feinstein's campaign gained momentum, Wilson largely abandoned that tactic. Feinstein has crisscrossed the state in recent months, hoping to overcome her earlier lack of personal contact with Democrats outside her San Francisco home base. Her unabashed support for the death penalty and her vocal anti-drug stand have won backing from moderate and conservative Democrats. Van de Kamp, however, received the official endorsement of the state Democratic Party and has the support of other grassroots Democratic groups and organized labor. Van de Kamp has built his campaign on ethics, the environment and crime, pushing ballot initiatives on each subject in hopes they will generate popular support for his candidacy. Feinstein is the first woman to make a serious bid for the California governorship. But it is Van de Kamp, who describes himself as ``the best feminist in this race,'' who has received the most backing from women's rights activists. A $1.3 million infusion into Feinstein's campaign from her wealthy husband, real estate magnate Richard Blum, has kept her drive alive and financed her television campaign. Van de Kamp, with perhaps double Feinstein's money, has received help from Democratic stars including San Francisco Mayor Art Agnos, Feinstein's bitterly critical successor. Wilson is likely to raise the most money before November, probably $10 million or more, with substantial help from out-of-state sources. President Bush has headlined two Wilson fund-raisers and reportedly plans to attend at least two more. Republicans consider a Wilson victory pivotal to protecting GOP interests in next year's reapportionment battle. The redrawing of political boundaries and the shifts in population are expected to boost California's congressional delegation by as many as seven members.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Mickey Rourke has joined his girlfriend, Carre Otis, his co-star in the steamy ``Wild Orchid,'' in suing the film's producers for releasing nude pictures to Playboy. The photos depict the couple's torrid sex scene. The lawsuit filed Tuesday alleges the producers did not get Rourke's approval before releasing the photos ``for use in tawdry sex pictorials for financial gain and in order to obtain publicity for the film.'' The lawsuit, which seeks unspecified damages, said the photos have hurt Rourke's reputation in the industry. Nude photos taken during filming of ``Wild Orchid'' appear in the June issue of Playboy and the April edition of the German magazine Kino. The lawsuit names Kruger-Brent Group Inc., Brazil Star Films, Vision P.D.G. and Vision International. Vision International chairman Mark Damon was unavailable for comment, his secretary said. Miss Otis filed a similar lawsuit last week.

Caroline Kennedy Schlossberg has given birth to her second child, a 7-pound, 10-ounce girl. Tatiana Celia Kennedy Schlossberg was born Saturday at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center, Nancy Tuckerman, a spokeswoman for Ms. Schlossberg, said Wednesday. The child and Ms. Schlossberg, the 32-year-old daughter of President Kennedy and Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis, are at home and doing well, the spokeswoman said. The child's first name is for Tatiana Grossman, founder of Universal Limited Art Editions. Ms. Schlossberg's husband, Edwin, worked with Grossman and admired her, Tuckerman said. Celia is for Schlossberg's grandmother, she said. The couple's other daughter, Rose Kennedy Schlossberg, will be 2 in June.

Film director David Lynch has a hit with the TV series ``Twin Peaks,'' but he's no fan of the small screen. ``I hate the quality of video. I hate the small screen, I hate the lousy sound and I wish it were different,'' Lynch said in this week's Entertainment Weekly magazine. Lynch, director of ``Blue Velvet,'' likens seeing his movies on video to looking at a bad reproduction of a painting. ``People say, `I saw your film. I saw it on video.' But the truth is, they didn't see the film,'' he said. As the public gravitates more and more toward videocassettes for movie viewing, directors are also losing control over how their movies are watched, he said. Viewers fast-forward, pause and rewind during viewing. ``It's a joke,'' said Lynch.

``Knight Rider'' David Hasselhoff and his wife are the parents of a girl. Pamela Bach, a 27-year-old actress, gave birth to the 5-pound baby by Caesarean section Saturday, spokeswoman Jonni Hartman said Wednesday. Hasselhoff, 37, drove a talking car on ``Knight Rider'' and is cruising Malibu beaches as a lifeguard on the TV series ``Baywatch.''

Luther Campbell of the rap group 2 Live Crew cannot use the stage name Luke Skyywalker until a trademark infringement lawsuit filed by the makers of the ``Star Wars'' movies is resolved. U.S. District Judge James Ideman issued the ruling Wednesday. Lucasfilm has filed a $300 million lawsuit alleging the singer, known for his profanity-laced lyrics, had soiled ``Star Wars'' hero Luke Skywalker's ``highly moral, wholesome aspect.'' That's Skywalker with one ``y.'' Lucasfilm lawyer Charles Shephard said a trial in the case is at least six months away. Campbell, 29, is the leader of 2 Live Crew, whose album ``As Nasty as They Wanna Be'' has sold more than 1.2 million copies.

Brigitte Bardot went on national television and used graphic film footage to condemn trafficking in wild animals. Miss Bardot, 55, was the host of Wednesday night's ``SOS Animal Trafficking,'' the latest in a series on animal abuse. Other programs have targeted vivisection, the ivory trade and the slaughter of elephants. The sex symbol-turned-animal rights activist said public reaction to her programs has been overwhelmingly positive. ``Hunters have sent me their hunting licenses, tourists have burned their ivory bracelets, doctors support me in my fight against vivisection, and the sale of horse meat in France has dropped by 30 percent,'' she said.

Andy Rooney, suspended by CBS for three weeks after being quoted as making remarks offensive to blacks and homosexuals, says special interest groups are squelching debate on television and in politics. The ``60 Minutes'' humorist said the United States has become a nation ``that doesn't say what it thinks about so many things'' for fear of those groups. In a speech to 1,000 people at a Constitutional Rights Foundation dinner Monday, he said, ``There are organized minorities for almost every cause, and politicians, along with network executives, are scared to death of them.''

DOC.HEAD: Veteran Diplomat Displaces First Choice for Managua Post
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration is expected to name career diplomat Harry Shlaudeman as the first U.S. ambassador to Nicaragua in almost two years, a U.S. official says. The administration had planned to send another career diplomat, Melissa Wells, to Managua but had a change of heart after concluding she might face a prolonged Senate confirmation fight because she has been a target of conservatives. The administration is eager to have an ambassador in Managua quickly because of the delicate political situation there now that U.S.-backed President Violeta Chamorro has taken over after almost 11 years of rule by the leftist Sandinista party. Mrs. Chamorro faces the demanding challenges of reviving Nicaragua's bankrupt economy and achieving national reconciliation after long years of warfare. The United States has had no ambassador to Nicaragua since July 1988. At the time, the Sandinista government expelled Ambassador Richard Melton and seven others at the embassy on grounds they were interfering in the country's internal affairs. The Reagan administration retaliated by expelling eight Nicaraguan envoys in Washington, including Ambassador Carlos Tunnermann. Shlaudeman, who has served as ambassador to Argentina, Peru, Brazil and Venezuela, is a premier State Department specialist on Latin America and is expected to win easy Senate confirmation. He retired from the foreign service a year ago but was called back to duty last fall to serve as a State Department liaison with the Nicaraguan Contra rebels. Shlaudeman, who will turn 64 next week, was approached by a senior State Department official weeks ago about going to Managua but said he was not interested. He told intimates he would agree to go only if asked personally by President Bush. When Bush telephoned him earlier this week, Shlaudeman agreed to the appointment, the U.S. official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said Wednesday. In addition to his ambassadorial posts, Shlaudeman was the top Latin America aide to President Ford in the mid-1970s and a diplomatic trouble-shooter in Central America under President Reagan. The U.S. official said Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., and several of his conservative allies would not assure the administration that they would not delay Wells' nomination. When Wells was nominated to be ambassador to Mozambique in late 1986, Helms and his colleagues blocked her appointment for 11 months. They took the action as a means of expressing opposition to the Reagan administration's friendship toward Mozambique's Marxist government.

DOC.HEAD: Trio to Attempt Non-Stop Balloon Trip Around World
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. airline pilot, a British tycoon and a Soviet cosmonaut hope to be the first adventurers to circle the globe non-stop in a balloon. ``Only three years ago, such a trip as this would have been considered unthinkable,'' co-captain Richard Branson of the United Kingdom said Wednesday at a news conference announcing the attempt. In the past, the Soviet Union refused to allow a balloon into its airspace, said project leader and captain Larry Newman of Scottsdale, Ariz. But the Soviet space agency Glavkosmos last year agreed to permit the expedition and even offered cosmonaut Vladimir Dzhanibekov as a partner, Newman said. Newman, an America West pilot, made the first successful trans-Atlantic balloon flight in 1978 and holds the world distance record for a balloon, 5,209 miles across the Pacific in 1981. Branson crossed the Atlantic in a hot-air balloon in 1987. Dzhanibekov, a pilot, is chief of Glavkosmos' cosmonaut training department and has been in space five times. The helium balloon will take off from Loral Airdock in Akron, Ohio, sometime between November and February, whenever weather conditions are best. Newman called the balloon, essentially a giant plastic bag whose design has not been unveiled, ``our secret weapon.'' It was conceived by Burt Rutan of Scaled Composites Inc., who also designed the Voyager aircraft that made the first non-stop flight around the world without refueling. Newman, Branson and Dzhanibekov will spend 14 to 25 days at an altitude of at least 35,000 feet in the balloon's 24-by-10-foot pressurized capsule. The 1,200-pound fiberglass craft, insulated with styrofoam to protect the crew from temperatures that can reach 60 below zero, will have no steering capability, leaving the crew at the mercy of the winds. ``The vagaries of the wind are essentially our engineer,'' Newman said. The three expect to be carried at 75 mph to 200 mph across the Atlantic, central Europe, the Soviet Union, north of the Himalayas, across the Pacific and back to the United States. They hope to land ``anywhere east of the longitudinal line of Akron,'' Newman said. Branson estimated the endeavor would cost ``in the hundreds of thousands of dollars,'' primarily financed by his Virgin Atlantic Airways. NASA will supply navigational and communications equipment, and the crew will conduct experiments for the agency to measure wind shears and examine the stratospheric ozone. The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration will provide advisories on weather conditions, maps and graphs and a search-and-rescue beacon, said NOAA official Gary Castle. In the early 1980s, Maxie Anderson of Albuquerque, N.M., and Don Ida of Boulder, Colo., made three unsuccessful attempts to circle the world in a helium balloon, taking a route south of the U.S.S.R. Newman, however, considers his own effort the first ``practical'' attempt. ``In my mind, this flight couldn't have been made with any other balloon that you've ever seen before,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Poverty No Excuse for Being Out of Shape, President Says
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Tuesday correct in 3rd graf, `I think'
DOC.TEXT: President Bush says being poor is no excuse for being out of shape. ``Even someone who is not having it so good can stay physically fit,'' Bush said in a session with health and fitness writers at the White House. ``I think that anybody can participate in certain kinds of fitness,'' said Bush, who gave the interview on Tuesday as part of his efforts to promote National Fitness Month. ``Yes, there's differences,'' he acknowledged. ``Some can afford snappy LifeCycles or Stairmasters and afford to go to health clubs, and plenty of people can't. ``But the concept of an individual doing some kind of athletics or some kind of calisthenics to stay fit transcends economic lines, it seems to me,'' Bush told reporters from the Detroit Free Press and other newspapers and magazines. Bush said he and his fitness czar, actor-bodybuilder Arnold Schwarzenegger, want to debunk the notion that only the fiscally fit have the time or means to worry about exercise. The president, who turns 66 next month, has an array of expensive exercise equipment for his personal use a few steps from the Oval Office, not to mention a horseshoe pit, heated pool and tennis court nearby. Bush captained the baseball team at Yale and has played tennis and golf all his life. He still jogs three times a week for two miles at a ``slowpoke'' 9{-minute pace. The 6-foot-2 president said he is about five pounds overweight. Bush credits all this exercise with helping him keep up a daily 7 a.m.-to-6 p.m. schedule in the Oval Office, plus ``two or three other events'' at home in the evenings. ``I don't believe I could do that if I weren't physically fit,'' he told interviewers. ``People think, `What's this Ivy League elitist doing playing horseshoes? This is some put-on deal,''' said Bush. ``But now they know I like it and, as Arnold can attest, I'm reasonably good.'' Bush acknowledged he came from a privileged background where competitive sports were part of growing up. ``I'm not suggesting that everybody's had it so good,'' he said. ``But I am suggesting that an example of an athletic presidency can set a tone for this concept of fitness that Arnold and I are working together on.'' The writers pressed the president on what he planned to do for Americans who cannot afford to see a doctor. An estimated 30 million Americans, most in working poor families, have no health insurance. Bush said Health and Human Services Secretary Louis Sullivan is searching for ways ``to get control of costs. And if we can do that, I think that will expand services.'' Asked if health care should be a basic right for all citizens, he said: ``I would think so, yes. But that doesn't mean that I think the federal government is the only way to do it.'' ``All levels of government'' must be involved, plus charitable care and ``neighbor helping neighbor,'' Bush said.

DOC.HEAD: EPA Studies Tobacco As Indoor Pollutant
DOC.TEXT: The federal government is looking at tobacco smoke as an indoor pollutant in a draft assessment that is becoming the focus of a debate over whether ``passive smoking'' is harmful to your health. Anti-smoking activists say the Environmental Protection Agency's work could encourage tighter restrictions on smoking, while tobacco industry spokesmen said a scientific review would show there is no evidence that non-smokers are being hurt. The EPA said Wednesday it is drawing up a policy guide to workplace smoking restrictions and an assessment of the cancer risk to non-smokers exposed to cigarette smoke. Agency spokesman Dave Ryan said he could not discuss the content of the draft until it is submitted to an independent science advisory board, probably later this month. But EPA sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the draft assessment includes a statement that ``passive smoking'' is a known carcinogen, responsible for more than 3,000 cases of lung cancer among non-smokers each year. The draft conclusions were reported first in Wednesday's Los Angeles Times. In a statement, the EPA said its risk assessment will classify ETS _ the smoke to which non-smokers are exposed at work and elsewhere _ ``according to the agency's carcinogen assessment guidelines.'' It said the risk assessment was based on 24 studies of the association between passive smoking and lung cancer. The separate policy guide ``will describe the technical basis for smoking restrictions as well as the technical and policy options for mitigating exposures'' to tobacco smoke, the agency said. The EPA's work usually involves regulating pollutants discharged outdoors by smokestacks or effluent pipes. The agency said the assessment of passive smoking's dangers is being carried out under the authority of the Radon Gas and Indoor Air Quality Research Act of 1986. John Banzhaf, executive director of Action on Smoking OR Health, an anti-smoking group, said the report could encourage the idea that the EPA should be more involved in controlling indoor pollutants. His group is suing another arm of the federal government, the Occupational Safety and Health Administration, to force it to ban smoking in workplaces nationwide or restrict it to separately ventilated areas. ``I think there's going to be a tremendous breakthrough when the average person realizes that tobacco smoke can kill him or his loved one,'' Banzhaf said. ``What they will report is that tobacco smoke is more dangerous than all of the other pollutants we regulate put together,'' he said. ``Tobacco smoke is far more dangerous than radon, it is far more dangerous than lead in gasoline, it is far more dangerous than asbestos.'' John R. Nelson, vice president of corporate affairs for Philip Morris U.S.A., said most of the studies the EPA is relying on examined very small groups of people, usually in the home rather than the workplace. He said they have found no evidence that tobacco smoke is causing lung cancer among American non-smokers. ``Our interest in this process is that the EPA consider all the scientific information out there,'' Nelson said. ``If they do that, they'll be compelled to conclude the evidence is not there to conclude that environmental tobacco smoke is a scientifically significant risk to nonsmokers.'' He said the largest study, for a Ph.D. dissertation at Yale University by Dr. Luis Varela, found that non-smokers exposed to tobacco smoke in the workplace or from their spouses at home had no statistically significant risk of lung cancer. The Varela study also found that the more smokers were exposed to smoke in social situations, the lower their risk of developing lung cancer, Nelson said. The EPA said in its statement that it was aware of the Varela study and was seeking more information about it.

DOC.HEAD: Hungarian Party Asks for Withdrawal from Warsaw Pact
DOC.TEXT: The country's second-largest political party has asked Parliament to declare its intention to leave the Warsaw Pact and become a neutral nation. The proposal made Wednesday by the League of Free Democrats advocates making it clear that Hungary does not wish to belong to either the Warsaw Pact or NATO. It is similar to a 1956 government statement that annulled Hungary's membership in the Soviet-led military alliance and prompted the Soviet invasion that crushed a nationalist uprising. Deputy Parliament Speaker Matyas Szueroes said the proposal would be discussed during the next session of the new Parliament, which was chosen in March and April in the country's first free elections in four decades. The liberal Free Democrats, led by former dissidents, won 94 of Parliament's 394 seats in the balloting. The largest party, the center-right Hungarian Democratic Forum, won 165 seats and is trying to form a coalition government with smaller, traditional parties. The Socialist Party, which is dominated by former members of the long-ruling Communist Party, won 33 seats. The Free Democrats have not been approached as coalition partners and it is unclear if a new government would adopt their proposal. The party campaigned on a platform of swift transfer to a free market economy, while the Democratic Forum emphasized the need to avoid social disruption and generally emphasizes conservative, traditional values. Hungary's leadership has until now pledged to remain in the Soviet-led alliance, although individual leaders have repeatedly suggested the country could one day become neutral. The Free Democrats proposed the new move on the basis of the 1956 statement. The proposal was presented by Miklos Vasarhelyi, an associate of Imre Nagy, the leader of the 1956 uprising. Vasarhelyi was imprisoned following the uprising. Nagy was executed after a show trial. Three days after Hungary declared its withdrawal from the Warsaw Pact, Soviet troops and tanks rolled into Budapest. They have since remained, though Hungary has negotiated the complete withdrawal of Soviet troops from its territory by the middle of next year. The new Parliament has asked to re-negotiate the accord to provide for a quicker withdrawal. A special subcommittee of the foreign relations committee in Parliament is examining the issue. Vasarhelyi said the proposal does not call for Hungary's immediate withdrawal from the Warsaw Pact but opens negotiations on the topic with Moscow. But he said that if the proposal is adopted, Hungary should suspend all activity in the East bloc alliance and forbid Warsaw Pact exercises on its soil. The Warsaw Pact was established in 1955 and includes the Soviet Union, East Germany, Poland, Czechslovakia, Hungary, Romania and Bulgaria. The alliance's future is uncertain now that most of its members have virtually broken free of Soviet domination.

DOC.HEAD: Minnesota Senator Faces New Ethics Charges
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Dave Durenberger faces new ethics charges that he abused his office and misused Senate money in a ``pattern of improper conduct'' involving his Minneapolis condominium. The Senate Ethics Committee on Wednesday widened its case against the Minnesota Republican by finding ``substantial credible evidence'' of financial wrongdoing, misrepresentations to the Senate and improper administration of his blind trust. The latest allegations stem from Senate expense payments that Durenberger claimed for renting the residence that he partly owned for several years. Durenberger may have violated federal law as well as Senate rules, the committee said. The latest charges were added to an earlier list of allegations that will be the subject of trial-like committee hearings scheduled to begin June 12. The committee last February charged Durenberger with six possible rules violations stemming from a $100,000 book promotion deal and acceptance of free limousine service for personal travel. The new allegations are the first mention in the case of Durenberger's blind trust, which had been approved by the Ethics Committee in February 1986. Durenberger's chief of staff, Bert McKasy, said the trust held the senator's interest in the condominium partnership. ``The question, as we understand it, is whether the trustee of a trust, who is also the senator's attorney, and the senator, should have discussed the sale of the condominium and related matters,'' McKasy said. The committee listed three other possible violations: _Submitting misleading travel reimbursement vouchers to the Senate. _Misrepresenting the ownership of the condominium. _Backdating real estate transactions and other documents through which Durenberger transferred the property to a partnership in 1984. The panel found ``substantial cause'' to conclude that Durenberger ``may have abused his United States Senate Office and misused United States Senate funds through a pattern of improper conduct which has brought discredit upon the United States Senate.'' ``This is the logical next step in the inquiry,'' said Durenberger's press secretary, Lois West. ``It's what we expected would happen.'' Durenberger has denied any wrongdoing in the condominium deal, although he admitted he was trying to cut the expense of maintaining homes in both the Washington area and Minnesota. Durenberger transferred the condominium to a partnership in which he was a partner in 1984 and backdated papers to obtain reimbursement for staying there in 1983, according to documents he provided the Senate Rules Committee. He sold the property to a company owned by his former campaign manager in 1987 but continued to get reimbursed for staying there until late last year. Durenberger repaid the Senate $11,005 last January after the rules committee decided he was not entitled to expenses incurred when he stayed at the condominium during official congressional recesses. He also used the condominium when he returned to Minnesota on weekends and at other times when the Senate was in session. Durenberger's aides claim the backdating was proper since the senator had made the agreement for the partnership at that time. Durenberger said last week that he had been negotiating informally with the ethics committee and that the hearing date served as a deadline for reaching a settlement. If he negotiated a plea agreement by then, the hearings would be unnecessary. McKasy said ``the committee's statement makes clear that all matters will be resolved together in the near future.'' Durenberger does not face re-election until 1994, but polls indicate he has lost significant support in Minnesota because of the year-old ethics investigation. Four of the six counts approved against Durenberger on Feb. 22 result from an arrangement he had with a publisher to promote two books he had written. A fifth count charged Durenberger with accepting gifts of limousine service for personal trips in the Boston area. The sixth count alleged that Durenberger's actions reflected poorly on the Senate.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Ready to Ease Ban on Political Activities by Bureaucrats
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Senate resumes debate 10 a.m. EDT; lead prospects uncertain.
DOC.TEXT: The Senate is moving toward passing a bill to loosen a ban on political campaigning by federal employees, as Republican opponents bowed to repeated defeats on amendments and agreed to allow a final vote. Under an agreement reached late Wednesday between the two parties' leaders _ Democrat George Mitchell of Maine and Republican Bob Dole of Kansas _ the Senate would vote on a wholesale revision of the 1939 Hatch Act before recessing tonight. Before the final vote, minority Republicans will have the opportunity to offer nine more amendments, including a measure by Dole to continue the current restrictions on employees in intelligence agencies, the Justice Department, the Internal Revenue Service and the Federal Election Commission. A similar amendment by Dole was defeated on a 51-46 vote Tuesday. Despite a veto threat by President Bush, the bill was overwhelmingly approved by the House a year ago. And in several test votes this week and last, several Republican senators joined Democrats in defeating amendments by Dole and other GOP leaders aimed at retaining most of the current restrictions. Some 2.9 million federal civil service and postal workers are now prohibited entirely from working in campaigns, soliciting contributions and holding office in the political parties or attending their state and national conventions as delegates. Even holding a campaign placard at a rally or voting in local caucuses on party nominations is a Hatch Act violation, for which a federal employee can be suspended from his or her job. The union-endorsed bill would still prohibit federal workers from engaging in any political activities while on the job and continue to bar them from running for public office or soliciting campaign contributions from the public. But they could start holding office in local, state and national political organizations and for the first time solicit campaign funds from the co-workers on behalf of candidates or federal employee union political action committees. Dole called the bill a ``pot of gold'' for the Democrats because they receive, on average, about 90 percent of the millions of dollars in PAC contributions already raised by postal and federal employee unions. Democrats have repeatedly denied an ulterior motive, saying they only want to give federal workers ``the same political rights that people in Eastern Europe are beginning to exert.'' Bush's senior advisers have said they would urge him to veto any change in the law as ``undermining the integrity and independence of the traditionally non-partisan civil service.'' The Senate has spent more than a week on the legislation, with Democrats mustering between a dozen and 17 Republican votes on each of the challenging amendments by GOP leaders. George Gould, a lobbyist for the National Association of Letter Carriers, called the stream of amendments an attempt by GOP leaders to ``slow the process to give the White House time to try to peel away votes.'' Republican Whip Alan Simpson of Wyoming admitted his party lacked the 40 votes needed to maintain a filibuster against the bill in the 100-member Senate. He said the real test will come later when the White House asks Republican leaders to scrape together the 34 votes needed to sustain a veto by Bush. In Bush's first 16 months in office, congressional Democrats have been unable in 10 attempts to override any of his vetoes.

DOC.HEAD: Man Covicted of Poisoning Historic Tree
DOC.TEXT: An ex-convict was convicted of poisoning the historic Treaty Oak with a powerful herbicide in an alleged occult ritual at the centuries-old tree and could get up to life in prison. Paul Stedman Cullen Jr., 46, faces five to 99 years in prison following his conviction by a jury Wednesday of criminal mischief. His sentencing hearing was to begin today. Cullen, jailed since his arrest last June, could receive a harsh sentence because of a previous burglary conviction and problems while on probation. Cullen refused to comment as he was led from court, but his father insisted his son had done no harm to the 60-foot oak discovered poisoned a year ago. ``They convicted an innocent man,'' said the elder Cullen. Legend has it that Texas patriarch Stephen F. Austin and Indians signed a treaty in the 1820s under the giant oak estimated to be at least 500 years old. The tree is a city landmark, and people have gotten married under its boughs. The tree shed six sets of leaves in as many months after it was poisoned with Velpar, and half the tree's crown is bare. Residents put get-well cards under the tree and lit candles for its recovery. Prosecutors said Cullen poisoned the tree in a ritual to either end his affection for his drug counselor or to protect her from harm. Defense lawyers Terry Kirk described the ex-convict as a ``loser'' with little self-esteem who boasted falsely about poisoning the tree to impress an acquaintance, Cindy Blaco. Kirk said Ms. Blaco became the prosecution's key witness to claim some $11,000 in rewards. Ms. Blaco testified that during February 1989 _ when experts believe the tree was poisoned _ Cullen had several books on witchcraft and the occult. She said she saw two containers of Velpar in the back of Cullen's truck. Traces of the herbicide also were found in the truck by police after Cullen's arrest. More than $100,000 has been donated to save the tree. Velpar-contaminated dirt has been removed from around its roots, the tree has been doused with spring water and elaborate screens were built to shade it.

DOC.HEAD: Barges Clearing Off Missouri River After Court Ruling
With PM-Flood Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Shipping companies scrambled to get barges off the Missouri River after a federal judge, acting to protect fishermen, reduced the amount of water that may be released from a reservoir upstream. ``We're going to lose a lot of money _ several hundred thousand dollars,'' said Roger Blaske, co-owner of Blaske Marine Inc. in Alton, Ill. His company was trying to get barges moved downstream from the Omaha, Neb., area Wednesday for fear they will be marooned by falling water. He said his company would try to get business on other rivers, including the Mississippi. U.S. District Judge Patrick Conmy's ruling, issued Wednesday in Bismarck, N.D., will keep the depth of South Dakota's Lake Oahe steady until June 1, when the reservoir's walleye hatch will have ended. South Dakota officials contended the hatch would have been destroyed if the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers had gone ahead with plans to lower the reservoir 3 feet this month, and the judge agreed there would be irreparable harm. Officials in South Dakota, North Dakota and Montana praised the ruling, saying it would save a vital fishing industry. But the downstream states of Nebraska, Iowa and Missouri said drinking water, wildlife and power plants would suffer, in addition to shipping companies. A spokesman for Nebraska Gov. Kay Orr called the decision ``very disturbing news,'' and the Army Corps of Engineers will appeal the ruling. But South Dakota Gov. George Mickelson said the three states, including his, already have won. Even an expedited appeal is likely to take a few weeks, Mickelson said. By then, ``we will have accomplished most of what we set out to do,'' he said. The river's main shipping channel runs 730 miles from Sioux City, Iowa, to St. Louis. Because of the ruling, the river was expected to begin dropping at Sioux City by midday today, at Omaha by May 11 and at Kansas City by May 14, said corps spokesman John Ferrell. Chet Worm, chief of the corps' reservoir regulation section, said the reduction would probably drop the river level by about 3{ feet at Sioux City and by about 3 feet at Omaha. Kansas City likely would see a drop of 2 feet. ``It couldn't come at a worse time,'' said Marion Conover, fisheries management supervisor for the Iowa Department of Natural Resources. He said most of the fish that build nests to lay their eggs spawn in May and early June. Don Cummings, wildlife management supervisor for the same agency, said the lower water would hurt waterfowl, too. ``We did see some little ducklings and geese along the river,'' he said. ``The lower water is going to leave them high and dry.'' Once the river is lowered, the corps may not be able to raise it again because the water could flood the nests of protected birds, Worm said. In Sioux City, water systems supervisor Rick Mach said the lower water would affect the alluvial wells where the city gets its water. The city has had to ration water the last two summers because of drought. ``If we are going to have a low Missouri River, we will have to consider water rationing at a sooner time,'' Mach said. Utility officials in Nebraska and Iowa said the lower water could cause problems for power plants, if they extend beyond June 1. Many plants draw in river water for cooling. ``It's entirely possible there would be some forced outages,'' said Omaha Public Power District spokesman Mark Gautier.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Opposes International CFC Fund
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration is opposing a special $100 million international fund to help poor nations curb their use of ozone-depleting chemicals, saying such assistance should be made through existing channels. ``The United States agrees that financial assistance should be made available to help developing countries phase out production of CFCs (chloroflurocarbons),'' White House deputy press secretary Roman Popadiuk said Wednesday in a prepared statement. ``However, we believe it is more sensible to use existing institutions and existing financial mechanisms already established by the World Bank,'' Popadiuk said. A World Bank spokesman said Wednesday that the institution has insufficient resources to handle the millions of dollars needed for such a project. ``The spirit of (former Interior Secretary) James Watt has been reincarnated in the bodies of (White House chief of staff) John Sununu and (budget director) Richard Darman, the Tweedledum and Tweedledee of environmentalism in the 1990s,'' said Sen. Joseph Lieberman, D-Conn. Sen. Claiborne Pell, D-R.I., said, ``It is incredible to me that the Bush administration would be unwilling to come up with the very modest sums involved in the transition fund.'' Sen. Al Gore, D-Tenn., began circulating a letter to the president among colleagues asking for a meeting with the administration on the decision. The establishment of such a fund was to be proposed at an ongoing CFC conference in Geneva, which U.S. representatives are attending, The Washington Post reported. The European-initiated proposal wants money to help Third World countries convert to alternative chemicals and identify ways to replace CFCs, the Post said. Such a fund would be administered by an international lending authority, such as the World Bank, according to the newspaper. CFCs are used widely for refrigeration and aerosol products, as well as some production. Scientists say CFC emissions ares depleting the ozone layer that protects the Earth from harmful ultraviolet rays. The United States has signed a treaty calling for cutting CFCs in half by the end of the century.

DOC.HEAD: Hostage Release Captures Public Attention
DOC.TEXT: The American public is more interested in the release of U.S. hostages held in the Middle East than any other news story so far this year, according to a new survey. Forty-six percent of those surveyed said they paid close attention to the April release of Robert Polhill and Frank Reed, according to the Times Mirror News Interest Index issued today. The index periodically measures public interest and awareness of the news. The response marked the first time in 1990 that more than one-third of the public had focused intense interest on an individual news event, the survey said. Political change in Eastern and Central Europe earlier had been the most consistently watched story, generating interest among about 30 percent of respondents since September, the survey found. The second most popular story in April was the celebration of Earth Day, which 31 percent of respondents said they watched closely. Stories about the Lithuanian independence movement interested 27 percent of those surveyed, slightly less than 29 percent the previous month Twenty-four percent of respondents said they closely followed news of the Hubble Space Telescope and of difficulties in taking the 1990 census, and 18 percent were interested in stories about renewed inflation and rising interest rates. The civil war in Cambodia drew the least attention among readers, generating interest from 4 percent of respondents. May Day protests in Moscow interested just 9 percent, the survey said. The Times Mirror News Interest Index is based on a telephone survey of 1,218 adults 18 or older, conducted May 3-7 under the direction of the Princeton Survey Research Associates. The margin of error is plus or minus 3 percentage points.

DOC.HEAD: Thornburgh Asks Stiffer Penalties for Cross Burnings
DOC.TEXT: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh says he has asked Congress to stiffen criminal penalties for cross burnings and other forms of racial harassment that do not result in personal injuries. The proposed amendments to the 1968 Civil Rights Act would make cross burnings a felony under federal law punishable by a five-year prison sentence and a fine up to $250,000. The offense is now a misdemeanor that carries a maximum one-year sentence and a $100,000 fine. Misdemeanor penalties would be retained to allow prosecutors to bring lesser charges in appropriate cases, the department said in a letter to Congress. The harsher penalties are proposed for what Thornburgh called ``particularly egregious cases _ those where firearms are used or fire or threats of fire, including cross burnings, are employed.'' Thornburgh's statement Wednesday cited a case in which people who burned down a home rented by a black family were prosecuted for a misdemeanor because there were no injuries.
DOC.HEAD: FDA Putting Stronger Warnings On Growth Drug
DOC.TEXT: The Food and Drug Administration says it will strengthen warnings about a possible risk of leukemia for children taking a growth-stimulating drug. Jeremy Rifkin, president of the Foundation on Economic Trends, asked the FDA in February to ban the sale of human growth hormone, or HGH, pending further study to determine whether it increases the risk of leukemia. Studies in Japan, Europe and the United States suggest that the risk of getting leukemia within four years after completing HGH treatment is two to three times greater than for children who have not received HGH, he said. FDA spokeswoman Faye Peterson said Wednesday the agency is aware of the studies. She said the agency has not yet responded to Rifkin's petition but added that FDA officials ``are going to adjust the labeling to make the wording stronger (on a possible leukemia risk). ``But we're not going to take any action on the drug,'' she said. ``There's not enough evidence to do anything that will disturb its use.'' The wording of the warning has not been worked out, she added. The genetically-engineered HGH is sold by Genentech Inc. under the trade name Protropin and Eli Lilly under the trade name Humatrope.
DOC.HEAD: More Americans Eligible to Vote
DOC.TEXT: The number of Americans old enough to vote this fall is up more than 3.6 million from two years ago, but the odds are fewer will actually turn out. The nation's voting-age population will climb to 186,382,000 by November's election, the Census Bureau projected on Wednesday. That's up from about 182.7 million two years ago, the bureau said. But the absence of a presidential contest this year means there will probably be less public interest and so a lower turnout. An estimated 50.1 percent of voting-age Americans voted for president in the 1988 general election. In 1986, the last congressional election year without a presidential vote, only 33.4 percent voted. The new Census report shows that voters in the 25-to-44 age group will make up 43.9 percent of eligible voters, up from 43.5 percent two years ago and 38.5 percent in 1980. Voters aged 18-to-24 will be only 13.8 percent of those eligible this fall, down from 14.5 percent in 1988 and 18.4 percent in 1980. Those aged 45 to 64, will be 25.2 percent of voters, down from 25.3 percent in 1988 and 27.3 percent in 1980. But voters aged 65 and over will be 17 percent, an increase from 16.7 percent two years ago and 15.7 percent in 1980. Women will outnumber men in the voting age population by 97.1 million to 89.2 million, the report shows. The voting-age population will include 21.1 million blacks and 6.1 million persons of other races, such as Asians, Pacific islanders and American Indians.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Up In Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 30,980.26, up 34.65 points, or 0.11 percent on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: British Spy Told Stalin of Nazi Attempt to Make Peace with Britain
DOC.TEXT: Kim Philby, the famed Soviet mole in British intelligence, told Soviet authorities about Rudolf Hess's secret mission to Britain to arrange a separate peace three days after it happened, Tass reported. The May 1941 mission came a month before Nazi Germany attacked the Soviet Union, and prosecutors at the Nuremberg war crimes trial said the Germans, through Hess, were seeking peace with Britain so they could concentrate their efforts against the Soviets. ``It would have been possible to save hundreds of thousands, or even millions, of human lives, if Stalin had trusted Soviet intelligence officers' reports about Nazi Germany's preparations for an attack on the Soviet Union,'' Tass, the official Soviet news agency, said Wednesday. Tass counted Philby among the Soviet agents. The British intelligence officer spied for the Soviets for 30 years. Soviet secret archives on the flight of Hess, Adolf Hitler's deputy, will be declassified in the next few days, the news agency said. It will include materials sent by Philby, Tass said. Hess flew to England in a Messerschmitt fighter plane on May 10, 1941 to try to arrange a peace treaty. He said he did so without Adolf Hitler's knowledge, but that was never proved. Hess was jailed after his flight. After the war, he was convicted of war crimes and imprisoned until his death in 1987 in Berlin. Tass claimed Philby helped thwart Nazi attempts to conclude a separate peace with the Western allies. Philby also gave Stalin the allies' strategy going into the Potsdam conference in July 1945, where the victors worked out details of the post-war arrangements for Europe, Tass said. It said Philby's reports were responsible for Stalin's cunning smile at the conference, which was noted by a number of journalists who covered it. Tass said British Prime Minister Winston Churchill wrote in his memoirs that he was shaken by the depth of Stalin's perception into British policy in North Africa during the war. ``However, this `perception' was based on precise information received from (British intelligence), where Philby was making a sky-rocketing career,'' Tass said. Philby also used his position in British intelligence to warn Stalin of Nazi plans for an offensive near Kursk in the summer of 1943, Tass said. The warning allowed the Soviets to build up troops in the area before the great battle. Philby had access to intercepted German radio messages and passed them on to the Soviets, allowing Soviet authorities to catch German intelligence agents smuggled into the Soviet Union, Tass said. A film about Philby, one of several Cambridge University graduates who became Soviet spies in the 1930s, is scheduled to be shown on Soviet television Friday. Tass promised it will contain ``many historical sensations'' on the spy, who fled to Moscow in 1963 ahead of British investigators. He died there in 1988. The television film, ``Cambridge Graduate,'' also will show Philby's liaison officer, a Moscow woman named Zoya Voskresenskaya, Tass said.

DOC.HEAD: Singer Becomes Second to Boycott `Saturday' Over Bad Boy Clay
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note contents 2nd graf.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY9
DOC.TEXT: Pop singer Sinead O'Connor became the second entertainer to boycott this weekend's ``Saturday Night Live'' because of guest host Andrew Dice Clay's foul-mouth brand of humor. ``Saturday Night Live'' cast member Nora Dunn announced Monday that she will not go on the air because of the comedian's expletive-laden routines _ which refer to women as ``bitches'' and ``pigs,'' seldom outside of a sexual context. On Wednesday, O'Connor joined the anti-Clay chorus. ``It would be nonsensical of `Saturday Night Live' to expect a woman to perform songs about a woman's experiences after a monologue by Andrew Dice Clay,'' her spokeswoman, Elaine Schock, said in a phone interview from Pelham, N.Y. ``Saturday Night Live'' producer Lorne Michaels said the NBC program will find a new musical guest and the show will go on. And Clay ``has given me his word'' that he will not violate programming standards, Michaels said. MTV banned Clay from its cable network last year after he delivered a monologue laced with lewd poetry and references to fat women and sex. Clay had assured MTV ``repeatedly, that his material would be in line with our programming standards,'' a network official at the time. Dunn, a five-year cast member, applauded O'Connor's boycott as a ``very classy thing to do.'' ``This is not about dirty words. This is about the language of rape. If you took the word `woman' in his routine and replaced it with `Jew,' I guarantee you that person would not be on Saturday Night Live,'' Dunn said. O'Connor's album ``I Do Not Want What I Haven't Got'' is No. 1 on the Billboard pop chart. Her single ``Nothing Compares 2 U,'' written by rock star Prince, also is the No. 1 pop song on Billboard's charts. Schock said the Irish singer watched videos of Dice's routine Wednesday and decided to back out of the show. ``I feel it shows disrespect of women that `Saturday Night Live' expected me to perform on the same show as Andrew Dice Clay,'' O'Connor said through her spokeswoman. Clay, whose act has been called racist and homophobic as well as sexist, called Dunn ``Nora Dunce'' in an interview taped for Wednesday evening on ``Entertainment Tonight.'' ``I think Nora Dunce is a very silly girl,'' he said, ``because I've watched `Saturday Night Live' many times and I've seen her play from hookers to just, like, street tramps and I wouldn't look at that and go, `If that's really her, I wouldn't do the show.' ``I think she's just doing this because I am the hottest comic in the world today. I didn't invent dirty words, I just know how to make 'em rhyme.'' In his act, Clay recites lewd parodies of nursery rhymes. Dunn, reached at her New York home Wednesday, responded, ``He's not too bright, is he? I've never played hookers or streetwalkers.'' Michaels said the defections took him by surprise. ``Suddenly we were getting phone calls and it sort of blindsided us,'' he said in a telephone interview from New York, where rehearsals were under way for Saturday's show. He said Dunn did not talk to him about boycotting the show, but ``if it is about conscience and principles, I have to applaud her for that.''

DOC.HEAD: Radical Students, the Pampered Elite
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: The highly organized radical students who have battled police by the tens of thousands this week are among the elite of South Korea's young, a pampered anti-establishment cadre. As university students, they are the pride and joy of a nation that equates education with success and prosperity. As international symbols of militance, they are a deep embarrassment in a society that values harmony. In Korea's strict authoritarian society, it seems paradoxical that senior government officials often urge students to avoid protest and then treat student protesters with leniency. Perhaps that is because Koreans generally sympathize with student protesters, though without necessarily agreeing with their opinions or tactics. On Wednesday, tens of thousands of students battled riot police in Seoul and 16 other cities to demand the ouster of President Roh Tae-woo. The violence coincided with the inaugural convention of the newly created Democratic Liberal Party. Opponents contend the gigantic new governing party, a merger of three political groups, will lead to dictatorship. The rioting was the most violent in the capital since 1987. Police said they arrested 1,864 people nationwide but released most with warnings. About 150 people, including some 100 police, were injured, they said. Koreans traditionally feel students are the only selfless group in society to fight perceived wrongs. They have no families to support, no jobs to protect. Students as well as many citizens cherish the notion of student uprisings. Three times in this century, student-instigated protests have challenged governments to force change and three times history has treated those battling students as heroes. Virtually all Koreans can recite student deeds in the 1919 uprising against Japanese colonial rule, in the 1960 toppling of the government of President Syngman Rhee and the 1987 protests that opened the door to democratic reforms. Wednesay's protests were the largest and most violent since nationwide anti-government demonstrations nearly three years ago forced authoritarian President Chun Doo-hwan to carry out major democratic reforms and step down. Radical students feel they have an obligation to confront authority, to fight the rich, the powerful and the privileged _ the very group many will join after graduation. Radical students dramatize their country's fever for unification with the communist north, but unlike their elders lack experience to express concern about conflicts in communist and capitalistic ideology. ``Korea is one!'' they shout at rallies. Campuses are adorned with colorful banners two and three stories high that show radical students astride the border between the two Koreas. None of them are old enough to remember the bloody 1950-53 Korean War, launched by North Korea to communize the south, a war in which 5 million Americans served. Some of them say they have never talked to an American. The government says most of the radical students are naive leftists who have been brainwashed by communist North Korean teachings. Some of them, the government has said, may be communist agents. Many Korean students reach college age without ever having discussed politics or ideology. Their middle and high school years are spent slaving over textbooks and rote memorization to pass the all-important college entrance exam. It's with a heady sense of righteousness and indignation that idealistic young radicals enter the political forum. Radicals view the January merger of the ruling party with two opposition groups as a political coup that altered party alliances without an election. They support the overthrow of the government but offer little solid plans on how a new leader could do better. Radicals wear American jeans and sneakers, carry their books in a backpack and look like college students everywhere. They go to some of the best schools in South Korea. The radicals number only about five percent of the roughly 1 million students in college. Other students listen to their rallies, read their newspapers and may agree with some of their thinking but usually do not join the militants in their pitched battles with riot police. Radicals claim Washington makes decisions for a Seoul puppet government. They demand the withdrawal of 43,000 U.S. troops based in South Korea because they say their presence hinders unification talks with North Korea. The radical movement consists of both men and women students and is organized vertically with a direct line of authority. Training retreats are held to indoctrinate recruits. At protests, women collect rocks, wave banners, tend to injuries and sing support songs. Men deployed in platoon fashion hurl firebombs and rocks. The radical student movement lost momentum after President Roh took office in February 1988 in the country's first direct presidential elections in 16 years and promised broad democratic reforms. The smaller numbers forced radicals to become more violent to be noticed. Some began to use homemade explosives. The government downplays the significance of violent protests, but privately worries they could breed discontent among older Koreans, especially laborers who often feel underprivileged and underpaid.
EDITOR`S NOTE: Seoul bureau chief Kelly Tunney has covered the country for two years.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Splits Hunting Rights Between Indians, Non-Indians
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge, in a decision with far-reaching consequences, has ruled northern Wisconsin's ``harvestable natural resources'' should be split 50-50 between Chippewas and non-Indians. The ruling Wednesday by U.S. District Judge Barbara Crabb came in a lawsuit over Chippewa rights under 19th century treaties to hunt deer, but state legal experts say the decision extends to fishing and logging. Lawyers for Wisconsin's estimated 4,000 Chippewas had no immediate comment on the ruling. Tom Maulson, a Chippewa active in treaty issues, said the tribe has supported the idea of sharing resources for years. He said dividing the resources will not unfairly deprive the Chippewa of their rights. ``I bet the tribe will never touch 50 percent,'' he said. ``We say the resource is for everybody. Maybe they'll start to realize that's what we've wanted all along.'' The ruling came in a case that began with the arrest of two Chippewas in 1974 for ice fishing off the reservation. Mrs. Crabb wrote that equal sharing ``is the fairest result, and the inevitable one, whatever analysis is employed.'' She said the Indians' ``needs for a moderate standard of living dictate their right to a full share of the harvest, subject to a ceiling set at 50 percent to prevent the frustration of the non-Indian treaty right.'' Previously Mrs. Crabb had ruled the Chippewa are entitled to 100 percent of the ``safe allowable'' catch of fish, an allowance the Indians had never come close to reaching. State lawyers said the new ruling alters the previous one. ``It's our understanding of this decision that it does not apply only to deer, but that it applies to all natural resources,'' said Wisconsin Attorney General Donald Hanaway. ``It includes fish, it includes fur-bearing animals, white tail deer and timber.'' Under treaties ceding Indian territory to the U.S. government, Wisconsin's Chippewas retain the right to spear fish, hunt and cut timber off the reservation on 23,929 square miles of public land in northern Wisconsin. Since a court affirmed those rights in 1983, the Chippewa have encountered huge and sometimes violent protests by non-Indians who claim the treaty rights give them an unfair edge and threaten to deplete fish and timber. The Chippewa have filed a series of lawsuits asking the court to define how much of the resources they are entitled to and to what degree the state can regulate tribal activities. State and tribal officials said that the Chippewa were unlikely to take 50 percent of the available deer and that the ruling could provide a model for resolving the dispute over the tribe's rights. Dean Crist, spokesman for the anti-treaty rights group Stop Treaty Abuse, said that Mrs. Crabb's ruling was a good step that didn't go far enough. ``The bad thing is you still have less than 1 percent of the population with 50 percent of the resource,'' he said. ``It looks to me like she's trying to court-appoint co-management.'' Co-management, the sharing of resources that has been used successfully in Washington state, has been touted by some as a solution to Wisconsin's dispute. Still to be decided are possible financial payments to the tribes for alleged state infringment on treaty rights.

DOC.HEAD: Birth of Test-Tube Tigers Buoys Hopes for Preservation of Species
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto AH1 of May 9
DOC.TEXT: The first birth of test-tube tiger cubs offers hope for the world's endangered tiger population, scientists say. Dr. Lee Simmons said two yellow cubs and one white one were delivered by Caesarean section April 27 at Henry Doorly Zoo. The surrogate mother was a 9{-year-old Siberian tiger. The parents, a male and two females, were Bengals. The white cub died shortly after birth from respiratory complications unrelated to the fertilization. But the yellow-and-brown striped cubs, a male and female, are healthy and being hand-reared at the zoo, Simmons said. The in-vitro technique, a technology developed on humans, already has been used for farm animals. An egg and sperm are taken from animals and combined in a lab dish, and the resulting embryo is implanted in a surrogate mother. Three zoos _ Doorly, the National Zoological Park in Washington and the Minnesota Zoological Gardens in Minneapolis _ have collaborated on the project for more than 10 years, beginning with experiments on house cats, Simmons said. The aim of the project is to take the technology into the wild, where tigers are endangered because of human encroachment. At least three of eight tiger subspecies have become extinct in the past 20 years, Simmons said. In the future, he said, frozen embryos from tigers in Omaha or other zoos will be used to impregnate females captured in the wild in places like India or Nepal. The tiger would then be released to deliver her cubs in the wild. The cubs born last month wouldn't be suitable for release because they were brought up around people, Simmons said. They are on display at the zoo. A project leader, Dr. David Wildt of the National Zoo, hailed the birth as ``bringing us one step closer to using reproductive techniques to preserve genetic diversity.'' Sperm and embryos could be collected from wild animals and frozen, helping ensure survival of endangered species, the scientists said. John Schalles, a professor of biology at Creighton University, said the program will likely help some endangered species, but ``the big problem out there is protecting the habitat these animals live in.''

DOC.HEAD: Center For Mouse Research Rebuilding Gradually
DOC.TEXT: The nation's No. 1 supplier of laboratory mice says it is up to 70 percent capacity after a fire one year ago today that dealt a blow to medical research projects around the world. The blaze at Jackson Laboratory killed 400,000 mice and destroyed much of the 29-year-old breeding complex. Now it is counting on at least $10 million from the National Institutes of Health for a full recovery. ``We'll be at 85 percent by the end of this summer. And we'll be at 100 percent by the end of 1991 if we get the $10 million from NIH,'' said Director Kenneth Paigen, who was about to assume the post when the fire broke out. An October report by a panel of consultants convened by NIH said the blow to Jackson represented ``a significant loss'' to important national research efforts. The panel urged the government to provide money to restore the research center quickly. JAX mice, as they are known in the scientific community, are used in research on cancer, AIDS, diabetes, arthritis and thousands of hereditary diseases. The research center, using frozen embryos, can breed mice of 1,700 strains to give scientists the genetic makeup they need for their experiments. The research center, founded in 1929 and struck by a catastrophic fire in 1947, reported annual shipments of nearly 2 million mice to researchers in all 50 states and 23 foreign countries before the fire. ``About half of our total production went to provide mice that are unavailable from any other source in the United States,'' Paigen said. ``In the kinds of mice, 95 percent of what's used in the United States ... is only available'' from Jackson. Paigen said the private, non-profit laboratory is unable to say exactly how much disruption the fire caused to an estimated $600 million to $1 billion in scientific projects, but it's ``a big chunk.'' The NIH consultants said some Food and Drug Administration research had to be re-evaluated, and the Pentagon was said to face ``major impact on the future directions and capabilities'' of its research. For now, the research center is doing some of its work out of six trailers. Construction is under way on a permanent wing. Plans envision a series of separate buildings to minimize the impact of any new calamity. ``Fire, health problems, utility breakdowns, tornados. Who knows what Maine is subject to? We can't lose it all again at one crack, God willing,'' Paigen said. Ironically, research at Jackson itself was largely unaffected by the fire because scientists there raise their own mice. Some researchers, however, have had their working quarters ``squeezed down,'' said Paigen.

DOC.HEAD: Jesse Jackson Visits Harvard; Urges Hiring of Law Professor
LaserPhoto BX1
DOC.TEXT: The Rev. Jesse Jackson said Harvard Law School is morally ``on trial'' for its failure to hire a black woman professor, and he ridiculed the school's claim that few candidates were available. Harvard officials say that 45 percent of the professors given full tnure at the university in the last decade were women or minorities. The law school, however, has three black men and no black women among its 60 tenured faculty members. Its administrators say hiring has been limited by a lack of applicants who have excelled at top law schools or clerked for the Supreme Court, two traditional pools for faculty members. Jackson, speaking at a rally of 400 students Wednesday, said those standards were too narrow and elitist. ``Harvard University is saying in effect there is no African-American woman alive who is qualified to teach at our university. To say (that) in 1990 ... is both an error and a gross insult to our intelligence,'' Jackson said. ``Harvard, at the top of the hill of academia, cannot cast shadows. It must cast light. In some sense the character of Harvard is on trial.'' Derrick Bell, Harvard Law's first tenured black professor, announced plans last month to take an unpaid leave of absence until the school hires a minority woman. Jackson came to Harvard hoping to mediate the dispute between Bell and the administration, but Law School Dean Robert C. Clark rejected the offer. Jackson did meet briefly with Clark early Wednesday, however. ``We had a very cordial visit. I tried to convey a sense of the efforts we are making to achieve greater diversity,'' Clark said. ``My sense is that he is concerned without a sense of urgency, (but) there is an emergency here'' Jackson said at a news conference. ``This matter is not just internal. Injustice anywhere is a threat to justice everywhere.'' Tatia Williams, a third-year law student from Washington who attended the rally, said recruitment of minority teachers is important for helping minority students succeed. ``If you have a homogeneous population of law professors, I don't think that they can give a perspective that everybody can relate to,'' she said. ``There's a comfortability factor, when people have like backgrounds and like lifestyles.''

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Falls Against Yen, Stock Up Slightly
DOC.TEXT: The dollar fell moderately against the Japanese yen today, while the Tokyo Stock Exchange's key index edged up slightly. The dollar closed at 156.75 yen, down 0.28 yen from Wednesday's close. It opened at 156.40 yen and traded between 156.37 yen and 156.83 yen. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues, a 24.97-point loser Wednesday, gained 34.65 points, or 0.11 percent, closing at 30,980.26. The dollars's lower opening in Tokyo followed its overnight plunge in New York, where it fell to 156.50 yen in late trading from 157.63 yen late Tuesday. ``There's no momentum except that the dollar is weakening against the European currencies,'' said Naohiko Yasuda of the Bank of Tokyo. ``The yen also is weak against the European currencies.'' He said the dollar should not weaken much further as many investors will buy it when it moves lower. On the stock market, the yen's strength induced profit-taking on high-tech, export-oriented issues in the morning, traders said. The Nikkei index firmed and ended the morning session at 31,241.95, or 296.34 points above Wednesday's close. However, the gains were largely erased by large brokers placing sell orders toward the close, they said. Volume on the first section was estimated at 730 million shares, down slightly from 753.5 million shares Wednesday. Meanwhile, the price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds was quoted at 86.55 points at 3 p.m. (2 a.m. EDT), compared to Wednesday's close of 86.65. The yield was 7.255 percent, up from 7.235 percent late Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Sailor: Crewman Died Trying to Rescue Fellows
DOC.TEXT: The sailor killed in the blaze aboard the guided-missile destroyer USS Conyngham roused sleeping crewmates from their quarters before he was overcome by smoke, a crew member says. Lt. Algernon Pope Gordon Jr., 34, helped evacuate fellow officers from their berths, which were filled with smoke from the fire Tuesday morning that began in a boiler room three to four decks below the berths. Gordon rescued one officer, who was among the 18 injured, then re-entered the smoky area and did not leave it alive. The crew member, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said in today's Daily Press and Times-Herald of Newport News that he didn't know why Gordon returned. ``He might have thought somebody else was in there,'' he said. ``He was an unselfish individual.'' Gordon, who was married with three children, was the son of a U.S. Bankruptcy Court judge in Montgomery, Ala. He was in charge of the ship's combat information center. Navy spokesmen said Gordon died of smoke inhalation but would not give the circumstances of his death. Capt. Paul Hanley, a spokeman for the Atlantic Fleet headquarters in Norfolk, said, ``One of the exceptional efforts by the ship's crew was in pulling everybody out of the berthing areas.'' The fire spread to the command center, leaving the ship temporarily dead in the water. The crew overcame a failure of communications and water-pumping equipment by using walkie-talkies and hand-held pumps that allowed fire hoses to draw sea water until other vessels arrived to help, the Navy said. The Navy has not provided a cause of the fire or the amount of damage. The Conyngham was conducting training operations about 100 miles southeast of Norfolk when the fire started. The 27-year-old vessel, which was to be decommissioned next year, returned home under tow early Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``Instead of subtracting it they added it, or vice versa.'' _ Jean Olivier, deputy manager of the Hubble project for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, explaining the math mistake that caused the Hubble Space Telescope to miss its target by trillions of miles.

``The big spenders on that side of the aisle are all just slobbering and drooling out of their mouths thinking they've gotten George Bush right where they want him.'' _ Rep. Tom DeLay, R-Texas, blasting Democrats over the issue of taxes and negotiation of a deficit-reduction pact with the White House.

``I didn't invent dirty words, I just know how to make 'em rhyme.'' _ Comedian Andrew Dice Clay, whose act includes lewd parodies of nursery rhymes, responding to the boycott of a second female performer to his appearance on ``Saturday Night Live'' this weekend.

DOC.HEAD: Nicaraguan Government In Bankruptcy, Official Says
DOC.TEXT: As thousands of government employees walked off their jobs demanding more pay, a top official said the new government's coffers are empty and it will have to impose harsh austerity measures. ``The situation of bankruptcy is very serious,'' Antonio Lacayo, minister of the presidency, told a news conference. He said President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro's Cabinet ministers had apprised her of the situation on Wednesday. Planned steps to try to bring down inflation ``will be deeper, more serious and more painful for the people and for all the country,'' said Lacayo, the president's son-in-law. Thousands of government employees went on strike Wednesday and thousands more elsewhere threatened to join them to demand hefty pay raises to compensate for soaring inflation. Employees at the National Assembly turned off the electricity and the sound system before going on strike, leaving deputies sitting in the dark, cavernous hall, unable to begin their session. The assembly workers were quickly joined by employees at other government offices, including the labor and foreign ministries. Jose Angel Bermudez, a leader of National Federation of Workers, told a rally of 3,000 government employees his organization was planning a nationwide strike if Mrs. Chamorro does not do more to help wage earners. He said the strike could be called later this week. The newly formed independent federation claims a membership of 60,000. Bermudez demanded a 200 percent pay increase, which he said will just cover the basic needs of an average worker's family. He scoffed at a 60 percent pay raise ordered by Mrs. Chamorro on Tuesday for the government's 61,000 employees, saying it was insufficient. No government estimates on inflation are available yet for this year. But the leftist Sandinistas, voted out of office in February, implemented 31 devaluations along with tough austerity measures to bring inflation from a record 33,600 percent in 1988 to 1,800 percent last year. They devalued the currency eight more times this year before leaving office. Mrs. Chamorro also ordered a sharp devaluation of Nicaragua's cordoba on Wednesday. She is urging the private sector to go along with 60 percent increases, but many businessmen complain that they cannot cover the cost. Daniel Ortega, her predecessor, accused Mrs. Chamorro's administration of pursuing ``a policy of terrorism in the economic field.'' The pro-Sandinista newspaper El Nuevo Diario called Mrs. Chamorro's policy anti-labor, saying that ``while Cabinet ministers in the new government make up to $5,500 a month, a worker barely makes $44.''
