It was Mrs. Chamorro's third devaluation in three weeks, dropping the value of the cordoba 20 percent on the official market, which handles only a few essential imports such as crude oil, and 5.1 percent on the parallel exchange, where most of the money is changed. Mrs. Chamorro devalued the cordoba by about half on the parallel market April 29, four days after she took office, and by another 20 percent on May 5. Officials said the devaluations were necessary because the Sandinistas left Nicaragua broke after 11 years, with only $3 million in the treasury and a foreign debt of $11 billion for a country of 3.5 million people. When the Sandinistas seized power, the cordoba was traded at 10 to the dollar. On Wednesday, 100,000 bought one dollar on the official market and the parallel market rate was 180,250 to a dollar. The devaluation makes Nicaraguan goods cheaper on foreign markets, encouraging exports, and makes foreign goods more expensive in Nicaragua, discouraging the spending of hard currency for non-essential goods.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mixed, Gold Steady
DOC.TEXT: The dollar was mixed in European trading this morning. Gold was steady in quiet trading. The dollar closed in Tokyo at 156.75 yen, down 0.28 yen from Wednesday's close. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 156.81 yen. ``There's no momentum except that the dollar is weakening against the European currencies,'' said Naohiko Yasuda of the Bank of Tokyo. ``The yen also is weak against the European currencies.'' Other dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Wednesday: _1.6395 West German marks, up from 1.6375 _1.3990 Swiss francs, down from 1.4039 _5.5260 French francs, up from 5.5010 _1.8405 Dutch guilders, down from 1.8470 _1,205.00 Italian lire, up from 1,203.00 _1.1656 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1660 The British pound traded at $1.6735, from $1.6785 late Wednesday. Gold dealers in London fixed a recommended price of $371.00 per troy ounce this morning, up from $370.75 late Wednesday. In Zurich, gold opened at $371, up from $370.75 bid late Wednesday. In Hong Kong, gold rose $1.29 an ounce today, to close at $372.22. Silver bullion traded in London at a bid price of $5.04 a troy ounce, up from $5.02 late Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Jumbo Jet Leaves Manila After Beingn Held for 15 Hours
DOC.TEXT: A chartered Northwest Airlines jumbo jet flew to Japan today nearly 15 hours after being forced to land for entering the country's air space without permit, an air force spokesman said. Col. Rodolfo Asistente, spokesman of the Philippine air force, said the Northwest Airlines Boeing 747 took off shortly before 2 p.m. for Tokyo with only its 13 crew members aboard. Asistente said its 45 passengers, which were of several nationalities, decided to remain in Manila and vacation instead of flying to Singapore, their original destination. He said the plane was allowed to leave after securing diplomatic clearance for entering Philippine air space without permit. Asistente said the plane flew from Singapore early Wednesday but strayed into Philippine air space en route to Tokyo. Air force trackers warned the pilots that it had entered Philippine air space and ordered the plane out, Asistente added. The plane changed course and proceeded to Tokyo but on its way back to Singapore late Wednesday the aircraft again wandered into Philippine territory and was again warned, Assistente said. Asistente said the pilot requested to land at the Manila airport because the plane was running low on fuel and could not make it to Singapore if it changed course. The intrusion was the second such air space violation this month. Air force jets intercepted a Nippon Air cargo plane on May 1 after flying over Philippine terrritory with an expired permit.

DOC.HEAD: `Hope' One Resource That Survives in Delta, Commission Finds
With PM-Delta-Good Faith Fund, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Mississippi Delta region, the nation's poorest, has plenty of reserves of hope and could become vital given enough assistance, a federal commission says. The nine-member Delta Commission conducted an 18-month study of 219 of the poorest counties and parishes of Tennessee, Illinois, Missouri, Kentucky, Arkansas, Mississippi and Louisiana. ``These are people who prefer hope to despair. This is a region that, given the right tools and knowledge, can help the nation as a whole strike a new balance of competitiveness in a global economy,'' the report's summary said. The Commercial Appeal of Memphis obtained a draft of the commission's report, which was to be presented Monday to the White House. Sen. Dale Bumpers, D-Ark., who proposed creating the commission two years ago, questioned where the money to back its plans would come from. ``The federal government and the states and the cities are all in a terrible fiscal crisis,'' Bumpers said this week. The draft report calls for a Delta development bank; a Delta Common Market, a Memphis-based agricultural technology center, conventions of Delta religious leaders and multistate economic planning. It seeks federal and state aid _ with a strong emphasis on volunteerism _ to improve education, highways, ports, health care and race relations for the region in which 8.3 million people live. Arkansas Gov. Bill Clinton, the commission chairman, wrote in a letter accompanying the draft that it is a ``handbook for action,'' not simply another government study. ``This is not a report that will collect dust. It is very practical and it can be used by a wide variety of groups and individuals,'' said Mississippi Gov. Ray Mabus, a panel member. The panel did not put price tags on its recommendations and cautions that there are no ``quick fixes.'' ``Not only must the federal government find new ways to invest in the Lower Mississippi Delta's future, but other levels of government, the private sector, civic and nonprofit organizations must step forward,'' the report said. Area lawmakers have all but ruled out chances for creation of a largely federally funded agency such as the Appalachian Regional Commission. The report recommends creation of an interim, state-funded advocacy group to follow up on findings after the panel dissolves. The draft leaves to Congress to decide what permanent body would monitor Delta progress. The report's recommendations include: _ Seeking federal funds to start a model magnet school in each Delta state; _ Asking area colleges to establish a Delta Higher Education Association to focus research on area development needs in aquaculture, wood, alternative fuels and clean coal; _ Designating the region as a ``national laboratory'' for seeking new ways to improve race relations; _ Creating an agency to promote regional tourism; _ Starting annual meetings of each state's religious leaders, including a Delta-wide meeting every two years, to mobilize volunteer efforts; _ Designating acquaculture _ catfish, shrimp and crawfish farming _ as full-fledged agricultural commodities in the 1990 farm bill; _ Providing an additional 400,000 units of housing for low-income Delta residents by 2001; _ Improving major roads in the region; _ Expanding Volunteers in Service to America (VISTA) by promising financial incentives to volunteers who work in the region.; The other panel members are Louisiana Gov. Buddy Roemer; Ed Jones, a retired congressman from Tennessee; Kentucky Local Government Commissioner Lee Troutwine, Missouri Agriculture Department director Charles Kruse; Rhonda Vinson of Southern Illinois University; Webb Franklin, a former congressman from Greenwood, Miss., and John Shepherd, a St. Louis lawyer.

DOC.HEAD: Israel Criticizes U.S. over Pro-Arab U.N. Resolution
DOC.TEXT: Foreign Minister Moshe Arens today criticized the United States for coordinating with Arab states in drafting a U.N. resolution opposing settlement of Soviet Jews in occupied areas. ``I am troubled by the activity of the United States when the Arab countries raise in the U.N. Security Council the issue of immigration from the Soviet Union,'' Arens said on Israel radio. Arens, who indicated U.S.-Israel relations were at a low point, took the unusual step of summoning U.S. Ambassador William Brown on Wednesday night to protest the U.S. activity. Foreign Ministry spokesman Yossi Amihud said Israel objected to the U.S. effort to formulate a resolution because it encouraged ``the Arab attack on the right of Jews to immigrate to Israel.'' A key paragraph of the working draft composed by non-aligned and Arab states claims settlement violates international law, a stronger wording than the U.S. position, which contends settlements are an obstacle to peacemaking. ``Israel's policy and practices of settling part of its population and new immigrants in those (occupied) territories are in contravention of the Fourth Geneva Convention ... and it is a serious obstruction to achieving a just and lasting peace in the Middle East,'' the Arab draft says. Israeli officials said there was no policy of settling immigrants in occupied lands and no basis to suggest such settlement was illegal under the conventions governing the conduct of occupying powers. Other hard-line sections of the two-page document, which was read to The Associated Press, state: _Palestinian exiles should have the right of return. _Aid that could be used for settlement should be withheld. _Palestinian civilians should have ``impartial protection.'' The draft grew out of a call in March by the Soviet Union for a debate on the settlement of Soviet Jews in occupied territory. A U.N. vote on a settlement resolution, which had been scheduled for today, was postponed with no new date set. Israeli officials said the United States should veto the resolution because it was part of a ``political warfare'' being waged by Arabs, who are opposed to all immigration to Israel not just to the war-won lands. They argued that Western countries could not support the resolution without violating their stand in support of freedom of movement. In the past, the United States has vetoed most anti-Israel resolutions, but officials said that this time U.N. Ambassador Thomas R. Pickering has been seeking agreed-on language with the Arabs. He proposed various changes earlier this week to soften the hard-line sections, but details were no available. Arens referred to the increasing strain in Israel-U.S. relations, saying ``there's no doubt that at this moment we are going through a period of tension with the United States.'' He contrasted the troubled relationship with Bush's administration to the more sympathetic treatment Israel received under former President Ronald Reagan. ``We have had differences of opinion with the United States on certain subjects for many years, with this administration especially, in all that is connected to settlements,'' said Arens. Despite U.S. expressions of concern, right-wing Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's caretaker government helped fund a Jewish settlement in Jerusalem's Old City, and started two new ones in the West Bank and Gaza Strip. There are more than 70,000 Jewish settlers in the West Bank and Gaza Strip, where 1.7 million Arabs live. Gad Ben Ari, spokesman for the Jewish Agency which assists immigrants, said only about 200 Soviet Jews, about one-third of 1 percent, had chosen to live in the occupied territories in the past year. He said about 1,000 had chosen to live in Jerusalem, but no figures were available on how many are in Israeli-annexed Arab east Jerusalem, where 120,000 Jews and 130,000 Arabs live. About 30,000 Soviet Jews have come to Israel so far this year and more than 150,000 are expected in the next 12 months.

DOC.HEAD: Premier Announces Measures To Boost Ruling Party Image
DOC.TEXT:
Premier Andrei Lukanov has announced wage hikes and measures to ease consumer shortages in an apparent attempt to boost the chances of the ruling former Communist Party in next month's free elections. Lukanov told a news conference Wednesday that minimum monthly wages will be raised as of June 1, the export of foodstuffs and other goods in short supply will be banned, and a steep hard currency tax on imported cars will be abolished. The government, which recently suspended payments on Bulgaria's $10 billion foreign debt, also will try to import food and will guarantee the jobs of workers at unprofitable companies until after the elections, Lukanov said. While approving free elections and professing to accept full democracy, the Communists remain in full control in Bulgaria prior to the elections, scheduled for June 10.
The premier, a leading figure in the re-named Communist party _ now the Socialists, said minimum monthly wages would be raised June 1 from 140 to 170 leva. Under the current official exchange rate, there are eight to nine leva to the dollar. The average wage in Bulgaria at present is about 250 leva. Before a drastic change in exchange rates decreed this spring, one dollar officially was worth 2.50 leva. By the end of this week, the government will issue a list of consumer goods that cannot be exported by either Bulgarians or foreigners, Lukanov said. The measure seemed intended to alleviate the fast increasing food shortages in this traditionally agrarian country of 9 million people. Also, new laws will be passed to punish speculators exporting consumer goods and to ``alleviate the tension on the internal market,'' Lukanov said. Yugoslavs, Romanians and Greeks are thought to buy up cheap Bulgarian appliances and other goods for resale at higher prices abroad. Bulgarians have also engaged in such trading in goods from the increasingly empty shelves. Sugar is the latest scarcity. A shop in Sofia's downtown Rakowski Street selling several hundred pounds of imported sugar was besieged by hundreds of citizens on Monday and Tuesday. Lukanov said draft legislation on privatizing farmland and industry will be published ``for public debate'' within the next few days. Currently, farmers are allowed to own only small plots of about 1{ acres around their homes with the bulk of agricultural land in state hands. Lukanov also disclosed that Bulgarian geologists had discovered rich oil fields in central northern Bulgaria around the town of Pleven. The oil deposits are some 13,000 feet deep, the premier said. Bulgaria is negotiating with foreign firms to exploit the oil fields, whose exact extent was not revealed. Bulgaria, long viewed as the Soviet Union's most loyal ally in Eastern Europe, is seeking to boost its ties to the West as it moves away from the hard-line Communist rule of Todor Zhivkov, ousted November after 35 years in power. But the ruling Socialists are cautious about scrapping centralized economic planning and subsidies and introducing a totally free market. Lukanov praised an accord signed with the European Community this week to give Bulgarian goods including agricultural produce and greater access to the EC market. He also said Bulgaria hopes to join the International Monetary Fund by September 1990.

DOC.HEAD: On the Light Side
DOC.TEXT: Oil rigs disguised as dinosaurs and four giant red lobsters were the winning entries in a national design contest to decorate a rundown gasoline station built in the mid-1950s. The jury initially dismissed the lobster motif as ``too whimsical,'' but ``we kept coming back to it, over and over,'' said former Mayor Pamela Plumb, one of the judges. ``It would become the Eiffel Tower of Portland,'' an instant landmark and potential meeting place, she said. ``They're not token lobsters or trite gestures. They're blown up to a scale where they're truly heroic,'' said Deborah Andrews, another judge. The 60-foot-long and 20-foot-tall lobsters, each resting on a giant canopy, were designed by Philadelphia architects Willis Pember and Andrew Blanda. That design and the dinosaur entry from Architect William Collett of Cambridge, Mass., were the winners in the Gateway Gas Design Competition devised by the C.N. Brown Co., owner of the dilapidated station. The two first-place winners announced Wednesday received $2,000 each. Residents in Portand will have a chance to comment about the winners and 157 other entries. C.N. Brown is not obligated to use any of the designs when it renovates the station. The contest came about when city planners balked at the company's bid to use a standard Mobil Oil Corp. design to replace the existing structure. Collett's design pays homage to fossil fuels. The roof is reminiscent of prehistoric animals and appears to mimic the action of oil drilling rigs when blown by the wind.

Bobby Stephenson and his friends needed something special to compete in the world's largest barbecue cookoff. So they built a 53-foot-tall, two-ton, steel replica of the Eiffel Tower. The cooking booth is this year's focal point at a Mississippi River bluff where 175 barbecue teams will spend today through Saturday cooking 25 tons of pork. The party includes a ``Miss Piggie'' beauty contest, a hog-calling competition and a parade. Stephenson said his 22-member group, The Not Ready for Swine Time Porkers, started working on their blue-and-white tower in January. A 22-foot-square base forms the cooking booth's roof and a second story observation tower. Next to the booth is a 7-foot-long steel cooker with three cooking surfaces and plenty of space for a whole hog. ``It got to be a bit more involved that my team had expected it was going to be,'' Stephenson said. This year's contestants come from 22 states and France, Ireland, Great Britain, Canada and the Soviet republic of Estonia. The Memphis in May World Championship Barbecue Cooking Contest is listed in the Guinness Book of World Records as the largest event of its kind anywhere. The listing was based on the 55,747 pounds of pork cooked last year.

DOC.HEAD: Charleston Dubbed Nation's Most Mannerly City
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 3rd graf, `Everyone just ....' to CORRECT spelling from Kewanne to Kewanee. Subs 8th graf, `Tied for ...,' to CORRECT spelling from Battendorf to Bettendorf.
DOC.TEXT: Executives once again declared this antebellum city by the sea the nation's most mannerly city, capable of watching its p's and q's even when a most unwelcome guest _ Hurricane Hugo _ dropped in. ``With the hurricane and the wonderful recovery you're making, everyone is in love with Charleston again,'' etiquette expert Marjabelle Young Stewart said Wednesday. ``Everyone just felt the manners under stress and under pressure was such a thrilling thing for the nation,'' she said in a telephone interview from her home in Kewanee, Ill. Mrs. Stewart bases her annual list on an unscientific survey of about 2,700 executives who have taken her etiquette courses during the past three years. ``They vote on where they have had great experiences _ on what type of community that would make you want to go back or to live there,'' said Mrs. Stewart, who has published 17 books on etiquette. Charleston has been represented since Mrs. Stewart began compiling the list 10 years ago. But the last time the city was No. 1 was four years ago. Ranked No. 2 this year is Council Bluffs, Iowa, followed by Atlanta, Chicago, Los Angeles, and last year's top choice, Portland, Ore. Tied for seventh are Rock Island and Moline, Ill., and Davenport and Bettendorf, Iowa. San Francisco, Denver and Phoenix round out the top 10. Charleston captured the heart of the nation with its recovery from Hurricance Hugo, Mrs. Stewart said. The hurricane came ashore Sept. 21, killing 29 people and causing $5.9 billion damage. Although Portland slipped out of the top position, that in itself does not mean the city is doing anything wrong, she said. It's just that people admire Charleston. ``It's like Camelot,'' she said. ``Every time they talk about Charleston there's a softness and sweetness that says a lot.''

DOC.HEAD: Report: GAO Finds Screening at Borders Inaccurate
DOC.TEXT: A computer system used at U.S. border crossings to screen out criminals contains inaccurate information and is ineffective, congressional investigators have concluded, a newspaper reported today. The system's defects may have resulted in a ``significant impairment'' of the ability of border agents to prevent criminals from entering the country, The New York Times said. The problem dates back to the creation of the computer records, investigators with the General Accounting Office, the auditing arm of Congress, said in a report to a House panel. Criminals may enter the country while innocent people may be stopped and searched at borders, the report said. The GAO report, given to the panel in March, was provided to the Times recently. The computer system, Treasury Enforcement Communications System II, is maintained by the Customs Service. Computer terminals linked to the system give customs agents background information based on the names and automobile license numbers of people wishing to enter the country. The Bush administration has recommended that the computer system be used as a central repository for information gathered by agencies that enforce drug laws. A Customs Service spokesman challenged the report's findings. ``This system is not rife with errors,'' said spokesman Dennis Shimkoski. He said many of the problems cited by the report had been identified previously by internal investigators at the Customs Service and were being corrected. The GAO report said no ``lookout records'' had been created in the computer system for known drug smugglers and other major criminals. As a result, border guards did not know which suspects to detain. The GAO reviewed files for 70 investigations in which customs agents had arrested or searched people last June. The report found that in 65 of those cases, the suspects' names were not entered into the system even though many of them were drug smugglers, had tried to enter the country with concealed weapons or were involved in other major crimes.

DOC.HEAD: Toyota Denies Keeping Pickens' Ads out of Japanese Media
DOC.TEXT: Toyota Motor Corp. denied today that it tried to prevent Texas oilman T. Boone Pickens from placing ads in local newspapers in his battle to assert ownership rights in a Japanese company. But several of Tokyo's largest newspapers said they held up the ads, which claim that collusive business practices force higher prices on consumers. The papers said they were considering printing a version that omits company names. ``There's no freedom of speech in Japan,'' said Pickens' lawyer, Kanji Ishizumi. ``Toyota published an ad in a U.S. paper saying `shut up' to Pickens. They were able to enjoy freedom of speech in the United States, but Pickens can't do that here.'' Pickens issued a statement Wednesday in Texas claiming Toyota and its powerful advertising agency, Dentsu, were trying to block him from publishing the ads. Since last year, Boone Co., a U.S. investment firm, has held the largest equity stake in Koito Manufacturing Co., a major automobile parts maker closely linked to Toyota, Japan's largest automaker. Pickens says his unsuccessful battle to gain a seat on Koito's board of directors and to exercise leadership in the company illustrates how investment opportunities are closed to foreigners in Japan. The Pickens ad is addressed to consumers, auto parts employees and shareholders of Koito, claiming the Texan's fight ``could be a major step toward freeing Japanese consumers from artificially high prices, and returning portions of the profits to the companies' investors.'' The ad asks Japanese consumers with any information on ``unfair practices'' of Toyota, Nissan, Honda or other carmakers to send it to Pickens in Dallas. ``It would never, ever happen _ that Dentsu would pressure the media not to carry Pickens' advertisement,'' said Jim Sakaguchi of Toyota's international affairs department. ``We have never discussed this matter with Dentsu.'' Pickens' statement said: ``Our ads were accepted, but we have now been told that there won't be any space available for several more weeks because Toyota's advertising firm, Dentsu, is buying up all available space.'' Dentsu, the world's largest advertising agency, places more than 20 percent of the ads in major newspapers and almost one-third of ads in major magazines. In his book ``The Enigma of Japanese Power,'' Karel van Wolferen wrote that Dentsu helps shelter big business from the scrutiny of consumers. ``Dentsu is able to apply enormous pressure on the media not to report, or to downplay, incidents that might harm the prestige of its clients,'' Wolferen wrote. The ad was to have been published Wednesday in the Asahi Shimbun's edition in Hokkaido, in northern Japan. A worker in the advertising section said the ad had been ``delayed.'' Japan's largest newspaper, the Yomiuri Shimbun, said it was considering running the ad without references to Toyota and Honda, two of the newspaper's principal advertising clients. ``We don't want to get involved in anything that upsets our major clients. That's how we support our business,'' said Ikuo Terai of the paper's advertising department. Terai said the paper refused the Pickens' ad twice because it didn't want to publish a ``personal dispute'' between Pickens and Koito. Representatives from the Mainichi Shimbun and Asahi Shimbun said the ads had been delayed but that they would run by May 16, with references to Toyota and Honda deleted from the original text.

DOC.HEAD: MOVE's Calm Voice Imprisoned, Won't Disavow Family
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 3 grafs to recast. Picks up 4th graf pvs, `According to...'.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto STC1
DOC.TEXT: Ramona Africa remains imprisoned five years after she survived a fire that killed 11 fellow members of the radical group MOVE, refusing to renounce her beliefs even though doing so would mean freedom. Ms. Africa, the only adult to survive the blaze touched off when Philadelphia police bombed MOVE's rowhouse, stays in an 8-by-10-foot cell at a prison for women, where she has fought losing battles large and small against ``the system.'' She wants freedom to associate with MOVE friends, but her refusal to renounce her ``family'' keeps her in her cell. And she wants to be known as Ramona Africa, a last name MOVE members generally adopt. But ``the system'' makes her use the name Ramona Johnson. ``According to your law, we have the right to speak freely and to demonstrate freely,'' Ms. Africa said in a prison interview. ``But because the police department and every agency of this system are designed to protect the institutions of this system, they are not going to support MOVE.'' On May 13, 1985, MOVE and police transformed a quiet neighborhood into a combat zone. Gunfire rang out for hours and a bomb dropped in an attempt to dislodge a bunker atop MOVE headquarters started a fire that destroyed 61 homes and left 270 people homeless. Eleven MOVE members, including five children, were killed in the attempt by police to evict them for harassing neighbors with foul-mouthed revolutionary rhetoric blared through a bullhorn at all hours. Memorials are planned for Friday and Saturday in Philadelphia. ``If people knew the truth about MOVE, they would not stand for this system treating us the way it does,'' Ms. Africa said. Those among the 14 imprisoned MOVE leaders who are eligible for parole have been told they can get out if they renounce the organization. None has agreed. Ms. Africa was eligible for parole five months after being sentenced in 1986. According to Ms. Africa, MOVE _ whose name stands for nothing in particular _ was once a peaceful but misunderstood group protesting in the '70s against abuse of animals, the elderly and the environment. ``The system'' made it mean. In 1978, in the group's first serious brush with the law, a policeman was slain in an attempt to evict MOVE from a house. ``We don't say that MOVE is innocent and expect people to just accept it,'' Ms. Africa said. ``Our innocence is documented all through the court records.'' Ms. Africa, who considered going to law school after becoming involved with MOVE, had been selected the group's spokeswoman before the 1985 battle. ``She was very articulate, direct and non-hostile,'' recalled Michael Nutter, who attempted to mediate the 1985 dispute between MOVE and police. Nutter said Ms. Africa spoke in calm, reassuring tones and asked questions of him that he could not answer. ``She put forth intelligent questions, asking me what I would do in the same situation,'' Nutter said. She still asks the same kinds of questions, calmly inquiring what other steps she could take against a society that imprisoned people she says are innocent. As for her personal battles, Ms. Africa said nothing less than her identity is at stake. Mail addressed to ``Ramona Africa'' is returned undelivered with a note saying no such person is lodged there. Consent forms for interviews, tape recorders and photographs come back to her if she doesn't sign the name Johnson. ``Is it worth it?'' she asked. ``Being right is worth it.''

DOC.HEAD: Florida Appeals Court Reinstates Cargo Airline's Libel Suit
DOC.TEXT: A state appeals court reinstated a libel suit filed by a cargo airline once controlled by the CIA against a television station over a report that the airline's planes carried drugs. The evidence tended to show that WPLG-TV, Miami's ABC affiliate, didn't give the airline ``a fair opportunity'' to respond to the drug allegations in a series aired in 1987, the 3rd District Court of Appeal ruled. The ruling Tuesday reversed a Dade Circuit Court decision dismissing the case and ordered a trial on defamation claims by Miami-based Southern Air Transport. Southern Air received widespread publicity before the series as a supplier for U.S.-based Contra rebels fighting Nicaragua's ruling Sandinistas. The station's report included an informer's statement that she watched as drugs were loaded on a Southern Air plane in Colombia. The same woman repeated the allegations before a U.S. Senate committee. Other defendants in the case are the station owner Post-Newsweek Stations of Florida, reporter Susan Candiotti and four others involved in the series production.

DOC.HEAD: India Says No to Negotiations With U.S. on Trade
DOC.TEXT: India today rejected negotiations with the United States over removing India from an American ``hit list'' of countries targeted for unfair trading practices. India is not going to be ``intimidated or policed'' by anybody on the issue of country's sovereignty and economic independence,'' Commerce Minister Arun Nehru told the national Parliament. Nehru's statement marked the first time Indian officials have openly rejected negotiations with the United States over the trade issue. On April 27, President Bush cited India under a 1988 law that provides for economic sanctions if protective trade barriers are not eliminated. Bush removed Japan and Brazil from the list, leaving India the only country on it. India has steadfastly refused to modify its restrictive trade policies, designed to protect domestic industries by limiting foreign investment and imposing high import duties. Nehru said India will not enter into either ``secret or open'' negitiations with the United States under threat of retaliation. Under the 1988 U.S. Omnibus Trade Act, Washington could levy tariffs of up to 100 percent on goods imported from a nation judged an unfair trader. Under former Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi, India began a program of relative economic liberalization, opening up to limited foreign investment. But India's new government, led by Prime Minister V.P. Singh, has shown few signs of continuing those policies. Singh's Cabinet includes some socialists who regularly denounce Gandhi's liberalizations. The government has rejected an investment proposal by Coca-Cola Co. and vowed to investigate an investment project backed by PepsiCo.

DOC.HEAD: China Releases 211 Arrested During Pro-Democracy Movement
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Adds 8 grafs at end to UPDATE with Ted Turner speech, demonstration outside Australian Embassy.
DOC.TEXT: China said today that it freed a second large group of protesters arrested for roles in last year's pro-democracy movement, including leading journalist Dai Qing and several famous academics. The official Xinhua News Agency said 211 ``lawbreakers ... have been given lenient treatment and released upon completion of investigations.'' Thousands of students, workers and others who took part in massive marches in Beijing and other cities were detained after the army's attacked protesters in the capital on June 4, killing hundreds of unarmed civilians. The releases come shortly before President Bush must decide whether to renew China's ``most favored nation'' trading status, which entitles it to lower tariffs. The United States grants most-favored-nation status to almost all countries, but Bush can deny it if a country does not allow its citizens freedom to travel. Some U.S. congressmen have indicated they favor lifting China's most-favored-nation status to protest its overall human rights record. The prison releases and the lifting of martial law in Tibet last week both appeared intended to placate such critics. The government announced in January that it had released 573 people, the only other large group to be freed. Xinhua quoted an unidentified spokesman for the Public Security ministry as saying 431 people remain in custody and under investigation. The report did not elaborate and the 431 presumably does not include those tried and sentenced. The official media has reported 20 executions of people who took part in the protests and violent clashes with the army and police, and the government has denied Western reports of other, secret executions. Few other sentences have been made public, and none of the trials have been open to foreign journalists. Dai Qing, a journalist for Guangming Daily, said she was released Wednesday. ``Coming back home was like a dream. After 10 months, my kitchen is like a stranger,'' she said, contacted by telephone at her home in Beijing. She declined to speak further, saying she would be arrested again if she spoke to reporters without permission. Sources have said Ms. Dai and other leading intellectuals were held at Qincheng Prison in western Beijing, and were generally well treated. She had made an emotional but unsuccessful appeal to the students to quit their occupation of central Beijing's Tiananmen Square days before the army crackdown. Also released was Cao Siyuan, former director of a research institute under the Stone Corp., China's leading computer company, and an adviser to ousted Communist Party chief Zhao Ziyang. Zhao was purged last summer for allegedly supporting the democracy movement and ``splitting the party.'' Zhou Duo, also of Stone Corp., one of four non-students who staged a hunger strike in the square on June 2, also was released. Only one of the hunger strikers, Liu Xiaobo, remains in jail, and sources have said he has been charged with counterrevolutionary incitement. The Public Security Ministry spokesman said protesters still in prison would be dealt with leniently if they ``show a good attitude ... make voluntary confessions and show repentance.'' ``Those who obstinately stick to a wrong course ... and continue to do evil will surely be punished strictly,'' he said. Also today, Cable News Network owner Ted Turner said he believed the Chinese government ``felt forced to'' call in troops last year to end the pro-democracy movement. In a speech to foreign journalists, Turner also accused the United States of interfering in the affairs of other nations. ``The thing that drives me most crazy and makes me most embarrassed is the fact that our leaders feel they have the right to interfere in the affairs of other countries and tell them what to do,'' he said. ``I personally don't feel that's done a bit of good.'' He added: ``You catch more flies with honey.'' Turner's CNN played an important role in showing the world the events of last spring, when students, intellectuals and workers, sometimes in the hundreds of thousands, took to the streets every day for seven weeks demanding political reforms and an end to corruption in government. In another development today, about three dozen Chinese demonstrated outside the Australian Embassy in Beijing to demand refunds of thousands of dollars from Australian schools. The protesters said they paid tuition and board money in advance to the English-language schools, but later were refused visas and could not attend. Diplomats inside the embassy refused to come out to talk to the students. ``We're simply not willing to cooperate in a staged publicity event,'' embassy spokesman Grant Thompson said later in an interview inside the embassy.

DOC.HEAD: Europe's Last Hard-Line Communist Country Announces Reforms
DOC.TEXT: Albania has announced it will ease restrictions on travel and religion as part of a package of laws representing a break from the country's Stalinist traditions. Europe's last hard-line Communist country also said it wants to join the 35-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, in a further move from its decades-long policy of isolationism. The proposed reforms were announced before the Albanian Parliament on Tuesday, and a report on the meeting, carried by the state ATA news agency, was made available to The Associated Press in Vienna on Wednesday. The moves come before an expected visit to Albania on Friday by U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar. In a speech to the Parliament, Deputy Premier Manush Myftiu said a new law was being drafted that would allow any Albanian to hold a passport to travel abroad. Ordinary Albanians have been forbidden to travel outside the country for more than 40 years. He did not say when the travel law would be ready or whether there would be any other conditions for travel. It was not clear whether the move was part of the country's bid to join the European security conference process. Myftiu also indicated that the death penalty would no longer be applied to people attempting to flee the country illegally. He said that ``defection,'' which remains an offense, would no longer be treated as a capital crime involving betrayal of the country. Myftiu added that Albania would no longer punish people for spreading ``religious propaganda'' and ease laws banning anti-socialist agitation. Albania's Communist leaders have vigorously promoted atheism. Under its former Stalinist leader Enver Hoxha, Albania banned all faiths and closed all houses of worship. Hoxha also pursued a policy of isolationism, shunning relations with both superpowers. Albania, which broke with the Soviet Union and the Warsaw Pact in the 1960s, refused to join the European security conference, charging it meant interference in the countries internal affairs. But since Hoxha's death in 1985, his successor, Communist Party chief Ramiz Alia, has moved gradually to re-establish contacts abroad and introduce new policies at home. Last month, the Communist leadership signaled Albania's willingness to resume relations with Moscow and Washington and to establish ties with the European Economic Community. At Tuesday's session of Parliament, Premier Adil Carcani said his country wanted to join the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe. He emphasized the country's ``desire to join the process of European Cooperation and Security and render our possible contribution to its process.'' Carcani's statement was believed to be the first such public pronouncement by an Albanian leader. Senior officials had previously only hinted that Albania might now consider joining the conference. The conference _ which first met in 1975 in Helsinki, Finland _ groups 35 nations: all the European nations, except Albania, as well as the United States, Canada and the Soviet Union. At the Helsinki meeting, the nations signed a key accord on European security issues, economic cooperation and human rights. At later conference meetings, the countries adopted supplementary documents that helped stir popular demands for human rights in Eastern European countries where Communist regimes were toppled in dramatic revolutions last year. One of the key points in the Helsinki accords is the right to free travel. Albania, wedged between Yugoslavia and Greece, has about 3.1 million residents.

DOC.HEAD: Homicide Rate in Nation's Capital Declines
DOC.TEXT: The homicide rate in the nation's capital declined for the first four months of the year, law enforcement officials say. As of May 1, there were 152 homicides in the city, 8.5 percent less than at the same time last year, when there were 165. Had slayings increased at the same rate as the two previous years, there would have been more than 250 people killed in the city by May 1. A year ago this month, there were 55 percent more killings than at the same time in 1988. The rate of increase between May 1987 and May 1988 was the same. D.C. Police Chief Isaac Fulwood Jr. said Wednesday he doesn't want to read too much into the statistics. He noted that a few bad nights of violence could send the homicide tally soaring. ``It's just too early to tell,'' Fulwood said. American University criminologist James Fyfe said one possible reason for the slight decrease in slayings is what sociologists call the ``ceiling effect.'' ``You hit a peak and you can't go much higher because there is only a limited pool of people who are committing the homicides or are subject to being victims of homicides,'' Fyfe said. ``This small group of people who account for the number of homicides are wearing themselves out.''

DOC.HEAD: Fearful East Germans Hold Mass Protests, Strikes
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 12 grafs to UPDATE with factory workers holding one-hour strike. Pickup 12th graf, `East Germans ...' Adds 1 graf at end to UPDATE with Kohl pressuring East Germans.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto BER1
DOC.TEXT: East German teachers, factory workers and farmers held protests nationwide today to demand job security when their nation unites with West Germany. Teachers closed classrooms, textile and leather workers shut off their machines, and farmers in tractors blocked border crossings into West Germany in the latest and largest demonstrations by an increasingly restive workforce. The protests came as lawmakers met to discuss the status of negotiations with West Germany on merging the two nations. There have been growing signs of a split in recent days in the coalition government of Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere. The left-leaning Social Democrats, the junior partners in the coalition, are demanding more social guarantees to protect workers from the loss of jobs and benefits when the nation shifts quickly to a free-market economy. Thousands of teachers held two- to four-hour warning strikes this morning in East Berlin, Frankfurt and der Oder, Magdeburg, Neubranderburg, Hohenschoenhausen, Rostock and Halle, the government news agency ADN said. About 2,000 kindergarten, primary school and college teachers marched through East Berlin to the Parliament building, where lawmakers were convening. The marchers demanded job and benefits security. Farm workers blocked highway border crossings at the East German cities of Magdeburg, Eisenach and Rudolphstein, police said. Traffic was snarled for about an hour in the latest of several blockades held by farm workers. After the protests started, Parliament Secretary Guenther Krause said discussions would begin next week with the 600,000-member farm workers union and eventually all labor organizations, ADN said. The farm workers are fearful of job losses from Western competition and the transition of state-owned land to the private sector. Thousands of leather and textile workers in Leipzig, Dresden and Chemnitz shut off their machines for an hour to call attention to their fear of Western imports, ADN said. East Germans have been buying better-made Western imports since the borders between the nations were opened in November, after the Stalinist regime was ousted. Last month, workers at a chocolate factory began selling their goods door-to-door because East German shops were buying cheaper, better-tasting West German chocolate. Economists predict that many inefficient East German factories will close in the next year and that between 500,000 and 2 million East German workers will lose their jobs. On Wednesday, the Ministry for Labor and Social Affairs said the number of unemployed rose from 38,313 in March to 64,948 last month. The unemployed included 36,000 skilled workers, 16,000 unskilled workers and 12,000 unemployed who have recently left school, according to the figures distributed by ADN. East Germany once had one of the strongest economies in the Soviet bloc, but since the beginning of the 1980s has been plagued by growing inefficiency. East Germany and West Germany plan to merge their economies and social institutions by July 2, when the West German mark will become the currency of East Germany. In Bonn, West Germany, today, Chancellor Helmut Kohl pressured East Germany to show greater flexibility in negotiations over unification and told Parliament that ``a series of important questions'' needs to be resolved before the two nations can seal their planned merger.

DOC.HEAD: Cold Weather in Parts of Plains; South Stays Soggy
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to UPDATE snow situation in Michigan, Wisconsin; INSERTS 2 grafs after 5th graf pvs, `Showers were...', to add background on effect of rains on farming regions. Picks up 6th graf pvs, `In Texas...'.
DOC.TEXT: Winterlike weather moved into the Plains, while much of the East and Midwest had rain early today. Frost and freezing warnings went up in the northern and central Plains. A snow advisory was posted in Upper Michigan, where 6 inches of snow fell by this morning at Marquette and several more inches were expected. Up to 5 inches fell across northern and eastern Wisconsin, and in Hartford, Wis., the mayor declared a state of emergency because of downed tree limbs and power lines. Major flooding continued, and a flood warning remained in place for the Red River in the border area of Arkansas, Oklahoma and Texas. Showers and thunderstorms lingered from Michigan across Wisconsin, Illinois, Iowa, Missouri, Arkansas, Kansas, Mississippi, Alabama, Georgia, Tennessee, South Carolina, North Carolina and Florida. Showers were scattered from Kansas into South Dakota. Snow, often mixed with rain, extended from northeast Wisconsin to central Upper Michigan. In parts of the upper Midwest, heavy rains Wednesday, on top of storms earlier in the spring, were credited with boosting soil moisture to near-normal levels after years of drought. ``It's dandy!'' said Veryl Schewe, a manager at the Alden Coop Elevator eight miles west of Albert Lea, Minn. ``We'll take all the moisture we can get.'' Drought problems continue in other farming regions such as the northern Plains. In Texas, several record highs were set for the date Wednesday; Austin reached 96 degrees and Brownsville 93. Today's forecast called for showers in parts of California and Nevada and snow in Wisconsin and Michigan. Rain was predicted in the Lake Michigan area, and showers changing to thundershowers were expected from New England to Florida. The nation's high Wednesday was 102 at Laredo, Texas. DOC.HEAD: Thousands Greet Mandela's Arrival In Angola
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela today arrived in Luanda where he was expected to brief Angolan leaders on recent talks with the South African government designed to pave the way for black-white power sharing. In a three-day visit, the anti-apartheid leader was also expected to thank the leaders of Angola for supporting his African National Congress in its struggle against white-minority rule in South Africa. Thousands of cheering Angolans greeted Mandela, on the first leg of a six-nation tour that will include Nigeria, Libya, Algeira, Egypt and Zambia. The black leader is making his first visit to the Southwest African nation since his release February 11 from 27 years imprisonment. Angola is one of six so-called frontline states opposed to the apartheid system of white-minority rule in South Africa. After independence from Portugal in 1975, the Marxist leaders allowed the ANC to operate bases in Angola. Since 1975 the rebel National Union for the Total Independence of Angola has fought a civil war in a bid to share power. The group, known as UNITA, was formerly supported by South Africa. But under a 1988 regional peace accord, South Africa agreed to end aid to UNITA and granted independence to Angola's southern neighbor, Namibia. Cuba also agreed to withdraw troops backing the Angolan government. Angolan President Jose Eduardo dos Santos joined the crowds awaiting Mandela at Luanda's February 4 airport. Traditional dancers lined the route from the airport. Mandela visited the tomb of Agostinho Neto, the guerrilla leader who led Angola to independence and became its first president until his death in 1979. Dos Santos presented Mandela with Angola's highest honor, the Order of Agostinho Neto, and Mandela laid a wreath on Neto's tomb. In February, South African President F.W. de Klerk ordered Mandela's release from prison and legalized the ANC, 30 years after it was banned. The measures came under de Klerk's moves toward reform of the apartheid system. De Klerk and Mandela last week agreed to work together to end political violence and clear the way for formal negotiations on a new constitution that would include South Africa's 28 million disenfranchised blacks. Mandela's arrival in Angola came one day after de Klerk began a nine-nation European tour aimed at gaining international support for his reforms.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs last graf of Philadelphia-datelined item about Sol Ruden death to explain that his service with orchestra was interrupted.
DOC.TEXT: Sol Ruden, a violinist for nearly 40 years with the Philadelphia Orchestra, died Sunday of respiratory failure at age 87. Ruden gave concerts in Budapest and Vienna and played a Town Hall recital in New York before switching to an orchestra career. Ruden was hired by the Philadelphia Orchestra in 1929. A back problem forced him to leave in 1952, when he was principal second violinist. He returned three years later as a first violinist, which he remained until his retirement in 1968.

DOC.HEAD: Analysts Debate Lawsuit's Benefit to Andrew Young
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs last graf to CORRECT that Justice Department declared unconstitutional practice of electing Superior Court, not Supreme Court, judges.
DOC.TEXT: A lawsuit to abolish runoff elections might help Andrew Young become Georgia's first black governor, but then again it might be the ``kiss of death,'' political analysts say. Twenty-seven legislators, civil rights leaders and others filed the federal lawsuit to end runoffs in most statewide and regional elections. They said Wednesday its aim is to boost black voting power, not help Young's campaign. ``This is not about candidates who are running this time,'' said state Rep. Billy McKinney. Georgia is one of nine states, eight of them in the South, that require candidates to win more than 50 percent of the vote in the primary or else face a runoff. The lawsuit, filed Tuesday, contends runoffs violate the 1965 Voting Rights Act by diluting black voting strength. The runoff requirement ``forces you to run twice to win once,'' said state Rep. Tyrone Brooks, the lead plaintiff. ``The law was enacted to deny black people access to the political process.'' It wasn't known whether the lawsuit would be settled before the July 17 primaries. No hearing was immediately scheduled. Young, former Atlanta mayor and U.N. ambassador, is the leading candidate for the Democratic primary, but recent polls give him only about 30 percent of the vote. If Young were to win the primary without having to prove himself in a runoff, he would be in ``the weakest possible position'' going into the general election, said Emory University political science professor Merle Black. ``Young would have the immediate political problem of attracting white votes. Anyone who wins the primary with only 30 percent of the vote has simply not demonstrated an ability to unite the party,'' Black said. Georgia's population is an estimated 27 percent black. Pollster Claibourne Darden called the lawsuit ``the closest thing to the kiss of death to the state Democratic Party than anything they could do,'' and said it would boost the chances of Johnny Isakson, the Republican frontrunner. Georgia has not had a GOP governor since Reconstruction. Young said he wants to win the Democratic nomination under the current rules to ensure unity against the Republican nominee. Charlie Schroder, executive director of the Democratic Party of Georgia, said he thinks the elimination of the runoff would be ``a travesty'' because candidates could win election with a small percentage of votes. ``The biggest loser in all of this is not the Democratic or Republican Party _ it's the voters of Georgia,'' he said. Alec Poitevint, chairman of the Georgia GOP, said he didn't know whether the Republicans had anything to gain from the elimination of runoffs. Lt. Gov. Zell Miller and state Sen. Roy Barnes, two of Young's Democratic opponents who are both white, said they opposed the lawsuit. ``I favor runoffs, and I believe they are constitutional,'' Miller said. ``If you read that great document you'll see in several places where a majority vote is mentioned.'' Tuesday's lawsuit is the second major federal case involving Georgia election laws. The U.S. Justice Department last month declared unconstitutional the state's method of electing some Superior Court judges.

DOC.HEAD: Rebels Urge U.N.-Sponsored Referundum in Eritrea
DOC.TEXT: Eritrean rebels today appealed for a U.N.-sponsored referendum to determine the future of Ethiopia's northernmost province. ``It is the only option to bring about a peaceful solution, and thereby ensure the basic rights of the Eritrean people to self-determination,'' rebel radio said in a clandestine broadcast monitored in Nairobi. The statement by the Eritrean People's Liberation Front said the nearly 30-year-old secessionist war was not merely Ethiopia's internal matter but a war of independence ``for which the world community will be held responsible.'' The rebels took up arms in 1962 to press for the independence of Eritrea province, a former Italian colony federated to Ethiopia in 1952 by a resolution at the United Nations. Eritrean rebels say the late Emperor Haile Selassie annexed the territory to his empire through bribery and threats to legislators, who then voted to join Ethiopia. The broadcast said the Liberation Front ``calls on the United Nations, as a representative of the world community and legitimate organ responsible for the Eritrean issue, to conduct, that is, to supervise, a referendum.'' It described as ``illegitimate'' President Mengistu Haile Mariam's proposal for autonomy as an alternative to Eritrea's independence. Last year, the Ethiopian government agreed to peace talks with the rebels but said any solution to the conflict must result in a unified Ethiopia. In two sessions of preliminary talks presided over by former President Jimmy Carter late last year, the rebels and the government agreed to enter into substantive talks with each side choosing two observers. However, the talks so far have failed to materialize because the United Nations declined observer status on the Eritrean side, saying it could not involve itself in what it considered a member state's internal problem. The rebels' appeal for the referendum came at a time when they appear to have an upper hand in the fighting. In February, the Eritreans launched their largest offensive in Africa's longest continuous civil war and captured the Red Sea port of Massawa, one of Ethiopia's two harbors.

DOC.HEAD: Uncounted Viewers Are Watching TV at Work, in Bars
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 2nd graf to CORRECT spelling of Nielsen.
DOC.TEXT: Word that hundreds of thousands of Americans watch TV at work may trouble their bosses, but it was welcome news to network executives. An A.C. Nielsen Co. study released Wednesday by ABC estimated that more than 1 million TV viewers aren't counted by current rating methods because they watch at work, in bars or other places, and not at home. ``These findings reinforce the need for improved measurement methods that accurately reflect how viewers really use television today in today's media environment,'' ABC research chief Alan Wurtzel said in a statement. The one-week study, made in November and conducted among 4,196 people, was sponsored by NBC, Nielsen, ABC and cable's ESPN sports channel. About 53 percent of the 4,196 completed the viewing diaries used in the study, ABC said. The study gave no margin of error. About 36 percent of those who completed the diaries watch TV at work, and 21 percent tune in in hotels and motels, the study said. Sixteen percent watch in bars and restaurants, 9 percent in second homes and 15 percent in ``other places.'' Nielsen, whose ratings represent 92.1 million homes with televisions, doesn't count viewers in such places as bars, hotels or college dormitories. Major networks have been losing viewers to cable, independent stations and the Fox network of 129 stations. CBS, NBC and ABC, which once had a 90 percent share of the viewing audience, last season accounted for a combined 65 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Residents Come Back to Ruins of Homes
DOC.TEXT: Residents returning to the fire-blackened Au Sable River valley were baffled by a wildfire that swept through eight miles of forest, sparing some homes but reducing others to smoking ash. The fire blackened an estimated 6,000 acres of northern Michigan and destroyed an estimated 66 homes before yielding Wednesday to firefighters and a spring storm. Yet it seemingly hopped over individual houses. ``I can't believe it took one, left one, took one,'' said Steven Horton, 34, as he stood Wednesday in the ashes of his father's house and looked at the unscathed home next door. Several miles down the road, Ed Biroth stood in his soot pile of a yard and tried to explain why his vacation house was one of the saved. Its clean aluminum siding gleamed in the blackened forest. ``It's a house on a prairie ... a big, black prairie,'' Biroth said. Norbert Szkotnicki didn't rely on chance to save his riverside home. He said he sneaked past police barricades to check on it and found part of it burning. ``I got a chain saw and cut off a (burning) corner of the cabin,'' he said. Then he joined a bucket brigade from the river up the hill to his house until firefighters arrived and saved the cabin. ``My family has been here 110 years. My grandfather built that house,'' he said. ``I wasn't going to lose it.'' The Au Sable fire, blamed on a trash or brush fire that got out of hand, cut an eight-mile path of black through the forest before dying to a smolder. An estimated 150 firefighters, foresters and National Guard soldiers battled the fire; one firefighter was treated for smoke inhalation. Crawford County officials pegged the loss at $2.4 million. A second fire 10 miles to the south charred an additional 450 acres and claimed nine homes Wednesday, authorities said. The area's year-round population is relatively sparse but grows when cabin owners visit for the summer and fall.

DOC.HEAD: Assembly Agrees to Indefinite Postponement of Membership Bid
DOC.TEXT: The World Health Organization today indefinitely deferred a bid by the PL0's self-declared State of Palestine to become a full voting member, averting the threat of a withdrawal of U.S. funds. The United Nation agency's annual assembly adopted a resolution sponsored by 28 West European, Third World and moderate Arab countries that urged WHO's director-general, Dr. Hiroshi Nakajima, to ``continue his studies'' on the membership bid and to report back ``at an appropriate time.'' By not setting a deadline, the 167-nation assembly in effect indefinitely postponed consideration of the PLO's bid. The measure also urged the health organization to continue a special health program to help Palestinians in the Israeli-occupied territories. The agreement was a diplomatic victory for the United States and a new blow for the PLO's campaign to gain universal recognition as an independent state by becoming a full member of international agencies. The PLO currently has non-voting observer status with the World Health Organization. More than 100 countries, many in the Third World, have recognized the Palestinian state declared by the PLO's parliament-in-exile in November 1988. This roughly encompasses the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. The United States, backed by most Western countries, maintains that the PLO is not entitled to full membership in U.N. organizations because it fails to meet internationally recognized criteria of statehood, including control of territory. Washington is pledged to contribute $78 million to the health organization this year, or 25 percent of the agency's regular budget. It is also a major funder of other organization programs, including the campaign against AIDS. U.S. officials said a cutoff of U.S. funds would be ``devastating,'' and Nakajima had warned that all major programs, such as the fight against tropical diseases, would have to be slashed.

DOC.HEAD: Another Hillary Conquers World's Highest Peak
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 2nd graf, `Peter Hillary...' to CORRECT spelling of mountaineer; Subs penultimate graf with 2 grafs to UPDATE with more climbers reaching summit, picking up trash left by others.
DOC.TEXT: The son of the man who first climbed Mount Everest reached the peak of the world's highest mountain today, following an American team and members of a three-nation peace climb to the crowded summit. Peter Hillary, son of mountaineer Edmund Hillary, reached the top of the 29,029-foot peak 37 years after his father and sherpa guide Tenzing Norgay pioneered the way. It was his fourth attempt. Hillary, 36, followed the traditional southeastern route first used by his father. He reached the top at 7:30 a.m. with the two leaders of an eight-member New Zealand team, their base camp reported by radio. The message said the trio was accompanied by a Nepalese sherpa guide, Apa Sherpa, 33. ``It's been a bit of a struggle over the years, but we're thrilled to bits that you're finally standing on top of the old mountain,'' Sir Edmund told Peter by satellite telephone from Auckland. Hillary said it had been a long, hard morning and he was feeling ``absolutely over the moon'' at reaching the summit. ``It's very, very cold up here. I've been having difficulty keeping some of my extremities, my hands warm so I'm going to be heading down as soon as I can,'' he said. The team aimed to return to the South Col camp, about 3,000 feet from the summit on the south side of the mountain. Most of the climbers were using oxygen. Sir Edmund was made a knight of the British Empire for his exploit four decades ago. He has retained a long association with Nepal and has led aid projects there, building schools and hospitals to improve the lives of the Sherpa people. His wife and daughter were killed in a plane crash in Nepal in 1975. Since Sir Edmund reached the summit of Mount Everest, many climbers have followed in his footsteps. Their expeditions have left behind an estimated two tons of trash, including empty oxygen bottles and cans. The summit, which can handle only about 20 climbers at a time, is sometimes nearly crowded. Minutes before the younger Hillary completed his feat today, five Americans _ three lawyers, a geologist and a mountain guide _ reached the peak, the Nepalese Tourism Ministry said. The five Americans were members of an 11-member team that also followed the traditional southeastern route. The American climbers are Peter George Alhams, a 32-year-old mountain guide from Snow Bird, Utah; Dana Quentin Coffield, a 31-year-old geologist from Columbia, S.C.; and lawyers Glenn Porzak, 41, of Boulder, Colo.; Michael Browning, 37, of Manitou Springs, Colo.; and Brent Manning, 39, of Salt Lake City. They were accompanied by two Nepalese Sherpa guides, the ministry said. Meanwhile, a Belgian Everest expedition abandoned its attempt on the same route Thursday after the regulator of an oxygen cylinder burst, the ministry said. On April 24, five members of a Nepalese army expedition climbed Everest. And three days ago, climbers from a three-nation team _ the United States, China and the Soviet Union _ scaled Everest from its northern side through Tibet. Six climbers in the fourth and last group from the expedition reached the summit today, China's official news agency reported. Included in the group was American Mark Scott Tucker. There was no hometown listed for Tucker. The climbers have been filling duffle bags with garbage left by previous expeditions and taking it back down the mountain. Expeditions from Switzerland and Australia are still on the mountain, waiting in line for a chance to reach the top.

DOC.HEAD: Defense Ministry Denies Sale of Soviet Weapons to United States
DOC.TEXT: The Defense Ministry today denied involvement in the secret sale of advanced Soviet military technology to the United States for 10 years prior to the overthrow of Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu. The Washington Post, quoting unidentified ``intelligence sources'' in Washington and abroad, reported Sunday that the program was coordinated by the Central Intelligence Agency. It said the program resulted in more than $40 million being paid to Romania through foreign middlemen and that about 20 percent of that ended up in Swiss bank accounts controlled by the Ceausescu family. In a statement carried by the state-run Rompres news agency, the Defense Ministry said some of the technology referred to in the Post article ``has never been'' in the inventory of the Romanian military. The Post said the Ceausescu connection was part of a larger weapons-buying operation that allowed the U.S. military to obtain the latest versions of Soviet made weapons and air defense systems. On Monday, The New York Times quoted unidentified current and former U.S. officials as confirming the reports. Stephen Hart, a deputy White House spokesman, has declined to discuss the report, saying: ``We don't comment on intelligence matters.'' The Post said the latest version of a Soviet antiaircraft system was among the items purchased from Romania, which also sold mobile rocket launchers and radar systems. ``The Romanian Ministry of National Defense makes it known ... that it did not know and does not know of operations like those mentioned,'' the statement said. The Romanian operation ended with Ceausescu's overthrow and execution in December, the Post reported. The newspaper said contacts in other East bloc countries had also been used in the purchase of Soviet-made weapons systems. On Monday, Hungary's Defense Ministry also denied any involvement. The Romanian statement did not mention former Deputy Defense Minister Ilie Ceausescu, one of Ceausescu's brothers, who was said in the U.S. report to be directly involved in the operation. Ilie Ceausescu, an army general, has been in custody awaiting trial for his role in attempting to put down the revolution that toppled his brother.

DOC.HEAD: Brother of American Detained in Vietnam Appeals For His Release
DOC.TEXT: An American businessman urged Vietnamese authorities today to release his brother, who has been detained in Vietnam for 18 days. Peter Morrow told reporters that his brother, Michael, a Hong Kong-based publisher, was taken into custody by Vietnamese security personnel in central Danang on April 23 and taken to Ho Chi Minh City. Morrow was traveling with a French investor, Thierry Rodzynek, who was held briefly then released. Initial reports said that two Americans were taken into custody, but the State Department confirmed only the arrest of Morrow. Peter Morrow made no mention of any other American detained with his brother. Official media in Vietnam have made no mention of the detentions. According to Peter Morrow, his brother and the Frenchman were in Vietnam investigating business opportunties in the hotel and tourist industries. The Vietnamese authorities were ``apparently very concerned with the large amount of business papers that Michael brought along with him,'' Rodzynek told reporters. It was not known if Morrow had been accused of wrongdoing. A longtime Hong Kong resident, Michael Morrow, 45, is the publisher of Petroleum News, an industry journal focusing on Asia's energy sector. He also heads Asia 2000 Ltd., a publishing house, and a trading company in Hong Kong. Michael Morrow has an association with Vietnam dating back to the Vietnam War, when he began a private news service in the country. He was captured by Communist forces during the war but was released after a short captivity. ``We urge the Vietnamese to release Michael immediately and unconditionally,'' said Peter Morrow, a businessman in Hong Kong. Both brothers are from Seattle. The authorities in Hanoi should also explain the reason for his brother's detention, and release his brother's notes and accounts, he said. Peter Morrow said his brother's Vietnamese business contacts may also have been detained. Peter Morrow said Vietnamese authorities told him his brother was in good health. Rodzynek said that while he was held with Morrow the two were ``well treated'' by the Vietnamese. The U.S. Embassy in Bangkok has applied to visit the American, according to the State Department in Washington. But an official there said an advisory against travel to Vietnam had been in effect since May 1988 ``because we cannot offer consular services and no third country represents U.S. interests in Vietnam.''

DOC.HEAD: Poland Dissolves Secret Police; Shipyard Workers Stage Protest
DOC.TEXT: The long-feared secret police force was formally dissolved today as part of a move to place law enforcement agencies under civilian control, the official PAP news agency said. Parliament had voted in April to shake up the Interior Ministry, which controls the Security Service, the secret police force known by its Polish initials SB, and the Citizens' Militia, the regular national police force. The announcement comes at a time when many Poles see the changes in their country lagging behind those in other formerly hard-line Communist East European nations such as Hungary and East Germany. In Gdansk, Lech Walesa criticized the Solidarity-led government for failing to resolve the status of the Gdansk Shipyard, where the labor movement was born nearly 10 years ago. ``I want you to know that I am ashamed of the present government, which is our government. I am ashamed because it has not yet resolved the problem of the shipyard favorably,'' the Solidarity chairman said in a letter to shipyard workers. Walesa released his letter as several hundred workers demanding pay raises staged a brief work stoppage at the shipyard in the Baltic port city. The workers shut down two departments for several hours to protest that their average monthly salary of $63 was now less than the national average of $78 a month. The workers suspended their protest pending the results of talks in Warsaw between Zbigniew Lis, chairman of the Solidarity local in the shipyard, and Minister of Industry Tadeusz Syryjczyk. Some 2,000 of the yard's 7,000 workers held a rally last month to protest the slow pace of government decisions on the fate of the state-owned facility, which was slated to be closed as unprofitable by the previous government. The current government has decided that the shipyard will be sold to shareholders under new regulations that provide for converting state-owned enterprises into private firms. Walesa's comments appeared to be part of a growing offensive to push for quicker action by the government led by Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki and other former top Solidarity activists. Walesa has criticized the government for acting too slowly in implementing reforms and removing Communists from key positions. In a brief dispatch, PAP said the government would restore civilian control over the law enforcement agencies, which in the past were organized under paramilitary lines to maintain Communist control of the society. The news agency said the Citizens' Militia was to be replaced in three months by a newly organized police force similar to those in Western countries. Members of the regular police were eligible to join the new department. Members of the secret police will continue to perform their duties until a newly created Office of State Protection starts to operate, also within three months, PAP said. The new office is supposed to limit its activities to fighting espionage and actual threats to national security. Under the former Communist regime, the secret police harassed and arrested dissidents, many of whom are now members of the parliament or government. Secret police officers hired before August 1989, when the Communists held power, must pass a review process to determine whether they abused their authority before being allowed to join the new office. The Interior Ministry, previously run by uniformed officers along paramilitary lines, is to become a smaller civilian-run organization, PAP said.

DOC.HEAD: Leading Maker of Aircraft Bolts Charged with Inspection Fraud
DOC.TEXT: A phantom ``Inspector 11'' was part of a scheme to falsify test reports by the biggest maker of aerospace fasteners and two managers over 15 years, the government has charged. A complaint filed Wednesday in U.S. District Court against VSI Corp. is the largest to date in a two-year investigation of the integrity, testing and inspection of bolts and other parts used to hold engines, wheels and other key aircraft components in place, assistant U.S. attorney Bruce D. Carter said. ``The integrity of these products is often essential to the safe operation of the aircraft on which they are installed,'' the complaint said. VSI, a Fairchild Industries Inc. subsidiary, is accused of skimping on tests and inspections, sometimes even delivering substandard parts to boost profits. Carter said an initial hearing before a federal magistrate is likely Friday. Eight previous defendants have pleaded guilty, and the investigation is continuing, he added. The probe against VSI was triggered by a complaint from whistleblower Tom Runion shortly after he left his job in the metallurgical laboratory at VSI's Voi-Shan plant in Chatsworth, Calif., Carter said. Some bolts made at the plant are intended to bear loads exceeding 200,000 pounds per square inch. Inadequate Voi-Shan parts were found during aircraft assembly and installation and were returned to the manufacturer, but investigators do not know whether others were not caught in time, Carter said. ``No accidents have been traced to Voi-Shan bolts,'' he said. Federal investigators learned that of the government and civilian buyers of Voi-Shan fasteners, The Boeing Co. and Northrop Corp. especially had been rejecting substantial deliveries after making their own tests. Boeing said in a news release Wednesday that use of Voi-Shan materials ``has not compromised the integrity of Boeing products.'' A key development in the case was a raid on Voi-Shan last year in which more than 50 boxes of test report packets stamped by a fictitious ``Inspector 11'' were seized, Carter said. James E. Ryan, a former Voi-Shan quality assurance manager, and Aram Marderian, a former metallurgical laboratory supervisor for Voi-Shan, also were named as defendants. Each faces a maximum sentence of five years in prison and a $250,000 fine if convicted. The company and managers are charged with conspiracy to commit mail fraud, to make false statements to the government and to cheat the United States. The company faces liability for false claims to the government, plus a maximum fine of twice the gross gain or loss, U.S. Attorney Mike McKay said.

DOC.HEAD: Iranian Charge d'Affaires Calls for Hostage Release
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Recasts lede to move reference to reports that Iranian hostages are dead lower in the story. Subs 7th pvs, `The longest...' with 1 graf to CORRECT Anderson's age. Pickup 8th pvs, `President Bush...'
DOC.TEXT: An Iranian diplomat said today that all hostages should be released, including four Iranians missing in Christian east Beirut. Iranian Charge d'Affaires Mohammad Jawad Zamanian, who was recently appointed to the Iranian Embassy in Beirut, talked to reporters after meeting with various leaders and politicians in the southern city of Sidon. ``As you know, we also were the victims of abduction. We know that the four Iranian diplomats are alive in east Beirut,'' he said. ``We express regret for the abductions. Our hostages and all the hostages should be released.'' The four Iranian men were seized as they traveled by car across the Christian enclave north of Beirut in July 1982 during Israel's invasion of Lebanon. They are thought to have been killed in shelling or by their captors. Iranian officials have repeatedly called for their release, and President Hashemi Rafsanjani said in October: ``If you say they are not alive, at least give us their bodies or show us their graves.'' Iran is believed to have influence over the Shiite Moslem factions holding most of the 16 Western captives in Lebanon. The hostages are six Americans, four Britons, two West Germans, two Swiss, an Italian and an Irishman. The longest held is Terry Anderson, 42, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press. He was kidnapped on March 16, 1985. President Bush has thanked Iran and its Arab ally, Syria, for helping secure the release of two American hostages, Frank Reed, 57, on April 30, and Robert Polhill, 55, on April 22. Bush also has offered to help Iran get information on the missing Iranians as a ``goodwill gesture,'' but he refused to negotiate any hostage releases. On Tuesday, Hussein Musawi, the reputed mentor of one Shiite faction, said he feared a Western captive would be killed if it was confirmed the four Iranians had been slain by their Christian captors. ``If the death of the four Iranians is ascertained, that will definitely affect the hostage issue. One of the kidnap groups might react by murdering a hostage,'' Musawi said. He said the ``positive indications'' that accompanied the release of Reed and Polhill ``have diminished.'' Musawi added: ``This issue has turned into a very complicated one because of the negative U.S. stand ... the hostage issue will be frozen for a certain period of time.'' In the past two months, a conflict has emerged in the Iranian government over the hostage issue. Leaders seeking more contact with the West have said 1990 should be the year of releasing all hostages. But radicals argue that holding hostages is a means of confronting the West, which the anti-Western faction considers a cornerstone of the 1979 Islamic Revolution.

DOC.HEAD: Hard-Core Cocaine Addiction Put at Double Official Estimate
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with details, state figures
DOC.TEXT: Nearly 2.2 million Americans are hard-core cocaine addicts, more than double the official count of those who use the drug at least once a week, according to a Senate report released today. ``This news is as alarming as it is tragic,'' Senate Judiciary Committee Chairman Joseph R. Biden, D-Del., said in a statement. ``It suggests that we have a hard-core addict problem that is far worse than virtually every previous estimate of its scope.'' Some states have ``extraordinarily high concentrations,'' with one in every 40 people in New York considered a hard-core user, according to the Senate Judiciary Committee report.
