The nation's capital has the highest per capita rate, 32.9 weekly users among every 1,000 Washington residents, the report said. The findings, prepared under the supervision of Mark A.R. Kleiman of the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University, underscored a dispute between Biden and a number of other lawmakers and the administration over whether to aim the thrust of the drug war against hard-core or casual users. Biden has said hard-core users should be the primary target, while national drug policy director William Bennett has advocated efforts directed mainly at stemming casual cocaine use. The report expressed doubt about the official findings of the National Institute on Drug Abuse's household survey, which estimated the number of Americans who use cocaine at least once a week at fewer than 900,000. ``How could fewer than 900,000 bring such havoc to a nation of 250 million?'' the report asked. The Census Bureau estimates the number of Americans at 250 million. The report's count of 2,159,000 million people who use cocaine once a week would wbe less than 1 percent of the population. The committee rounded off its estimate to 2.2 million in the executive summary of the report and in a statement distributed to the news media Thursday. Drug centers treat about 200,000 hard-core cocaine addicts each year, according to the report, which added that most who are arrested are quickly back on the street. It estimated there are approximately 55,000 homeless addicts, a number that ``does not contribute significantly to the national total'' but that was ``overlooked in the household survey.'' The report estimated that 1.5 million hard-core cocaine addicts are arrested annually and represent about 20 percent of all arrestees nationwide. ``This suggests that cocaine is a major cause of crime in the United States,'' the report said. The report estimated that New York had the most hard-core addicts, with 434,000. After that came California, 325,000; Texas, 144,000; Illinois, 142,000; and Florida, 93,000. New York had 24.4 weekly users among every 1,000 residents; Nevada 22.4; Arizona 12.7; and Illinois 12.2.

DOC.HEAD: Bensonhurst Juries Deliberate
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 3rd graf to UPDATE with juries resuming deliberations today.
DOC.TEXT: Demonstrators shouting ``No peace for racists'' surrounded, kicked and punched an attorney for a young white man being tried for murder in the death of a black teen-ager in the Bensonhurst attack. Stephen Murphy, defense lawyer for Keith Mondello, said he was not seriously hurt during the lunchtime incident Wednesday and he would not file charges if police identified his assailant. Separate juries deciding the fates of Mondello and accused triggerman Joseph Fama, both 19, did not reach a verdict Wednesday. They resumed deliberations today in state Supreme Court in Brooklyn. Fama and Mondello, both white 19-year-olds, face 25 years to life if convicted of murdering Yusuf Hawkins, 16. Hawkins was fatally shot Aug. 23 in an attack by a white mob when he went to Bensonhurst with some black friends to see a used car. The jury weighing the evidence against Mondello took a second look Wednesday at his signed, three-page statement taken by police the day after the shooting. In it, he admits organizing the mob, carrying a baseball bat and knowing that at least one person had a gun when Hawkins was shot. Murphy says police tricked Mondello into putting his name on the statement. The defense attorney said the 15 to 20 people who surrounded him on his way to a restaurant Wednesday shouted, ``Yusuf! Yusuf! No peace for racists!'' As he neared the restaurant, he said somebody kicked him in the buttocks. ``I felt the kick and, when I turned around, I was punched in the face,'' Murphy said. ``How come they're engaging in the same conduct they're accusing (the defendants) of?'' said Murphy. Plainclothes police officers closed in and escorted Murphy to lunch and back to the courthouse. Murphy has a multiracial clientele; the demonstrators' anger at him had no apparent basis beyond his involvement in the Bensonhurst case.

DOC.HEAD: Violent Protests Continue in Korea on Smaller Scale
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 8 grafs to UPDATE with street battles; Edits to trim; Pickup 5th, `The government...'
DOC.TEXT: Radical students and dissidents ignored a government warning and took to the streets again today to battle riot police in nationwide demonstrations demanding the president's resignation. Meanwhile, striking shipyard workers in a southeastern industrial city ended a 13-day holdout atop a giant crane, apparently because of illness. In scattered street protests in Seoul, groups of 200 to 500 students chanted ``Down with President Roh Tae-woo!'' Riot police moved swiftly to drive protesters off the streets. Thousands of riot police were deployed in downtown Seoul. They tightened street checks and took away pedestrians suspected of participating in clashes. Shortly before nightfall, riot troopers firing volleys of tear gas, dispersed about 1,500 students carrying firebombs who had occupied a main street in the capital's downtown. News reports said thousands of radical students armed with rocks, steel pipes and firebombs battled police today outside 40 campuses or in the streets nationwide. But details were not provided. Police did not say how many protesters were arrested today. Police arrested 1,864 protesters in Wednesday's street protests in Seoul and 16 other cities, the largest and most violent since Roh took office in February 1988. About 100,000 students and dissidents clashed with riot police in Wednesday's protests and 150 people, including 100 police, were injured. ``The government will mobilize all available resources to restore law and order,'' Justice Minister Lee Jong-nam told a televised news conference today, joined by security-related ministers. ``The government will strictly enforce laws to eradicate crimes and maintain social stability,'' said Home Minister Ahn Eung-mo, who controls the nation's 130,000 police. But student leaders, reached by telephone, said they would continue their daily anti-Roh protests. Students have demanded he annul the recent merger of his governing party with two opposition groups and speed up reform. Wednesday's protests were the largest and most violent since nationwide anti-government demonstrations forced authoritarian President Chun Doo-hwan to initiate democratic reforms in 1987 and step down. The 51 shipyard workers in southeastern Ulsan ended their 13-day holdout on top of a 240-foot crane and were admitted to a hospital for medical tests. Details were unavilable, but state radio KBS said the workers were exhausted from a hunger strike begun five days ago. The workers had climbed to the top of the crane on April 28 when 12,000 police raided their shipyard, the world's largest, to end a strike. They demanded the release of jailed union leaders. Officials of the Hyundai Heavy Industries Co. in Seoul said they planned to reopen the shipyard next week. In Seoul, thousands of radical students and dissidents rampaged through downtown streets for more than three hours late Wednesday, setting fire to a U.S. diplomatic building and firebombing police offices and vehicles. Pitched street battles lasted several hours in the city's fashionable downtown commercial districts as thousands of students, hurling rocks and firebombs, clashed with combat-clad riot police firing tear gas. Shouting, ``Yankee go home,'' the students attacked the U.S. Information Service center in central Seoul with firebombs, setting off a first-floor fire that raged out of control for two hours.

DOC.HEAD: Thornburgh Suggests Mexican Police Deliver Suspects
DOC.TEXT: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh today suggested that Mexican police deliver to American hands more of the suspects wanted in connection with the 1985 kidnapping and murder of a U.S. drug agent. Thornburgh said U.S. drug agents did nothing wrong last month when they arrested a Mexican doctor wanted in the case who was grabbed by Mexican police and whisked across the U.S. border. Asked if he would object to a repeat of last month's operation, the attorney general said: ``Whatever actions that are carried out by Mexican authorities in Mexico are of no moment to us.'' ``In fact, the more cooperation we can get the better,'' the attorney general said. Fourteen suspects wanted in connection with the kidnaping or murder are still at large, mostly in Mexico. They include the former head of the Mexican federal police and the Mexican office of Interpol, the international law enforcement agency. Mexico has refused to extradite any of the suspects, following a longstanding practice of not turning over its citizens for prosecution in this country. Thornburgh said he was more concerned about protecting the lives of American citizens overseas than about any diplomatic protests, such as the one resulting from last month's arrest of Dr. Humberto Alvarez Machain. The arrest produced a political and diplomatic furor in Mexico, where authorities accused the U.S. government of violating Mexican sovereignty. Six suspects in Mexico have been arrested in the kidnaping case. ``I place the integrity and the value of the life of American citizens No. 1,'' said Thornburgh, who discussed the case last week with Mexican authorities attending a conference in Santa Fe, N.M. ``The misunderstandings that crop up on a day-to-day basis between neighbors who are dealing with the same problem can be addressed and dealt with without sacrificing the determination to enforce the law, particularly in such a heinous crime,'' the attorney general said during a breakfast interview. ``This case has to do with the prosecution of Dr. Alvarez Machain, an individual who is charged with ... using his medical skills to keep alive an American citizen who was being tortured so that he could be tortured some more.'' Mexico filed a strong protest after Alvarez was arrested by Drug Enforcement Administration agents in El Paso, Texas, after he apparently was kidnapped in Guadalajara and flown across the U.S. border. The attorney general noted that American courts have upheld the arrest of fugitives on U.S. soil even if they were kidnapped overseas and brought to this country. ``So long as there is no conduct outside of this country by other persons that shocks the conscience of the court, how a person gets here within our jurisdiction is not a material concern,'' Thornburgh said, Thornburgh stressed that no DEA agents were involved in the operation, which he said was initiated by high-ranking Mexican police authorities. ``In an era of increased cooperation, it's my view that our people regarded this in good faith as another example of the type of cooperation that was being extended. And it's not unique,'' the attorney general said. The attorney general said he had no intention ``at this time'' of disciplining any DEA personnel because an internal investigation by that agency had found no evidence department rules were broken. Alvarez, among those charged with the torture and murder of Enrique Camarena, is now challenging the legality of his arrest in federal court in Los Angeles.

DOC.HEAD: Susan Lucci Again Nominated for Daytime Emmy Award
DOC.NOTE: Eds: No other version planned.
DOC.TEXT: ABC soap opera star Susan Lucci, always an Emmy nominee but never a winner, was nominated Thursday for her 11th Emmy in as many years as a total of 205 daytime Emmy nominations were announced here. CBS' veteran ``Guiding Light'' and ``The Young and the Restless'' led the pack with 14 nominations each, followed by 13 for ABC's ``All My Children'' in which Lucci stars and 12 for CBS' ``Pee-Wee's Playhouse.'' The nominations for the 17th annual Daytime Emmy Awards even included two for a rival awards show, NBC's ``The 6th Annual Soap Opera Awards.'' CBS shows easily lead the nominations, getting 74, followed by 39 for ABC, 30 for NBC, 29 for PBS, and 29 for syndicated programs. There only were two cable nominees. One was for a Home Box Office special, ``Buy Me That'' which warned parents and kids of deceptive advertising, and another for the lighting of an MTV special, ``Club MTV.'' Winners in the major categories will be announced here on June 28 in a two-hour ABC broadcast hosted by Oprah Winfrey. The show will be aired live in the East at 3 p.m. EDT, but shown in the West on a tape-delay basis at 2 p.m. PDT. There also will be a non-televised Emmy ceremony in Los Angeles on June 23, primarily for winners in such creative arts categories as hair design, makeup, editing, and graphics and title design. The nominations in 51 categories were jointly announced by the Los Angeles-based Academy of Television Arts and Sciences and the New York-based National Academy of Television Arts and Sciences. In the talk show field, ``The Joan Rivers Show'' and ``The Oprah Winfrey'' show each got four nominations, followed by three for Phil Donahue's ``Donahue'' and two for ``Sally Jessy Raphael.'' All are syndicated series. Geraldo Rivera's syndicated ``Geraldo'' wasn't cited, though, and the only network morning show nominated for Emmy honors was ABC's top-rated ``Good Morning America,'' which got two nominations. CBS' ``The Price Is Right'' led the game show race with six nominations, followed by the syndicated ``Jeopardy,'' which got four. Although ``Pee-Wee's Playhouse'' was the most-nominated children's series, PBS' long-running ``Sesame Street'' got nine nominations. CBS' ``Jim Henson's Muppet Babies'' and PBS' ```Mister Rogers' Neighborhood'' and ``Square One TV'' each got four.

DOC.HEAD: Business, Farm Groups Oppose Any Tax Increases
With PM-Budget
DOC.TEXT: Business and farm leaders joined several Republican members of Congress today in a plea to President Bush to keep his campaign promise against raising taxes. ``Trying to bring down the deficit by raising taxes is like giving a drunk another drink to sober him up,'' Sen. William Roth, R-Del., told a news conference. ``My president, who I believed when he said no more taxes ... is not going to raise taxes,'' said Rep. Tom DeLay, R-Texas. ``The American business community is overwhelmingly against any tax increase,'' said Richard Rahn, chief economist for the U.S. Chamber of Commerce. Grace Rice, speaking for the American Farm Bureau Federation, said farmers want to reduce the budget deficit through ``a freeze in total federal spending including agriculture, defense, Social Security and every other program except for interest on the national debt.'' Al Cors of the National Tax Limitation Committee said opposition to higher taxes is not limited to income-tax rates. ``We consider `no new taxes' to mean no new income taxes, no new corporate taxes and no new gas taxes, no new sales taxes ... no new excise taxes and no new sin taxes.''

DOC.HEAD: Faulty Valve Will Delay Columbia Launch for Weeks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 5-6 bgng `Technicians today...' with 3 grafs to UPDATE with payload doors opened this morning, other details. Pickup 7th graf, `NASA said...'
DOC.TEXT: A faulty cooling valve in need of replacement will delay space shuttle Columbia's launch two to three weeks while NASA undertakes the first such repairs ever attempted on the launch pad. Columbia had been scheduled to lift off May 16 or 17 with seven astronauts and the $100 million Astro observatory, capable of probing ultraviolet and X-ray radiation. But engineers this week spotted a problem with the valve, which controls the flow of coolant in the shuttle. ``We are obviously disappointed that we are not ready to fly,'' William Lenoir, head of NASA's space flight program, said Wednesday. ``However, this particular system is absolutely critical to the safety of the crew and overall mission success.'' The shuttle's payload bay doors were opened today and technicians began the long process of gaining access to the valve in the shuttle's payload bay. The cooling system must be drained of toxic coolant before workers on platforms can replace the valve assembly, NASA launch director Bob Sieck said. Technicians are to start draining the system late Friday, a process that involves ``the lion's share of work,'' agency spokesman Bruce Buckingham said this morning. NASA said nets would be placed over Astro, below the valve, so that its scientific instruments are not damaged. Such work has never been performed at the launch pad before. But returning Columbia to its hangar for repairs would have resulted in a considerably longer delay. ``The only unknown is how long it's going to take because we don't have any experience base,'' Sieck said. A two- to three-week delay is expected to have little impact on the rest of this year's shuttle schedule, Sieck said. Columbia's nine- to 10-day flight will be the 36th shuttle mission.

DOC.HEAD: Estonia Proposes Council of Baltic Governments
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to raise higher reference to agricultural agreement; CORRECTS spelling of Mitterrand in 8th graf. Minor editing. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Estonia today proposed establishing a council of the leaders of the three Baltic republics to coordinate policies as they seek independence from the Soviet Union, government spokesmen said. The proposal, if accepted by Baltic neighbors Latvia and Lithuania, would further integrate the republics. All three were forcibly annexed by the Soviet Union in 1940. ``So far, it's just an Estonian proposal,'' said Leivi Sher, spokesman for Estonia's Supreme Soviet, or parliament. The parliament's Executive Committee approved the measure. Also today, the three republics said they signed an agreement for the direct exchange of agricultural supplies without going through central Soviet organizations. Most transactions in the Soviet Union are channeled through central ministries or trade organizations. The Kremlin imposed a partial economic embargo on Lithuania after it declared independence. Sher said the proposed Council of Baltic States ``would decide political questions.'' Asked whether the council would constitute a confederation of the Baltic states, he said: ``It will lead to their integration.'' The proposal would revive a council that the three republics formed in 1934 when they were independent between the world wars, said Valle Feldman, a spokesman for the Estonian Foreign Ministry. It would consist of the president, prime minister and foreign minister of each republic, and could make non-binding recommendations to the three governments. Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev opposes immediate independence for the Baltic republics and imposed economic sanctions on Lithuania after it declared independence on March 11. It was unclear whether Latvia and Lithuania would agree to the proposal. Lithuanian spokesmen said no agreement was likely before the return to Vilnius next week of Lithuanian Prime Minister Kazimiera Prunskiene, in Paris as part of a tour of Western capitals. Mrs. Prunskiene told reporters in Paris that Lithuanian officials want to negotiate their independence with Moscow according to a formula proposed by French President Francois Mitterrand and Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany. They suggested that Lithuania temporarily suspend laws implementing the declaration of independence. The agricultural agreement, ``which entered into effect today, provides that each of the three ministries must have permanent representatives in the other Baltic republics, who will perform the functions of coordinators and assistants in joint efforts to resolve agricultural issues,'' the official Soviet news agency Tass reported. The establishment of direct exchanges of food and other agricultural supplies and products, and the proposed Council of Baltic Governments, signal determination by the three republics to overcome Kremlin opposition to their separatist aspirations. All three republics have been seeking independence from the Soviet Union. Following Lithuania's declaration, Latvia on May 4 declared its independence, saying it would take effect after an unspecified transition period. On Tuesday, Estonia dropped the trappings of Soviet power _ including its flag and name _ invoked sections of the 1938 constitution that declared independence, and proclaimed solidarity with Latvia and Lithuania. Gorbachev has not responded to the Estonian actions and is said to be studying Latvia's actions.

DOC.HEAD: Last of PTL Defendants Pleads Guilty
DOC.TEXT: John Wesley Fletcher, the last of six defendants to come to court on federal charges in the PTL scandal, has pleaded guilty to a single perjury count. Fletcher was accused of lying to a grand jury about his bringing Jessica Hahn to Florida to meet Jim Bakker for the sexual encounter that led to the downfall of the PTL television ministry. Fletcher entered his plea Tuesday in an unpublicized session at U.S. District Court in Charlotte. U.S. District Judge Robert Potter accepted the plea but did not set a sentencing date. Fletcher, who was a frequent guest on the jailed Bakker's ``PTL Club'' television show, was indicted in December. According to the indictment, Fletcher denied during a September 1987 appearance before the grand jury that he brought Miss Hahn to a hotel to have sex with Bakker. Testifying later, he admitted sex was the purpose of the meeting, according to the indictment. Fletcher, 50, is free on $25,000 unsecured bond. Late last month, he was released from the Butner Federal Correctional Institution, where he underwent a lengthy psychiatric evaluation. In his order releasing Fletcher, U.S. Magistrate Paul Taylor said Butner official Deborah Poe informed him that the evaluation was completed. ``Ms. Poe had advised that there is nothing in the report of Mr. Fletcher's evaluation indicating that he would be a danger to himself or the community,'' Taylor wrote in his April 25 order. Fletcher is believed to be living in the Durham area. Under the plea agreement, Potter said he could sentence Fletcher to a reduced term of eight to 14 months in prison. Fletcher had faced five years and a $250,000 fine. Bakker is serving a 45-year prison sentence in Minnesota. He was convicted of 24 counts of fraud and conspiracy in October; he is appealing the conviction. Former PTL executive vice president Richard Dortch is serving a 30-month sentence on related charges; former Bakker aides David and James Taggart are serving long terms for federal income tax evasion. Perjury charges against former PTL pastor Sam Johnson were dropped.

DOC.HEAD: FCC Gives New York Company Permission to Operate Pocket-Sized Telephone
DOC.TEXT: The Federal Communications Commission said today it has given a New York company permission to operate a new type of pocket-sized telephone in Houston and Orlando, Fla., that proponents claim could replace traditional wire or cellular phone service. The new system, known as personal communications networks, will be built by PCN American Inc. Millicom. It will use high-frequency microwave signals to connect telephones over short distances, such as in office buildings or neighborhoods. Like existing cellular telephones, the new service will be able to ``pass off'' phone calls as users move from one transmitter area to another. And because the range of the devices _ as little as 600 feet _ is short compared with cellular phones, many more conversations can be crammed onto existing microwave channels without causing interference. This large-capacity feature is expected to make the devices popular and drive down their costs. Officials at American Personal Communications Inc., which earlier this year received FCC permission to test the new type of phones in the Washington area, told The Washington Post they hoped the phones ultimately would cost $50 to $75. ``I fundamentally believe that PCNs are going to be the first serious means of competition for local communications,'' an AT&T official, Richard B. Snyder, was quoted as saying in today's New York Times. Millicom told the newspaper it would spend $20 million to build a 25,000-subscriber system in Houston and a 20,000-subscriber system in Orlando.. Both systems are expected to begin operating in two years. Cellular phones use a few large radio towers to transmit calls across what are known as ``cells.'' The equipment automatically passes off calls as a caller in an automobile, for instance, passes from cell to cell. The new PCN system will rely on refrigerator-sized, low-power transmitters that will transmit across a more limited area. Millicom told the Times it would transmit calls from one transmitter to the next, rather than connecting with the local telephone system. At least one regional Bell company, BellSouth, is interested in the new technology and plans to apply for permit to develop it if the Millicom experiment succeeds and regional or municipal licenses are issued, the Times said. The British government already has selected three consortiums to build nationwide PCN systems in Britain. One company, Cable and Wireless PLC, has predicted the costs for the service will be only slightly more than for today's wired phone calls.

DOC.HEAD: Highest Floodwaters in 47 Years in Arkansas; Farmers Blame Army Corps
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with governor's aide saying corps reviewing flood management, rivers receding slowly; CLARIFY that Clinton's comments aimed mainly at management of Red River sted Red and Arkansas rivers; ADD background on corps. Picks up 7th graf pvs, `If it...'. SUBS 15-18th grafs, `On the Texas...', with 5 grafs to UPDATE situation in northeastern Texas, river stage at Pine Bluff. Picks up 19th graf pvs, `Some bitter...'.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto XPB1
DOC.TEXT: The Army Corps of Engineers will take steps to lower river levels in flood-battered southwestern Arkansas, an aide to Gov. Bill Clinton said today. In the central part of the state, water levels were slowly receding after cresting at the highest point in 47 years. ``We've been notified by the corps that they are going to try to reduce the flow,'' said Mike Gauldin, Clinton's press secretary. ``They are making a complete new assessment,'' Gauldin said. ``They're sending people down to southwest Arkansas today and they're going to reduce the flow over the next day or so.'' Heavy rain and flooding along the Trinity, Arkansas and Red rivers in the past two weeks have claimed 13 lives, one in Oklahoma and the rest in Texas. As the bulge of water has moved downstream to the east and south, the worst of the flooding has shifted from north-central Texas and Oklahoma to Arkansas and northeastern Texas. Flooding was also affecting parts of northern Louisiana. Thousands of cattle were stranded and crops flooded out in Arkansas, and some homeowners shot at joy-riding boaters roiling the water. At a meeting with angry farmers in Ashdown, Ark., on Wednesday, Clinton said a task force should look at corps management of the Red River in the state's southwest border. Some farmers also criticized the corps activities on the Arkansas River, which runs diagonally through the state from northwest to southeast. Decisions made by the Corps of Engineers on how fast to release water from the reservoirs it manages can have a crucial effect on who is flooded, and how severely. A quick release of water after a heavy rain increases flooding downstream, while slower release can mean more flooding upstream. Appearing on ABC's ``Nightline'' Wednesday with Brig. Gen. Robert C. Lee, the regional corps commander, Clinton said southwestern Arkansas residents ``feel that maybe the corps could be holding some more water back. The levees have broken there in places, in other places, there's no opportunity even to put the sandbags up.'' If it proves impossible to hold some of the water at dams upstream, he said, ``we're going to lose several thousand head of cattle and maybe the opportunity to plant rice and soybeans in this season.'' Red River valley farmers said the corps should have released more water from reservoirs during the winter. ``They hold the water when the water should be let out, and when they need to be able to hold the water in the spring when we have these big rains, they're turning it out,'' said Paul Hawkins, whose 3,000 acres were under water. The area's wheat was three weeks from harvest, farmers said. Lee defended the Engineers' procedures. If not for the corps' efforts, he said, ``the water would be eight feet deeper now than it is.'' Diana Hinton, a trailer park owner, said Red River levees had been neglected and were unable to hold back floodwaters. ``Why aren't these levees being upkept?'' she asked. ``I just lost a trailer park, and these people are losing their land and their cattle.'' About 15,000 head of cattle were stranded in flood waters with no way to get them to higher ground or to feed them, said Judge Clyde Wright, administrator of Little River County. On the Texas side of the Red River, the state was using a helicopter to feed about 1,000 stranded cattle. The corps brought 30,000 sandbags to shore up levees along the Texas side of the river on Wednesday, where about 200 people have been evacuated from rural areas north of Texarkana. Water earlier broke through the top of a 60-foot-long levee section. Jane Mueller, dispatcher for the Texarkana Office of Emergency Services, said officials believe the Red River crested at 32.13 feet at 1 a.m. today. By 6 a.m., the water level had dropped to 32.06 feet, seven feet above flood stage. In Arkansas, Joe Brady of the Office of Emergency Services said damage to the state's roads and bridges was at least $10 million. Officials said they hadn't yet calculated damage to agriculture and other property. The Federal Emergency Management Agency planned to set up 200 telephone lines to take calls from those seeking disaster aid. In Pine Bluff, floodwaters crested Wednesday morning at 47.5 feet, the highest level since 1943, when they reached 52.1 feet. The water dropped to just under 47 feet by this morning, but about 300 homes remained flooded, officials said. Some bitter homeowners fired shots at anglers taking advantage of the flood to fish for bass, crappie and catfish drawn to insects flushed out by the rising water, said Boe Fontaine, a sheriff's lieutenant outside Pine Bluff. ``These boats go by and make a wake, and it wakes into the house,'' Fontaine said. ``People are hot enough right now that they get around too close and somebody's liable to take a shot at them, and it happened today.'' Health officials warned that mosquitoes carrying the encephalitis virus were hatching in swamped Dallas neighborhoods, which are starting to dry out after the Trinity River crested there last week. Some residents of Dallas' Rochester Park neighborhood returned home. Hundreds of houses in the poor neighborhood were inundated by the worst flooding in more than 70 years. City officials promised to build a new levee by 1993 to shelter the area, but William Andrews, pastor of the Independent Missionary Baptist Church, said he can't understand why the levee hasn't been built before now. ``It's been dirty year after year. I don't know what they're waiting on,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Ground Victims of Pan Am Lockerbie Crash Reach Settlement
DOC.TEXT: Ground victims of the terrorist bombing of Pan Am's Flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland, have reached a settlement with the airline, an attorney for the victims said today. All 259 passengers and crew aboard the plane were killed when the jet plowed into the quiet Scottish town Dec. 21, 1988. Eleven people on the ground were killed, a dozen others were injured and many homes were damaged or destroyed. About 250 Lockerbie familes filed claims in Dade Circuit Court because two Pan Am subsidiaries have headquarters here, said Miami attorney Aaron Podhurst. ``It was negotiated over a period of time, and it just culminated this week,'' said Podhurst, who represents the Lockerbie Air Disaster Committee. Under the agreement he was prevented from releasing any details, he said. New York-based Pan Am spokesman Jeffrey Kreindler acknowledged a settlement but also said he could not discuss its terms. The agreement doesn't affect lawsuits filed by the families of those aboard the plane, Podhurst said. Some of those suits also were filed in Miami, but the majority are in federal court in New York. The passenger claims are covered by international agreements and are limited to $75,000 unless victims can prove gross negligence. Pan Am agreed that the Lockerbie ground victims were covered by Scottish law, which Podhurst said had no limit. A Scottish investigation into the crash is to be completed in September and probably will be the basis for settling the passenger claims, Podhurst said. Flight 103 was flying from London to New York when a bomb went off in the luggage hold. Investigations indicated a bomb may have been placed inside a radio in baggage put aboard the flight in Frankfurt, West Germany. The luggage was transferred to the Pan Am Boeing 747 in London, and it exploded over Lockerbie shortly after takeoff. U.S. authorities acknowledged they had received an alert about a possible attack on a Pan Am airliner and had even warned diplomatic personnel to avoid using the carrier. The Lockerbie suits charged Pan Am ``had actual and constructive knowledge'' that Flight 103 ``was subject to a specific and known danger of terrorist or other criminal or wrongful activities.'' Pan Am's Miami subsidiaries, Pan Am World Services and Alert Management Systems, were accused of failing to provide adequate security for the flight.

DOC.HEAD: Consumer Groups Say Government OK No Guarantee of Product Safety
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS 4 grafs after 5th graf pvs, ``There is... to UPDATE with drug manufacturers statements; picks up 6th graf pvs, The study...
DOC.TEXT: A government stamp of approval is no guarantee a product is safe, so manufacturers should not be exempt from punishment when an approved product causes death or injury, consumer advocates said today. Four national consumer groups reported that more than 1,300 deaths and thousands of serious injuries in the last 10 years resulted from the use of drugs and medical devices approved by the Food and Drug Administration. The report was issued as the Senate Commerce consumer subcommittee held its third hearing on federal product liability legislation backed by the Bush administration. The legislation includes a provision to exempt from punitive damages in product liability cases those manufacturers whose products received premarket approval from the FDA or the Federal Aviation Administration. ``There is no principled basis, nor is there a need, to shield manufacturers from punitive damages just because they have complied with government standards,'' the report said. However, drug manufacturers argued today that under the proposed legislation, injured victims would be protected and research and marketing of potentially life-saving drugs would be speeded. ``This defense would not prevent full compensation from being awarded to injured persons,'' said Richard Kingham, an attorney representing the Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association. ``There is documented evidence that liability concerns ... about punitive damages have caused manufacturers to withdraw beneficial drugs from the market,'' Kingham said. ``This is a disincentive to safety,'' he added. The study was issued jointly by Consumers Union, Public Citizen, U.S. Public Interest Research Group and the Consumer Federation of America. It cited several cases in which FDA-approved drugs and devices caused deaths or life-threatening and permanent injuries. ``It is documentation of the failures of the FDA,'' said Pam Gilbert, legislative director for Public Citizen's Congress Watch. The report said regulatory delays are one reason agency approval should not be used as an excuse for corporate liability. It said that although strong evidence linked Reye's Syndrome, a rare and often fatal disease, to the use of aspirin to treat chicken pox and flu in children, it was four years before the government required warning labels. ``In those four years, approximately 3,000 children developed Reye's Syndrome, about 1,000 children died and many of the surviving children suffered brain damage,'' the report said. The consumer groups also cited the FDA's approval of the sedative Versed, used in short diagnostic surgical procedures, as a sign that flaws in the regulatory process make the agency unreliable. ``Several serious flaws in the approval process and subsequent monitoring of Versed resulted in 40 deaths from cardiac or respiratory depression in patients using the drug in the United States,'' the report said. Business and industry representatives argue the liability exception should be included in the bill because regulatory agencies have more expertise than the courts to set and measure product standards. ``Allowing the courts to second-guess regulatory standards may result in unjustified imposition of liability,'' Robert C. Holland, president of the Committee on Economic Development, told an earlier hearing by the subcommittee. The CED is a research organization representing top business executives and presidents of several major universities.

DOC.HEAD: Workers Stage Demonstrations Nationwide Demanding Protection
LaserPhoto BER1
DOC.TEXT: Tens of thousands of East German workers put down their tools, closed classrooms and blocked borders Thursday to demand protection from the high unemployment that is expected to be the price of German unification. The protests by teachers, textile workers and farmers were called by unions and lasted only a few hours. They were timed to coincide with a Parliament discusstion with West Germany. ``We want to prevent the initiation of the monetary union from causing the social deterioration of our work force,'' Sigrid Jauernig, head of the textile workers union, told the government news agency ADN. The protests were the latest and largest demonstrations of anxiety by a work force worried about what will happen July 2, when the Germanys are to merge their economies and social institutions. After the protests, Parliament Secretary Guenther Krause said discussions would begin next week with the 600,000-member farmworkers union and eventually all labor organizations, ADN said. The Germanys have been negotiating on the draft of a state treaty under which East Germany's economy and social structure would be absorbed by the West in six weeks. Economists predict many inefficient East German factories will close in the next year because they will not be able to compete in the free market, and that between 500,000 and 2 million East German workers will lose their jobs. Both West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl and East German Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere say a quick influx of Western investment will create new jobs and raise East German living standards. The left-leaning Social Democrats, the junior partner in de Maiziere's governing coalition, are pressing de Maiziere to push for more social guarantees for East Germans dependent on heavy subsidies under the old socialist system. Joblessness already has begun rising. On Wednesday, the government said the number of people who registered for unemployment rose from 38,313 in March to 64,948 last month. The head of East Germany's Association for the Unemployed, Klaus Grehn, criticized the government's official jobless figure, saying the ``real amount'' is ``significantly higher.'' Grehn predicted that 600,000 workers will lose their jobs this summer, with the biggest losses likely to come in the contruction and textile industries. In Bonn, West Germany, Kohl said Thursday that East Germany must restructure its beleaguered economy before the two nations share the same West German currency. Kohl also renewed his demand that East Germany be prepared to start dismantling its 41-year-old system of state ownership if economic union with West Germany is going to be a success. ``Enormous efforts stand before us,'' he said. Thousands of teachers held two- to four-hour warning strikes Thursday morning in East Berlin, Frankfurt an der Oder, Magdeburg, Neubrandenburg, Hohenschoenhausen, Rostock, and several other cities, ADN said. About 2,000 kindergarten, primary school and college teachers marched through East Berlin to the Parliament building. They demanded job and benefits security. Highways linking major East and West German cities were blocked by convoys of dilapidated tractors and farm trucks for 10 minutes to an hour. The blockade was the third in the past two weeks. The farmworkers are fearful of job losses from Western competition and the transition of state-owned land to the private sector. Thousands of leather and textile workers in Leipzig, Dresden, Chemnitz, Cottbus, Erfurt and other industrial cities shut off their machines for an hour to call attention to their fear of Western imports, ADN said. Several thousand shoe and textile workers rallied in East Berlin's main square, Alexanderplatz. East Germans have been buying better-made Western imports since the borders between the nations were opened in November, after the Communist regime was ousted.

DOC.HEAD: Snow Blankets Wisconsin, Spring May Return Monday
DOC.TEXT: The worst spring snowstorm on record blanketed much of Wisconsin today, creating hazardous conditions for stunned motorists, closing schools, and downing power wires and trees. The storm, packing heavy snow, gusty winds and sleet, came two days after temperatures peaked in the high 70s throughout much of the state. It caught most municipal officials by surprise; most winter road equipment had been placed in storage. The National Weather Service issued a winter storm warning for eastern Wisconsin, forecasting snow totals as high as 8 inches in areas north and west of Milwaukee. ``Until the weather lets up and the winds die down, it's not safe to be outdoors,'' said Hartford Mayor Dean Kirley, who declared a state of emergency in his city of 7,000 located 30 miles northwest of Milwaukee. Kirley said Hartford had about 6 to 8 inches on the ground by midmorning. ``We've felt the brunt of it. I've asked the citizens to stay off the streets and sidewalks,'' he said, noting that downed wires and icy roads made conditions hazardous. The storm, spun off from a massive low pressure system centered over the Upper Peninsula of Michigan, began Wednesday with soaking rains. Many areas of Wisconsin reported more than 2 inches of rain by midnight. The storm's approach dropped temperatures in Milwaukee from the mid-60s Wednesday to 33 degrees at 9 a.m. today, creating a mixture of heavy snow, sleet and some rain. The wet snow weighed down tree branches covered with leaves, increasing the damage to trees and power lines. Weather Service specialist Edmond Lowe said the accumulation was not the latest snowfall ever recorded in Wisconsin but did set a record for the heaviest spring snow accumulation. To the south, in Illinois, the storm system brought up to 4 inches of rain in the Chicago suburbs and snow flurries and sleet at O'Hare International Airport.

DOC.HEAD: Three Killed as Kurdish Guerrillas Attack Train
DOC.TEXT: Suspected Kurdish guerrillas attacked a freight train in the eastern province of Bingol, setting it on fire and killing three people, the Anatolia News Agency reported Thursday. The dispatch said the attack occured Wednesday night. Five guerrillas built a barricade on the railway to halt the train. They forced the driver and two other workers out of the train and shot them, then fled after setting the train on fire, Anatolia said. Kurdish guerrillas have killed 14 people in attacks in southeastern Turkey over the past week. The guerrillas belong to the Kurdish Labor Party, a Marxist group fighting since 1984 to establish an independent nation in Turkey's southeastern provinces.

DOC.HEAD: Dozens Dead in Mine Fire
DOC.TEXT: A coal mine fire caused dozens of deaths in northeastern China this week, the official Xinhua News Agency reported Thursday. The brief report gave no specific casualty figure and did not say if the fire, which broke out Tuesday morning, had been extinguished. It said the cause was still under investigation. The fire occurred at the Xiaohengshan Colliery in Heilongjiang province in China's northeast. The exact location of the mine was not given. It was the second serious mine accident in Heilongjiang in a month. Thirty people were killed and 11 injured April 15 when an explosion occurred in the Taoshan Colliery. Most Chinese coal mines lack modern equipment and safety provisions. Official figures indicated that about 1,780 miners were killed in accidents in 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Sentences 12 Drug Smugglers to Death
DOC.TEXT: A judge Thursday sentenced 12 drug dealers to death for smuggling into Egypt and distributing 10 tons of hashish and 858 pounds of opium, the Middle East News Agency reported. Judge Gamal Abdel-Halim of the Cairo Criminal Court sentenced another five defendants to life imprisonment. He gave one defendant a five-year prison term and sentenced two others to three years in prison. Ten defendants were acquitted.

DOC.HEAD: Kohl Presses East Germans on Economic Reforms
With AM-East Germany, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Chancellor Helmut Kohl on Thursday warned that East Germany must restructure its beleaguered economy if it wants to get the powerful West German mark. In a three-hour parliamentary debate, Kohl also reiterated that he wants the question of a united Germany's military attachments cleared up before the two nations actually merge. Kohl pressed East Germany for greater flexibility in bargaining over the merger of their economies, planned by July 2. Parliament was debating problems facing the unity process. He said there must be an overall agreement on restructuring the East German economy before East Germany can replace its weak currency with the West German mark. ``It is for me self-evident that the currency conversion stands in indissoluble connection with total agreement'' on economic union, Kohl said. The two German nations have reached basic agreement on terms for replacing East Germany's currency with the deutsche mark but are divided on some key elements of overall economic union. Kohl renewed his demand that East Germany be prepared to start dismantling its 41-year-old system of state ownership if economic union with West Germany is going to be a success. ``Enormous efforts stand before us,'' Kohl said. ``Of course this concerns foremostly the budget of East Germany, which ... can and must put to use the so-called peoples-owned property,'' he added. West German officials have said private ownership of property and industry is crucial to creating a market economy that could spawn jobs and incomes in East Germany. Kohl reiterated his discomfort over a Soviet suggestion that German unity could come before all the international military complexities are worked out. The Soviet Union opposes NATO membership for a united Germany, but Bonn and its NATO allies say Germany's membership in the western alliance is crucial. West Germany wants ``both processes to proceed ... in unison with each other, and in close consultation with our partners and allies,'' Kohl said. Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze suggested last week the external aspects of unification _ such as a united Germany's military attachments _ would not have to be settled before the merger actually occurred. He proposed that the four World War II victors _ the Soviet Union, the United States, Britain and France _ retain some of their special postwar rights for a transition period after unity. Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher, who initially greeted Shevardnadze's idea as a means of speeding up the unification process, changed his tone during Thursday's debate. ``The German people are entitled to German unity, and are also entitled to having the external aspects of unity cleared up without delay,'' Genscher said. Genscher said an ``understanding'' should be reached over the ``external aspects of German unification'' before this fall. But he did not say when he thought all the special rights of the four World War II allies should be actually stripped away. Genscher also said the West must ensure the Soviet Union is allowed to play ``an important and constructive role in Europe's future. Europe does not end at the Polish border.''

The last three shows are syndicated.

DOC.HEAD: Detroit Symphony Orchestra Executive Resigns
DOC.TEXT: The executive director of the Detroit Symphony Orchestra who helped stabilize its bleak finances has resigned to become president of the Minnesota Orchestral Association. Deborah Borda, 40, who joined the Detroit Symphony in January 1989 when it was struggling with a $10-million deficit, said Wednesday she will leave Aug. 1. ``This is a challenge I am eager to undertake, but I am also very proud of what I have done in Detroit,'' she said. Borda and orchestra Chairman Robert Miller are credited with helping to raise $8 million from corporations in emergency funds, winning wage concessions from the musicians, moving the DSO to Orchestra Hall and hiring Conductor Neeme Jarvi. Also, ticket sales increased by 45 percent since the two arrived in Detroit about the same time. Jarvi said he was shocked by Borda's resignation. ``It's bad, very bad news,'' Jarvi said. ``Now we have to find a person to start from zero to continue that which she has started.'' But Miller said the resignation will not hamper plans to improve finances.

DOC.HEAD: Democrats Angered at Bush Aide's `No Taxes' Statement
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Combines pvs; edits at end to tighten; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: The White House today disavowed comments by a senior administration official ruling out tax hikes at the upcoming budget summit and said President Bush assured congressional leaders nothing was off the bargaining table. Presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said the remarks, widely understood to be by White House Chief of Staff John Sununu, did not reflect Bush's position and that the official did not speak for the president. The official was quoted as saying that the White House would say ``no'' to any tax increases proposed by Democrats at the upcoming budget summit. ``That's crazy,'' declared Fitzwater. Fitzwater said Bush called House Speaker Thomas S. Foley this morning to assure him he had not changed his position. Meanwhile, Bush came under fire from congressional Democrats for failing to make his position clear on the issue of higher taxes. ``It is time for the president to speak,'' said Rep. Robert Torricelli, D-N.J. ``What is it that he would bring forward? The president waits, but the nation deserves to hear.'' Although administration aides have asserted that negotiations to get under way next Tuesday would have ``no preconditions,'' Bush himself has not yet spoken out on whether he will accept a tax increase as part of a deficit-cutting package. Democratic skepticism toward the summit appeared to grow today after a ``senior administration official'' was quoted in today's editions of The Washington Post and The Washington Times as suggesting the White House would reject any attempt by Democrats to propose a tax increase. The official was identified as speaking on a plane from Costa Rica to Washington with Barbara Bush and White House Chief of Staff John Sununu. The official was further described as ``the main White House link to conservatives.'' Sununu, who is generally viewed as conservatives' main pipeline into the White House, was the only senior White House official on Mrs. Bush's plane. Other passengers on the plane said that Sununu was the speaker. The official was quoted as saying: ``We're allowing them (Democrats) to bring their good arguments for taxes to the table. ... They were not persuasive last time and are likely not to be persuasive again.'' ``But if they want to come to the table and say they put (tax increases) there, it is their prerogative to put them on the table, and it's our prerogative to say no. And I emphasize the no.'' The comments appeared to contradict earlier White House assertions that nothing was off the table on budget talks, including taxes. Fitzwater, while not willing to state publicly that the speaker was Sununu, said that the official was not speaking for the president. ``I speak for the president. It's as simple as that,'' he declared. The spokesman said he had spoken to Bush directly today and was told by the president that ``his position is no preconditions.'' As to the fact that Sununu is one of the White House negotiators in the budget talks, Fitzwater said: ``The president is the chief negotiator. He will be responsible for all the negotiations. Period.'' Rep. Charles Schumer, D-N.Y., said that whether the remarks on the plane were by ``John Sununu or someone else, we have a message to the whole White House ... Don't worry _ Democrats will not put taxes on the table.'' ``After all, it was the White House that called the summit, the president that called the summit. It's up to the president to tell us, one, what the crisis is and number two, what he intends to do about it,'' Schumer added. Torricelli said: ``We have heard from his press spokesman, we have heard from his political aides, we have heard from his consultants, but the American people have not heard from the president of the United States.'' Many Democrats have voiced suspicion that Bush's call for a budget summit was a trap to draw them into supporting an election-year tax hike. House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., while saying he won't question Bush's motives, put a top critic of Bush's tax policies in charge of their negotiating team seeking a deficit-reduction pact with the White House. House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo., will serve as chairman of the talks and will preside except when Bush himself is in the room, Foley said Wednesday. White House officials say that _ without action _ the federal deficit could be up to $100 billion higher than the $64 billion shortfall allowed by law. The president has proposed a $1.23 trillion budget for the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1. Failure to cut the deficit could force huge domestic and military spending cuts under the Gramm-Rudman budget-balancing law that neither party wants, and the Democrats quickly agreed to the talks. But there is no clear path to agreement on spending restraint and new revenue sources to avert the cuts.

DOC.HEAD: Mohawk Chiefs Ask Governor To Help Set Up Tribal Police Force
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 5 grafs to UPDATE with raid today. Picks up in 2nd graf pvs, `The three ...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto XMAS1
DOC.TEXT: Police launched an early morning raid today on the Canadian side of this troubled reservation, arresting 21 people on weapons and drug charges and confiscating about $1 million in drugs. The raid by 100 officers from three Canadian police forces culminated a 14-month investigation; hundreds of police officers stationed on the reservation because of recent violence helped in making the arrests, according to Peter West, a spokesman for the Ontario Provincial Police. Police had planned to make the raid earlier, but were ``delayed by the unrest on the reserve,'' West said. Police also raided homes in the city of Cornwall, just outside the Ontario portion of the reservation, West said. The reservation is also split between Quebec province and New York state. The drug raid is the latest police action on this reservation that has been occupied by a force of several hundred police from Canada and the U.S. Police sealed off the reservation to outsiders after a Mohawk gambling war claimed two lives on May 1. The three chiefs governing the U.S. side of the St. Regis Indian Reservation, which straddles the U.S.-Canadian border, sent a letter Wednesday asking Cuomo to help set up a tribal police squad. Cuomo last week proposed the creation of a Mohawk police force for the 28,000-acre reservation, where two Indians were shot to death May 1. ``We welcome your positive approach and appreciate your offer of assistance as we attempt to bring order back into the daily lives of our Mohawk people,'' read the letter from chiefs Harold Tarbell, L. David Jacobs and Lincoln White. Cuomo's response to 10 months of sporadic violence involving opponents and backers of gambling on the reservation drew fire Wednesday from a member of another Iroquois tribe who quit the governor's Humanities Council. ``You are, in effect, urging the Mohawks to give up their sovereignty,'' Onondaga Indian Nancy Johnson said in her resignation letter to Cuomo. ``Such unrealistic paternal advice will only further escalate violence.'' Cuomo appointed Johnson to the panel in 1986. The letter asking Cuomo to maintain a state police presence in what many Mohawks consider an independent territory was an unusual sign of harmony among the three chiefs. Jacobs and White support reservation gambling as an economic boon, while head chief Tarbell says the casinos are destroying the Mohawk way of life. Tarbell is up for election June 2 for a second three-year term. Pro-gambling Mohawks hope to unite on a candidate to oppose him, said Melvin White, who is a nephew of Lincoln White and who organized a meeting for that purpose Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Pro-Abortion Patrick Kennedy Disinvited From Speech at Catholic School
DOC.TEXT: The Roman Catholic Diocese of Providence ordered a church high school to cancel a speech by state Rep. Patrick Kennedy because the Democrat supports a woman's right to seek an abortion. The 22-year-old son of Sen. Edward Kennedy said he had no intention of discussing abortion during his talk, but diocesan officials told officials at Prout Memorial High School in South Kingston to find another speaker for last Sunday's mother-daughter breakfast. ``I felt it would be inappropriate that he speak,'' Brother Daniel F. Casey, diocesan school superintendent, said. ``His position runs opposite to what the school is teaching.'' Casey was quoted in Thursday's editions of The Providence Journal-Bulletin. A parent who helped organize the breakfast said Kennedy was invited to speak because ``he's young, he's aggressive and he's a Kennedy,'' not because of his stance on abortion. ``He just seemed to be a great choice,'' said Edward H. Torgen, an attorney whose wife, Mary Ann, headed the committee that organized the event. Kennedy, who is Catholic, said he was angry. ``I understand that the church is being very careful about who is invited to speak at these things. But I think the manner in which it was handled obviously was disturbing. I don't think anybody likes being disinvited.'' Kennedy said he had intended to use his speech to encourage students to ``become active in their communities and make a difference.'' Casey said he learned that Kennedy was to speak through a newspaper notice. He checked and found out that Kennedy supported abortion rights, then told Prout administrators to withdraw the invitation. However, word did not reach Kennedy's office until Friday, two days before the breakfast. Deborah Thompson, co-founder of Dorcas Place, a Providence school that helps the illiterate, spoke in Kennedy's place. Torgen said few of the 120 people who attended the breakfast complained about Kennedy's absence. The flap came almost a year after Kennedy's father had a similar experience in Rhode Island. The St. Vincent de Paul Society, a Catholic organization, canceled the Massachusetts senator's appearance at its annual meeting in Providence when abortion opponents threatened to picket.

DOC.HEAD: House Votes to Guarantee Workers Unpaid Leave in Emergencies
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs.
DOC.TEXT: The House voted today to guarantee workers up to three months of unpaid leave in family emergencies, ignoring a White House threat to veto the bill. The House voted 237-187 to approve the bill after turning back opponents' efforts to send it back to committee. The bill now goes to the Senate. The bill requires business and government employers to provide workers with up to 12 weeks of unpaid medical leave or for the care of a new or ill child, parent or spouse. It exempts small businesses with fewer than 50 workers, and drops earlier language setting various periods of leave for workers with different emergencies. The vote, while a victory for supporters, was short of what would be needed to override a presidential veto. Though the bill had bipartisan support and the backing of the House Democratic leadership, more than 50 Democrats voted against it. Approval came as opponents withdrew a series of amendments, and after a 259-167 vote to adopt a substitute measure sponsors said was a compromise aimed at drawing more support to the measure. The bill, strongly opposed by the Bush administration, faces an uncertain future in the Senate. The Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee approved a similar measure more than a year ago, but sponsors have not yet scheduled floor action and none is expected before Memorial Day. Supporters of the measure pointed to President Bush's own campaign rhetoric. Opponents charged the measure would be costly and burdensome for small businesses. Rep. Bill Green of New York, a liberal Republican who supports the measure, quoted from remarks Bush made as a presidential candidate and said he seemed to be supporting just such a measure then. Green said Bush told a Republican women's group in September 1988: ``We need to assure that women don't have to worry about getting their jobs back after having a child or caring for a child during a serious illness. That is what I mean when I talk about a gentler nation.'' White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said Tuesday that the president wants employers to offer guaranteed job-protected leave but opposes any bill requiring periods of leave. ``Let me note he used the word `assure','' Green said, referring to Bush's campaign speech. ``He didn't say we should urge employers to do it.'' Green said the only to assure such leaves is by legislation. One opponent, Rep. Barbara Vucanovich, R-Nev., charged today that the bill ``would erode the very basis of democracy'' by ordering businesses to offer a particular benefit. She said it would actually hurt women by encouraging employers not to hire or promote them. ``This is a wolf in sheep's clothing'' she said. ``Many have attempted to mislead Congress by calling it a pro-family, pro-woman bill. It is anything but that.'' Rep. James Quillen, R-Tenn., said it would reduce employers' flexibility in offering benefits to employees and ``do serious damage to many small businesses.'' Several supporters argued that most Western nations already require time off for workers with new children or other family needs, and many provide for leave with full or partial pay. The increasing role of women in the workforce makes such protections important for families, they said. The bill is the second dealing with family concerns that the White House has threatened to veto this year, and Democrats hoped to contrast that record in an election year with Bush's public support for family values. A conference committee has been named to work out House and Senate differences on a broader bill designed to help families find and afford child care, which also is under a veto threat. Under the family leave bill, employers would have to continue health insurance benefits for those on leave and restore a returning employee to his or her previous job or an equivalent position. Women's groups supporting the bill contend that workers, particularly women, suffer substantial earnings losses after the birth of a child or during illnesses because many can't return to their jobs at the same pay. Business groups, including the U.S. Chamber of Commerce, oppose the bill, saying it would be costly to employers and hurt productivity. Although the measure requires employers to offer only unpaid leave, some opponents were concerned it could lead to later legislation requiring paid leave or other benefits.

DOC.HEAD: `Nameless' Abortion Protesters Released From Jail
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf bgng `McHugh vowed...' with 2 grafs to UPDATE with protest today. Pickup 5th graf, `The 95 ...'
DOC.TEXT: The leader of 95 anti-abortion protesters who spent up to 11 weeks behind bars for refusing to identify themselves after their arrest vowed more protests today upon the group's release from jail. The protesters finally agreed to give their names Wednesday and were promptly freed. Under an agreement with the state, they were found guilty of trespassing and sentenced to the amount of time they had already served. ``They wanted to break us,'' said the Rev. Michael McHugh, leader of the local anti-abortion movement. ``They didn't do it.'' Fifty to 60 protesters knelt in prayer and sang hymns this morning on the sidewalk in front of the Planned Parenthood office in Burlington. Other protests were scheduled for later today, McHugh said. ``If they come on our property, we'll take legal action against them,'' Rachel Atkins, spokeswoman for the Vermont Women's Health Center in Burlington, said today. The 95 demonstrators were arrested in a series of sit-ins at two Burlington clinics from Feb. 21 to April 17. Most were charged with unlawful trespass, punishable by up to 90 days in jail. District Judge Matthew Katz jailed them without bail because they insisted on giving their names as ``Baby Jane Doe'' and ``Baby John Doe'' to represent the fetuses not allowed to come to term. Katz ruled those ``monikers'' did not constitute identification. The demonstrators had been jailed for up to 78 days, about a week more than they probably would have been held if they they been tried and convicted. The standoff ended with an agreement between Edward Sutton, deputy state's attorney, and Daniel Lynch, a lawyer for the protesters. The protesters gave their names, addresses and birth dates and let themselves be fingerprinted and photographed, then signed a statement agreeing to the basic facts of their cases, Sutton said. ``We're very happy to be out in our freedom,'' said Joan Andrews, a national leader of the anti-abortion movement who was jailed 78 days. ``Maybe in the next weeks some children will be saved because of us.'' Lynch said the protesters accepted the deal because the state did not assess fines or probation as conditions of release, did not force the protesters to plead guilty and released them all at once. Eight of the 95 protesters were from Vermont; the rest were from all over the country. ``It's a tremendous victory,'' Lynch said. ``Mission accomplished.''

DOC.HEAD: `Milk and Honey' Playwright Don Appell Dies
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to CORRECT name of hospital
DOC.TEXT: Don Appell, who wrote the 1961 musical comedy, ``Milk and Honey'' and other plays and acted and directed on Broadway, has died at age 73. He died Friday of heart failure and pneumonia at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. Besides ``Milk and Honey,'' about Americans in Israel, Appell wrote ``Lullaby'' and ``A Girl Could Get Lucky.'' A native New Yorker, Appell began his acting career at age 12 in summer stock theater. He appeared in Broadway in ``Odyssey,'' ``Native Son'' and ``Tapestry in Gray.'' Among the Broadway productions directed by Appell were ``Dr. Social,'' ``Career Angel'' and his own play, ``This, Too, Shall Pass.'' He also directed many television productions in New York and Los Angeles. There were no immediate survivors.

DOC.HEAD: $1 Million Bequest Happy Burden for Small Town
DOC.TEXT: Madonna Mae Morgan didn't make much of an impact on this small northwest Kansas town during her life, but she has been the main topic of discussion since her death in March. Mrs. Morgan's will left the city an estimated $1 million. But the gift came with strings attached _ the town of about 2,300 must raise a matching amount within two years and use the money to build a community center. Mrs. Morgan, 88, was not well-known in the town, and the bequest caught nearly everyone by surprise. ``We were absolutely stunned at first,'' said City Administrator Jerry Fear. ``But everybody decided it was just too much money to pass up. Not many communities have this type of opportunity.'' Mrs. Morgan died March 4 at a nursing home. She and her late husband, Robert, had amassed their estate by investing in farmland. The couple had no children. ``Everyone knew Bob, but hardly anyone knew her,'' said Mrs. Morgan's sister-in-law, Laura Dechert. ``She was a dear, sweet lady but she was quiet.'' Mrs. Morgan was born in Illinois and spent most of her life in northwest Kansas, where her husband was a postal carrier in Seldon. They moved to Oberlin after he retired in 1962. Mrs. Dechert said Mrs. Morgan ``sort of gave up'' after her husband died in 1983 and spent a lot of time indoors before going to the nursing home. Mrs. Dechert took care of Mrs. Morgan for seven years and now lives in the Morgans' home. Not even her sister-in-law knows why Mrs. Morgan left the money to Oberlin. ``I was a little disappointed because I think she could have done more good by spreading it around a little. I think it put Oberlin in kind of a bind,'' she said. The will stipulates that construction on the municipal auditorium must begin within two years after Mrs. Morgan's death. That is March 4, 1992. Mrs. Morgan's attorney, Kenneth Clark of Hill City, said the town had talked about a municipal auditorium. Mrs. Morgan thought it was a good idea to have such a building, which townspeople envision as a place for agricultural events and entertainment that also could have offices, a kitchen, meeting rooms and an indoor pool. ``She figured if she was willing to give them most of their estate, they would be willing to match it,'' Clark said. ``And she put the two-year deadline on it because she was a lady who liked to get things done.'' The exact amount of money involved will not be known until the Morgans' farms are sold and other bequests are paid. But attorneys and city officials estimate Oberlin will have to raise about $1 million. If Oberlin doesn't raise the money, it will go to the Shrine Burn Center in Galveston, Texas, a beneficiary of the Masonic Lodge that Morgan belonged to. The town has set aside $60,000 to study the issue and plans to pursue state, federal and arts foundation grants. Fear said a bond issue would be a last resort to raise money, but ``the local community is going to have to support it somehow.'' ``This is a town willing to take a risk,'' said Mayor Idella Frickey. ``It is a town that gets things done. And I think we'll get this thing done, too.'' In a time when many small farming communities are struggling, this town nestled in the short-grass prairie 380 miles west of Kansas City and 230 miles east of Denver appears to be thriving. The red brick streets wind through a town with a strong business community and several new homes. A $2.5 million renovation of the hospital and nursing home was recently completed. The city also runs its own carnival and theater. Local investors have helped start private enterprises, such as boat and bus factories. Frickey says she is sure conflicts will arise over plans for the building. But she and Fear acknowledge it is a pleasant burden. ``How many small towns in this part of the country wouldn't like to have a $1 million gift?'' Fear asked. ``We're sure not going to give it up without a fight.''

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING to ADD byline
Frank Releases Letter from Landlady
DOC.TEXT: Rep. Barney Frank was ``stunned'' to discover that his Capitol Hill home was being used by a male prostitute to sell sex, according to a letter written by Frank's former landlady and released Thursday. Frank released the letter in response to comments by a female prostitute who said the Massachusetts Democrat knew that Stephen Gobie was running a prostitution ring from the apartment. The House ethics committee is investigating Frank's relationship with Gobie. The female prostitute insisted that Frank knew his residence doubled as a brothel. The woman, who said she sold sexual services from Frank's apartment along with Gobie, reportedly is telling her story to the committee. Frank said the woman's statements, which first appeared in the March issue of Penthouse magazine, ``are complete lies, fabricated stories about events which did not happen.'' The former landlady, Mary Jo Daugherty, gave her sworn statement Oct. 25 to the ethics committee, officially the Committee on Standards of Official Conduct. She said she became aware in the summer of 1987 that different women _ and, on one occasion, men _ would visit Gobie at Frank's residence. ``Until this type of activity began to occur, it never dawned on me that prostitution might be taking place,'' she said, noting that Frank had moved into the basement apartment in 1983. ``I called Congressman Frank and reported what I had observed,'' Mrs. Daugherty said. ``He seemed stunned. I never saw Gobie again.'' She said ``none of the activities'' occurred when Frank was present. ``It is my strong belief, based on my knowledge of both Congressman Frank and Mr. Gobie, that Gobie took advantage of Congressman Frank and had begun to misuse the apartment without Congressman Frank's knowledge or permission,'' she told the committee. Frank, a homosexual, has admitted that he paid Gobie for sex when they first met. However, Frank said he later hired Gobie as a personal aide in an effort to turn Gobie's life around. Gobie has said Frank knew sex was being sold from the apartment. The investigation has proved troubling to the committee, as members grapple with incidents involving personal behavior. Some committee members reportedly are holding out for a recommendation that Frank be punished on grounds he discredited the House. Rep. William Dannemeyer, R-Calif., has promised to introduce a resolution to expel Frank _ a move that would force at least a procedural vote. Frank, first elected in 1980, has announced he's running for re-election.

DOC.HEAD: House Sends Gun Waiting Period Bill to Connecticut Governor
DOC.TEXT: Connecticut residents would have to wait two weeks before buying any gun so that authorities could conduct criminal background checks under a bill approved by the Legislature. A national gun-control group pushing a similar bill at the federal level called the Connecticut vote Wednesday an important, ``common-sense'' victory. But anti-gun-control forces said bill would do nothing to keep firearms out of the hands of criminals. Earlier this year, California became the first state to enact a waiting-period law. Gov. William A. O'Neill, a gun owner whose administration recently put up $25 million in state pension funds to save Colt's Manufacturing Co., a Hartford-based gun maker, has said he would sign the bill if it passed. It would probably be at least a week before the paperwork reaches O'Neill's desk, gubernatorial spokesman Jon Sandberg said Thursday. Current Connecticut law requires a waiting period for handguns only. The 76-66 vote in the House of Representatives came after more than 2{ hours of debate. ``In no way does this impede or restrict a law-abiding citizen from obtaining a weapon,'' said Rep. Joseph S. Raia, a city police officer who marshaled support for the bill. Others said the measure infringed on the constitutionally protected right to keep and bear arms. Opponents failed to attach several amendments that would have weakened the bill. Exempted from the waiting-period requirements are police officers, members of the armed services and anyone who has a pistol permit or hunting license. ``Today, in a state where many of America's guns are made, the Legislature showed that common sense can prevail,'' said Sarah Brady, chair of Handgun Control Inc. Susan Misiora, lobbyist for the National Rifle Association, said the bill would do nothing to keep guns out of the hands of criminals. ``Criminals just don't go to gun stores,'' Misiora said, adding that a waiting period implies that ``you're guilty until proven innocent.''
