DOC.HEAD: NATO Sees Diminished Need For Nuclear Artillery
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with final statement saying need for battlefield nuclear weapons diminished. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: The United States and its NATO allies agreed today there is a ``diminishing need'' for battlefield nuclear weapons in its alliance arsenal given the recent political changes in Eastern Europe. NATO also welcomed the prospect of early negotiations with the Soviet Union on cutting short-range nuclear missile forces. The 14 defense ministers of the NATO's Nuclear Planning Group also called on the Soviet Union to make ``substantial reductions'' unilaterally in its short-range nuclear missile systems. The statement came as the group wrapped up its two-day session in Kananaskis at a Rocky Mountain ski resort. The alliance's statement follows President Bush's recent decision to cancel the development of new tactical nuclear missiles and artillery systems designed for deployment by the NATO allies. The alliance statement did not address calls by the Dutch and West Germans for unilateral NATO withdrawal of its hundreds of aging nuclear artillery shells, which are designed to be shot on European battlefields at very close range in the event of an overwhelming Warsaw Pact conventional attack. ``Given the political and military changes now taking place in Central and Eastern Europe, together with the prospect of early signature and implementation of a Conventional Forces in Europe treaty, we agreed that there is a diminishing need for nuclear systems of the shortest range,'' it said. The alliance ministers welcomed Bush's decision to cancel the planned update of nuclear weaponry and said it ``demonstrates once again the ability of the alliance to take the initiative in a rapidly changing situation.'' The alliance ministers said they welcomed ``the prospect of early negotiations between the United States and the Soviet Union on short-range nuclear missile systems and emphasized the importance of consultation within the alliance on the development of objectives for these negotiations.'' While the alliance members agreed on the need to cut NATO's short-range nuclear arsenal, they left decisions on how deep those reductions should be to the leaders of the NATO summit nations who will meet in London in early July. The alliance ministers said that they recognized that a lessening need for short-range nuclear weapons means ``relatively greater importance'' on sub-strategic nuclear weapons that offer ``both flexibility and longer range.'' This appeared to be a reference to an alliance interest to shift a greater reliance on air-launched nuclear weapons, which are already based in Europe and slated for upgrading sometime during this decade. The ministers said they wanted their aides as well to step up work on a lengthy study of how to best reduce the alliance's nuclear stockpile amid the rapidly changing political and military environment in Europe. It was the pact's first evaluation of its nuclear weapons strategy since the dramatic upheavals in Eastern Europe and the withering of their once-strong adversary, the Warsaw Pact. ``There is scope for reductions,'' Britain's defense chief Tom King said of the tactical nuclear weapons. ``I think there is general agreement on that.'' There are some 1,600 aging nuclear-tipped artillery shells based in West Germany, Greece, Italy, the Netherlands and Turkey. They are designed to be shot at very close range to halt an overwhelming advance of Warsaw Pact tanks and other conventional forces. It isn't known how many short-range artillery shells the Soviets possess. Generally, the Soviets have relied more on missiles in their tactical arsenal. But with the recent pro-democracy revolutions in Eastern Europe and the steps being taken toward German unification, the artillery is seen as increasingly irrelevant to some NATO governments and their constituents.

DOC.HEAD: Precede DURANGO
Pope Speaks Out Against Contraception
LaserPhoto XDUR2,3
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with pope reiterating his opposition to contraceptives. TRIMS to tighten. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Pope John Paul II, taking issue with this populous nation's family planning program, told Mexicans today that it is wrong to use contraceptives. ``If, in the conjugal union, the possibility of conceiving a child is artificially eliminated, the couple closed themselves to God and opposed his will,'' John Paul admonished a crowd of more than 100,000 people on the fifth day of his eight day Mexican trip. The crowd at the prayer service included thousands of U.S. residents who traveled to Chihuahua, 220 miles south of El Paso, Texas. Thousands more were expected an an afternoon Mass in Monterrey, 100 miles southwest of Laredo, Texas. The pontiff spoke from a platform on a wide soccer field, with the bare, craggy peaks of the Sierra Madre in the background. John Paul, in his homily, reiterated standard Roman Catholic church policy against artificial birth control, but his message had clear political implications in Mexico, where the government has encouraged the use of contraceptives in order to limit a mushrooming population of 85 million. John Paul also paid tribute to Mexican women during the ceremony, held on the date Latin Americans celebrate Mother's Day. On Wednesday night in Durango, John Paul gave a stern lecture to a group of wealthy businessmen. He said the poor have been hit hardest by Mexico's economic crisis, while the rich have helped create even more poverty through greed. Mexico, ``despite the inherent resources that the Creator gave this country, is still very far from the ideal of justice,'' the pope said Wednesday, noting the vast contrast between the rich few and the poor majority. Business must create more jobs, pay fair salaries and protect the environment, the pontiff said in the address delivered at a theater in Durango, 450 miles northwest of Mexico City. The speech followed an emotional visit to a nearby prison, during which the pope mixed with inmates in an unscheduled visit to the prison yard for 20 minutes.

DOC.HEAD: Religious Coalition Seeks Rehearing on Drug Case
DOC.TEXT: An unusual coalition of religious groups asked the Supreme Court on Thursday to reconsider its decision letting states outlaw the use of illegal drugs as a religious practice. ``I seriously doubt these groups have ever been in the same room together, much less have ever joined in so important an undertaking,'' Oliver Thomas of the Baptist Joint Committee on Public Affairs told reporters. The April 17 high court ruling said members of the Native American Church had no constitutional right to take the hallucinogenic drug peyote during religious ceremonies. Officials from the American Jewish Congress, the National Association of Evangelicals and the National Council of Churches also participated in a news conference held after the petition for rehearing was filed with the court. Others supporting the petition included the Presbyterian Church USA, Luthern Church Missouri Synod, American Friends Service Committee, Americans United for Separation of Church and State and the Christian Legal Society. Religious leaders were more disturbed by the court's method of deciding the case than by the decision's bottom line. Five members of 6-3 court majority agreed that religious beliefs cannot excuse failure to comply with ``otherwise valid laws prohibiting conduct states are free to regulate.'' Departing from a long series of prior cases, the court did not require states to have a ``compelling reason'' before forcing someone to comply with laws interfering with religious beliefs. The court's new reasoning, said Robert P. Dugan Jr. of the National Association of Evangelicals, ``effected a sea change in freedom-of-religion law.'' Henry Siegman of the American Jewish Congress said that if the decision remains, ``all Americans ... will have reason to feel less free and more vulnerable under our Constitution.'' The court rarely grants requests for reconsideration, and Thomas acknowledged Thursday's move was ``a long shot.'' ``Nevertheless, it is our only shot,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Study Says Arms Collaboration May Undermine U.S. Security
DOC.TEXT: The United States may be mortgaging its future defenses by not limiting collaboration with allied nations in high-tech weapons development, according to a congressional study released Thursday. Such collaboration makes business sense for the companies involved but may ultimately make the United States too dependent on foreign suppliers and erode parts of the U.S. defense industrial base, said the study by the Office of Technology Assessment, a nonpartisan analytical agency of the Congress. More joint weapons projects with European or Japanese companies will mean less business for all but the largest American defense companies, the study said. ``The United States could end up with a defense industrial structure inadequate for the defense of the nation,'' it said. The study added, on the other hand, that erosion of U.S. defense industries may not be a security risk because the United States may need less weapon-making capacity as the Cold War winds down and East-West arms cuts are implemented. Even so, the trend toward greater U.S.-European collaboration is casting doubt on America's long-held commitment to global superiority in weapons technology, the study said. Traditionally the United States has kept this edge by focusing on military applications for new technologies, with little regard for possible civilian uses. Now, as defense industry competition heats up in the post-Cold War period, the focus of multinational defense collaboration will be on dual-use technologies, it said. This ``might ultimately undermine the position of the United States as a military superpower _ because dual-use technologies would be available to many nations,'' the study said. ``In time, the U.S. military position might degenerate to the status of first among equals.'' The study quoted an unidentified high-ranking military officer as saying, ``If we want to stay a superpower, we will invest to be ahead of the world in next-generation systems. ... Otherwise, we are co-developing and therefore not leading. We lose the superpower label.'' Sen. Jeff Bingaman, D-N.M., chairman of the Armed Services subcommittee on defense industry and technology, took a different view, saying more U.S. emphasis on dual-use technologies would help the domestic industry survive leaner times. ``In light of the declining defense budgets of the 1990s, we may need to concentrate more of our cooperation both with our European allies and especially with Japan on dual-use technology ... rather than full-scale weapons systems,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: WHO Defers PLO Bid to Become Voting Member
DOC.TEXT: The World Health Organization indefinitely postponed a decision on whether to admit the PLO's State of Palestine as a full voting member, thus averting the threat of a withdrawal of U.S. funds. The U.N. agency's annual assembly adopted by consensus a resolution sponsored by 28 West European, Third World and Arab countries. The resolution called on WHO Director-General Dr. Hiroshi Nakajima to ``continue his studies'' on the Palestinian membership bid and report back ``at an appropriate time.'' By not setting a deadline, the 167-nation assembly indefinitely postponed consideration of the Palestine Liberation Organization's application. The measure also called on WHO to continue a special health program to help the 1.7 million Palestinians in the Israeli-occupied Gaza Strip and the West Bank. John Bolton, U.S. assistant secretary of state for international organization affairs, said he hoped the decision would end attempts to politicize WHO. ``WHO should return to life and death issues such as controlling AIDS, helping to develop a vaccine against malaria ... and fostering health care everywhere,'' he told delegates. The PLO has been campaigning to gain recognition as an independent state by becoming a full member of U.N. organizations. It currently has non-voting observer status with WHO. But Dr. Fathi Arafat, head of the Palestinian delegation and brother of PLO leader Yasser Arafat, said he did not see the decision as a rejection of the membership bid. He said the PLO would not give up its campaign for membership in international organizations. More than 100 countries, many in the Third World, have recognized the ``State of Palestine'' declared by the PLO's parliament-in-exile in November 1988. The United States, backed by most Western countries, maintains the PLO is not entitled to full membership in U.N. organizations because it does not meet internationally recognized criteria of statehood, such as control of territory. Washington has pledged $78 million to WHO this year, or 25 percent of the agency's budget. It is also a major sponsor of WHO programs outside the regular budget, including the campaign against AIDS. U.S. officials said a U.S. funds cutoff would be ``devastating,'' and WHO chief Nakajima had warned that all major programs such as the fight against tropical diseases would have to be slashed. Nakajima said he was ``extremely pleased''with the outcome of the session. In 1989, fears of a withdrawal of U.S. financing prompted a WHO assembly to defer a decision until this year on the PLO bid. Diplomats said fears of the U.S. aid cutoff prompted Thursday's decision as well. The assembly called on WHO to continue its ``special technical assistance to improve the health conditions of the Palestinian people in the occupied territories.'' Nakajima said the program budget was $18 million over two years. A report to the assembly by a special committee cited high infant mortality rates and poor health care facilities in the Israeli-occupied territories. ``The incidence and prevalence of chronic diseases such as anaemia among pregnant women and children are increasing significantly,'' it said. ``Mental diseases are presenting increasingly serious problems on account of the increase in violence in the region.'' The report is to be discussed later in the meeting, which began Monday and runs for two weeks.

Plane Crash Kills 26 People in Mexico
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with 26 dead, details on flight, many of victims headed to see the pope. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Pope
DOC.TEXT: A twin-engine plane crashed today as it tried to land in this southeastern city, killing 26 of the 38 people on board, the manager of the airline said. Most were headed to see the pope. The plane crashed this morning nearly two miles short of a runway at Military Air Base No. 6 on the outskirts of Tuxtla Gutierrez, Miguel Angel Guadarrama, manager of Aviacion de Chiapas, S.A., said. ``There were 38 people on board, including the crew, and 12 of them survived. The rest died. Many of the passengers, in fact most of them, were government officials,'' Guadarrama said in a telephone interview. The medical condition of the survivors was not immediately known. An unconfirmed report said a Roman Catholic bishop was among the fatalities. An earlier television report said that about 28 people had died. Guadarrama said the cause of the crash was under investigation. Live television coverage from the scene showed a badly charred wreck with twisted propellers scattered in a field. Soldiers surrounded it, keeping back several hundred onlookers. Despite the security, the live broadcast showed looting of luggage scattered by the crash. The plane, a propeller driven F-27 Fokker made in Holland, was on a scheduled run from Tapachula, on the border with Guatemala. Officials said many of the government people were coming for Pope John Paul's visit to Tuxtla Gutierrez, the capital of Chiapas state, on Friday. Aviacion de Chiapas, or Avicsa, is a regional commercial airline that operates in southeastern Mexico and uses the military base. The pope will be traveling through the Tuxtla Gutierrez municipal airport. The government news agency Notimex quoted an unidentified source at the Roman Catholic archdiocese in Chiapas as saying that among those killed was Tuxtla Gutierrez Bishop Luis Miguel Canton Marin. However, Guadarrama said he did not have a complete passenger list and could not immediately confirm the report. The plane can carry up to 44 passengers and a crew of four.

DOC.HEAD: Private Colleges Provide $2.3 Billion in Student Aid
DOC.TEXT: Student financial aid provided by private colleges to attract low-income and minority students more than doubled from 1970 to 1987, an association of the schools said Thursday. But Richard Rosser, president of the National Institute of Independent Colleges and Universities, said such aid cannot continue to grow at that pace without the colleges jeopardizing ``their own financial health and commitments to other areas of need.'' An institute study, entitled ``A Commitment to Access,'' said that independent colleges and universities provided $2.34 billion from their own resources for financial assistance to undergraduate students in the 1987-88 school year, a 102 percent increase, adjusted for inflation, over 1970-71. ``The federal government's commitment to providing student financial assistance, especially in the form of grants, must be strengthened if low-income and middle-income students are going to be allowed the choice of an education best suited for them. The independent sector cannot do it alone,'' he said. More than three-quarters of the growth occurred since the 1980-81 school year, the study said, estimating that the figure reached $2.626 billion in 1988-89. In the 1975-76 school year, federal aid was almost 3{ times the aid provided by the institutions themselves, Rosser said, adding that ``independent colleges and universities now provide more grant assistance to undergraduates than all federal student aid grants combined.'' Federal aid, he said, now focuses on the ``truly needy'' with little help for students from middle-class families. The schools also provide little aid to middle-class students. More than 85 percent of the aid provided by private colleges in 1987-88, $2 billion, was awarded as grants and scholarships. Other aid was offered as loans and work-study grants. In the 1986-87 term, expenses for a typical private-college student receiving aid averaged $10,300 for tuition, fees, room and board. An average of $7,300 was provided in financial aid, grants, loans and work-study, leaving the student out-of-pocket expenses of about $3,000. The study said that on average 59 percent of all undergraduates attending independent colleges and universities received some form of institutionally provided aid in 1987-88, up from 44 percentin 1970-71. To finance increased student aid, Rosser said, private colleges are often forced to keep faculty salaries low, defer maintenance and cut back on purchases of library material and science equipment.

DOC.HEAD: Kurosawa's ``Dreams'' Opens Cannes Festival
DOC.TEXT: Stars from around the world gathered Thursday for the 43rd annual Cannes Film Festival, but the man of the hour was 80-year-old Japanese director Akira Kurosawa. His new film, ``Dreams,'' provided a dignified and imaginative opening for 12 days of partying, salesmanship and awards-giving in the seaside city. Based on Kurosawa's dreams, the film is eight separate segments, including one in which a filmmaker confronts Vincent Van Gogh in a wheat field, and another about mountain climbers facing death in a blizzard. ``Dreams'' is not among the 19 films competing for the coveted top prize, the Golden Palm. This year's entries include offerings from the Societ Union, Poland, Czechoslovakia, China, Burkina Faso, Great Britain and Italy. A preview of ``Dreams'' was held in the afternoon. The 10-member jury that will choose the winner of the Golden Palm is headed by Italian director Bernardo Bertolucci and includes American actress Anjelica Huston, French actress Fanny Ardant, and English screenwriter Christopher Hampton, who wrote the English adaptation of ``Liaisons Dangereuses.'' American offerings in competition for the Golden Palm include Clint Eastwood's ``White Hunter, Black Heart,'' based on John Huston's filming of ``African Queen'' in 1952; David Lynch's ``Wild at Heart,'' and an American production by English director Alan Parker, ``Come See the Paradise.'' The French are offering four films, including Jean-Paul Rappeneau's ``Cyrano de Bergerac,'' starring Gerard Depardieu and ``New Wave,'' starring Alain Delon and directed by Jean-Luc Godard. But it was ``Dreams'' that created the stir. At a news conference after the preview, Kurosawa said he had been inspired to write down his dreams by a Dostoevski passage ``in which the author said dreams revealed men's deepest thoughts, liberated in sleep.'' He then decided to make a film about his dreams, but he left out three of his best ``because technically they were too difficult, or expensive enough to bankrupt the producer.'' While some dreams had a nightmare quality, others were beautiful, such as one concerning the director in an imaginary encounter with Van Gogh, played by Martin Scorsese. Akira Terao was lauded for his interpretation of a younger Kurosawa. ``I was trembling at doing the different parts,'' he said. ``But Mr. Kurosawa told me to just `be natural,' and then I felt better. While being natural is difficult, it gave me reassurance nonetheless.'' Kurosawa fielded questions about his film with aplomb. ``I think none of my many films has more than two or three moments of pure cinema,'' said the director of ``The Seven Samurai'' and ``Ran,'' and winner of a special award at this year's Oscar ceremony in Hollywood. ``I wanted to have more moments of pure and perfect cinema with `Dreams,' but while I did my best, I don't think I got much more than those two or three moments.'' ``Which were they?'' asked a reporter. ``That's for you to decide,'' said Kurosawa.

DOC.HEAD: Greenspan Outlines Proposal for Banking Reform
DOC.TEXT: Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan on Thursday outlined the central bank's ideas for reforming the nation's financial system, including charging banks with risky investments more for their deposit insurance. In his first extensive public remarks on deposit insurance reform, Greenspan told a Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago conference that the issue ``should be high on our agenda'' as Congress and the Bush administration consider permitting banks to expand into securities and insurance. Among the specific reforms he suggested were varying deposit insurance premiums according to the riskiness of a bank's investments, more frequently examining banks' books, more swiftly seizing weak banks and requiring bank owners to risk more of their own money. Greenspan did not address such proposals as cutting back on the $100,000 per-account insurance, limiting insurance to one account, imposing a ``deductible'' on the insurance or finding a way to allow large banks to fail without endangering the system. ``He is proceeding gingerly ... but in the chairman are the seeds of a most radical reform of our existing financial system,'' said Kenneth A. Guenther, executive vice president of the Independent Bankers Association of America, which represents smaller banks wary of deposit insurance changes. The Treasury Department is due to release its banking reform plan by February. Greenspan is expected to be a major influence in that plan's development and in congressional debate on the issue next year. Greenspan appeared to reject the notion of simply doing away with deposit insurance and other safeguards, which some free-market conservatives advocate. ``The United States has not suffered a financial panic or systemic bank run in the last 50 years. In large part this reflects the safety net,'' he said. But the protection comes at a cost, he said. Three parts of the safety net pose a ``moral hazard'' for bankers by allowing them to shift some of the risks of their actions onto the public. They are deposit insurance, the ability of banks to borrow at low rates in emergencies from the Fed's discount window and banks' access the Fed's electronic payments wire, which guarantees payments between banks. Reform of the safety net, Greenspan said, should be considered in tandem with expanding bank powers. Offering banks no new powers likely would cause commercial banking to shrink in relationship to the rest of the financial system. That, in turn, ``may create systemic risk similar to that faced in earlier years.'' Bank owners now risk about six cents of every dollar they lend. However, Greenspan noted that in the 1800s, before the creation of deposit insurance and the discount window, bankers risked 25 cents to 50 cents for every dollar they loaned. That encouraged them to use more caution. A text of Greenspan's speech, delivered at the Chicago Fed's Annual Conference on Bank Structure and Competition, was released in Washington.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Britain's Prince Charles and Princess Diana on Thursday ended their first visit to a Warsaw Pact country by viewing Budapest from a boat on the Danube and taking a streetcar ride through the city center. The royal couple delighted Hungarians and made front-page news. During a speech Tuesday, Charles was full of praise for Hungary's pioneering role in Eastern Europe's transformation. His wife drew admiration for her charm, her smiles and her elegant clothes. About 2,000 people crowded a square adjoining the Danube to greet the prince and princess after their streetcar ride. Costumed folk dancers delivered a traditional send-off. ``After so many hard years, only now that I see them here on the streets of Budapest and see everyone freely expressing their enthusiasm do I really believe that things have changed,'' said Emilia Imredi, a 68-year-old pensioner.

An obsessed fan who allegedly broke into the home of actress Sharon Gless wrote numerous love letters to her for years, Gless testified. The Emmy-award winning star of the television show ``Cagney and Lacey,'' said she dismissed the letters because they contained no threats. Miss Gless testified Wednesday at a preliminary hearing for Joni Leigh Penn in San Fernando Municipal Court on a burglary charge. Police say Penn, 30, was carrying a semiautomatic assault rifle and nearly 500 rounds of ammunition March 30 when she barricaded herself in Gless' home for seven hours. Police say she planned to sexually assault Gless and then commit suicide. She is being held without bail. In a similar case, a federal judge declined to dismiss charges against a man accused of sending threatening letters to ``Remington Steele'' TV actress Stephanie Zimbalist. Michael Lawrence Shields, 42, of Plymouth, Mich., contended his case should be thrown out because he was examined by a prosecution psychiatrist without a court order. The judge instead barred prosecutors from using the psychiatric report.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: A longer version moving on sports wires.
DOC.TEXT: Milwaukee Brewers infielder Gary Sheffield says verbally abusive police put a gun to his head during a confrontation in which New York Mets pitcher Dwight Gooden tried to intervene. The same two baseball players got into a brawl with officers in 1986, resulting in probation for Gooden for resisting arrest and battery. That incident brought Tampa's police harsh scrutiny after Gooden, who is black, charged racial discrimination. Sheffield said police stopped him and a friend outside a nightspot March 14, and Gooden, who was driving behind them, tried to intervene. Sheffield is Gooden's nephew. ``I said, `I'm Gary Sheffield and I'm a professional ballplayer.' They said, `I don't care who you are, you're driving a dope dealer's car,' and they threw me up against the car.'' Sheffield and his friend Chuck Jones said they filed complaints with the police internal affairs bureau. Police on Thursday cited confidentiality laws and refused to say whether a complaint had been filed. ``My complaint was, `I've been harassed too much, and my life was in danger,''' Sheffield said, according to Thursday's St. Petersburg Times. It remained unclear what may have led police to mistake Sheffield's black Mercedes-Benz for a drug dealer's car. Deputy Police Chief Tom DePolis refused to say whether Sheffield and Gooden were involved in a confrontation with his officers. Gooden had no comment, said his agent, Jim Neader.

Columbia Pictures Television has offered a record $32 million to keep writers Ron Leavitt and Michael Moye, who write the comedy series ``Married ... With Children,'' a newspaper reported Thursday. The writers are considering a three-year contract renewal that includes a significant share of syndication profits from ``Married,'' the Los Angeles Times reported. Their contract with Columbia expires in November. Columbia produces the show, about the disrespectful family of a shoe salesman, for Fox Broadcasting Co.'s network. The writers' agent, Cary Cosay of Leading Artists Agency, said Wednesday that no deal had been reached. Gary Lieberthal, chairman of Columbia Pictures, declined to comment. The stakes have risen in the talks because Columbia is preparing a highly publicized campaign to sell reruns of ``Married'' to local stations. Depending on how much the stations pay, Columbia could gross $124 million to $153 million for ``Married,'' not including revenue from advertising sales, the Times said. The Disney and Universal studios have expressed interest in signing up the writing team, but have been unable to match Columbia's immediate advance against syndication revenues, the newspaper said.

Zsa Zsa Gabor is going ahead with a benefit for the homeless. A judge had chastised her for counting time she had spent on the project toward fulfilling a sentencing obligation. In addition to three days in jail, which she is appealing, Miss Gabor was sentenced to serve 120 hours of community service at a shelter for homeless women for slapping a police officer. Miss Gabor spent 34 hours at the shelter answering phones and handing out food, and the rest of the time raising money and planning a gala fund-raiser for the shelter June 5 at the Beverly Hilton Hotel. ``I will do everything I can to save the group from financial trouble,'' Miss Gabor said Tuesday. But Beverly Hills Municipal Judge Charles Rubin wouldn't give her credit for fund raising. And as punishment, he tagged on 60 hours to the time she must spend at the shelter for her October conviction for slapping a Beverly Hills motorcycle officer. She said her celebrity friends have rallied to the fund-raiser. Phyllis Diller has donated a $4,000 oil painting for auction and sister Eva Gabor, actress Valerie Harper and Bob Hope have promised items. In addition, a Los Angeles car dealer will donate an automobile for auction and Miss Gabor is throwing in a sable coat and other personal items.

DOC.HEAD: Bright & Brief
DOC.TEXT: City officials seeking a non-sexist term for ``manhole'' ducked the issue. They decided to take no formal action on the contest, even though they received suggestions from as far away as New Zealand. Among the ideas were ``sewer viewers,'' ``peopleholes'' or even ``peepholes.'' The decision will be taken informally and will not require formal council action, a spokeswoman for the City Council said Wednesday. ``We do have a commitment to change any offensive terminology, but we just do it internally. It's no big deal,'' said Christine Olsen, a city spokeswoman. Prompted by sensitivity to the City Council's first female majority, the Public Works Department last month called for suggestions to replace the term for ``manhole,'' and said it was holding an informal, tongue-in-cheek contest to come up with gender-neutral substitute. ``The calls came in from everywhere,'' Ms. Olsen said. Some people are calling with ``lewd and offensive suggestions,'' a city receptionist said, while others want to know about ``the women who are taking over the City Council.'' Olsen stressed that the five women on the nine-member council had nothing to do with the Public Works Department contest. A radio station in Hamilton, New Zealand _ Sacramento's sister city _ held a renaming contest in which ``sewer viewer'' captured the prize. Olsen said many city workers for years have called the things ``utility covers.''

Students and administrators at Exeter-West Greenwich School District spent a year searching for a nickname for their new high school. They finally picked Scarlet Knights. But officials at Rutgers University in New Jersey didn't think it sounded so good. Rutgers Vice President David Pramer said Wednesday the nickname was a registered trademark of the university, just like Alabama's Crimson Tide and Notre Dame's Fighting Irish. Walter Gibson, assistant superintendent at Exeter-West Greenwich, said he was disappointed. The selection process required polling students five times before a nickname was settled on for the athletic teams at the high school, which is due to open in September. Undaunted, the School Committee has suggested that Superintendent John F. Eldridge to ask Rutgers for permission again. ``If we get a hassle, we'll just go back to the kids and look for another name,'' Gibson said.

A federal brochure that instructs the reader to put on shoes, stay away from the waterfront and not go sightseeing during an earthquake has not received high marks from local officials. The pamphlet, called ``Self-Help Advice: Earthquakes,'' was produced by the Canadian government. Among other advice proffered, the booklet urges people not to injure themselves. ``This is a classic case of a person writing a brochure who doesn't know what people want to read,'' Mayor Gordon Campbell said Wednesday. ``Stay away from waterfront areas? That's not very easy to do around here,'' said Marilyn Baker, mayor of North Vancouver district. The Greater Vancouver regional district has asked the provincial government to apply for federal funds so that the regional district can write its own brochure.

DOC.HEAD: Former Klan Leader Says Race-Relations Lesson Won't Change His Mind
DOC.TEXT: The president of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference says he will talk about the human family when he teaches a race-relations course to Klansmen, but not all his students may be listening. ``I don't know what he's going to say, but he's not going to change my way of thinking,'' said Roger Handley, a former Ku Klux Klan leader in Birmingham who was accused of attacking an SCLC march in Decatur in 1979. The Rev. Joseph Lowery, who organized the march, is to lead the course Saturday for the Klansmen as part of a court settlement growing out of the bloody clash. Lowery said he plans to talk about ``the oneness of the human family'' and how the Klansmen themselves may have been exploited by demagogic leadership. He said he plans to sit in a circle with the former Klansmen and attempt an informal discussion. Told of Lowery's plan to make the two-hour session informal, Handley said, ``Good. Maybe I'll convert him.'' Handley, a 44-year-old disabled sheet-metal worker, called the discussion a ``waste of time.'' ``I don't believe in integration, I don't believe in interbreeding. I don't hate anybody, but I'm not going to change my way of thinking on that,'' he said. Lowery would not disclose the location of the meeting because he doesn't want reporters to attend. ``I don't think the Klan would cooperate if news media people were sitting in the room,'' he said. ``They've got to protect their pride, and I think they'd turn it into a circus. There would be no serious discussion. ``At best, it's going to be difficult to have a serious discussion.'' ``One of their cyclops up in Connecticut called it `cruel and unusual punishment,''' Lowery told the Birmingham Post-Herald in a telephone interview. ``I reckon it might be.'' The meeting grew out of a lawsuit against the Klan by Montgomery attorney Morris Dees of the Southern Poverty Law Center. Dees said that in the Decatur clash, Handley gave the order for Klansmen to fire on black marchers. Four men, two blacks and two whites, were wounded in an exchange of gunfire. An FBI investigation failed to bring criminal charges in 1980, but information Dees gathered led to criminal indictments for years later against nine Klansmen, including Handley, who served four months in prison. Handley said he was innocent, but agreed to attend the race-relations course because ``it was a way to get out of the lawsuit,'' which Dees filed in U.S. District Court in Huntsville.

DOC.HEAD: British Airliner Nearly Collides With U.S. Fighter Jets
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 3 new grafs to UPDATE with two passengers injured, and that plane also carrying crew of six. Pickup 3rd graf pvs: A newspaper...; SUBS grafs 8-9 pvs, The captain ..., to eliminate outdated material. Pickup 10th graf pvs: `The incident...
DOC.TEXT: A British airliner nearly collided with two U.S. Air Force jets Thursday, and two passengers were injured when the plane's pilot made a nose dive to avoid a crash, authorities said. The Dan-Air British turboprop was carrying 15 passengers, including a child, and a crew of six on a flight from West Berlin to Saarbruecken, near the French border. Two passengers required hospital treatment for contusions suffered when they were thrown out of their seats as the plane dived suddenly, according to a statement released by the Interior Ministry of the state of Rhineland-Palatinate. A newspaper said the passenger plane missed the two fighters by 50 feet. But an Air Force spokesman estimated the planes were about 500 feet apart. A U.S. Air Force statement said the incident involved two F-15 jet fighters from the 36th Tactical Fighter Wing. ``The U.S. Air Force pilots and the Dan-Air captain took successful evasive action and reported the event to the authorities,'' said a statement issued by the 36th Tactical Fighter Wing at the Bitburg Air Base. A spokesman for West Germany's federal air traffic control authority said the Dan-Air plane was flying from West Berlin to Saarbruecken in southern West Germany at the time of the incident. Spokesman Hans-Urlich Ohl told The Associated Press the Dan-Air captain reported seeing only one military jet. He said military jets usually fly in formations of two and it was possible that the Dan-Air captain did not see the second jet. The captain sent the plane into a nose-dive to avoid a crash, and several passengers were thrown out of their seats, Ohl said. The incident occurred at 11:17 a.m., 24 miles north of Saarbruecken, Ohl said. The British plane, a twin-engine Hawker Siddeley 748, was at an altitude of 7,590 feet and was preparing to land at the time of the near-hit, the spokesman said. The plane can carry about 50 passengers. The Saarbruecker Zeitung newspaper reported that the Dan-Air plane missed the oncoming jets by 50 feet. ``Fifty feet, that's impossible, they would have collided,'' Air Force Capt. Jerry Brown told The Associated Press. ``We don't know precisely, but our best estimate is that they were approximately 500 feet apart.'' The Dan-Air turboprop plane was being guided by the U.S. Air Force air control at the Ramstein Air Base, Ohl said. Airliners serving West Berlin still fly through designated air corridors controlled by the victorious World War II allies. Warplanes from eight NATO countries fly in West German airspace. There have been several fatal air accidents in recent years involving American and other allied aircraft, prompting sharp demands from West Germans for a stop to low-level military flights and reduction of other flying activity.

DOC.HEAD: Texas Company Recalling Some Pulmanex Resuscitators
DOC.TEXT: Medical personnel who use Pulmanex Manual resuscitators are being asked to return the devices because of a defect that in some cases could be fatal to patients. The Food and Drug Administration said Life Design Systems Inc. of Carrollton, Texas, is voluntarily recalling resuscitators with model numbers beginning with 90, 91, 95 or 96 and ending with a 0, 1, 2 or 3 after the hyphen. The recalled models have lot numbers 9321 through 9361 and were made from Nov. 17 through Dec. 27 last year. In five previous recalls, Life Designs Systems has recalled other models of the resuscitator for various reasons, the FDA said. The agency said it did not know of any deaths that have resulted from any of the faulty resuscitators. The resuscitator subject to the latest recall comes in adult, pediatric and neonatal sizes. It consists of a mask that is placed over the patient's mouth and nose and is attached to a plastic bag. Squeezing the plastic bag forces air into the patient's lungs. In faulty resuscitators, the rear valves can become dislodged and prevent air from reaching the person being resuscitated, the FDA said. If the problem is not recognized in time, the patient could die.

DOC.HEAD: USDA Predicts Bumper Soviet Grain Crop
DOC.TEXT: The weather is favorable for a bumper grain crop in the Soviet Union this year, the Agriculture Department said Thursday. The department's first forecast of the year predicted the 1990 Soviet grain crop would be 215 million metric tons, up from 211.1 million tons produced last year. It would also be the largest Russian harvest since the record production of 237.4 million tons in 1978. Officials said the forecast includes 95 million tons of wheat, 106.5 million tons of coarse grains such as barley and sorghum, and 13.5 million tons of miscellaneous grains and pulses. Most of the increase from last year would be in wheat, up from 90.5 million tons harvested in 1990. Despite the outlook for a bumper harvest, the report said Moscow will continue to be a large buyer of foreign grain, with 1990-91 imports projected at 36 million tons during the trading year that will begin July 1. That would be down only slightly from the import level of the last two years, the report said.

DOC.HEAD: First Child Called in McMartin Retrial Begs Off Witness Stand
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note contents especially grafs 8-9, `On Wednesday ...'
DOC.TEXT: An 11-year-old girl who says she was fondled and photographed nude when she attended the McMartin Pre-School insisted Thursday she could not continue to testify for a second day at a molestation retrial. Under cross-examination, the first child witness in the retrial of Raymond Buckey began to answer every question regarding her past allegations by saying, ``I can't remember.'' Deputy District Attorney Pam Ferrero said the girl's parents called her Wednesday night saying the child was ``extremely reluctant'' to return for more questioning. But the parents agreed to bring her anyway. Ms. Ferrero told Superior Court Judge Stanley Weisberg that the girl expressed the same desire not to testify when she arrived at court Thursday but ``was trying to be cheerful'' and agreed to take the stand. Shortly after Buckey's attorney, Danny Davis, began asking her intimate questions about her body, the girl asked, ``May I be excused? I have a stomach ache.'' Minutes later, she was observed in the hallway sobbing in her father's arms. The judge recessed court. After about an hour of private talks with prosecutors, the child was escorted back to the witness stand, where her father was allowed to stand next to her and she clutched a stuffed toy. The girl provided no more answers, however, saying she could not remember events that occurred when she was 3 or 4 years old. On Wednesday, the girl denied that Buckey raped or sodomized her but said he touched her ``in the vagina and the bottom'' as she sat on his lap. The girl also said she couldn't remember if she was clothed at the time but recalled that ``I didn't like it.'' The 31-year-old Buckey is charged specifically with raping the girl and using a foreign object to sodomize her. Buckey's lawyer asked the girl in clear terms whether she had been raped and sodomized by Buckey and she said she could not recall that she had. In Buckey's first trial she did not take the stand, and the jury deadlocked 11-1 for acquittal on the two charges. The first Buckey trial, the longest and costliest criminal proceeding in U.S. history, ended in January with Buckey acquitted of 40 counts of molestation at the family owned preschool in Manhattan Beach. His mother, Peggy McMartin Buckey, was acquitted of 12 charges. But the jury deadlocked on 13 counts against Buckey, and the district attorney decided to retry him on eight of those charges involving three children. Numerous children in the first trial testified about a ``naked movie star game'' allegedly played at the school. The 11-year-old witness made the same claim, saying she and other children took off their clothes for the game and were photographed nude by Buckey.

DOC.HEAD: Greenspan Outlines Proposal for Banking Reform
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RETRANSMITS a0625 to restore cycle designator
DOC.TEXT: Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan on Thursday outlined the central bank's ideas for reforming the nation's financial system, including charging banks with risky investments more for their deposit insurance. In his first extensive public remarks on deposit insurance reform, Greenspan told a Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago conference that the issue ``should be high on our agenda'' as Congress and the Bush administration consider permitting banks to expand into securities and insurance. Among the specific reforms he suggested were varying deposit insurance premiums according to the riskiness of a bank's investments, more frequently examining banks' books, more swiftly seizing weak banks and requiring bank owners to risk more of their own money. Greenspan did not address such proposals as cutting back on the $100,000 per-account insurance, limiting insurance to one account, imposing a ``deductible'' on the insurance or finding a way to allow large banks to fail without endangering the system. ``He is proceeding gingerly ... but in the chairman are the seeds of a most radical reform of our existing financial system,'' said Kenneth A. Guenther, executive vice president of the Independent Bankers Association of America, which represents smaller banks wary of deposit insurance changes. The Treasury Department is due to release its banking reform plan by February. Greenspan is expected to be a major influence in that plan's development and in congressional debate on the issue next year. Greenspan appeared to reject the notion of simply doing away with deposit insurance and other safeguards, which some free-market conservatives advocate. ``The United States has not suffered a financial panic or systemic bank run in the last 50 years. In large part this reflects the safety net,'' he said. But the protection comes at a cost, he said. Three parts of the safety net pose a ``moral hazard'' for bankers by allowing them to shift some of the risks of their actions onto the public. They are deposit insurance, the ability of banks to borrow at low rates in emergencies from the Fed's discount window and banks' access the Fed's electronic payments wire, which guarantees payments between banks. Reform of the safety net, Greenspan said, should be considered in tandem with expanding bank powers. Offering banks no new powers likely would cause commercial banking to shrink in relationship to the rest of the financial system. That, in turn, ``may create systemic risk similar to that faced in earlier years.'' Bank owners now risk about six cents of every dollar they lend. However, Greenspan noted that in the 1800s, before the creation of deposit insurance and the discount window, bankers risked 25 cents to 50 cents for every dollar they loaned. That encouraged them to use more caution. A text of Greenspan's speech, delivered at the Chicago Fed's Annual Conference on Bank Structure and Competition, was released in Washington.

DOC.HEAD: Foreigners Continue to Own Less Than 1 Percent of U.S. Farmland
DOC.TEXT: Foreigners continue to own just under 1 percent of the nation's agricultural land, a level that has varied little over the years, the Agriculture Department said Thursday. The department's Economic Research Service made its 1989 year-end review of reports under a 1978 law requiring foreigners to register U.S. agricultural land holdings. As of Dec. 31, 1989, about 12.9 million acres of agricultural land were owned by foreigners, an increase of 263,273 acres from a year earlier. ``Foreign ownership of U.S. agricultural land remained relatively steady from 1981 through 1989, slightly above or below 1 percent of the privately owned agricultural land in the United States,'' said John Lee, administrator of the agency. Of the land owned by foreign interests, 46 percent was forest land, 18 percent cropland, 31 percent pasture and other agricultural land, and 5 percent agricultural land not under cultivation. Corporations, both U.S. and foreign, owned 81 percent of the foreign-held acreage; partnerships, 10 percent; and individuals, 7 percent. The remainder is held by estates, trusts, associations, institutions and others. Japanese investors owned 2 percent of the foreign-held acreage, while about 73 percent of the total was owned by investors from Canada, Britain, West Germany, France, the Netherlands Antilles, Switzerland and the Netherlands, the report said. Maine continued to have the heaviest concentration of foreign ownership, with holdings of almost 2.1 million acres. The report said that 93 percent of the foreign-owned acreage will remain in agricultural production, according to its owners.

DOC.HEAD: Cyclone Heads Inland, Leaves At Least 85 Dead
DOC.TEXT: The worst cyclone to hit India in more than a decade moved inland Thursday, killing at least 85 people and leaving hundreds of homes flattened and more than 90 villages under water. The storm first began bashing India's southeastern coast with heavy rains and tidal surges Tuesday, and it made landfall Wednesday evening hitting coastal districts along the Bay of Bengal with winds up to 155 mph. By late Thursday, the storm lay over the inland town of Bhadrachalam, about 105 miles north of the coast. Wind speeds were decreasing as the cyclone's fury weakened, said officials in Hyderabad, the capital of Andrha Pradesh state. United News of India said winds of 70 to 80 mph would continue for another three days as the storm moved inland. The weather office said the storm was likely to move north and weaken gradually but that low-lying, heavily populated coastal regions would continue to receive much rain. TV and radio reports said the storm killed 57 people. But local officials reported a higher death toll, saying at least 75 people died in Andrha Pradesh and 10 more in neighboring Tamil Nadu state. The death toll was expected to rise as rescue workers reached isolated villages. The officials, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said at least 2 million people in four districts of Andrha Pradesh state were affected by the cyclone. Tens of thousands of people were cut off from rescue workers, as the heavy rains and towering waves left at least 90 villages under water, the state-run television said. The storm dumped more than 16 inches of water on the coastal regions. But late Thursday, rescue workers did manage to reach the low-lying coastal village of Yedurumudi, where about 7,000 residents had been marooned by the storm, officials said. They said it was a miracle that residents were not too badly affected by the storm. Indian news reports said residents there rejected an evacuation order because the village was not affected by a 1977 cyclone, which killed more than 10,000 people in southern India. Officials said casualties from the current storm were relatively low because early warnings gave authorities time to evacuate more than 150,000 people from the coastal districts. In 1977, few people were evacuated. As the storm struck the coast, the high winds and waves up to 33 feet knocked down hundreds of thatched huts and uprooted thousands of trees. Residents who left the coastal town of Machilipatnam, which bore the brunt of the cyclone, said the streets were waist-deep in water. One resident who escaped to Hyderabad said it rained continuously for 20 hours in Machilipatnam. United News of India said thousands of houses were damaged by gales and heavy rains that lashed the area before and during the cyclone. Many towns and villages were plunged into darkness as electricity lines were downed and several power stations severely damaged, it said. Trains stopped running. The news agency quoted officials as saying about 100 telephone exchanges were damaged, disrupting telecommunications, and the roads were littered with fallen trees. The hardest-hit districts, comprising a small peninsula that juts out into the Bay of Bengal, were Krishna, East Godavari and West Godavari, United News said, adding that more than 400,000 people were affected in East Godavari alone. The highest casualties were in Krishna district, where 24 people were killed, the news agency said. At least 33 others died in other parts of the state, it said. Most of the deaths in Andhra Pradesh occurred when walls collapsed or when flood waters swept people away. Cyclones are the Indian Ocean's equivalent of hurricanes. They usually come in the spring just before the monsoon season begins.

DOC.HEAD: Visit to Mom Turns into Visit to Court
DOC.TEXT: A man flying to Florida to visit his mother in a nursing home landed in court for slugging the airline pilot after being told he was too tipsy for another drink, authorities said. Lonnie Alton Lee, 50, a lawn and pest control worker from Albuquerque, N.M., has been charged with endangering a commercial flight, a federal offense punishable by up to 20 years in prison. Lee was en route to Haines City on Tuesday night for a surprise Mother's Day visit. He was released on a $10,000 signature bond during an appearance Wednesday before a U.S. magistrate in Tampa. Donald T. Woods was piloting Continental Airlines Flight 528 from Denver to Orlando when the incident occurred somewhere over Alabama. A flight attendant refused to serve Lee any more drinks because he was tipsy and had become belligerent, authorities said. Lee began hurling obscenities at the male flight attendant, then punched Woods in the jaw when he tried to intervene, said FBI spokesman Larry Curtin. Lee was restrained, strapped into his seat until the plane landed and was arrested, Curtin said. Woods told federal agents the blow endangered the flight because he wore glasses and the swing could have shattered them or otherwise impaired his vision. After asking authorities not to call his mother about the arrest, Lee told the magistrate he might just skip the holiday visit and return home.

DOC.HEAD: Artillery Barrages Break Lull in Christian Fighting
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 10 grafs to UPDATE with resumption of artillery battles, new casualties. Pickup 6th graf pvs: The crackle ...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto BEI2
DOC.TEXT: Rival Christian forces under Gen. Michel Aoun and militia chieftain Samir Geagea exchanged artillery and tank barrages in east Beirut on Thursday, shattering a relative lull in the fighting. Police said four people were killed and eight wounded in the heavy barrages that erupted after a day of intermittent skirmishes with machine guns and mortars. It was the 101st day of the inconclusive showdown between Aoun and Geagea for control of the 310-square-mile Christian enclave. A daytime lull gave the exhausted population a chance to emerge from underground shelters to take stock of damage from the savage shelling of the previous two days. But residents quickly scurried back to their shelters when the heavy shelling resumed. The casualties included a Moslem driver whose vegetable van took a direct hit from a shell hit at the mid-city Museum gateway that links east Beirut with the city's Moslem sector across the dividing Green Line. The gateway was opened only minutes before being closed again, police said. The Aoun-Geagea fight has killed 980 people and wounded 2,572 since it erupted Jan. 30. The guns generally fell silent by midnight Wednesday, a police spokesman said. But snipers manning roof-top firing nests kept most roads blocked in east Beirut and the Christian enclave northeast of the city. Snipers also targeted the Museum gateway, and few civilians ventured across the dividing line. The crackle of automatic fire echoed across the Museum gateway as a woman and three men sped on foot toward west Beirut. ``Hurry up, keep your heads down!'' shouted a Moslem soldier on the western side. The four made it safely across and said they were going to stay with relatives. The woman, Janette Elia, said the street where she had lived in Furn el-Shubbak district was reduced to ``mere piles of rubble, debris and glass shards.'' Geagea's men ``fired salvo after salvo of rockets from multi-barrelled launchers at our street,'' Mrs. Elia said. ``The rockets came in like endless sea waves, whistling and exploding.'' Mrs. Elia said she spent the whole day and night Wednesday in the basement of her home. ``Most of the residents had already fled to safer areas,'' she said. The fighting has forced 400,000 of the enclave's 1 million residents to flee to safer areas in Lebanon and neighboring countries, and inflicted damage estimated at $1 billion. Aoun's troops and Geagea's fighters also used the lull to defuse scores of unexploded shells and rockets, remove the rubble that blocked some streets and resupply their positions with food, water and ammunition, a police spokesman said. ``They are preparing for another round of destruction,'' the spokesman said. ``The reason for the clash is still there and the weapons are still there. They'll fight again.'' The fierce shelling was apparently halted by a cease-fire call from Maronite patriarch Nasrallah Sfeir. Both Aoun and Geagea are Maronites too. The violence had escalated Wednesday when Aoun imposed restrictions on sea outlets controlled by Geagea along the 28-mile Christian coastline.

DOC.HEAD: China Announces Release of Pro-Democracy Protesters
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 11 grafs to ADD State Department reaction, quotes, minor editing to conform. Picks up 9th pvs, `Students at...'
DOC.TEXT: China announced Thursday it had released 211 jailed pro-democracy protesters, including several prominent academics, in a move that appeared timed to head off possible U.S. trade sanctions. Those released include Dai Qing, a leading journalist; Cao Siyuan, director of a social science research institute; and Li Honglin, head of the Fujian Provincial Academy of Social Sciences. All signed petitions or otherwise showed support for the democratic reforms demanded last spring by hundreds of thousands of protesters in Beijing and other cities. The protests ended in June when the army opened fire on the demonstrators, killing hundreds and possibly thousands. The official Xinhua News Agency described those released as lawbreakers and said they were ``given lenient treatment and released upon completion of investigations.'' It inserted the word ``former'' before the titles of Ms. Dai and the others, indicating they were fired while in prison. ``Coming back home was like a dream,'' Ms. Dai said, contacted at home by telephone. She said she was let out Wednesday. ``After 10 months, my kitchen is like a stranger.'' She declined to speak further, saying she would be arrested again if she talked to a reporter without permission. ``We welcome this announcement,'' said State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler. ``We are pleased that the official announcement provided the names of six of those released. We believe that the interests of all parties would be best served by a full public accounting of the number and identity of those detained as well as those released.'' Ms. Tutwiler added that the Chinese government has not provided information to date on how many people remain as detainees or as prisoners. According to unoffical estimates, 10,000 to 15,000 were detained nationwide at some point but most have been released, she said. ``The official announcement said 431 were still under investigation by Beijing public security organs but it is not clear whether all of these are imprisoned,'' she said. None of the six listed by Xinhua was a student. Xinhua did not say if any student leaders were among those released. Students at Beijing University said they knew of no students who had recently been returned to campus. Campus sources in Beijing have reported that several student activists were released in the past few weeks, but none was a top leader of the pro-democracy movement. Xinhua quoted an unidentified spokesman for the Public Security Ministry as saying only 431 ``lawbreakers involved in the turmoil and rebellion are still being investigated.'' It said some ``are being dealt with by judicial departments.'' The figures still leave hundreds of people unaccounted for. China previously announced the release of 573 people during the winter. Arrests reported by the official media last summer alone totaled more than 2,000, and arrests continued during the fall and winter. Few trials have been publicized, although 20 executions have been reported in the official press. Sources have reported that several leading dissidents still in jail have finally been charged after months of detention, despite Chinese legal requirements that charges be filed within 45 days. The releases came as debate begins in the United States over whether to renew China's most-favored-nation trade status. The status, given to all but a handful of nations, substantially reduces tariffs on goods exported to the United States. As a socialist country, China's status must be renewed each year. President Bush must issue his decision by June 3, and some congressmen have said they favor suspending most-favored-nation status as a protest of China's human rights record. China has said suspension would set bilateral relations back 20 years. It has insisted it will not yield to foreign pressure, but last week it ended 14 months of martial law in the Tibetan capital in what was widely interpreted as an effort to placate critics. Martial law had been imposed to quell demonstrations against Chinese rule. Prominent protesters from Beijing's democracy movement who remain in jail include Wang Dan, a Beijing University history major who was one of the top student leaders, and seven other students named on a student most-wanted list last summer. Five students on that list are known to have escaped China, and the rest are believed still in hiding. Also still in jail are Liu Xiaobo, a university lecturer who took part in a hunger strike during the last days of protest, and Ren Wanding, an accountant who gave pro-democracy speeches during the movement. He was also jailed four years in the early 1980s for having helped lead an earlier democracy movement.

DOC.HEAD: Premier Prepared to Head Non-Socialist Government
DOC.TEXT: Premier Andrei Lukanov said Thursday he is prepared to head Bulgaria's next government even if his Socialist Party _ the former Communist Party _ is defeated in elections next month and forced into a coalition with the opposition. The Socialist Party seeks a firm break with its Stalinist past, Lukanov said in an interview with The Associated Press. The party, which changed its name last month, is ``now dominated by those who want a new European Socialist party, who are resolutely anti-Stalinist,'' Lukanov said. Bulgaria's Communist Party draws on almost a century of tradition. In the months immediately following November's ouster of Todor Zhivkov after 35 years in power, it retained stronger standing than any other Communist party in eastern Europe. But the democratic opposition, while still splintered, has gained ground and is approaching the elections June 10 and 17 with confidence. Petko Simeonov, a leading opposition figure, predicted Tuesday that the newly named Socialists would suffer a ``catastrophic defeat'' at the polls. But Lukanov, an economist who is well respected by all political groups in Bulgaria, maintained the Socialists will emerge as the strongest political force after the elections. He stopped short of predicting a majority for Bulgaria's erstwhile Communists, in view of the recent electoral defeat of Hungary's Socialists, who guided their country to peaceful reform. Asked if he would be willing to head a government if the Socialists do not emerge victorious, Lukanov replied, ``If the party considers this the right thing to do, I would not have a personal position on it'' and would take the job. But he later added, ``this prospect does not make me happy.'' Several leaders of the opposition Union of Democratic Forces say they would like to see the savvy Lukanov stay at the helm in a coalition. ``A coalition is necessary. Whoever wins, we need, at least for a transitory period, a government enjoying, if not 100 percent, very massive public support,'' Lukanov said. ``The political, economic and legal reforms ahead of us are of such a magnitude, of such complexity that we do not think it possible for anyone in a single political force to shoulder this,'' he added.

DOC.HEAD: Nuclear Free Zone Vote in Eugene, Ore., Hinges on Economic Development
DOC.TEXT: Eugene long has enjoyed a reputation as the city where the peace crusade of the 1960s did not die, so it wasn't surprising that voters declared it a nuclear free zone in 1986. But as Oregon struggles to diversify its economy to make up for the decline of the timber industry, residents are confronted with paying a price for their convictions. On Tuesday, they will decide whether to toughen the ordinance that bans the local manufacture of nuclear weapons and their components. Although Eugene, population 110,000, is in many ways a timber town, the presence of the 18,500-student University of Oregon has given it a liberal tone not found elsewhere in Oregon. But the proposed city charter amendment has scared away the builders of a $15 million factory. One small defense contractor vows to move out of the city if the nuclear free zone measure passes. Rohr Industries earlier this year decided to build a new jet engine parts plant in San Marcos, Texas, rather than Eugene. With it went 250 jobs. ``Eugene had made the short list,'' said Jerry Broening, director of public affairs for Rohr in San Diego. ``Indeed, we had selected Eugene, tentatively, to locate the facility. ``Then it came to our notice that there was this pending stiffening of the existing nuclear free zone ordinance in Eugene.'' Supporters launched the latest initiative after the City Council and a special task force refused to establish an elected board to oversee the nuclear free zones approved by voters in 1986 and 1988. The latest initiative would amend the city charter, keeping the council out of the process. A nuclear-free zone in Oakland, Calif., was declared unconstitutional last month in the federal government's first lawsuit against a such a law. A federal judge said the ordinance interfered with exclusive federal control of national defense, atomic energy and shipments of hazardous materials. Steve Johnson, the chief petitioner for the initiative to make the nuclear free zone part of the city charter, said the Oakland case shouldn't affect the his proposal because it does not attempt to directly limit decisions by the federal and state governments, as Oakland's did. And while Eugene's measure would prohibit hauling nuclear wastes over city streets, it doesn't try to stop passage on Interstate 5 or the railroad, Johnson said. Johnson, an adjunct sociology professor at the University of Oregon, calls the initiative a chance to force the City Council to finally accept the will of the people as expressed in the previous nuclear-free votes. ``I thought the voters got a rotten deal,'' he said. But Mike Schwartz, co-chairman of Citizens Against an Irresponsible Nuclear Free Zone, said the vote is really about whether people want to see their economy grow. ``This is camouflage that people who don't want growth are using,'' said Schwartz. Though nuclear free zone advocates say Rohr wouldn't have been covered by the ballot measure, Broening said the company didn't want its future restricted in any way. Besides, it was in a hurry to build its plant. ``We are a subcontractor and our customers ask us to do things and if they ask us to do things, we respond,'' Broening said. ``We needed to have a plant in operation by October, which was patently undoable if we had to wait until June,'' for the outcome of the vote. Robert Ellis is president of Biodynamics, a 10-year-old Eugene defense contractor that employs 25 people to make flight simulators and handle secret military projects. Ellis finds the local climate so hostile to his company that he plans to move it if the new nuclear free zone passes. ``It's 1969 in Eugene,'' he said. ``For our children there is no good potential employment in Eugene, Oregon, unless you want to make belts.'' David Zupan, a staffer for the organization PeaceWorks who is active on the nuclear free zone campaign, figures Rohr's decision should encourage people that the new improved nuclear free zone will work. ``They should be relieved that a company that wants to make nuclear weapons ... is not coming to Eugene,'' Zupan said. ``The impression was that Rohr would employ out-of-work mill workers,'' Johnson said. ``The fact is these are people they bring with them or attract from outside the area. We don't have a big pool with specialty metal fabrication experience.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush to Nominate Californian, Bostonian
DOC.TEXT: President Bush will nominate Sylvia Alice Earle, a California research biologist, as chief scientist of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, the White House said Thursday. Dr. Earle, 54, is the founder and director of Deep Ocean Technology, Inc., of San Leandro, Calif. A resident of Oakland, Calif., she would succeed Melvin N.A. Peterson. The White House also announced Bush will nominate two new members of the United States Sentencing Commission: A. David Mazzone, a federal judge from Boston, and Michael S. Gelacak, a private attorney in Washington, D.C.

DOC.HEAD: Ed McMahon Says When Johnny Goes, So Will He
DOC.TEXT: Johnny Carson still hasn't signed for his 29th season as the star of NBC's ``Tonight Show.'' But sidekick Ed McMahon says it's likely Carson will stay on for two more seasons. The big-voiced announcer with the booming laugh made his prediction during an interviewed tape this week for NBC's ``Later With Bob Costas.'' The interview is scheduled for broadcast May 16. McMahon said he'll leave ``Tonight'' when Carson does, and ``the night he says goodbye, I say goodbye. That's gonna be a sad night. ...'' Asked if he thought he personally will make it 30 years on the show, McMahon replied, ``I think so. Yeah, I think so.'' NBC Entertainment President Brandon Tartikoff has said he expects that Carson will return next fall. But McMahon noted that Carson is ambivalent each year about continuing on ``Tonight,'' which has consistently beaten its late-night rivals in ratings. ``If it were me, I would say 30 (years),'' he said. ``But Johnny has his own mind about that. ... He's supposed to tell them (NBC) pretty soon whether he's going to stay or not. I think right now he's probably still vacillating.'' Carson is ``the master of timing,'' McMahon said, ``and he'll know when it's the right time to go. But I think 30 years would be wonderful.''

DOC.HEAD: Jury Considers Tree-Poisoning Sentence
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Will be topped with verdict or deliberations ending for the day.
DOC.TEXT: Jurors began deliberating Thursday whether a man convicted of poisoning the historic Treaty Oak should be given a life sentence for the crime. Paul Stedman Cullen, 46, was convicted in state district court Wednesday of poisoning the beloved landmark in what authorities said was an occult ritual. Because he was previously convicted of a felony _ burglary _ he faces a maximum sentence of 99 years or life in prison. The minimum sentence is five years. Cullen refused to comment as he was led from the courtroom by sheriff's deputies after his conviction Wednesday. His father insisted his son hadn't harmed the tree. ``They convicted an innocent man,'' said Paul Cullen Sr. The tree, estimated to be as much as 500 years old, was poisoned with Velpar, a powerful liquid herbicide, early in 1989. News reports about the case brought international attention to the giant live oak tree, which according to legend was the site of a treaty signing between Stephen F. Austin and Indians. About two-thirds of the tree is now dead, foresters said, but the remaining third is still producing leaves. Cullen was arrested in June after bragging to a woman that he poisoned the tree, authorities said. During the eight-day trial, prosecutors said Cullen poisoned the Treaty Oak as part of an occult ritual to both protect a woman he liked and to ``kill'' his love for her. Cullen's attorneys tried to portray him as a lonely loser who claimed he poisoned the tree to impress a woman. ``That's the key to this entire case,'' defense attorney Terry Kirk said. ``He wanted her to think that he was somebody.'' Since the poisoning was discovered, more than $100,000 has been donated to to pay for extraordinary measures that were taken to try to save the tree. Velpar-contaminated dirt was removed from around its roots, the tree has been doused with spring water and elaborate sun screens were built to shade it.

DOC.HEAD: US Worried About Election Process in Romania; Recalls Ambassador
DOC.TEXT: The United States is recalling its ambassador to Romania as a signal of displeasure over intimidation and harassment of opposition parties, the State Department said Thursday. The recall of Ambassador Alan Green was based on ``reports of irregularities in the Romanian electoral process which raise questions about whether those elections will be free and fair,'' spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said. She said Green will return to Bucharest in time for the May 20 elections when Romanians will vote for a president and a bicameral parliament. Anti-communist demonstrators in Romania contend the elections are being manipulated by the interim government in a way that could lead to domination by communists previously associated with the regime of the late president, Nicolae Ceausescu. Government leaders maintain that they were, for the most part, dissidents who suffered under Ceausescu's rule. Ms. Tutiler said, ``We have urged the interim Romanian government to take more vigorous steps to maintain order and to protect the rights of all candidates in these elections.'' Among the electoral problems she cited were the incidence of ``organized acts of intimidation and harassment directed against some opposition parties and candidates. ``We are also concerned about complaints that several major parties still encounter obstacles in obtaining their fair share of broadcast time on the publicly controlled radio and television and in distributing their campaign literature through the mail, as well as problems with distributing independent newspapers,'' Ms. Tutwiler said. She said a fair election is crucial to the further democratization in Romania and to good relations with the United States. The International Human Rights Law Group, a private research organization, issued a report expressing concerns similar to those of the State Department. The report said there is widespread apprehension throughout Romania that the National Salvation Front, which dominates the interim government, has unfair advantages over other parties. A Law Group delegation which visited Romania in April said it could not judge the truth of the allegations ``but the belief that these advantages exist is pervasive and has created deep resentment in many sectors of the population,'' the report said. If the allegations are not promptly addressed, it said, ``there is a risk that the election process will be regarded by substantial segments of the politically active population as not being free and fair, and therefore that the legitimacy of the elected government will be questioned.''

DOC.HEAD: Mandela Arrives in Angola and Gives Thanks For Support
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela arrived Thursday for his first visit to Angola and thanked the Marxist government and its allies for supporting his African National Congress in its struggle against white-minority rule in South Africa. Mandela, in an emotional speech to tens of thousands of Angolans packing Luanda's dusty May 1 Square, said, ``I pay tribute to comrade President (Jose Eduardo) dos Santos, his government and the Angolan people for all the help they have given us.'' ``The progress we have made in our struggle is owed largely to Angola, and we hope that one day we will be as free as you,'' said Mandela. Mandela, shielded from the blazing midday sun by an umbrella, also praised Cuban President Fidel Castro and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev for helping independence movements in southern Africa. He described Cuba as a poor country economically but said, ``There's one thing where that country stands out head and shoulders above the rest _ that is in its love for human rights and liberty.'' He said he hoped to visit Havana and Moscow soon. Last week, the ANC agreed in principle with South African President F.W. de Klerk to seek a peaceful end to apartheid and minority rule in South Africa. But Mandela's speech in Luanda mixed optimism for peace with revolutionary rhetoric, more reminiscent of the battle cries of the mid-1970s when Angola became host to at least seven major ANC military training bases. Angola's prominent military and logistic aid to the movement ended in 1988 as part of a regional peace accord with South Africa and Cuba. Those U.S.-brokered agreements also set terms for Namibian independence, the withdrawal of some 50,000 Cuban troops from Angola, and the end of South African support to UNITA rebels fighting Angola's government. According to Mandela, the ANC ``has noted the moves afoot to bring about peace in Angola ... and we support those moves.'' Heavy, sustained applause from the crowd followed his words. ``We are distressed that such a great and beautiful country is split from top to bottom by a civil war that has been engineered by South Africa and other hostile powers,'' said Mandela. He promised unspecified ANC support for the Angolan government. South African troops fought alongside UNITA in the field against Angolan government forces and their Cuban allies from 1975. Dos Santos claimed Thursday that former South African President Pieter Botha offered to cease aid to UNITA if Luanda agreed to halt support for the South West African People's Organization. It recently won Namibia's independence elections. South African aid to UNITA formally stopped with the New York accords, but Luanda recently renewed accusations that assistance from Pretoria is still reaching the rebels. The rebels also receive a reported $50 million in U.S. aid. Dos Santos struck a conciliatory note Thursday, praising de Klerk as ``an advocate of peace in the region'' for allowing Namibia to gain independence and for opening talks with the ANC. ``Peace should be brought to South Africa and to southern Africa as a whole a soon as possible,'' said dos Santos. Security was heavy in Luanda with troops and military police manning roadblocks at most major intersections. Western and African diplomats said the government could be concerned that UNITA might try to stage guerrilla attacks during Mandela's stay.
