Increased rebel sabotage and bomb attacks this year have left Luandans nervous and dependent on emergency electricity and water supplies. Mandela's arrival in Angola came one day after de Klerk started a nine-nation European tour to gain international support for his attempts to reform South Africa. De Klerk ordered Mandela's release from prison and legalized the ANC in February, 30 years after the organization was banned.

DOC.HEAD: Lawmakers Say Prison Industry Has Unfair Advantages
DOC.TEXT: The preferential treatment the federal prison system gets in selling products to the government is hurting the nation's private industry, some members of Congress said Thursday. ``This is a playing field that is obviously not level,'' said Rep. Howard Coble, R-N.C., sponsor of a bill to limit the prison system's guaranteed share of the federal market. Coble said furniture and textile companies in North Carolina are hurt by the burgeoning prison manufacturing program, which sold 240 different products to federal agencies last year. The sales totaled $361 million and are expected to double by 1992. The program employed 13,000 inmates and 1,400 civilians. The prisons sold $90 million worth of furniture in 1989, a 20 percent increase over the previous year, said Rep. Fred Upton, R-Mich. Industry officials believe the prisons have 23 percent of the federal office furniture market, he said. Federal agencies must now buy products from the prison system if it can meet the purchaser's price and delivery requirements. Upton said the growing federal inmate population could make the prison industries program the equivalent of a Fortune 500 company by 1992. ``To me it seems inherently unfair that private industries must compete for federal market share in this uncompetitive situation,'' he said. Upton and Rep. Paul Henry, R-Mich., testified at a hearing of the House Judiciary subcommittee on courts, intellectual property and the administration of justice. The panel is considering a bill that would have the prisons compete equally with private companies once the prisons obtain a 10 percent share of the federal market for a given product. Aside from textiles and furniture, the prisons produce leather, electronic, plastic, wood and metal goods, and graphic products. Federal Bureau of Prisons Commissioner J. Michael Quinlan spoke against the measure at a Jan. 30 hearing, saying the manufacturing program helps inmates learn job skills and defuses potential inmate unrest from overcrowding.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Southern Sudan Facing Acute Food Shortage
DOC.TEXT: Southern Sudan, where tens of thousands of people starved to death in previous years, once again faces an acute food shortage, according to a report Thursday. The Sudan News Agency carried the report, written by the government's Relief and Rehabilitation Commission in cooperation with the United Nations and Western relief organizations. The report said that despite food shortages, there was no threat of famine. But Western relief sources said there was an imminent threat of starvation in northern parts of Bahr el-Ghazal and around Juba, capital of Equatoria. They said in some areas malnutrition was high among children under five years old. The report followed a two-week survey of the southern Sudanese regions that have been battered by a 7-year-old civil war. Christian and animist rebels in the south want autonomy from the Moslem-dominated government in Khartoum. The war led to food shortages that killed 250,000 Sudanese in 1988, U.N. figures show. The report did not indicate this year how many people were affected by what it said was an ``acute food shortage.'' It called for the transportation of food to the southern regions before the summer rains, which begin in June. The United Nations has said 4.5 million southerners need emergency relief this onth. Laughrun said he was hoping for probation for his client. ``We're going to ask for it and the government (prosecutors) indicated they aren't going to fight us on that,'' he said. ``We hope the judge will go along with it.'' In the plea agreement, the court said the sentencing guidelines called for a prison sentence of between eight and 14 months. Fletcher had faced a maximum term of five years and a $250,000 fine. Fletcher, a regular guest on Bakker's old ``PTL Club'' television show, was indicted last December for lying to the grand jury that investigated PTL's operations. Fletcher was accused of lying to the investigative panel in September 1987 about why he brought Miss Hahn to Florida to meet Bakker in 1980. He denied then that he took her to a hotel to have sex with Bakker. Testifying later, however, he admitted that sex was the purpose of the meeting, according to the indictment. The meeting ultimately led to the demise of the multimillion-dollar televangelism empire run by Bakker and his wife, Tammy Faye, in nearby Fort Mill, S.C. Bakker resigned as PTL chairman when it was about to be revealed in March 1987 that PTL had paid Miss Hahn $265,000 in hush money. PTL fell into bankruptcy and a federal grand jury began looking into Bakker's fundraising activities and spending. Bakker went on trial last year on charges he defrauded his followers who sent him $158 million in exchange for phony offers of guaranteed lodging at the Heritage USA Christian retreat. In October, Bakker was convicted on all 24 counts of fraud and conspiracy and sentenced to 45 years in prison. He is appealing the conviction while he is serving his time at a Minnesota prison. Three other PTL associates _ former executive vice president Richard Dortch and ex-Bakker aides David Taggart and James Taggart _ are in prison for crimes they committed while working at the TV ministry. Fletcher, 50, is free on $25,000 unsecured bond. Late last month, he was released from the Butner Federal Correctional Institution in northeast North Carolina, where he underwent a court-ordered 45-day psychiatric evaluation.

DOC.HEAD: Kaifu Seeks Radical Reform of Japan's Electoral System
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu on Thursday urged a radical revision of the electoral system, saying it is the only way to reduce the power of money in Japanese politics. ``It is clear to me that the public wants clean, easy-to-understand politics,'' Kaifu said in a nationally televised news conference. ``I will bet the fate of my administration on achieving this reform.'' Kaifu endorsed the recommendations of an advisory council to change Japan's system of multiple-seat constituencies, reduce politicians' ability to raise money on their own, and tighten rules on reporting political donations. ``Looking back on the `Recruit' influence-peddling scandal, it is the central theme of my administration to clear political distrust and shift elections from a race of individuals to one of political parties,'' he said. Kaifu, 59, came to office in August after two predecessors resigned in quick succession over the Recruit and sex scandals. Recruit Co., a giant in the information industry, made lavish donations and questionable stock sales to leading politicians, businessmen and bureaucrats. Initially seen as a stop-gap prime minister because he lacked a power base within the governing Liberal Democratic Party, Kaifu has gained public support with his clean image and efforts to ease U.S.-Japan trade friction. Analysts express skepticism, however, over the possibilities of drastic electoral system reforms. ``While some politicians are aware that electoral reforms are essential to wipe out money politics, it is too risky for most of them to accept such drastic reforms,'' said Takashi Inoguchi, a political science professor at Tokyo University. Kaifu said he would consult with the opposition parties to build a consensus for introduction of an electoral reform bill by November. Japan now has 130 constituencies for elections to the 512-seat lower house. Most elect three to five legislators. To win a majority, the governing party must field more than one candidate in each constituency. Candidates from the same party thus cannot compete on policy issues, said Isao Sato, a law professor at Tokai University and co-chairman of the Electoral Review Committee. ``They inevitably vie for popularity by spending lavishly to court voters,'' Sato said. ``That not only leads to corrupt money politics, but also reduces the significance of policy debates.'' The committee, formed in June, proposes creating 300 single-seat constituencies and having 200 members elected to nationwide, at-large constituencies in the powerful lower house. The lower house can override the upper house and enact legislation on its own. The lower house proposals would limit each candidate to having two fund-raising groups _ now there is no limit _ and require the reporting of donations more than $64. The current limit is $6,400. The governing party was seriously shaken by public outrage after the Recruit scandal came to light in 1988. Prime Minister Noboru Takeshita and three Cabinet ministers were forced to resign, and the Liberal Democrats lost upper house elections last July for the first time in their 34-year history. Liberal Democrats gradually regained enough support by February to win a comfortable majority in national elections for the lower house.

DOC.HEAD: Winter Wheat Crop Forecast at 9-Year High
DOC.TEXT: Winter wheat production is rebounding after last year's drought-reduced harvest in the Great Plains, the Agriculture Department said Thursday. Based on field conditions as of May 1, production could be a nine-year high of 2.09 billion bushels, up 44 percent from last year's harvest of 1.45 billion bushels. The department's Agricultural Statistics Board said the average yield based on current indications was estimated at 41.1 bushels per acre, compared with 35.1 bushels last year. In Kansas, for example, winter wheat production was estimated at 460.2 million bushels, more than double the shriveled 1989 harvest of 213.6 million bushels. Both the acreage and average yield were up. Overall, farmers are expected to have about 50.8 million acres of winter wheat for harvest this year, up 23 percent from 41.5 million in 1989, the board said in its report. Winter wheat is planted in the fall and harvested the next year. It accounts for about three-fourths of the U.S. total wheat production. The remainder is planted in the spring. Carl Schwensen, executive vice president of the National Association of Wheat Growers, said the larger harvest will ``put us in a stock-building mode'' for some time in the future. At least until something can be done about worldwide capacity for producing too much grain. Schwensen said the United States has ``made a real accomplishment'' by putting millions of acres of marginal land in the Conservation Reserve Program, which takes it out of crop production for 10 years. He said around 11 million acres of that land has come from nation's wheat base. ``No other major producing and exporting nation has even attempted to take the initiatives that we've had _ to set aside marginal lands specifically from wheat production,'' he said in a telephone interview. The USDA's first official estimate of 1990 production of all wheat will be issued July 12, with the first estimates for corn, soybeans and some other major spring-planted crops scheduled for Aug. 9, along with revised figures for wheat. Although no official estimates based on field surveys were included, except for winter wheat, department analysts in a related supply-and-demand report did project ``highly tentative'' 1990 production of all wheat at more than 2.69 billion bushels, up from less than 2.04 billion last year. Projections for all wheat and some other crops were based on yield trends and an assumption the crop would have normal weather the remainder of the growing season. The 1990 corn harvest was projected at 8.1 billion bushels, up from 7.53 billion harvested last year. Soybean production was projected at 1.925 billion bushels, virtually the same as the crop of 1.927 billion bushels in 1989. According to the supply-and-demand report, the U.S. wheat stockpile will be drained to a 15-year low of 442 million bushels on June 1, the beginning of the new wheat marketing year. But with the expected larger 1990 harvest, the wheat stockpile could be rebuilt to about 765 million bushels a year from now. The projected larger 1990 wheat harvest could put pressure on market prices, which were indicated in the range of $2.90 to $3.30 per bushel in 1990-91, compared with an estimated $3.71 this season. If corn production turns out at the projected level of 8.1 billion bushels, it still wouldn't be quite enough to match domestic and export demand, the report showed. Thus, the U.S. corn stockpile, which may be around 1.33 billion bushels next fall, could edge lower by Oct. 1, 1991. Corn prices were projected at $2.25 to $2.65 per bushel in 1990-91, compared with the current season's forecast of $2.30 to $2.40 per bushel. Looking at the global situation, the analysis said prelminary indications ``point to larger crops in a number of countries and continued growth in use.'' World wheat production is expected to be record large in 1990-91, the report said.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Cocaine, Bjt
Company Says It Will Begin Tests of Wireless, Personal Phones
DOC.TEXT: A New York company said Thursday it will begin testing within two years a revolutionary, wireless ``personal'' telephone system in Houston and Orlando, Fla., designed to compete with wired and cellular systems. The lightweight, wallet-sized phones will use high-frequency microwave signals to connect telephones over short distances, such as in office buildings or within neighborhoods. The new systems, known as personal communications networks, could be connected with PCNs in other cities to provide nationwide communications. PCN owners would need dial only a code to let the system know where they are at any time, said J. Shelby Bryan, chairman of Millicom Inc., a New York-based international cellular company. Shelby said a Millicom subsidiary, PCN America Inc., will conduct a two-year test of the system in the Texas and Florida cities. The Federal Communications Commission on Thursday approved the experiment. Company spokeswoman Andrea Van Raalte said the test would begin sometime in the next two years. Officials at American Personal Communications Inc. earlier this year received FCC permission to test a similar type of phone, but which would be unable to receive calls, in the Washington area. The company has said when it hopes to begin testing next year. Because of the short range of high-frequency microwave signals _ as little as 600 feet _ the PCN, unlike regular cellular service, will be able to share space with other private microwave users. This feature greatly increases the system's capacity _ and its attractiveness to businesses that may find PCNs more convenient to use in an office building than wired systems. A large number of users in small areas would greatly lower the cost of the phone units _ perhaps to $100 or less, Bryan said. ``We can basically have many more subscribers per network so our cost per subscriber will be lower,'' Bryan said in a telephone interview. Officials at American Personal Communications told The Washington Post they hoped the phones ultimately would cost $50 to $75. The phones also will use much less power than cellular ones, and should have battery lives of up to a week, Bryan said. ``I fundamentally believe that PCNs are going to be the first serious means of competition for local communications,'' an AT&T official, Richard B. Snyder, was quoted as saying in Thursday's editions of The New York Times. Bryan commented: ``We'll always have copper (wire) communications, but I think it's going to be viewed over time as kind of an old-fashioned technology. ... I think we will be in direct competition to cellular.'' Cellular phones use a few large radio towers to transmit calls across what are known as ``cells'' in a metropolitan area. The equipment automatically passes off calls as a caller in an automobile, for instance, passes from cell to cell. The PCN system will rely on refrigerator-sized, low-power transmitters that will transmit across a more limited area. Like existing cellular telephones, the new service will be able to ``pass off'' phone calls as users move from one transmitter area to another. The British government already has selected three consortia to build nationwide PCN systems in Britain. Millicom is one of the consortia; service is expected to begin there by 1993. ``We envision that by the turn of the century ... 25 percent of the population of England will be on some form of radio telephone,'' Bryan said.

DOC.HEAD: Urban Lawmakers Band Together To Oppose `Anti-Consumer' Farm Bill
DOC.TEXT: A diverse group of House members said Thursday they will present a united front against agriculture subsidy programs that they consider anti-consumer in the 1990 farm bill. The group led by Reps. Richard Armey, R-Texas, and Charles Schumer, D-N.Y., includes liberals and conservatives who have two things in common. None is a member of the Agriculture Committee and all believe government farm programs are too expensive. Schumer, of Brooklyn, said many House members have been interested in change but haven't banded together before to give each other support. This year, ``we're working together,'' said Schumer, though acknowledging they weren't all interested in the same subsidy programs. ``In general we have agreement that agriculture has gotten out of control.'' Rep. Claudine Schneider, R-R.I., said she opposed the wool subsidies while Reps. Thomas Downey, D-N.Y. and John Porter, R-Ill., spoke out against the sugar program. Others opposed the peanut program or any subsidy for farms with annual profits over $100,000. Other congressman at a press conference to introduce the coalition were Reps. Bill Frenzel, R-Minn., Dana Rohrbacher, R-Calif., and Barney Frank, D-Mass. Armey said Reps. George Miller, D-Calif., Thomas Carper, D-Del., Jim Bates, D-Calif., Robert Torricelli, D-N.J., and Sam Gejdenson, D-Conn. also were a part of the group. Schumer said that rather than work through the agriculture committee, the coalition decided the best strategy was to amend the farm bill on the floor. Committee Chairman Kika de la Garza, D-Texas, has acknowledged that the Armey-Schumer opposition to farm programs gained a lot of attention and will have ``some effect on the members.'' He indicated, however, that plenty of support existed in the House for the work the agriculture committee is doing. De la Garza is not likely to send a bill to the floor that will be drastically amended, said a committee staff member. Frank said the multi-billion dollar farm bill was ``one of the last vestiges of the bad old days when differences were worked out by adding money to the budget.'' He said urban lawmakers traditionally voted for farm programs without question in exchange for legislation they wanted for city dwellers. Frank said the government should save its money and let the free market regulate agriculture. He called the government programs ``anti-consumer, anti-taxpayer and over-regulated.'' Since the Great Depression of the 1930s, the federal government has enacted laws to regulate the food supply and assure farmers certain prices for their crops. Every five years, Congress approves a farm bill that determines the way and degree in which tax dollars will be used to support farmers. Both the Senate and House agriculture committees have been approving sections of the 1990 legislation for several weeks and are cognizant of the demands for reduced government support. Intense negotiations are under way in each committee over the programs that will regulate the big money crops of wheat, soybeans, corn, rice and cotton. The Bush administration has said that support for those crops must be limited to $10.2 billion fiscal 1991.

DOC.HEAD: Treasury Opens Center to Trace Drug Money
DOC.TEXT: A computerized analytical center to help federal, state and local law enforcement agencies combat drug money laundering and other financial crimes opened Thursday. ``The U.S. drug trade alone is estimated to be a $100 billion per year business,'' Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady said at a ceremony marking the inauguration of the Financial Crimes Enforcement Network. ``If we are ever going to be successful in getting drugs off the streets of our cities, we must hit the business side by taking the profit out of drug dealing,'' Brady said. The Treasury center will gather information from prosecutors and police around the country and overseas, process it and try to identify potential targets for investigation. Center employees also will conduct research on money laundering and serve as a liaison between local, state and federal officials. ``Some have talked about turf problems,'' said William J. Bennett, White House drug policy adviser. ``Here is another example of turf cooperation, indeed turf harmony.'' Attorney General Dick Thornburgh said the paper trail that investigators once followed has become the electronic trail. ``Drug dealers are ... making a lot of money and they're moving that money through sophisticated and complicated financial channels not only across state lines but across international boundaries,'' he said. ``We will be matching, effort for effort, the kind of sophistication the drug lords are imparting into their operations,'' Thornburgh said.

DOC.HEAD: Nixon Says It's OK For Bush To Raise Taxes
With AM-Taxes-Budget
DOC.TEXT: Does George Bush hurt himself politically if he breaks his campaign promise not to raise taxes? Nonsense, says Richard Nixon. ``My view is, he sits down with the leaders of Congress; he gets them to agree to cut spending, and as far as he is concerned he will agree to some kind of tax compromise,'' Nixon said Thursday in a television interview with Larry King on Cable News Network. ``First, if the Congress agrees to it, he doesn't have a problem because they are all in it together. But if he doesn't get agreement, he goes before the American people, he has enormous popularity. ``The purpose of popularity is not to hoard it, it's to use it. And he can use that popularity to bring the Congress along and let these lily-livered people come along with them.'' Nixon was asked how Bush can overcome his ``read-my-lips'' campaign stance against raising taxes. ``No problem at all,'' he said. ``He can say, `I believed at the time, but the situation has changed and I'm dealing with it.'''

DOC.HEAD: Senate Votes to Loosen Prohibitions on Federal Workers Politicking
With BC-Hatch Act Roll Call
DOC.TEXT: The Senate brushed aside a threatened veto by President Bush and voted Thursday to allow federal civil service and postal workers to take a more active role in partisan politics. On a 67-30 vote after eight days of debate, the Senate approved a wholesale revision of the 1939 Hatch Act, which prohibits 2.9 million government employees from participating in political campaigns. The law would still prohibit federal workers from engaging in political activities on the job and from running for public office or soliciting campaign funds from the public. But they could in their off time hold office in local, state and national political organizations, attend political conventions as delegates and solicit campaign funds from co-workers on behalf of candidates or federal employee union political action committees. Thirteen Republicans joined all 54 Senate Democrats in passing the bill despite an intensive effort by the White House to prevent it from garnering the 67 votes it would need to override a veto. ``Hopefully we can sustain a veto,'' Senate Republican Leader Bob Dole of Kansas said before the vote. Congressional Democrats have been unable to override any of Bush's 10 vetoes in his first 16 months in office. A year ago, the House passed by a veto-proof 297-90 vote a broader bill that also would remove the prohibitions on running for public office and soliciting campaign funds from the public. Bush's senior advisers have said they would urge him to veto any change in the law as ``undermining the integrity and independence of the traditionally non-partisan civil service.'' The legislation was sought by federal employee and postal unions after the Reagan administration filed Hatch Act charges against three union presidents for endorsing Democrat Walter Mondale in the 1984 presidential election. Before the final vote, minority Republicans tried to continue the current restrictions on employees of the IRS, intelligence agencies, the Justice Department and the Federal Election Commission. ``Certain critical agencies of this govrernment need to be beyond political involvement ... (and) not have any taint of politics or coercion,'' said Sen. Pete V. Domenici, R-N.M. His amendment to exempt all employees of those agencies from the looser restrictions on political involvement and also forbid all government workers from soliciting co-workers for campaign funds was defeated on a 58-39 vote. The Senate did adopt on a 97-0 vote an amendment by Dole that would maintain the current restrictions on the 240 employees of the Federal Election Commission. But Republicans failed in several attempts to delete language from the bill that would allow federal workers to spend their off time soliciting campaign gifts from co-workers on behalf of union PACs. Dole called the provision a ``pot of gold'' for the Democratic Party, citing statistics that 88 percent money raised and distributed by federal employee and postal union PACs in the 1988 election went to Democrats.

DOC.HEAD: Soldiers Kill Palestinian, Settler Rampage in West Bank Town
DOC.TEXT: Soldiers on Thursday shot and killed a Palestinian and wounded 20 other Arabs in the occupied Gaza Strip, and Jewish settlers rampaged through the West Bank town of Hebron, firing on homes and smashing cars. Also Thursday, Ziyad Al Rugeeby, 14, died of a head wound suffered in a Wednesday clash with soldiers, Arab reporters said. They said he was buried in his hometown of Hebron. In the Gaza Strip village of Beit Hanoun, soldiers opened fire at stone-throwing Palestinians, striking Fayez Mohammed Hamad, 24, in the back. He was pronounced dead at Gaza City's Ahli hospital, officials said. The army confirmed the death. About 1,500 villagers later marched in Hamad's funeral procession, which developed into a nationalist protest, Arab reporters said. Troops in a helicopter and 30 vehicles monitored the ceremony and fired into the crowd, wounding at least 20 people, when confrontations broke out. Most of the wounded, including a teen-age girl, were shot in the head, hospital officials said. The girl, who was not identified, was rushed to an Israeli hospital in serious condition, Arab reports said. Under army regulations, soldiers are ordered to fire at the legs of protesters if violence is unavoidable. Israel radio described the confrontation as ``serious,'' but an army spokesman confirmed only five of the wounded and said there were no special circumstances concerning the clash. The two deaths Thursday raised to 685 the number of Palestinians killed by Israeli gunfire in the 29-month-old uprising against Israeli occupation. At least 212 Palestinians have been slain by their Arab brethren as suspected collaborators, and 43 Israelis have died in the violence. In Hebron, about 30 settlers from the nearby Jewish enclave of Kiryat Arba rampaged through the town using clubs and stones to smash the windshields of Arab-owned cars and firing their army-issued guns at Palestinian homes, Arab reports and the national Itim news agency reported. `They smashed the windows of five cars and fired for two hours. Come and see how many bullets they shot at my house. My wife and son were beaten,'' Issa Baradai, a Hebron resident, said in a telephone interview. Arab reports said the rampage began after settlers were earlier stoned by Palestinians. Hebron police said they were investigating the incident. Hebron has been the site of repeated clashes between its 70,000 Palestinian residents and the 200 settlers living in the town's center and 5,000 Jewish settlers living in nearby Kiryat Arba.

DOC.HEAD: Orange Harvest Prospects Brighten
DOC.TEXT: Orange harvest prospects are forecast at 179.2 million boxes, up 4 percent from last month but still 14 percent below last season, the Agriculture Department said Thursday. Most of the reduction from last year was attributed to declines in the Florida and Texas harvests, which were hit by December freezes. The Florida crop was estimated at 108.1 million boxes, compared with 146.6 million in 1988-89. Texas production was indicated at 1.2 million boxes, down from 1.85 million in 1988-89. California production, estimated at 68 million boxes, is up from 58.8 million last season, while the Arizona harvest was indicated at 1.9 million boxes, up from 1.7 million last season. Total grapefruit production was forecast at 48.4 million boxes, down 30 percent from last year, reflecting the freeze in Florida and Texas.

DOC.HEAD: Democrats Accuse White House of Double-Talk on Taxes
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates in top 10 grafs with Quayle defense of Sununu, confirmation Sununu was unnamed official, CORRECTING 7th graf pvs to say revenues not falling but lower than expected, picking up in 8th graf pvs, White House
DOC.TEXT: Congressional Democrats reacted angrily Thursday to a suggestion by Chief of Staff John Sununu that White House negotiators would reject all tax-increase proposals at next week's ``no preconditions'' budget summit. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater disavowed Sununu's remarks, saying they did not reflect Bush's views, but the chief of staff was defended by Vice President Dan Quayle. House Speaker Thomas S. Foley said any more such incidents could ``threaten the success of these talks,'' which are deemed of major importance in the face of growing federal deficit problems. ``What John Sununu was saying was that the president doesn't want to raise taxes,'' Quayle said in an interview with Cable Network News. ``Sununu was just simply reflecting what the president's instincts are, what his stated policies are.'' For his part, Sununu said, in a brief comment, ``The point is that the position is as it always has been: that `no preconditions' means no preconditions. There is nothing that has to be in the agreement and nothing excluded from the agreement.'' Democrats reacted sharply to published accounts quoting a ``senior administration official,'' later identified as Sununu, saying that Bush would stand fast to his previous ``no new taxes'' pledge during budget negotiations. The comments appeared to directly contradict earlier administration assurances that there were ``no preconditions'' to the high-level talks, to get under way Tuesday. Sununu's assertion ``raises the potential it's all a political trap,'' said House Budget Committee Chairman Leon Panetta, D-Calif. Fitzwater told reporters the official was not speaking for the president in making such remarks. President Bush relayed the same message to Foley by telephone, assuring him that nothing was off the bargaining table at the budget summit, Fitzwater said. However, Congress' top Democrats held a news conference to denounce Sununu's remarks. ``It is a question of trust, of whether or not agreements are to be honored, of whether or not the administration is prepared to negotiate in good faith on this important matter,'' said Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, reading a statement bearing the names of 11 Democratic congressional leaders. Foley, D-Wash., said, ``We view this incident as an extremely serious one, because it could, if repeated, threaten the success of these talks.'' Bush's reaction to the report of Sununu's comments ``was that there are no preconditions. He wanted me to reiterate that toyou today,'' Fitzwater told reporters. Bush proposed the summit last Sunday to deal with a budget deficit that administration and other analysts say could be about to explode. Officials blame rising interest rates, lower-than-expected revenues to the Treasury and a higher-than-expected cost of the savings and loan bailout. White House officials say that without action the federal deficit for fiscal 1991 could be up to $100 billion higher than the $64 billion shortfall allowed by law, causing huge automatic cuts in programs throughout the government. The official later identified as Sununu was quoted in The Washington Post as saying: ``We're allowing them (Democrats) to bring their good arguments for taxes to the table. ... They were not persuasive last time and they are likely not to be persuasive again.'' ``But if they want to come to the table and say they put (tax increases) there, it is their prerogative to put them on the table, and it's our prerogative to say no. And I emphasize the no.'' Asked about such an assertion, Fitzwater said: ``That's crazy.'' But the remarks caused an uproar among Democrats already fearful of being trapped by the administration into supporting an election-year tax increase. Rep. Richard Durbin, D-Ill., a member of the House Democratic leadership, said: ``We feel we're setting ourselves up for a sucker punch.'' But Rep. Dan Rostenkowski, D-Ill., chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, shrugged off the remarks and said he assumes higher taxes will be part of the negotiations ``unless George Bush says again `no new taxes.''' Speaking to the National Press Club, Rostenkowski said it was Bush _ not Sununu _ who invited congressional leaders to negotiate, ``and that's encouraging.'' Still, Rostenkowski said, ``I have no intention of moving on taxes until the president does. I will not repeat the partisan warfare that marked last year's budget debate.'' He referred to Bush's unsuccessful effort to win a reduction in taxes on capital gains. Panetta, the House Budget Committee chairman, said Bush himself has to clearly state what the conditions for the talks are. ``The time has come to hear from the president,'' Panetta said. Fitzwater said: ``The president's position is clear. I am stating it. It comes directly from him. We will not prejudge anything that comes to the table'' in the budget talks. Asked how Democrats could believe the White House was negotiating in good faith when he was saying one thing and Sununu was quoted as saying the opposite, Fitzwater said: ``I speak for the president. It's as simple as that.'' Asked if Bush had reprimanded Sununu for the remarks, Fitzwater declined to say, adding, ``There is no sense getting sidetracked on these sorts of things.'' Twenty Republican senators, led by Sen. Connie Mack of Florida, have sent Bush a letter urging him to not renege on his ``read my lips'' campaign promise against new taxes. ``He understands their position. He's had a very strong position as well on taxes,'' Fitzwater said. ``But the fact is that he's got to try to solve the deficit problem and he's got to try to keep the economy growing and he wants to continue economic growth and that's a bigger problem that requires some long term thinking and requires the political courage to take leadership now.''

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Barry, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a summary of the 14 charges filed against Mayor Marion Barry: _One misdemeanor count of conspiring to possess cocaine and crack cocaine. The charge covers an unspecified number of incidents between the fall of 1984 and Jan. 18, the night Barry was arrested in an FBI sting operation. It carries a maximum penalty of one year in jail and a fine of up to $100,000 upon conviction. The indictment was handed up Thursday. _Ten misdemeanor counts of possessing cocaine, covering a period from Nov. 7, 1987, until Jan. 18. Four of the possession charges result from a probe of Barry's ties to convicted drug dealer Charles Lewis. Each possession charge carries a maximum penalty of one year in prison and up to a $100,000 fine upon conviction. Five of the charges were filed Feb. 15 and five Thursday. _Three felony counts of perjury alleging Barry lied to a grand jury. Barry is accused of lying when asked by the grand jury whether he knew of Lewis' involvement with cocaine, if he ever gave drugs to Lewis and if he received cocaine from Lewis. The perjury charges, returned Feb. 15, each carry a maximum penalty of five years in prison and a maximum $250,000 fine. If convicted of a felony, Barry would be barred from holding office or running for re-election.

DOC.HEAD: May Shocker: Record Snowfall in Wisconsin
LaserPhoto MI1
With AM-Floods-Dam, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Residents of Wisconsin, Illinois and Michigan residents traded swimsuits and garden hoes for parkas and snow shovels Thursday as freak storm brought back winter in May. The spring shocker was worst in Wisconsin, where snowfall up to 8 inches shattered records for late season snow. Some communities had to reassemble snowplows that had been stored for the season. Residents who broke out the lawn furniture and headed for the beach when tempeatures reached the 70s and 80s just two days before dug their coats out of mothballs. ``We expect anything up here,'' said police Officer Ron Michelson in Marquette, on Michigan's Upper Peninsula. ``It was up in the 80s for a while and I had my lounge out. It's still sitting on the porch getting full of snow.'' The Wisconsin snowstorm, accompanied by sleet and wind up to 30 mph, was blamed for hundreds of accidents and two traffic deaths. Powerlines downed by wind or accumulated ice caused temporary blackouts in more than 40,000 homes. The storm was caused by a low-pressure system that sucked cold air down from Canada and moisture up from the south, according to the National Weather Service. Weather service specialist Edmond Lowe said the snowfall, while not the latest in Wisconsin history, was a record for spring, surpassing the 5 inches recorded April 30, 1907. The latest snow ever to fall in spring in Wisconsin was May 31, 1889. In Hartford, a city of 7,000 about 30 miles northwest of Milwaukee, Mayor Dean Kirley declared a state of emergency, ordering residents off streets and advising businesses and schools to close after 8 inches of snow fell. ``It's not safe to be outdoors,'' the mayor said. Several cities in southeastern Wisconsin reported snowfalls deeper than 6 inches. Milwaukee recorded 2 inches, Madison 3 inches and Green Bay 3 inches. In Michigan, a May record of 12.8 inches of snow fell at Marquette County Airport. But in downtown Marquette, 800 feet lower and close to Lake Superior, only about an inch fell. ``It's terrible,'' said Bernice Haapala in Herman, Mich., where 4 inches of wet snow covered the ground. ``My tulips were blooming and all that kind of stuff. Now, that's why a person gets depressed.'' In Waukesha County west of Milwaukee, a near-blizzard during morning rush hour resulted in up to 100 accidents, authorities said. Some 2,500 bus riders were stranded when the service shut down. Flights at Milwaukee's Mitchell International Airport were delayed as runways were closed several times so slush could be cleared, said Greg Hetzel, assistant operations manager. In Washington County, Wis., snowplows and salting trucks were hastily retrieved from storage and assembled. ``We're strictly playing catch-up,'' said Frank Scharrer, the county highway commissioner. The misery dipped south into Illinois, where more than 4 inches of snow fell Wednesday night and Thursday morning on Chicago's northwest suburbs. Heavy rain brought out precautionary sandbagging crews along the Des Plaines and Illinois rivers, and a tornado toppled a silo in Virden, 20 miles south of Springfield. The storms eased in the afternoon, and were expected to move out of the area overnight. But that wasn't the last of the late winter _ clear skies mean temperatures can drop, and frost warnings were posted overnight in many areas. ``We're having normal May weather _ whatever that is,'' said weather service meteorologist Jack Cooley in Michigan. ``It's normal for the weather to be abnormal.''

DOC.HEAD: State-by-State Look at Flood Damage
With AM-Floods-Dams Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a state-by-state look at the damage caused in the south-central United States, experiencing some of the worst flooding in decades as rivers have flowed over their banks:
DOC.HEAD: ARKANSAS
DOC.TEXT: About 300 homes in Jefferson County flooded. Agricultural losses range up to $15 million and total losses, including reduced crop yields plus damage to equipment and buildings, will be about $20 million. Hundreds of cattle drowned or trapped on knolls in pastures surrounded by backwater from the Arkansas River. Spring wheat crop beyond salvage in some counties. Rice farmers unable to plant flooded fields. In Faulkner County, damage to farm buildings, equipment and land is about $870,000. About 400 cattle worth $250,000 missing along the river are presumed dead.
DOC.HEAD: TEXAS
DOC.TEXT: Twelve people killed. Between $500 million and $700 million in damage to agricultural production in north, northeast, east and central Texas. Federal Emergency Management Agency added nine counties to 16 already named in a May 2 disaster declaration. In north and central areas of the state, people remained unable to return to their homes. In the state's northeast corner, about 200 people have been evacuated from rural areas north of Texarkana. Much ranch and farm land still covered in water and officials have been unable to gauge extent of damage because lands are inaccessible. Estimate 11,000-15,000 acres of small range and rye grass will be lost. Extensive damage to farm equipment and miles of fencing. Four counties along the Red River _ Bowie, Lamar, Red River and Hopkins _ have received funds from the federal Soil Conservation Service to help shore up dams and levees and open clogged waterways. At least 600 cattle lost north of Texarkana and more than 1,000 head were stranded by high water. In the county surrounding Texarkana, estimated 65 percent of 4,500 acres of wheat was destroyed and corn crops were also under water. Along the Trinity River at Long Lake, 33 homes were damaged. As many as 300 people have left their homes in Liberty County, where four feet of water flooded homes.
DOC.HEAD: OKLAHOMA
DOC.TEXT: One person dead. State estimates of damages not expected before Friday. Red Cross says at least 600 homes damaged by high water. Number will increase as falling water reveals more damage. Gov. Henry Bellmon asked the Federal Emergency Management Agency to assess damage in 39 of the state's 77 counties.
DOC.HEAD: LOUISIANA
DOC.TEXT: High water expected to cause flooding only in low-lying areas. Major flooding will come only from backwater flooding if heavy rains develop. Slight flooding in the Bayou Rigolette area east of Pineville. Minor flooding reported along river bottoms north of Louisiana Highway 537 outside Plain Dealing and south of Elm Grove. Floods forced Shreveport to shut down two riverfront parks.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Hatch Act
Baltics Sign New Agreements, Unity Emerging
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS 5 grafs on Lithuania takes over TV-radio, military draft situation.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto RIGAB3
DOC.TEXT: The three separatist Baltic republics strengthened their solidarity Thursday, implementing an agricultural agreement that allows them to bypass Moscow and weighing a plan to coordinate their government policies. Estonia proposed reviving a Council of Baltic States that was created in 1934 when the republics were independent. It would include the president, prime minister and foreign ministers of Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania, said Valle Feldman, a spokesman for the Estonian Foreign Ministry. Estonian President Arnold Ruutel invited Presidents Vytautas Landsbergis of Lithuania and Anatoly Gorbunov of Latvia to sign an agreement with him in Tallinn on Saturday. They did not respond immediately. The three governments also implemented an agreement for the direct exchange of agricultural supplies and products, bypassing the central Soviet ministries and trade organizations that usually handle such transactions, the official Soviet news agency Tass reported. Last month, the republics signed a package of agreements to integrate their economies, and the deals are being implemented in stages. Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev opposes immediate independence for the Baltic republics, which were forcibly annexed by the Soviet Union in 1940. The proposed Council of Baltic States would further integrate the republics politically but would not constitute a confederation, said Leivi Sher, spokesman for Estonia's Supreme Council, or parliament. It could make non-binding recommendations on the three governments. ``So far, it's just an Estonian proposal,'' he said, adding that the parliament's executive committee approved the measure. It was unclear whether Latvia and Lithuania would agree to the proposal. Lithuanian spokesmen said no agreement was likely before the return to Vilnius next week of Lithuanian Prime Minister Kazimiera Prunskiene. She was in Paris as part of a tour of Western capitals. Mrs. Prunskiene told reporters in Paris that Lithuanian officials want to negotiate their independence with Moscow according to a formula proposed by French President Francois Mitterrand and West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl. They suggested that Lithuania temporarily suspend laws implementing the declaration of independence enacted March 11. The establishment of direct agricultural exchanges and the proposed Council of Baltic States signal a determination by the three republics to overcome Kremlin opposition to their separatist aspirations. The agricultural agreement, ``which entered into effect today, provides that each of the three ministries must have permanent representatives in the other Baltic republics, who will perform the functions of coordinators and assistants in joint efforts to resolve agricultural issues,'' Tass reported. Gorbachev imposed economic sanctions against Lithuania after the republic declared its independence. On May 4, Latvia declared its independence after an unspecified transition period, and Gorbachev is studying that action, according to Latvian officials. On Tuesday, Estonia dropped the symbols of Soviet power, changing its flag and name, invoked sections of the 1938 constitution that declared independence, and proclaimed solidarity with Latvia and Lithuania. Gorbachev has not responded to the Estonian actions. His embargo of oil and natural gas has taken its toll in Lithuania. Private automobile owners in Lithuania have been restricted to about seven gallons of gasoline per month, and rations for the month of May already have been exhausted, according to the unofficial Postfactum Information Agency in Moscow. It said rations might be reduced further in June as supplies dwindle further. Also on Thursday: _Lithuania's Parliament formally took control of the republic's radio and television. Under Soviet law, the broadcasting system reported to both the Vilnius government and Moscow. However, Lithuanians have effectively controlled their own broadcasting for some time. Shortly after declaring independence, the republic ordered one of the three Russian-language channels to switch to Polish television for the benefit of the 7 percent of Lithuania's population that is ethnically Polish. _Estonian Prime Minister Edgar Savisaar will meet Friday with Soviet Defense Minister Dmitri Yazov to discuss the spring military draft. Most Estonian youths up for the draft took advantage of a new Estonian law allowing them to perform alternative service at home, to the fury of the Soviet military. The newsletter Interfax, an affiliate of Moscow Radio, reported that 1,500 young men chose alternative service and only 800 signed up at draft offices.

DOC.HEAD: Backers, Foes of Bill to Regulate Liability Laws Clash at Hearing
DOC.TEXT: Congressional backers of a proposal to standardize state product-liability laws charged Thursday that consumer groups have tried to thwart the legislation through a campaign to ``trash anybody who stands in their way.'' The legislation, backed by the Bush administration and business representatives, would create a uniform federal standard for imposing punitive damages in lawsuits involving products that cause death or serious injury. Consumer groups have said the bill would unduly limit people's ability to collect for deaths and injuries that result from industry negligence or irresponsibility. Backers of the legislation argue that variations in liability laws from state to state offer potentially limitless damages and hinder product development and American competitiveness. The accusations against consumer groups came as Linda Lipsen, legislative counselor for Consumers Union, outlined what she said were misrepresentations given at previous hearings by the Senate Commerce Committee's consumer subcommittee into the safety of a never-marketed substitute for asbestos that was manufactured by the Missouri-based Monsanto Co. ``The administration and the manufacturing community have asserted before you that the product liability system prevented a totally safe substitute for asbestos _ calcium sodium metaphosphate _ from being marketed,'' said Lipsen, beginning her testimony before the panel. Sen. John Danforth, R-Mo., interrupted Lipsen, noting that she had not included her comments about Monsanto or its product in the 21-page written testimony she submitted to the panel for review before Thursday's hearing. ``I think you wanted to catch people unawares,'' said Danforth. ``It is a sneak attack. It is a sneaky, sneaky move on your part,'' he added to the applause of many spectators. Lipsen responded, ``It is not our normal course of business to impugn, even indirectly, members of this administration or witnesses before you.'' Lipsen was speaking on behalf of four organizations _ CU, the Consumer Federation of America, Public Citizen and the Public Interest Research Group. The last two groups were founded by noted consumer advocate Ralph Nader. Consumers Union is the nonprofit membership group that publishes Consumer Reports magazine. Asbestos is a fire-retardant fiber that was used widely in building construction until it was found to cause cancer. ``I think this is very typical of the Nader organizations ... to trash people, trash politicians, trash businesses, trash anybody who stands in their way,'' added Danforth. Nader, who was not present at the hearing, was again mentioned by Sen. Jay Rockefeller, D-W.Va., who angrily noted an open letter to him from the consumer advocate. The letter, which questioned Rockefeller's integrity, was sent to newspapers in West Virginia. According to Rockefeller, Nader's letter asked, ``Why are you spending your time huddled in Washington with corporate lobbyists, many of whom finance your campaign, gambling with the lives and safety of millions of people by taking away rights'' to seek relief by supporting federal product liability law? Completing her statement, Lipsen told the panel it had not been informed in previous testimony about a 1986 review by the Environmental Protection Agency that said there was reason to believe the asbestos substitute also could be carcinogenic. The bill would place a two-year limit on most product liability claims, with the exception of a 25-year limit on workers' injury claims. The measure also would allow separate trials or settlements of damage claims when a suit involves more than one company. Firms would pay damages in proportion of their responsibility for harm. The legislation would exempt from punitive damages manufacturers whose products had received pre-market approval from the Food and Drug Administration or the Federal Aviation Administration. Asked later about the charges levied by backers of the bill, Nader dismissed the criticisms as ``a side show'' designed to distract attention from key liability issues. ``These senators don't want to concentrate on explaining why they are siding with the corporations that are producing deadly toxic materials that are killing and injuring hundreds of thousands of Americans a year,'' he said. ``Furthermore, they don't want to answer the question to document the reason for their supporting this Wall Street legislation with specific numbers,'' Nader added.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Sends Amtrak Bill to Bush
DOC.TEXT: The Senate on Thursday sent President Bush a bill authorizing the government's subsidy of Amtrak rail passenger service through. The White House has threatened a veto. The House-Senate compromise, approved by voice vote, envisions more than $2 billion in federal money going to the railroad over the three-year period between last Oct. 1 and Sept. 30, 1992. The actual dollar amount will be determined as part of Congress' annual appropriations process. Bush administration officials have said they would recommend a veto of the bill because of the high cost, which it said amounts to about $29 a passenger, and because of a provision which would require Interstate Commerce Commission approval of railroad takeovers by non-railroad companies.

DOC.HEAD: Results Show Clear Croatian Democratic Union Victory
DOC.TEXT: The Croatian Democratic Union, a center-right group advocating the republic's independence from the rest of Yugoslavia, has won 196 of the 331 seats so far decided in the region's first free elections, partial results showed Thursday. The state news agency Tanjug, announcing the latest results from a second round of voting in the republic completed Monday, said 25 seats remain to be decided in the 356-seat, tricameral legislature. But the CDU already has a clear majority with 196 seats, versus a total of 83 for the republic's reform communists and their allies. Figures for a third group, a coalition of centrist forces that failed to make good on promising showings in pre-election polls, were not given by Tanjug. Political observers expect the CDU landslide to exacerbate Croatian tensions with the largest of Yugoslavia's six republics, Serbia. The victory also is expected to increase pressure for Croatia and Slovenia, the two wealthiest republics, to pull away from the rest of the federation. Croatia and Slovenia are the only republics that so far have held multiparty elections. In both, the ruling Communists were defeated by center-right parties emphasizing national interests over preservation of Yugoslavia's fragile federation.

DOC.HEAD: Group Wants Emphasis on Education, Health, Jobs
With AM-Children of the Delta V
DOC.TEXT: A $3 million study aimed at breaking the grip of poverty on the Mississippi Delta aims to shift government spending from welfare to creating jobs, a commission member said Thursday. A report on the study, prepared during the past 18 months by the Lower Mississippi Delta Commission, will be presented to Congress on Monday. A summary of the report shows that the commission will offer more than 400 recommendations that include establishing a regional bank for loans to area businesses, improving highways and schools, upgrading regional health care and attracting more tourists, The Commercial Appeal reported Thursday. The commission's study area took in 219 counties in Illinois, Missouri, Kentucky, Tennessee, Arkansas, Mississippi and Louisiana. The region, where 20.9 percent of the residents live below the federal poverty level, is one of the poorest in the country and has one of the highest rates for infant deaths. Former Rep. Ed Jones, a commission member from Tennessee, said he doubted the report would have many immediate, practical effects but its benefit over the long run could be substantial. ``(Congress) will slowly try to do something about it, but it will take time,'' Jones said from his home in Yorkville. ``The report is going to have to be researched by the committees that prepare the laws for Congress. A lot of it will be knocked out, no doubt about it.'' Jones, a Democrat who represented rural northwestern Tennessee for 29 years, said the report tries to refocus government spending because commissioners know that new federal and state spending will be hard to come by. ``There's no new money. We know that. But there's money that can be redirected,'' he said. ``Thirty to 40 percent of the people in the Delta region are on food stamps or some sort of welfare. If you could reduce that by half, look at the amount of money you would save.'' The commission, financed by a $3 million appropriation from Congress, is scheduled to disband Sept. 30, but the report suggests that states in the region create a successor organization to work as ``advocate for the Delta initiatives.'' ``Not only must the federal government find new ways to invest in the Lower Mississippi Delta's future, but other levels of government, the private sector, civic and non-profit organizations must step forward,'' the report's summary said. Among its recommendations, the report calls for: a regional development bank and community-based loan pools using federal, state and private funds; an agriculture center in Memphis to help educate Delta farmers on the latest farm technology; the addition of 400,000 housing units for low-income Delta residents by the year 2001; federal funding for magnet schools in each Delta state; a residential high school specializing in math and science; and an agency to promoting tourism throughout the region. Rep. Mike Espy, D-Miss., said lawmakers from the region have formed the Lower Mississippi Delta Congressional Working Group to press their colleagues to deal with the commission's report. ``We've got to get off to a fast start,'' Espy said. ``This is the road map.''

DOC.HEAD: Debt Load Swells by $2.6 Billion
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 4th graf pvs, bgng Credit grew, to CORRECT years to 1989 and 1988, sted 1988 and 1987; picks up 5th graf, With the
DOC.TEXT: Americans took out $2.6 billion more in consumer credit than they paid off in March as borrowing to buy automobiles rebounded from February, the government said Thursday. The Federal Reserve said consumer credit increased at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 4.4 percent, up from a scant 0.1 percent rise in February. That represented a sharp revision from the 5.7 percent rate estimated earlier reported for February and made the month the weakest in a year. Credit grew at a 3.7 percent annual rate in January rather than the earlier estimate of 6.4 percent, the Fed said. With the dampening of economic growth this year, consumers are borrowing less. The first quarter annualized rate of 2.7 percent compares with 7.6 percent for all of 1989 and 8.5 percent for 1988. Economist Sandra Shaber of The Futures Group, a Washington consulting firm, said the economy has been expanding for so long, 7{ years, that consumers have less appetite for ``big ticket'' items that are purchased with loans. ``I think there also has been an erosion of consumer confidence. ... People are worried. ... They read in the paper that the unemployment rate went up or that interest rates are going up. People pay attention,'' she said. Automobile loans in March advanced $1.8 billion, a 7.5 percent annual rate, after falling at a 5.2 percent rate in February and advancing at only a 1.7 percent rate in January. Credit card debt rose by $2 billion, or a 12.1 percent annual rate, in March, up from a 4.7 percent rate a month earlier. Bank, thrift and credit union loans not secured by real estate were down $1.2 billion, a 7.2 percent rate, after climbing at a 3 percent rate in February. Borrowing for mobile homes rose $17 million, a scant 0.9 percent annual rate, after rising at a 1.7 percent rate. The various changes left total consumer debt at the end of March at $721.5 billion.

DOC.HEAD: 100,000 March in Algiers Against Islamic Fundamentalism
DOC.TEXT: At least 100,000 men, women and children marched through downtown Algiers on Thursday to protest the rising trend of Islamic fundamentalism in this North African nation. The protesters carried banners reading ``Yes to Dialogue'' and ``Islam and tolerance'' as they marched two miles in a drizzling rain through the center of town. The so-called ``March of Democrats'' was organized by four of the nation's 24 political parties and was staged as an answer to a huge demonstration held three weeks ago by the Islamic Salvation Front. The Front is expected to capture almost 30 percent of the vote in June 12 municipal elections. Absent from Thursday's march were officials from the National Liberation Front, the party that has ruled Algeria since its independence from France in 1962. The protest was briefly interrupted twice by followers of the Islamic Front who tried to enter the march while shouting fundamentalist slogans. In a Thursday interview with Radio Monte Carlo, Premier Mouloud Hamrouche said Algeria was ``in an apprentice phase of democracy.'' ``We must permit all people to express themselves,'' he said. The June elections will be the first elections since opposition parties were legalized in February 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Modifies Position On Double Hulled Oil Tankers
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration dropped its opposition to requiring double hulls on oil tankers Thursday, announcing support for a bill to require them on new vessels. Transportation Secretary Samuel Skinner outlined the new administration position, which calls for some exemptions to the requirement, in a letter to a House-Senate conference committee mulling over two versions of oil pollution legislation. Skinner previously opposed a House version of the bill that would mandate double hulls on all tankers within 15 years and said the administration preferred a Senate bill which gave the secretary some discretion to require them on new vessels. The oil industry complained that the costly retrofitting of existing tankers would take too many out of service. The legislation was prompted by concern over last year's Alaskan oil spill from the single-hull Exxon Valdez, which ran into a rock ledge in Prince William Sound. Opponents of mandatory double hulls have said the 10 million gallon Exxon Valdez spill probably would have occurred anyway and might even have been worse with a double hull because the ship could have capsized and lost all its cargo instead of 10 percent of it. The new proposal would apply to tankers flying the U.S. flag and foreign tankers serving U.S. ports. Many foreign-flag tankers are owned by U.S. oil companies who register their ships under the flags of Panama, Liberia and other ``flags of convenience'' to avoid U.S. safety and wage regulations. Trade between U.S. ports is reserved to U.S.-flagged ships. ``The administration generally supports requiring double hulls on new construction of oceangoing tank vessels,'' Skinner said, noting that a National Academy of Sciences study concluded that double hulls are safe and give better protection to the environment. ``We believe that existing single-skin, oceangoing tank vessels should be phased out after they are 25 years old ... beginning in the year 2000,'' Skinner said. He said this would give U.S. and foreign tank owners about 10 years to replace their older vessels. The administration would not object to exemptions for vessels serving deepwater ports until 2015, he said, unless an international standard for double hulls is adopted before then. Tank barges plying only the Great Lakes could also be exempted until 2015, Skinner said. ``This deadline is reasonable yet would serve as a strong encouragement to owners to build only double-hulled inland barges and Great Lakes tank vessels,'' he said. Skinner said the new position was prompted by a compromise proposal by senators on the conference committee. He said the administration would work with the committee to write a bill that ``will afford the greatest protection to the environment without disrupting oil supplies, sending American refining jobs offshore or imposing unjustified burdens on the American consumer.''

DOC.HEAD: Renewed Eruption of Kilauea Volcano
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with second official saying eruption at Kupaianaha vent, not Pu`u O`o; overflight planned for later to determine extent of flow. No pickup. Pu`u O`o is pronounced poo'-oo-oh'-oh. The ` symbol, or glottal stop, divides the vowels in the Hawaiian name to show they constitute different syllables.
DOC.TEXT: Kilauea Volcano came to life again early Thursday after a rest of just a few days, officials said. A bright red glow in the night sky over the east flank of Kilauea signaled the resumption of the movement of molten rock at the surface in the area, officials said. Civil defense spokesman Rick Agan had said that the glow appeared to indicate that the Pu`u O`o vent in the east rift zone began erupting. But Christina Heliker, a geologist at the U.S. Geological Survey's Hawaiian Volcano Observatory, said later that the glow visible around that vent was from lava just below the surface that was moving to a second vent two miles away, known as Kupaianaha. Scientists and civil defense officials planned to fly over the rift zone later Thursday to determine the extent of the activity and direction of any new flows, she said. ``A lot of glow usually means there are lava flows on the surface,'' said Heliker. An earlier eruption at Pu`u O`o produced a lava flow that caused considerable destruction in the Royal Gardens subdivision. The Kupaianaha vent is the source of lava that destroyed more than 60 homes in the Kalapana Gardens subdivision during the past six weeks. The Kupaianaha vent shut down Monday but small amounts of lava were continuing to drain from the eight-mile flow into the ocean next to Harry K. Brown Park at Kalapana. A total of 139 homes have been destroyed by lava flows since the original eruption began Jan. 3, 1983. Damage to public and private property has been estimated at more than $60 million.

DOC.HEAD: Banks Opposing New Student Loan Service
DOC.TEXT: Bankers complain their business would be hurt under a plan to offer college loans directly through student aid offices. Three large student aid organizations are joining to form CollegeCredit, a new program designed to offer college students one-stop shopping for assistance. It will help aid officers to more easily package loans with other forms of assistance. The partners in the joint venture are: _the Student Loan Marketing Association (Sallie Mae), a federally-chartered, shareholder-owned company that buys student loans from lenders and collects the payments. _The College Board, a non-profit group which administers financial aid for colleges and provides a common aid application form. _the Teachers Annuity Association-College Retirement Equities Fund, a large pension plan for college and private school employees. CollegeCredit plans to offer $150 million in loans through The College Board starting in the 1990-91 school year. Teachers Annuity is setting aside $50 million and other lenders will supply the rest. Sallie Mae will buy the loans, replenishing the money available for future loans. All three groups will earn fee income in the process. Banks complain the program will skim off the cream of the student loan market degree-granting institutions, leaving them loans to trade school and community college students, which have a higher default rate. ``This program would service the most profitable part of the student loan market, leaving lenders with a higher concentration of higher-risk, low-balance loans to students,'' said Joe Belew, president of the Consumer Bankers Association, the trade group fighting the program. ``This process will further drive lenders out of the loan programs, ultimately denying thousands of low-income students access to student loans,'' he said. Bankers tried unsuccessfully to get Sallie Mae to drop the program. Now they're lobbying members of Congress and threatening to sue the organization. By law, Sallie Mae cannot originate student loans _ only buy them from others. CollegeCredit is a scheme to circumvent the restriction, Belew said. However, Gisela Valandigham, a spokeswoman for Sallie Mae, said the company is only providing the CollegeCredit venture with the same sort of support and loan servicing assistance it already provides to banks. She said Sallie Mae purchased $5 billion in student loans last year, mostly from banks, and the CollegeCredit program is not large enough to be a competitive threat. Aides to Sen. Claiborne Pell, D-R.I., chairman of the Senate Labor subcommittee on education, had expressed concern about CollegeCredit. But, Pell said in a letter to The College Board that his concerns had been eased after the program agreed to limit 1990-91 lending $150 million.

DOC.HEAD: Car Dealer to Decide Fate of `Christian' Car Deals
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS 4th graf pvs, Jackson said, to UPDATE with Jackson planning to meet next week with partners; Freddye in 2nd and 8th grafs is cq.
DOC.TEXT: A car dealer criticized by Jewish organizations said Thursday he's reconsidering a sales program that offers discounts aimed at Christians. ``I don't want to give up my program, but I don't like to step on anybody's toes,'' said Freddye ``Action'' Jackson, part owner, president and general manager of Brown Lincoln-Mercury. ``Hopefully we can come up with a program that satisfies everybody,'' he said after his nine-month-old Christian Members Buyers Plan was called discriminatory. The program offfers discounts to Jews as well as Christians. Jackson said he intended to meet next week with his business partners and separately with the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith, which has called for an end to the discount program. The Washington Post on Thursday quoted William E. Schuling, chairman of Mid-Atlantic Cars Inc. of which Brown Lincoln-Mercury is the major dealership, as saying he and Jackson had agreed to end the program. But Jackson said, ``I haven't made a decision on it at all.'' Shuling told the newspaper: ``No one's perfect. Everybody makes a mistake. Freddye is a preacher and a salesman. He meant no harm.'' A woman in Schuling's office said Thursday he was unavailable for comment. Jackson started the CMBP last August. But the uproar began Wednesday, to Jackson's surprise, after a local newspaper reported on the incentive program. ``Any time you talk about Christianity, people blow it out of proportion, people take it negatively. I don't know why,'' he said Wednesday. Jews may get the discounts because, said Jackson, they believe in God. Jews are the only non-Christians who can participate in the program. Jackson spoke by telephone Thursday to the Anti-Defamation League's David Friedman and they agreed to meet early next week. Friedman said, ``Fundamentally, he does not see anything wrong with the plan. He doesn't understand why it would be divisive or potentially discriminatory.'' Jackson, Friedman said, is ``a deeply committed person who sees this as a way of returning to the church money he has made as a businessman. But he also sees this as a business proposition. It's been very successfl.'' Friedman added: ``He's clearly not been sold on a number of the concepts I presented to him.'' Under Jackson's program, people who prove membership in a Christian church or Jewish synagogue may buy upscale Lincoln automobiles for $600 over cost to the dealer and Mercury cars at $250 over cost. Ministers pay $400 over factory cost for a Lincoln and $150 extra for a Mercury. In addition, the dealership donates to the church of the buyer's choice $100 for a Lincoln and $50 for a Mercury. Friedman said the inclusion of Jews ``doesn't change things one bit.'' ``The central point is that the customer should never have in the back of his mind the message that you're going to receive better or worse treatment because of the color of your skin, your sex or your religion,'' Friedman argued. Jackson, who said he became deeply religious, recalled that shortly after taking over the dealership last July, he prayed for ``a way of giving ... something from the dealership.'' He said he donates 10 percent of his personal income to the Shiloh Baptist Church in Landover, Md. Jackson said the CMBP was never intended to discriminate against anyone, likening it to incentives for military personnel, members of auto associations or employees of certain companies. ``If you're not a member of a buyer's plan, you can still get the same discount. You just have to negotiate,'' he said. Ford Motor Co., which builds Lincolns and Mercurys, is staying clear of the matter. ``The company knows about it. But Freddye Jackson is an independent businessman,'' John Spelich, a spokesman for Lincoln-Mercury in Detroit, said Wednesday. ``Ford Motor Co. has not and would not structure any of its consumer incentive programs in this nature, but we don't address those sort of things in our franchise agreement with our dealers,'' Spelich said. An Alexandria, Va., attorney has said he filed a Federal Trade Commission complaint against Brown Lincoln-Mercury. FTC spokeswoman Brenda Mack said she could neither confirm nor deny that the agency had received it.

DOC.HEAD: Thornburgh: Would Welcome Mexican Delivery of More in Drug Case
DOC.NOTE: EDS: INSERTS grafs 14-15 (two grafs before penultimate graf): ``Thornburgh reiterated,'' statement no DEA agents partcipated in capture, no evidence of agents' wrongdoing
DOC.TEXT: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh invited Mexican authorities Thursday to deliver more suspects accused of participating in the 1985 kidnapping and murder of an American drug agent. The attorney general defended the actions of Drug Enforcement Administration agents who last month arrested a Mexican doctor wanted in the case after he was whisked across the border to El Paso, Texas, in an operation the Mexican government has bitterly criticized. Thornburgh said the delivery of Dr. Humberto Alvarez Machain into U.S. custody was ``initiated by high-ranking Mexican police officials'' who offered to help the United States arrest those accused of kidnapping and killing DEA agent Enrique Camarena. ``If they want to turn over more of the defendants who are awaiting trial in this case _ I think it's probably unlikely _ we would certainly receive them and bring them to trial,'' the attorney general said. Asked if he had any objection to a repeat of the operation that brought Alvarez to U.S. custody, Thornburgh said that ``we're not dictators to how law enforcement operations'' take place in foreign countries. ``So long as there is no conduct outside of this country by other persons that shocks the conscience of the court, how a person gets here within our jurisdiction is not a material concern,'' Thornburgh said, alluding to U.S. court decisions that uphold the kidnapping of fugitives in foreign countries. ``Whatever actions that are carried out by Mexican authorities in Mexico are of no moment to us,'' Thornburgh said. Fourteen other suspects wanted in connection with the slaying, including two former high-ranking Mexican law enforcement officials, are still in Mexico. The Mexican government has a longstanding practice of not extraditing Mexicans to this country. Alvarez's defense lawyer has alleged that the Guadalajara gynecologist was kidnapped at gunpoint by four armed men and flown to Texas aboard a private airplane. The Mexican government, which accused U.S. authorities of violating Mexico's sovereignty, demanded an explanation of the DEA's role in the arrest. Six people have been arrested in Mexico in connection with the kidnapping of Alvarez, who is awaiting trial in Los Angeles. Mexico has also demanded the extradition of Antonio Garate Bustamante, a former Mexican police officer living in Los Angeles who told the Los Angeles Times that he directed the operation. Thornburgh said he ordered DEA to investigate the circumstances of the arrest to counter Alvarez's claims that he was unlawfully arrested by U.S. authorities. The attorney general, who met last week with Mexican authorities, said, ``In an era of increased cooperation, it's my view that our people regarded this in good faith as another example of the type of cooperation that was being extended. And it's not unique.'' Thornburgh reiterated that ``no Drug Enforcement Administration agents were involved in bringing ... (Alvarez) to the United States. The first contact that DEA had with him was when they took him into custody'' in El Paso. The attorney general said there was no evidence ``at this time'' that DEA agents violated any regulations and therfore he had no plans to discipline anyone involved in Alvarez's arrest. Discussing the subject during a breakfast interview, he said, ``I place the integrity and the value of the life of American citizens No. 1.'' ``This case has to do with the prosecution of Dr. Alvarez Machain, an individual who is charged with ... using his medical skills to keep alive an American citizen who was being tortured so that he could be tortured some more,'' Thornburgh said.

DOC.HEAD: Winter Revisits Great Lakes; Rain Douses East
DOC.TEXT: Winter revisited the Great Lakes on Thursday, bringing record spring snowfall, while rain pelted much of the East. Flooding continued to bedevil some residents of Texas, Oklahoma, Arkansas and Louisiana. A late storm that began Wednesday night and continued into Thursday dumped wet snow on Wisconsin, Michigan and parts of Illinois. Snow accumulations ranged from a trace in central Illinois to four inches in Chicago's northwest suburbs to over a foot in some high points on Michigan's Upper Peninsula. Eight inches piled up in Michigan's Marquette, Negaunee and Ishpeming counties, and 12.8 inches fell at Marquette's airport. Overnight snowfall across eastern Wisconsin ranged from half an inch to nearly four inches. Three inches fell at Green Bay, Wis. Advisories for frost and freezing temperatures have been posted Thursday night across western and northern Michigan and much of Wisconsin. South of the late-season snowbelt, there were thunderstorms scattered from southern Michigan and Wisconsin, across Illinois and Indiana into Kentucky. In the East, scattered showers were reported from southern Florida through New England. Marble-sized hail fell near Carbondale, Ill, and there was local flooding elsewhere in the state and in Wisconsin. A flood warning was in effect over the Sabine and Neches river basins in eastern Texas, the Brazos river in northern and central Texas and the Trinity river in northern and southeast Texas. Also flooding was the Red River, which forms the Texas-Oklahoma line and flows into Arkansas. Flood warnings were posted for the Louisiana's Atchafalaya and Black rivers and the Mississippi in Louisiana. On Friday, showers were predicted from Montana to Louisiana, with thunderstorms possible over parts of Nebraska, Kansas and Colorado. Showers also were forecast for northern New England, and the rest of the nation was expected to get fair or partly cloudy skies. During the 6 hours ending at 2 p.m. EDT, heavier rainfall included 1{ inches at Camp Springs, Md., more than an inch at Fort Belvoir, Va., and New Bern, N.C., and Richmond, Va., and almost an inch at National Airport in Washington, D.C. In Valdez, Alaska, 9 inches of snow were on the ground Thursday morning, the latest installment in a record-breaking season. Since Oct. 23, 560.2 inches have fallen at Valdez, breaking the recored of 517 inches set in the winter of 1928-29. Low temperature records were broken in Casper, Wyo., 20 degrees, and Rapid City, S.D., 24. The low temperature in the lower 48 states was 10 degrees at Pinedale, Wyo.

DOC.HEAD: NATO Defense Chiefs Agree: Less Need for Battlefield Nuclear Arms
