DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with quotes from Cheney, Woerner, final statement, details. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney and other NATO military chiefs agreed Thursday that battlefield nuclear weapons will be less important in a changing Europe, but failed to back a Dutch call for a quick pullout of such arms. The officials repeatedly emphasized that NATO would continue to need nuclear weapons in its arsenal. ``We think there will be no denuclearization of Europe,'' West Germany's defense chief, Gerhard Stoltenberg, told German reporters. Cheney said the alliance may decide after careful study to make unilateral cuts in nuclear-tipped artillery shells, mostly based in West Germany. ``That's entirely possible,'' he told a news conference at the end of two days of talks by NATO's Nuclear Planning Group talks in the Kananaskis area, about 50 miles west of Calgary in the Canadian Rockies. ``There's no need today to make that decision. We did not make a decision here.'' Dutch Defense Minister Relus ter Beek had urged his fellow ministers in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization to eliminate those weapons and challenge the Soviet Union to follow suit. Stoltenberg, whose country is home to most of the alliance's nuclear forces, supported him. With East-West tensions easing, NATO diplomats increasingly believe they can safely cut back on both the artillery shells and short-range nuclear missiles. The land-based weapons are deployed to hit targets in East European countries, now no longer adversaries. In their final statement, the ministers said, ``We agreed that there is a diminishing need for nuclear systems of the shortest range.'' NATO Secretary-General Manfred Woerner reported ``clear agreement to reduce or even ... eliminate'' nuclear artillery. But he said a decision would be made only after a detailed study on the role nuclear weapons should play in the future. The ministers welcomed President Bush's decision last week to cancel plans to develop a more powerful version of the Lance surface-to-surface missile and modernize 155mm artillery shells. They supported his call for early negotiations between the United States and the Soviet Union on trimming their stockpiles of short-range nuclear missiles. NATO agreed last spring to start bargaining, but only after both sides agreed on an accord to slash tanks, artillery, troops and other non-nuclear forces in Europe, and began implementing that accord. Bush said last week he would be willing to speed up the timetable so nuclear negotiations could start as soon as an agreement was signed. Negotiators for NATO and the Warsaw Pact are pushing to wrap up a deal this fall. Woerner said Bush and other NATO leaders will set out objectives for the negotiations at a summit, which he announced will be held July 5-6 in London. The alliance has a limited arsenal of land-based nuclear weapons. There are 88 Lance launchers, with some 700 nuclear warheads, according to analysts. The missile, expected to be obsolete in 1995, has a maximum range of about 75 miles. The Warsaw Pact has a 12-to-1 advantage in short-range launchers, according to NATO estimates. The West has about 1,500 nuclear artillery shells. There are no estimates on the Soviet arsenal, although analysts say the Kremlin has tended to rely more on missiles than on artillery. The defense ministers urged Moscow ``to carry out substantial reductions'' in theater nuclear missiles. Under the planning, NATO would rely more on air-launched nuclear weapons. The United States is developing a tactical air-to-surface missile, known as the TASM, to replace gravity bombs. It would be launched from fighter aircraft capable of firing both conventional and nuclear weapons. Woerner said the TASM, likely to be highly controversial in Western Europe, was not discussed at this meeting. But he said dual-capable aircraft ``will acquire greater importance as shorter range systems are phased out without replacement.'' Britain's defense chief, Tom King, said the alliance must make sure its nuclear deterrence ``is credible, which means it's got to work, which means that if necessary it has to be modernized.'' The ministers hold nuclear strategy sessions twice a year. All 16 nations, except France, attend the sessions. France is not part of NATO's joint military command. Iceland, which has no armed forces, attends as an observer.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Insists U.S. Capacitors Were Imported Legally
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Saddam on 2nd reference is correct
DOC.TEXT: Iraq on Thursday repeated its claim that it legally imported electronic capacitors from the United States for a university project. American officials say the devices can be used as nuclear bomb triggers. A spokesman for Iraq's Foreign Ministry said some of the capacitors displayed by President Saddam Hussein during a Tuesday speech were ``imported from the United States in 1988 by the University of Technology in a legal manner and in conformity with U.S. regulations.'' The anonymous spokesman, quoted by the official Iraqi News Agency in a dispatch monitored in Cyprus, said the capacitors were imported solely for scientific research. The State Department said Wednesday it was asking Iraq for ``urgent clarification'' of Saddam's earlier claim that his country had acquired the devices. ``We are certainly interested in knowing where these capacitors came from and what their (Iraq's) intentions are,'' said Richard Boucher, State Department's deputy spokesman. ``We have not authorized the sale to Iraq of any capacitors that would be useful in a nuclear military program,'' Boucher said, adding that the export of such devices to Iraq would violate U.S. law. He said the U.S. ambassador to Iraq, April Gillespie, ``has asked for urgent clarification of (Saddam) Hussein's comments.'' Saddam asserted on Tuesday that Iraq circumvented a U.S. export ban to obtain the devices, and that scientists at the Ministry of Industry and Military Industrialization had succeeded in producing two similar devices. The Iraqi president denied, however, that the devices were intended as nuclear triggers. He said they are electrical capacitors for use in research. Saddam said the Iraqi-made devices were completed in March, five days after British authorities seized a consignment of 40 U.S.-made capacitors at Heathrow airport near London.

DOC.HEAD: Bus Rolls Down Embankment Outside Guatemala Capital, 38 Killed
DOC.TEXT: A bus swerved to avoid an oncoming vehicle and rolled off a mountain road west of the capital Thursday, killing 38 people and injuring 23, an official said. Fire department spokeswoman Carolina de Leon said the bus was on its way from the capital to Antigua when the driver made a sharp turn to avoid another vehicle. The turn sent the bus rolling down an embankment, 25 miles west of the capital, she said. The fire department and Red Cross workers said the dead were not immediately identified and many were Indians from area villages who carried no personal documents.

DOC.HEAD: Three Captured Frenchmen Freed in Africa
DOC.TEXT: Three Frenchmen and three Congo residents taken hostage by rebels last month near the Congo-Angola border have been freed, the foreign ministry said Thursday. The six, and a French colleague freed earlier this week, were part of an oil exploration team working in the Congo near the Angolan enclave of Cabinda. The oil-rich region is separated from the rest of Angola by a strip of Zaire along its southern border, and is bordered by the Congo on the north. The hostages were captured April 27 by rebels seeking independence for Cabinda. The Frenchmen were being taken to Zaire's capital, Kinshasa, to be flown back to France, the ministry said. The ministry said the French were in good health, and expressed thanks to Zairean authorities for helping obtain their release. No details were given about any negotiations.

DOC.HEAD: Child Witness Resists Testifying, Changes Testimony
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note contents.
DOC.TEXT: The first child witness in the retrial of the McMartin Pre-School molestation case tearfully resisted testifying Thursday, but she was persuaded by prosecutors and her parents to go on. The 11-year-old girl then pleaded memory lapses and ended her testimony on an inconclusive note, saying she couldn't remember if she was sexually assaulted by defendant Raymond Buckey when she attended nursery school. ``I don't remember if it happened or not,'' she said when asked if Buckey touched her sexually. To the final cross-examination question about whether she was sodomized, she answered, ``I don't remember.'' The first McMartin Pre-School trial, the longest and costliest criminal proceeding in U.S. history, ended in January when Buckey was acquitted of 40 counts of molestation at the family-owned school in Manhattan Beach. His mother, Peggy McMartin Buckey, was acquitted of 12 charges. The jury, however, deadlocked on 13 counts against Raymond Buckey, and the district attorney decided to retry him on eight of those charges involving three children. The girl who testified Thursday did not appear at the first trial, and the jury deadlocked 11-1 for acquittal on the charges which involved her. The child witness offered one answer that seemed to conflict with her earlier testimony that Buckey neither raped nor sodomized her. The response came after a prosecutor read from grand jury and preliminary hearing transcripts of testimony offered by the girl six years ago. ``I don't recall but I remember it did happen,'' the girl said when asked whether she was sexually hurt by Buckey. The prosecutor asked no further questions to clarify the answer. Deputy District Attorney Pam Ferrero read sections of the transcript of a 1984 hearing in which the girl used anatomically explicit dolls to show that she had been raped and sodomized. The youngster said repeatedly she couldn't remember giving any of that testimony nor whether any of the events related happened. It was only at the end of the long series of readings that she appeared to change her mind. During questioning by Buckey's attorney, Danny Davis, she said she also didn't remember testifying that she was taken to a farm where she saw a pig killed with a knife. ``I can't remember,'' she said. ``A pig killed with a knife would be pretty important to you?'' asked Davis. ``Yes,'' responded the girl. ``Knowing yourself, would that be something you would forget?'' he asked. ``I really can't remember that,'' she said. Nor could she remember that in 1984 she described a woman teacher as lying on top of her nude and women teachers playing ``naked games.'' ``I can't remember,'' she answered repeatedly. Charges against five women teachers, stemming in part from those allegations, were dismissed after the preliminary hearing for lack of evidence. Ms. Ferrero told Superior Court Judge Stanley Weisberg that the girl's parents called her Wednesday night saying the child was ``extremely reluctant'' to return for more questioning. But the parents agreed to bring her anyway. Ms. Ferrero said the girl expressed the same desire not to testify when she arrived at court but ``was trying to be cheerful'' and agreed to cooperate. As Buckey's attorney began asking intimate questions about her body, she suddenly announced, ``May I be excused? I have a stomach ache.'' Minutes later she was observed in the hallway sobbing in her father's arms as he tried to comfort her. After and hour's recess, the child returned to the witness stand. Her father was allowed to stand next to her and she clutched a large stuffed toy snake. But during her testimony, the father developed a nosebleed and had to leave. ``Oh God!'' the girl exclaimed as he left. Her mother replaced him standing next to the girl for the balance of her testimony.

DOC.HEAD: Ted Turner, in China, Talks of Attack on Democracy Protesters
DOC.TEXT: U.S. broadcast magnate Ted Turner said Thursday that the Chinese government felt forced to call in troops last year to put an end to a massive, pro-democracy movement. He also remarked that the hudnreds of thousands of students who occupied central Beijing's Tiananmen Square for weeks ``were breaking the law.'' Turner, owner of the Cable News Network, criticized the United States in a speech to foreign journalists for what he said was U.S. interference in the affairs of other nations. ``The thing that drives me most crazy and makes me most embarrassed is the fact that our leaders feel they have the right to interfere in the affairs of other countries and tell them what to do,'' he said. ``I personally don't feel that's done a bit of good.'' Turner was asked what he felt the U.S. response should have been to China's violent crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators on June 3-4, which left hundreds dead and thousands wounded in the streets. After the crackdown, the United States banned high-level contacts, imposed economic sanctions, allowed Chinese students in the United States to overstay their visas and criticized China for human rights abuses. Beijing has repeatedly accused Washington of ``interfering in China's internal affairs.'' Turner said, ``Whatever we are trying to accomplish, we would accomplish more by saying that a tragedy occurred (and that) we bleed for the students as well as for those in government and the soldiers who felt forced to take that action. ``You catch more flies with honey.'' Turner's CNN played an important role in showing the world the events of last spring, when masses of students, intellectuals and workers took to the streets every day for seven weeks demanding political reforms and an end to corruption in government. When the army was called in, world viewers watched TV film of bloodied victims being rushed to hospitals on flatbed tricycles, columns of army tanks on Beijing's Changan Avenue and a tank, set afire by furious students, blazing in the shadow of the Goddess of Democracy, erected in the square days before. Turner is in Beijing for a meeting of the Better World Society, a Washington-based group of which he is founder and chairman. On Friday, Turner and the society's board of directors are to meet with Premier Li Peng, a conservative who supported the army crackdown.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 3 grafs to UPDATE with cause of death.
DOC.HEAD: Novelist Walker Percy Dies At 74
DOC.TEXT: Walker Percy, whose deeply humane novels and essays made him a unique voice in American letters, died of cancer Thursday at his home. He would have been 75 on Monday. Percy's first novel, ``The Moviegoer,'' won him the National Book Award in 1962 and set the themes that would occupy him for his entire career: modern malaise in the New South and the tenuous, often outlandishly comic, hope for human connection. His best friend and fellow author Shelby Foote was in Covington at the time of Percy's death at his home here on the banks of the Bogue Falaya river, across Lake Pontchatrain from New Orleans. In Jackson, Miss., author Eudora Welty said, ``I'm very grieved and very, very hurt for all his family. His friendship meant a lot to me and his work meant a great deal to me, too.'' Services will be Saturday at St. Joseph's Abbey near Covington. After ``Moviegoer,'' Percy's novels included ``The Last Gentleman'' (1966), ``Love in the Ruins'' (1971), ``Lancelot'' (1977), ``The Second Coming'' (1980), and ``The Thanatos Syndrome'' (1987). Once described by critic Alfred Kazin as ``the satiric Dostoyevsky of the bayou,'' Percy claimed to have been influenced more by the European existentialists, especially Kierkegaard, than by fellow Southerners. He peddled his 1983 ``Lost in the Cosmos'' as ``the last self-help book'' and set out to ``explain why it is that man is the only alien creature, as far as we know, in the entire planet.'' His other major piece of non-fiction was ``The Message in the Bottle'' (1975), essays on the philosophy of language. Percy revealed his thoughts in the mid-50's as he contemplated his future after two failed novels: ``It crossed my mind, what if I did something that American writers never do, which seems to be the custom in France: Namely, that when someone writes about ideas, they can translate the same ideas to fiction and plays. ... So it just occurred to me, why not take these ideas I'd been trying to write about, in psychiatry and philosophy, and translate them into a fictional setting in New Orleans, where I was living.'' All six of his novels send upper-middle-class Southern heroes out in hot pursuit of those ideas. Born in Birmingham, Ala., Percy was 11 when his lawyer father killed himself. Two years later, his mother was killed in an automobile accident. He and his two brothers went to Greenville, Miss., to live with ``Uncle Will'' _ William Alexander Percy, his father's cousin. Uncle Will was the author of ``Lanterns on the Levee,'' the classic treatise on the best of the Old South. A famed World War I infantry officer, poet, politician, lawyer, and planter, he presided over a bachelor household that was a teeming crossroads of Southern culture. It was ``visited regularly by other poets, politicians, psychiatrists, sociologists, black preachers, folk singers, itinerant harmonica players,'' Percy has written. The young ward found him ``the most extraordinary man I have ever known.'' Percy graduated from University of North Carolina in chemistry and got a medical degree from Columbia University in 1941. The next year, working as a pathologist at Bellevue Hospital in New York City, he caught pulmonary tuberculosis while performing autopsies on derelicts. ``I've often said that getting a light case of TB was the best thing that could've happened to me. It gave me a period of enforced idleness,'' said Percy, who spent his three years of recovery reading voraciously. By the time he was well, he had turned to a life of writing. Inheritance allowed him to move to New Orleans and marry. He converted to Roman Catholicism. In 1950, he settled in Covington with Uncle Will's desk in his study. He raised two daughters and became a grandfather. Between his recovery and the publication of ``The Moviegoer'' are 20 years that Percy joked about not remembering what he did with. During those apprentice years, he wrote two failed novels and numerous articles on language and psychiatry _ ``I felt more at home on the psychiatric ward than anywhere else ... maybe it takes one to know one.'' Both his religious conversion and three years of Freudian psychoanalysis during medical school played an integral role in his writing. One book's subtitle is ``the adventures of a bad Catholic at a time near the end of the world.'' Percy won the prestigious Campion Award in 1986 from the Catholic Book Club despite downplaying the role of the Church in his work. He insisted he was not a Catholic writer except that his writing is informed by the Judeo-Christian view of man: ``But that's about it.'' Named by Pope John Paul II as the only American on the Pontifical Council for Culture, Percy said, ``I understand it only requires one trip a year to Rome. I do well just to get to New Orleans.'' The seclusion of Covington served him well. He often gave credit to his ``original Presbyterian work ethic'' for the discipline and steadiness he brought to his work. Mornings by the bayou he wrote, left-handed, in a three-ring binder. Afternoons, he often typed what he'd written. He said he had no terrors, he had no writer's block. But he found it hard work. He could describe the maddening frustration. He claimed no secrets or solutions. He told one interviewer, ``It's a question of being so pitiful God takes pity on you, looks down and says, `He's done for. Let's let him have a couple of good sentences.' ``It's a strange, abject, little-understood profession.'' He is survived by his wife Mary Bernice, two daughters Mary Pratt and Ann Boyd and four grandsons.

DOC.HEAD: Canadian Police Seize Drugs On Mohawk Reservation
DOC.TEXT: Canadian police seized about $800,000 in drugs and cash on strife-torn Mohawk territory Thursday, and some Indians complained of rampant drug smuggling by the reservation's gambling supporters. Authorities said, however, that the raid was not connected to a violence-filled struggle over gambling rights on the reservation. About 100 officers led by Ontario Provincial Police seized the cocaine and marijuana from homes at Cornwall Island on the St. Regis Indian Reservation and in nearby Cornwall, Ontario, said OPP spokesman Peter West. The four pounds of cocaine and about a half-pound of marijuana was worth nearly $1 million in Canadian dollars, or $800,000 in U.S. dollars, West said. He said 21 people were charged with drug and weapons counts under Canadian law, while 16 more were being sought. Police said about half of the suspects lived on the reservation, which straddles the U.S.-Canadian border. The 6 a.m. raid came after a 14-month undercover investigation by Ontario and Quebec police, the Royal Canadian Mounted Police and New York state troopers, West said. Twelve guns were seized, including at least three automatic rifles. Police also seized about $32,000 cash in U.S. dollars. Reservation violence had been quelled since hundreds of New York and Canadian police swarmed onto the Mohawk land May 1, when two Indians were shot to death in a 10-month-old casino gambling feud. The calm and the heavy police presence gave authorities the opportunity to make the arrests safely, West said. ``We figured it was better to do it now, rather than waiting for it to quiet down and us pulling our people off,'' he said. ``We figured we had the resources there now.'' Mohawks who resent the police presence said authorities used excessive force in making the arrests. Pat Martin, who runs a clothing store on the reservation, said police went to her daughter's and niece's homes by mistake. ``My niece is all bruised up,'' Martin said. ``They got her up out of bed and made her run outside in just her nighty.'' Broken glass was strewn around the living room at the home of Elvis Thompson, where police smashed the door to arrest him, said Thompson's girlfriend, Amanda Adams. Police ``said they knocked, but we got up and didn't get halfway to the door before they broke it down,'' Adams said. Three of Thompson's brothers and two cousins also were arrested, she said. Some tribal leaders say drug smuggling is widespread among gambling supporters on the 28,000-acre reservation, where eight casinos and bingo halls operate on the U.S. side. All but one of the gambling halls has been closed since police took over the reservation. Harold Tarbell, head chief of the tribal council that governs the U.S. side of the reservation, said drugs, prostitution and other crime associated with gambling is rampant. ``We need the support of outside police forces to remove the criminal element'' from the reservation, Tarbell said in a statement after the raid. Tarbell, who opposes gambling, and the other two U.S. chiefs Wednesday asked Gov. Mario Cuomo to leave state police on the reservation until a reservation police force can be created to patrol the U.S. sector. Gambling supporters call the police an invading army that is violating the reservation's sovereignty.

DOC.HEAD: Senator, Drug Policy Director Clash Over Hard-Core Estimates
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS grafs 6-8: ``After being,'' clash on MacNeil-Lehrer
DOC.HEAD: With BC-States-Cocaine
DOC.TEXT: A study indicating there are nearly 2.2 million hard-core cocaine addicts in the United States proves the administration has adopted the wrong strategy in the drug war, the chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee said Thursday. ``This news is as alarming as it is tragic,'' Sen. Joseph R. Biden, D-Del., said at a news conference. Biden released a report prepared by his committee that indicated the number of hard-core addicts was more than double an earlier estimate by the National Institute of Drug Abuse. William Bennett, director of the Office of National Drug Control Policy, called Biden's statement ``ridiculous'' and said it was designed to provide ammunition for next fall's congressional elections. The administration, Bennett said, has assumed from the outset of the drug war that there are about 4 million hard-core addicts and that the national drug strategy is working. After being at odds in separate interviews throughout the day, Biden and Bennett clashed Thursday night on the Public Broadcasting System show, the ``MacNeil-Lehrer Newshour.'' Bennett told Biden sharply that ``you are trying to discredit our policy'' and ``we think this is just a bit disingenous.'' ``I don't like this rhetoric, Bill,'' Biden shot back. ``I don't like these cheap shots about being disingenuous.'' Nearly one of every 100 Americans is a weekly cocaine user, and some areas of the United States have ``extraordinarily high concentrations'' of addicts, according to the report. The study defined a hard-core user as someone who uses cocaine once a week. One of every 40 people in New York state uses cocaine at least once a week, the study said. The nation's capital has the highest per capita rate, 32.9 hard-core users among every 1,000 Washington residents, according to the report. Biden said an an earlier estimate of 862,000 U.S. addicts made by the National Institute of Drug Abuse was far too low. The Judiciary Committee findings, prepared under the supervision of Mark A.R. Kleiman of the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard, underscored a dispute between Biden and a number of other lawmakers and the administration about whether to aim the thrust of the drug war against hard-core or casual users. Biden has said hard-core users should be the primary target, while Bennett has advocated efforts directed mainly at stemming casual cocaine use. ``Our consciences demand that we act, our pocketbooks command that we do so and our safety demands that it be done immediately,'' Biden said, unveiling a $3 billion drug-fighting plan that includes stepped up research to find new treatments and doubling crime-fighting grants to $900 million a year. Dr. Edgar Adams of the National Institute of Drug Abuse described the 37-page report, ``Hard-Core Cocaine Addicts: Measuring and Fighting the Epidemic,'' as ``a good attempt to look at what is a very complex problem.'' Adams cautioned that it might be hard to figure the margin of error in the Senate figures, but praised the study because it ``restates the fact that drug abuse is a very serious problem.'' The report said that only one out of 10 hard-core addicts receives drug treatment and that most who are arrested are quickly back out on the streets. Bennett said in a telephone interview that he saw no way in which the report contributed to the war against drugs and was scornful of its claim that the government had undercounted. ``This is ridiculous,'' Bennett said. ``What official estimate is he talking about? There is no official estimate. In the national drug control strategy we use a number larger than the one he is using. We use 4 million.'' Adams said homeless invididuals were not counted in the the NIDA study. He said the institute maintained a 95 percent confidence level for its estimate of 862,000 hard-core addicts in households. The committee report said 1.5 million hard-core cocaine addicts were arrested annually and represent about 20 percent of arrestees nationwide. ``This suggest that cocaine is a major cause of crime in the United States,'' it said. The report estimated that New York state had the most hard-core addicts, 434,000, followed by California, 325,000; Texas, 144,000; Illinois, 142,000; and Florida, 93,000.

DOC.HEAD: Bell Atlantic OK'd for Government Contracts Again
DOC.TEXT: The Treasury Department said Thursday it had agreed to let Bell Atlantic Corp. and a subsidiary, Chesapeake and Potomac Telephone Co., bid on government contracts again. The department had suspended Bell Atlantic and C&P on April 3 from contracting with the executive branch on the grounds the companies had ``made a material misrepresentation in competing for the contract'' in January to provide a new digital telephone system for Treasury offices in the Washington area. ``We came to an agreement with them'' to lift the no-contracting order, said Treasury spokesman Art Siddon. He would not elaborate on what the agreement was or what the misrepresentation been. Bell Atlantic said it ``has since submitted information in support of its position that it did not misrepresent any fact to Treasury.'' ``Treasury has agreed to terminate the suspension and all related administrative action, and Bell Atlantic has agreed to reemphasize to its employees, and to the employees of its subsidiaries, the need to verify all information provided to the government, including information supplied by subcontractors.'' Bell Atlantic spokesman Ken Pitt said confusion arose over the type of phones the company was offering. He said the subcontracting equipment manufacturer, Northern Telecom, had several versions of the phone being offered, all carrying the same model number. ``Treasury alleged we were offering one set, but really were offering another,'' Pitt said. ``We submitted the manufacturer's documentation but the manufacturer's documentation had not kept pace with its market offerings.'' Siddon said Bell Atlantic did not lose any Treasury business during the suspension. The digital phone system contract at Treasury is valued at between $60 million and $100 million. Treasury twice has awarded the contract to the American Telephone and Telegraph Co., and Bell Atlantic won appeals to reopen the bidding. Pitt said he did not know if Bell Atlantic was still in the running for the contract.

DOC.HEAD: Twin Juries in Racial Killing Deliberate A Second Day Without Verdict
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead, INSERTS one graf after 8th graf pvs, `Inside, jurors...,' to UPDATE with both juries ending deliberations for the night without reaching verdicts. Pick up 9th graf pvs, `Prosecutors allege...
DOC.TEXT: Two juries in the Bensonhurst racial slaying deliberated a second day without a verdict Thursday as police in riot gear stood guard at the courthouse, where demonstrators attacked a defense attorney a day earlier. Separate state Supreme Court juries are considering the cases against alleged gang leader Keith Mondello and accused gunman Joseph Fama, both 19. The defendants, both white, are charged with second-degree murder and other crimes in the Aug. 23 slaying of 16-year-old Yusuf Hawkins, who was black. Each faces 25 years to life if convicted of murder. Rain sent demonstrators in the courthouse square scurrying for cover and their cardboard placards became sodden and smeared. A police officer on the scene said 100 protesters gathered in the square at one point Thursday but virtually no one remained by late afternoon. On Wednesday, Mondello's attorney, Stephen Murphy, was punched in the face by one of about 300 protesters demanding murder convictions in the case. When Murphy took a lunch break Thursday he was surrounded briefly by a handful of protesters shouting ``Yusuf, Yusuf,'' but he returned to the courthouse without incident. Lines of blue police barricades were erected in front of the courthouse and more than 50 police officers, many in riot gear, were on hand. Inside, jurors considering the charges against Mondello and Fama continued to rehear trial testimony and to re-examine evidence. Thursday was the third full day of deliberations for the Fama jury and the second full day for the Mondello panel. Both juries went home for the night Thursday without reaching verdicts. Prosecutors allege Mondello organized a mob of bat-carrying whites who surrounded Hawkins and his three companions, all black. Fama allegedly stepped from the mob and fatally shot Hawkins in the chest with a .32 caliber automatic. Justice Thaddeus Owens said the juries, which are sequestered during deliberations, would work through the weekend if they fail to reach a verdict earlier.

DOC.HEAD: Western Powers Urge Greater Air Access for Berlin
With AM-East Germany
DOC.TEXT: The United States, France and Britain have asked the Soviet Union to allow more air travel to and from Berlin, a U.S. spokesman said Thursday. The four World War II Allies still retain control over air travel in the once-divided city. The Western powers for several years have been urging more access, to boost Berlin's status. ``In view of the significant changes in and around Berlin in recent months, the Allies believe that greater aviation access and greater coordination among Berlin's aviation authorities can and should be achieved,'' said a statement from Anthony W. Sariti, spokesman for the U.S. mission in West Berlin. It continued: ``Even prior to unification, the Four Powers can work constructively with the two German states for greatly improving Berlin's aviation links.'' The statement said representatives from France, Britain and the United States presented the proposals during a meeting with officials from the Soviet embassy on Thursday. In addition to possible objections from the Soviets, the proposals for more air traffic are likely to run into difficulties with German environmental groups. Ecologists say Berlin's skies are already overcrowded with commercial airliners, and have urged more use of rail travel.

DOC.SECOND: Four Policemen Killed, Drug Trafficker's Aide Arrested
DOC.TEXT: Gunmen killed four policemen in the last 24 hours in Medellin, raising to 42 the number of law enforcement officers slain in that city the last two months, police said Thursday. Authorities have blamed cocaine traffickers for most of the attacks against police. Police said last month the cartel was offering $4,300 for each police officer killed and $10,500 for each anti-terrorist squad leader assassinated. The unit has been sent to the city to search for leader of the Medellin drug cartel, Pablo Escobar. A police communique said unidentified assailants shot and killed three officers Thursday and one policeman was killed Wednesday night. Despite the violence, Colombian authorities continued their crackdown on drug traffickers Thursday, arresting a lawyer who relayed messages between the cartel and the government. Soldiers raided the Medellin home of Guido Parra and arrested the lawyer on charges of aiding and abetting drug terrorists, an army communique said. They also arrested Berta Mejilla de Serna, a councilwoman for the town of Envigado, and an architect, Diego Londono White, on the same charges, the communique said. Authorities have long suspected that Envigado, a town outside Medellin, is a center of drug trafficking. The arrests are part of the an anti-drug campaign that has netted 30,800 pounds of cocaine the past two weeks. The chief of Colombia's national police, Gen. Miguel Gomez, warned that violence could increase as the May 27 presidential election approaches. At a news conference Wednesday night, he said more than 230,000 members of Colombia's security forces would be deployed to prevent election violence. Three candidates have been assassinated by suspected drug dealers in the campaign. Also Thursday, the Supreme Court disqualified four minor presidential candidates who did not meet eligibility requirements. The ruling reduced from 12 to eight the number of candidates contesting the elections. Political analysts gave the disqualified candidates no chances of winning. Colombian law requires candidates to have a university degree and four years of work experience.

DOC.HEAD: Key Witness Tells of Secret Marcos Accounts, Payments for Buildings
DOC.TEXT: The former president of a Manila bank testified in Imelda Marcos' fraud trial Thursday that millions of dollars from accounts secretly held by the Marcoses were used to buy Manhattan real estate. Rolando Gapud, a key government witness, said he personally managed a series of numbered accounts at his bank, Security Bank and Trust Co., for Mrs. Marcos and her husband, former Philippine president Ferdinand E. Marcos. Gapud said Marcos had secretly acquired control of the bank in 1980 and ordered the opening of the accounts a year later. Gapud testified that between 1982 and 1985, he transferred $50 to $60 million from the accounts for the purchase and maintenance of four New York buildings _ 40 Wall St., the Crown Building at 730 Fifth Ave., Herald Center and 200 Madison Ave. The transfers were made on the instructions of Mrs. Marcos' personal secretary, Fe Roa Jimenez, Gapud said. Mrs. Marcos is accused of helping her late husband loot their nation's treasury of more than $220 million to secretly buy the New York properties identified by Gapud. She has pleaded innocent to charges of racketeering, racketeering conspiracy, mail fraud and obstruction of justice. Her co-defendant, Saudi businessman Adnan Khashoggi, is charged with mail fraud and obstruction of justice for allegedly helping the Marcoses hide their ownership of the four buildings and artwork. Gapud described the complicated process by which the Marcoses' involvement in the transactions was kept confidential. He said the accounts at his bank, which all had ``7700'' numbers, were opened through other numbered accounts at a Hong Kong bank that were secretly held by the Marcoses. The money transferred from the Security Bank accounts went to corporations controlled by the Marcoses, which were used to buy the buildings, Gapud said. The banker also told of the means by which the Marcoses bypassed Philippine Central Bank regulations that limited the amount of U.S. dollars allowed out of the country. In one scheme, Gapud said he and Geronimo Velasco, Marcos' former Minister of Energy, arranged to have the dollar profits from exports of the government-owned Philippine National Oil Company deposited into Marcos bank accounts in the United States. The oil company was reimbursed with the equivalent in Philippine pesos from the ``7700'' accounts at Security Bank and Trust Co., Gapud said. These transactions took place between October 1982 and the spring of 1983 and involved $70 million, he said. Part of the money was used toward the purchase of 40 Wall St. in December 1982, he said. Gapud said Philippine businessmen also were asked to submit phony applications to the Central Bank for approval to transfer dollars from the Philippines. In two instances _ one involving a $30 million transfer and another $8 million _ Gapud said the businessmen were acting as fronts for Marcos, who gave them pesos from the ``7700'' accounts to pay for the U.S. dollars.

DOC.HEAD: Vandals Descecrate 35 Jewish Graves in Paris
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS comment from Simon Wiesenthal Center. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Thirty-four tombs at a Jewish cemetery were desecrated by vandals, and the body of an elderly man was dug up and impaled on an umbrella, authorities said Thursday. Leaders across the political spectrum reacted with outrage at the desecration, one of the worst such incidents ever in France. It occurred two days after a nationwide telecast of a three-hour documentary about Nazi Germany and the Holocaust. Interior Minister Pierre Joxe said several tombs in the south-central town of Carpentras were left ``in conditions so abominable that one can't describe them without embarrassment.'' He traveled to the town to inspect the site. ``I learned with horror of this criminal act,'' President Francois Mitterrand said in a telegram to Freddy Haddad, a Jewish leader in Carpentras. Mitterrand later went to the Paris home of France's chief rabbi, Joseph Sitruk, to express his distress and solidarity. ``I've come as one does for a family in mourning,'' Mitterrand said. Sitruk said: ``A civilization that doesn't respect the dead is headed toward destruction of the living.'' Police said the body of an 81-year-old man who died about two weeks ago was found impaled on an umbrella when the desecration was discovered early Thursday. Grave markers were knocked over and flower pots were trampled, but no graffiti were found. ``It is unimaginable that such deeds are possible in France,'' said Joxe. Jean Kahn, leader of a national coalition of Jewish groups, said the desecration came at a time when racial hatred was being encouraged ``by those who promote anti-Semitic rhetoric and fascist themes.'' Jean-Marie Le Pen, whose extreme-right National Front party has been accused of condoning anti-Semitism, condemned the desecration as ``barbaric behavior.'' No one claimed responsibility for the desecration, and no arrests were reported. Carpentras, with a population of about 26,000, is 60 miles north of Marseille. Its mayor, Jean-Claude Andrieu, described it as a quiet town in which the Jewish community lived harmoniously. Several incidents of vandalism have occurred at Jewish cemeteries in recent years, most recently when anti-Semitic slogans were scrawled on tombs near Paris late last year. In Los Angeles, Rabbi Marvin Hier, head of the Simon Wiesenthal Center, condemned the desecration as a ``despicable act that stains the name of humanity. It shows that in the heart of Western civilization there are those against us who given the opportunity would operate once again the gas chambers of Auschwitz.''

DOC.HEAD: Israel Criticizes U.S. over Pro-Arab U.N. Resolution
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS three grafs after 7th graf, `He said...' to UPDATE with State Department reaction. Pickup pvs 8th graf, `A key...'
DOC.TEXT: Israeli officials on Thursday criticized the United States for creating an ``artificial storm'' over Jewish settlements in the occupied territories. Foreign Minister Moshe Arens said he was concerned by reports the Bush administration was coordinating with Arab states in drafting a U.N. resolution opposing the settlement of Soviet Jews in the occupied territories. ``I am troubled by the activity of the United States when the Arab countries raise in the U.N. Security Council the issue of immigration from the Soviet Union,'' Arens said on Israel radio. Yossi Ahimeir, a spokesman for Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, said recent Israeli moves to build settlements in the occupied territories had ``raised some resentment in the United States.'' But, he added, ``We hope that this artificial storm will be over very soon.'' Arens summoned U.S. Ambassador William Brown to the foreign ministry Wednesday night to protest the U.S. efforts to formulate the U.N. resolution. He said the move encouraged ``the Arab attack on the right of Jews to immigrate to Israel.'' In Washington, State Department spokeswoman Margaret D. Tutwiler said the United States strongly supported the immigration to Israel. ``We want to see immigration take place and will oppose efforts by anyone to block it,'' Tutwiler said. But, she added, ``the government of Israel is well aware of our concern that Soviet Jews not be encouraged to move into the (occupied) territories.'' A key paragraph of the working draft composed by non-aligned and Arab states claims settlements in the occupied territories are in violation of international law, a stronger wording than the U.S. position that contends settlements are an obstacle to peacemaking. Israeli officials said there was no policy of settling Soviet immigrants in occupied lands and no basis to suggest settlements were illegal under conventions governing the conduct of occupying powers. Other hard-line sections of the two-page document demanded the right of return for Palestinian exiles, ``impartial protection'' for Palestinian civilians and a halt in aid that can be used for settlements. The draft grew out of a March call by the Soviet Union for a debate on the settlement of Soviet Jews in the occupied territories. A U.N. vote on the settlement resolution, scheduled for Thursday, was postponed with no new date set. Israeli officials said the United States should veto the resolution because it is part of ``political warfare'' being waged by Arabs, who were opposed to any immigration to Israel. They argued Western states could not support the resolution without violating their stand in support of freedom of movement. In the past, the United States has vetoed most anti-Israel resolutions, but officials said this time U.N. Ambassador Thomas R. Pickering has been seeking a compromise with Arab states. He proposed various changes earlier this week to soften the hard-line sections, but details were not available. ``There's no doubt that at this moment we are going through a period of tension with the United States,'' Arens said. Despite the concerns, Shamir's caretaker government helped fund a Jewish settlement in the Christian quarter of Jerusalem's Old City, and began construction on two new settlements, one in the West Bank and one in the Gaza Strip. ``One can say some mistakes were made by elements responsible'' for the Old City settlement, Ahimeir acknowledged, ``but it does not justify a political campaign against Israel.'' The Old City settlers were ordered out of the building they inhabited after the Supreme Court decided it was purchased illegally. More than 70,000 Jewish settlers live in the West Bank and Gaza Strip, home to 1.7 million Palestinians. Gad Ben Ari, spokesman for the quasi-governmental Jewish Agency that assists immigrants, said only about 200 of the 30,000 Soviet immigrants who arrived this year have chosen to live in the occupied territories.

DOC.HEAD: Pope Hits at Populous Mexico's Family Planning
DOC.NOTE: Eds: 5 grafs SUB for 8th graf `The pope' to UPDATE with Monterrey crowd of more than 500,000, pope to fly to plane crash town. Picks up 9th pvs, `At Chihuahua' with minor editing to trim
DOC.TEXT: Pope John Paul II on Thursday criticized populous Mexico's family planning program, called for freedom of religious education and demanded greater parental input on sex education in public schools. John Paul backed Roman Catholic parents' groups pressing for religious education. He said they have ``the right to freely educate their children according to their own religious convictions'' and to have the laws of their country ``explicitly recognize that right.'' Religious schools are constitutionally prohibited in Mexico, although many exist and are tolerated despite the ban. Religious education would probably expand quickly if the ban were lifted, however. The pontiff noted in a speech before more than 100,000 people that educational freedom is a right recognized by the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, ``even though serious legislative limits still exist in some countries.'' It was the fifth day of the pontiff's eight-day Mexican journey. The crowd included thousands of U.S. residents who traveled by bus and car to Chihuahua, 220 miles south of El Paso, Texas. The pontiff spoke from a platform on a dusty field with the bare, brown Sierra Madre mountains in the background. Thousands in the audience waved flags in Vatican yellow and white. Many wore straw hats and caps. The sunny day was marred by word that a plane carrying pilgrims crashed near Tuxtla Gutierrez, more than 1,000 miles away in southeastern Mexico. The pope visits Tuxtla Gutierrez on Friday; more than two dozen were reported dead in the crash, including the bishop of Tapachula, Luis Miguel Canton Marin. ``May God grant the dead eternal rest and a rapid recovery to the injured,'' John Paul said Thursday evening in the northern industrialized city of Monterrey, in a brief comment on the accident. He spoke before a crowd there estimated at more than 500,000, by far the largest of the trip. The pope changed his Friday schedule and will visit the cathedral in Tuxtla Gutierrez to pray for the victims and offer condolences to their families. In his homily at a Mass dedicated to workers, the pontiff again condemned the materialism of the capitalist system. ``Without denying the good results obtained ... where a free system reigns, we still cannot be blinded to the defects of an economic system that not infrequently makes riches and consumption its principle engine,'' he said. Monterrey, Mexico's third-largest city, is less than 100 miles from Laredo, Texas, and the crowd included thousands of U.S. residents. The service took place in the dry bed of the Santa Catarina River. At Chihuahua, the pope reiterated the church's opposition to artificial contraceptives. ``If, in the conjugal union, the possibility of conceiving a child is artificially eliminated, the couple closed themselves to God and opposed his will, '' John Paul said. The standard church message has political implications in Mexico, where since the mid-1970s the government has encouraged use of contraceptives to limit a mushrooming population. Government health clinics distribute contraceptives and perform vasectomies, but abortion is illegal. The program, one of the most succesful in the Third World, has helped cut the population growth rate from nearly 3.7 percent in 1977 to 1.9 percent, according to government figures. Nearly half the married women in this overwhelmingly Catholic country use contraceptives, according to International Planned Parenthood figures. Still, the population has increased nearly 30 percent _ reaching 85 million _ since John Paul first visited in 1979. Strong religious restrictions were written into the 1917 constitution after liberals defeated church-backed conservatives during the Mexican Revolution. The pope said that by using birth control, a husband and wife ``closed themselves to each other, in that they reject the mutual giving in paternity and maternity, reducing the conjugal union to an occasion for satisfying the egoism of each one.'' The papal position has drawn fire in Mexico, where infant mortality, illiteracy and malnutrition are major problems. John Paul also said sex education that ignores moral values ``constitutes an impoverishment of the person and contributes to obscuring his dignity.'' The pope attacked elements he said violated the human rights of children, including abortion, malnutrition, lack of affection, violence and drugs. He also paid a Mother's Day tribute to Mexican women; Mother's Day is celebrated on May 10 in Latin America.

DOC.HEAD: Despite Criticism, Corps of Engineers Says Dams Did Their Job
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 10th graf, `Thirteen deaths...,' with 4 grafs to update with tour by Marilyn Quayle. Pick up 11th graf pvs, `A disaster declaration...' Eufaula is pronounced yoo-FALL-uh.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos TRK1, TRK2; LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: Lake Eufaula, the reservoir some call a ``gentle giant,'' has turned into a menace as farmers and residents hundreds of miles away in Arkansas battle floods unleashed from the lake because of heavy rains. But U.S. Army Corps of Engineers officials, criticized about the timing of the release of water from reservoirs, are standing their ground. Were it not for reservoirs like Eufaula on the Arkansas River and Lake Texoma on the Red River, the flooding downstream could have been much worse, they say. Decisions made by the corps on how fast to release water from the reservoirs it manages can have a crucial effect on who is flooded, and how severely. A too-early release of water through the dam's floodgates after a heavy rain increases flooding downstream, while slower release can mean more flooding upstream if the reservoir fills up. Questions about the management of the reservoirs was raised anew Wednesday when Arkansas Gov. Bill Clinton met with a group of angry farmers and agreed with a suggestion that a study of corps efforts to control Red River floodwaters might be in order. But in the main, said corps spokesman Ross Adkins, the reservoirs have done their job this past week. ``Our projects operated as they were designed to. We managed them just exactly as they were designed to operate,'' said Adkins. ``What we do is capture all the water we can to minimize any damages downstream. When Mother Nature dumps as much rain as we had ... (the reservoirs) took off a heck of a big bump that could have gone downstream. ``If we had not been here, a lot more houses and perhaps lives would have been lost,'' he said. The flooding on the Trinity, Red and Arkansas rivers was touched off by severe storms last week. Some areas of eastern Oklahoma, already saturated from a wet spring, had as much as 12 inches of rain. Thirteen deaths were blamed on the storm, most of them in Texas. Marilyn Quayle, wife of Vice President Dan Quayle, toured hard-hit south Dallas on Thursday. She backed proposals to extend levees that protect the hard-hit Rochester Park neighborhood. ``You will be in our prayers,'' Mrs. Quayle told residents whose homes are still underwater. Complete damage figures for the region were not yet compiled, but the Red Cross says as many as 600 homes in Oklahoma may have been damaged by the flooding. In Texas, estimated damage to agricultural production stands at $500 million and $700 million. A disaster declaration was expanded Thursday to cover nine north Texas counties. Sixteen counties had already been declared disaster areas, an action that leads to federal assistance and low-interest loans for repairs. In Arkansas, preliminary figures from six counties and one metropolitan area show flood damage to 251 homes and 13 businesses, said Gary Talley, spokesman for the state Office of Emergency Services. As the water moved downstream from here, Arkansas has experienced some of the worst flooding in decades as the Arkansas and Red rivers flowed over their banks. Hundreds of homes have been damaged. The Arkansas crested at Pine Bluff in central Arkansas on Wednesday, and the Red crested near Texarkana, Texas, at the Texas-Arkansas line Thursday morning, but officials say rivers are receding so slowly and the ground is so saturated that the floodwaters will remain for days or even weeks. After the rains, Lake Texoma, built in 1944, reached a record 644.76 feet, almost 27 feet above the normal level, and water roared over its spillway and down the Red River for the first time since 1957. Lake Eufaula, completed in 1964, also reached a record height. The resulting flooding downstream led some Arkansas farmers to unleash their frustrations at the meeting with Clinton. ``So many of them down there felt, rightly or wrongly, that the corps could have made different decisions over the last few months (and) there would be less flooding,'' Clinton said afterward. One farmer asked if a task force could be established to evaluate the corps' policies. Clinton said he thought that was a good suggestion. But residents upstream from the lakes also have their questions, wondering if the corps should have started to release water earlier. Jeff Van Cleave, who runs the Salty Pelican restaurant on the shore of Lake Eufaula, said he had to close April 27 because water had covered roads leading to the restaurant. He wasn't able to reopen until Wednesday. ``It was a serious matter,'' Van Cleave said Thursday. ``There were a lot of people concerned around here that they were holding the water back too long.'' But Van Cleave acknowledged that Eufaula is a flood control lake and said corps officials must concern themselves with downstream flooding as well as upstream problems. ``I wouldn't take that job for all the tea in China,'' he said. At Eufaula on Thursday, mist rose over the lake where 98,000 cubic feet of water was being released per second. The amount of water being sent downstream was less than half the 230,000 cubic feet per second released at the peak of the flooding last week, but still more than twice the old record release rate of 40,000 cubic feet per second, said Jim Holderfield, a corps supervisor at Lake Eufaula. Barbara Craven, a spokeswoman in the corps' Tulsa office, said water was coming into the lake at up to 490,000 cubic feet per second because of heavy rains and runoff from three rivers upstream. Without the reservoir, she said, people and businesses downstream ``would have had 490,000 cubic feet per second come right at them.'' ``By controlling the amount of water releases, we bought a little time to prepare people downstream,'' she said. Officials said they are more concerned with what lies ahead in the next six weeks, typically the rainy season in Oklahoma. ``May is our wettest month,'' Ms. Craven said. ``We're looking at reservoirs that are filled to the brim right now. We're trying our best.''

DOC.HEAD: Two Dutch Jet Fighters Collide Over Labrador, One Pilot Missing
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with five grafs to UPDATE with identities of pilots, details, edits thereafter to conform. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Two Dutch F-16 jet fighters collided three miles over Labrador on Thursday during NATO training maneuvers. One pilot was injured while ejecting from his single-seat craft, but there was no sign the second pilot survived. The mid-afternoon collision occurred at 17,000 feet, about 45 miles north of Canadian Forces Base Goose Bay and 8 miles west of Grand Lake, the Canadian military said. ``One pilot was seen to eject and has been reached by a Canadian Forces search-and-rescue helicopter,'' the Forces said in a statement. Lt. Rein Sneek, based in Lewarden, the Netherlands, was airlifted to a hospital in Goose Bay suffering from multiple abrasions and bruises, a base spokesman said. The spokesman, Lt. Jeff Agnew, said they had no idea how the crash occurred. He said the military was hoping to get more information from the injured pilot, who was hospitalized overnight for observation. The search continues for the second pilot, identified as Capt. Leo Vogt. Agnew said a NATO aircraft in the area at the time of the crash saw no parachute from the second plane and that there was no evidence Vogt was able to eject. Asked if low-level flying _ a practice long protested by natives in the area _ played a part in the accident, Agnew replied: ``Absolutely not.'' A Forces statement said: ``The collision occurred at 17,000 feet and was not due to low-level flying.'' Jets on low-level flights often dip as low as 100 feet from the ground _ the height of a tall tree. The Dutch aircraft were taking part in a NATO air defense exercise. Known as the Falcon, the American-built F-16 is a single-engine fighter used by the U.S. and Dutch air forces. The Netherlands is among several NATO countries that send hundreds of pilots each year to CFB Goose Bay to train in low-level flying and combat techniques. Innu who live in the area say the training flights, which take place each year from April to November, are disrupting their way of life and harming caribou herds. There have been numerous protests to try to stop the flights. A board of inquiry will be convened by the Royal Netherlands Air Force to investigate the crash, Agnew said.

DOC.HEAD: Plane Carrying Pilgrims to See Pope Crashes, Killing at Least 27
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with pope's prayers, CORRECTS survival figure. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: A plane carrying pilgrims to see Pope John Paul II crashed Thursday and killed at least 27 of the 38 people on board, including a bishop and some government officials, authorities said. The crash was near the military airport of the southeastern city of Tuxtla Gutierrez, where the pope is to visit Friday. The Rev. Jorge Valenti, secretary to the bishop of Tapachula, Monsignor Luis Miguel Canton Marin, said the bishop died in the crash. The Dutch-made, propeller-driven F-27 Fokker crashed at about 8:55 a.m., just under two miles from the airport runway, said Miguel Angel Guadarrama, manager of the airline Aviacion de Chiapas, S.A. He said 38 people were aboard, including the crew. One of the 12 initial survivors later died of injuries, a Red Cross worker said. ``Many of the passengers, in fact most of them, were government officials,'' Guadarrama said. The pope, who earlier flew to the northern city of Chihuahua on Thursday, isolated himself en route to his next stop, Monterrey, to pray for the victims. ``We pray that God will give eternal rest to the dead and for the recovery of the wounded and we pray that God will console the habitants of Tapachula so they keep the faith,'' he said. The cause of the crash was not immediately known. The weather appeared to be clear on television footage from the scene, but the area is known for fog. The badly charred wreck lay scattered in a field, its propellers twisted. Soldiers surrounded it, keeping back onlookers. Despite the security, some looting of luggage occurred. ``Just imagine the scene, it was quite awful,'' Red Cross volunteer Guillermo Diaz Gorodillo said in a telephone interview. ``Luckily, the plane crashed in an open field, surrounded by private homes so that many people rushed out to help the survivors.'' Diaz Gordillo said the plane was in flames when he and about 18 other Red Cross volunteers reached the crash site. ``Five of them were unscathed, including a mother and her newborn baby. The others were badly injured, and one just died here at the Red Cross,'' he said. The plane was on a scheduled run from Tapachula, on the border with Guatemala. Officials said many of the government people were coming for John Paul's visit to Tuxtla Gutierrez, capital of Chiapas state. Aviacion de Chiapas, or Avicsa, is a regional commercial airline that operates in southeastern Mexico and uses the military base. The plane can carry up to 44 passengers and a crew of four.

DOC.HEAD: Actor Charlie Farrell, Television Father of `My Little Margie,' Dies
DOC.TEXT: Actor Charlie Farrell, silent film star of ``Seventh Heaven'' and the TV father in the popular 1950s series ``My Little Margie,'' died at his desert home, it was disclosed Thursday. He was 89. Farrell died of heart failure Sunday at his Palm Springs home, said Willim Broman, a deputy at the Riverside County Coroner's Office. The coroner was involved because there was no attending physician at the time of death. The actor was buried Wednesday at Welwood Murray Cemetery in Palm Springs. Farrell ran an exclusive Palm Springs tennis club for years and helped to boost the reputation of the desert resort as a Hollywood mecca. He even dabbled in politics, serving as the city's mayor at one point. Born Aug. 9, 1902, in Walpole, Mass., Farrell came to California in 1923 seeking a show business career. He stepped into $3-a-day extra roles, then leapt into stardom with a minor role in ``The Ten Commandments,'' the 1923 Cecil B. de Mille production. Farrell retired from movies after making about 10 silents and more than 40 talkies. It was in the 1927 silent ``Seventh Heaven'' that Farrell and Janet Gaynor established themselves as the screen's top heartbeats. ``Janet and I were in the Top 10 box-office draws for two years after that ... even into talkies,'' he said in a 1977 interview. ``We had a string of real good pictures. `Street Angel,' `Sunnyside Up'... `Seventh Heaven' was the best, though.'' ``Seventh Heaven'' walked away with the best director and actress Oscars at the first Academy Awards. With the invention of television, Farrell was brought into America's living rooms as a widower father opposite Gale Storm on 150 episodes of ``My Little Margie.'' ``I had a helluva career,'' he said in a 1977 interview. ``The truth of it was, I didn't get along with the studio brass. They wanted that Cagney thing all the time. So I got out.'' Before World War II, Farrell was a polo fanatic who would play with Will Rogers at the humorist's Sunset Boulevard ranch. But he eventually moved to the desert and concentrated on tennis. Farrell and his actress-wife Virginia Valli, who died in September 1968, worked with partner Ralph Bellamy to develop the posh Palm Springs Racquet Club, which became a popular refuge for Hollywood elite. ``He was very affable, a wonderful friend,'' Bellamy said Thursday after learning of Farrell's death. ``He was a great greeter and a great back-slapper, much better than I was. He was the perfect fella to run the club.'' When they started the club in 1934, there were less than 200 people living there and ``no paved roads,'' said Bellamy. The Farrells were first citizens of the now-thriving desert community 100 miles east of Los Angeles. They were probably as much responsible as anyone for the growth of Palm Springs from an Indian reservation into a famed playground for millionaires. ``There is no doubt about it, the club started the popularity of Palm Springs. And everybody liked Charlie,'' said Bellamy. Farrell enjoyed running the club more than show business. ``The club is more fun, I'm playing tennis all the time and socializing, but it's harder work,'' he said before selling the Racquet Club in 1959. Farrell was mayor of Palm Springs for six years, from 1948 to 1953, and he successfully fought efforts of gamblers intent on moving into the area. His movie roles included parts in ``Wings of Youth,'' ``Sandy,'' ``Old Ironsides,'' ``The Rough Riders,'' ``Street Angel,'' ``Fazil,'' ``The Red Dance,'' ``The River,'' ``City Girl,'' ``Lucky Star,'' ``Sunny Side Up,'' ``Happy Days,'' ``High Society Blues,'' ``Girl Without a Room,'' ``The Big Shakedown,'' ``Aggie Appleby'' and ``The World is Ours.''

DOC.HEAD: Missing Chinese Farmers Send Letter to Host
DOC.TEXT: Seven Chinese peasants reportedly kidnapped shortly after they arrived in the United States for an exchange program apparently slipped away for some sightseeing in New York, officials said Thursday. The Massachusetts farmer who is hosting the rest of the group received a letter from the missing Chinese, police said. It was the first contact since the farmers disappeared shortly after arriving at Kennedy International Airport on April 26. The letter says they arranged to slip away from the airport, and have been afraid to come forward since for fear of being deported as illegal immigrants, said Sgt. Thomas O'Reilly of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. The seven, part of a group of 16, had been hustled into a waiting car at the airport, according to their host, Molly Aitken, president of the World Energy Foundation. She said she believed they had been abducted. The Port Authority, which operates the airport, has been investigating the case as a possible kidnapping. But officers suggested all along the disappearance could be a scheme to enter the country illegally. Federal involvement has been minimal. The group, from the Fujian Province in southern China, was headed to Ms. Aitken's farm in Athol, Mass., to study organic farming for 11 months. The seven apparently wanted to see some of New York before heading off to rural Massachusetts, according to the letter, O'Reilly said. The letter was signed by three of the missing peasants, and began by saying it was from all seven, O'Reilly said. The letter, with no return address and a New York postmark, arrived at Aitken's Green Gables Farm on Wednesday and Aitken telephoned Port Authority police. Investigators were always skeptical about the kidnapping theory, questioning how three alleged abductors were able to grab seven people without using any weapons, then stuff them into a small car. Apparently the missing Chinese made contact with their friend at the airport and ran for the car, O'Reilly said. The letter said they planned to stay in town for a couple days and see Chinatown, but they have been unwilling to come forward for fear they may be deported or never see their families in China again. O'Reilly said the Port Authority police haven't any legal complaint against the seven, and suggested they could smooth over any problems with the U.S. Immigration and Naturalization Service. ``Then their only problem would be with mainland China,'' O'Reilly said.

DOC.HEAD: Nicaraguan Government Workers Go on Strike
DOC.TEXT: Government workers declared an indefinite strike and said they would take over state offices after President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro suspended a civil service law on Thursday. The 60,000-member General Federation of State Workers said the strike included ``immediate takeover of installations and blocking of access by ministers and vice ministers of the government of Mrs. Chamorro.'' A Federation communique said the government is ``preparing general conditions for massive firing of state workers.'' Earlier Thursday, Mrs. Chamorro ordered another devaluation of Nicaragua's currency, the fourth in three weeks, and steeply increased prices for utilities and public services. Adding to her woes, in Miami, the Contra rebels accused lefist Sandinista holdovers in her administration of failing to live up to signed agreements and announced plans to stop demobilizing. The president ordered the value of the cordoba cut by 9 percent in relation to the U.S. dollar, in her second devaluation in two days. She also abolished government subsidies for transportation and raised rates for many state-run public services. The price of running water was doubled, electricity rates went up 300 percent and telephone service, 1,300 percent. In announcing the ``painful'' measures, presidential aide Antonio Lacayo said 10 years of Sandinista rule left Nicaragua ``badly and seriously bankrupt.'' Officials say there was only $3 million in the treasury and a foreign debt of $11 billion when Mrs. Chamorro took office last month in this country of 3.5 million people. The Sandinistas devalued the cordoba 41 times last year and eight more times before leaving office on April 25. When the Sandinistas overthrew rightist dictator Anastasio Somoza and seized power in July 1979, the cordoba was traded at 10 to the dollar. On Thursday, 196,472 cordobas bought $1 on the parallel market, where most of the country's money is traded. Lacayo said the Chamorro administration had no idea Nicaragua's economy was in such a shambles _ ``Consequently, measures will be deeper, sharper, weightier and more painful for the people and the country as a whole.'' Inflation hit 33,600 percent in 1988, but dropped to 1,800 percent in 1989. There are no reliable estimates yet for this year. Mrs. Chamorro ordered a 60 percent pay increase for government employees Wednesday. Workers protested it was not nearly enough to catch up with soaring prices and labor leaders rejected it. Laborers average about $44 a month and white collar workers about $100. Thousands of government employees at the national legislature, the treasury, labor and foreign ministries and elsewhere staged wildcat strikes. Hundreds of employees blocked the ministry entrance Thursday and refused to let Construction and Transportation Minister Jaime Icablzeta go in because he had fired an adviser, a civil servant. Jose Angel Bermudez of the new National Federation of Workers, which claims a membership of 61,000, demanded a 200 percent increase for all wage earners. The Council for Labor Action and Unity immediately backed him. It is an arm of the Communist Party, which forms part of Mrs. Chamorro's 14-party United National Opposition coalition. About 80 Contras turned in their weapons Tuesday to United Nations troops, but spokesman Alejandro Acevedo said in Miami no more rebels would do that. He said the procedure was ``being re-evaluated. This could slow the process of disarmament.'' The rebels, once backed by the United States, complain that the demobilization agreement signed May 4 by their commanders and Mrs. Chamorro was being subverted by former Sandinista officials who still dominate many ministries, especially the military. Acevedo put the number of Contra fighters still holding arms at more than 12,000, but most independent observers say their forces have been reduced to a few thousand.

DOC.HEAD: Official Vote Count: Vargas Llosa Won by Small Margin
DOC.TEXT: Novelist Mario Vargas Llosa won the first round of presidential elections by a slightly smaller percentage of the vote than previously projected, according to the official vote count Thursday. The National Election Board said the center-right Vargas Llosa won 27.6 percent of the vote in the April 8 election while centrist Alberto Fujimori captured 24.6 percent. The rest of the vote went to other candidates. Post-election projections had shown Vargas Llosa winning 32 percent of the vote to Fujimori's 30 percent. The second round of elections next month pits the two front-runners against each other. Polls indicate Fujimori leads Vargas Llosa, author of such novels as ``Aunt Julia and the Scriptwriter'' and ``The Green House,'' by 3 to 8 percentage points. The official vote tally took more than one month to release because the results of 52,157 polling stations in this rugged South American country had to be transported to the capital Lima to be individually verified. The government had to await for the final election results to announce the date of the final elections. Officials had said it would probably be June 3 but many now say it may be held on June 10. The election took place in the midst of Peru's worst economic crisis this century. The government is virtually bankrupt and the annual inflation rate is above 2,000 percent. The balloting showed Luis Alva Castro, candidate of the ruling populist Aprista Party of President Alan Garcia, received only 19.1 percent of the vote. Traditionally strong Marxist parties also faired poorly. Henry Pease of the United Left coalition took only 7 percent of the vote while his former colleague, Alfonso Barrantes of the Socialist Left alliance, finished with only 4.1 percent. Another 15.3 percent of the ballots were blank or declared invalid and the remainder of votes went to smaller parties. The official results show 19.9 percent of the 9,823,062 registered voters did not take part in the election, despite the threat of penalties including a $50 fine that almost equals a month's wage for the average worker. Most of the absenteeism was in zones in the country's central Andean mountains, where the Maoist-inspired Shining Path guerrillas launched a violent campaign to keep voters from the polls. It was not clear whether the high absenteeism was due to voter fear or sympathy with the rebels, analysts said. More than 18,000 people have died in political violence since the Shining Path launched its armed insurgency on May 17, 1980, the day before national elections ending 12 years of military dictatorship.

DOC.HEAD: South Korean Students Clash With Police in Scattered Battles
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERT one graf after 9th graf, On Wednesday ... to UPDATE with wheat promotion office destroyed. Picks up 10th graf, Roh's government ...
DOC.TEXT: Radical students and dissidents fought riot police in street battles in Seoul and other cities Thursday for the second day, despite a government warning against violence. Riot police moved swiftly to disperse the groups of 200 to 500 students who chanted ``Down with President Roh Tae-woo!'' during scattered protests in the capital. Thousands of riot police were deployed in downtown areas. They tightened street checks and took away young pedestrians suspected of participating in the clashes. Shortly before nightfall, riot troopers fired tear gas to disperse 1,500 students carrying firebombs who had occupied a main street on the eastern edge of downtown. News reports said thousands of radical students armed with rocks, steel pipes and firebombs battled police Thursday outside about 40 campuses or in the streets nationwide. Details were not given. Police did not say how many people were arrested Thursday. Police detained 1,864 people in Seoul and 16 other cities during Wednesday's street clashes, the largest and most violent since Roh took office in February 1988. About 100,000 students and dissidents participated in Wednesday's protests, and 247 police were injured. Protesters demanded Roh annul the January merger of his ruling party with two opposition groups and resign. On Wednesday, protesters attacked 24 police stations, governing party offices and government buildings. An office of the U.S. Information Service center in Seoul was gutted by firebombs. Country Director Eul Byong Yoon of U.S. Wheat Associates reported when reached by phone that the Seoul office of the international wheat promotion organization was in the same building as the USIS and was destroyed in the fire there. Roh's government warned Thursday it would move swiftly and forcibly to block labor and political violence. ``The government will mobilize all available resources to restore law and order,'' Justice Minister Lee Jong-nam told a televised news conference. Home Minister Ahn Eung-mo, who controls the nation's 130,000 police, told the same conference: ``The government will strictly enforce laws to eradicate crimes and maintain social stability.'' Dissidents said they would stage more protests. ``Let's destroy the pro-American fascist'' and ``Drive out the Yankees,'' about 200 people shouted during a rally Thursday at Myungdong Cathedral in central Seoul. The cathedral in 1987 was the focal point of nationwide anti-government protests. That unrest involved hundreds of thousands of demonstrators and forced authoritarian president Chun Doo-hwan to carry out major democratic reforms, including the presidential election that brought Roh to office. In southern Seoul, police firing tear gas clashed with about 1,000 honking taxi drivers who tried to rally to demand a 17.3 percent wage hike. The taxi drivers responded with rocks. Opposition and radical students say Roh's ruling Democratic Liberal Party, formed after the merger of three parties, was a ``political coup d'etat,'' as it had not been ratified in an election. Roh took office in 1988 after winning the country's first direct presidential elections in 16 years. But his popularity has been declining. Dissidents say the United States was behind a plot by government conservatives to prolong their power through the merger. In the southeastern industrial city of Ulsan, 51 shipyard workers ended a 13-day holdout on top of a 240-foot crane and were admitted to a hospital for a medical checkup. Details were unavailable but the state radio, KBS, said the workers were exhausted from a hunger strike begun five days ago. It was unknown whether Thursday's government warning influenced the workers' action. The workers fled atop the crane when 12,000 police firing tear gas raided their shipyard on April 28 to end a strike. The workers had threatened ``extreme action'' unless their demand for the release of jailed union leaders was accepted. Officials of the Hyundai Heavy Industries Co. in Seoul said they plan to reopen the shipyard next week.
